webTitle: Old Firm join in 'charter' for new league

fields.headline: Old Firm join in 'charter' for new league
fields.trailText: Celtic and Rangers have joined nine clubs from the continent in calling on Uefa to approve a new Euroleague to counter the growing gap between football's rich and poor.
fields.body:
Celtic and Rangers have joined nine clubs from the continent in calling on Uefa to approve a new Euroleague to counter the growing gap between football's rich and poor.

They say clubs from the five largest European leagues - England, France, Germany, Italy and Spain - have dominated the Champions League and Uefa Cup and are monopolising revenues.

The Scottish sides, along with Ajax, Feyenoord and PSV Eindhoven of the Netherlands, Anderlecht and Bruges of Belgium, Brondby and Copenhagen of Denmark, and Portugal's Benfica and Sporting, signed a "charter" in which they call for a review of the quality, competitiveness and economics of European club football.

The clubs said: "Unless stakeholders in football in our countries take positive action now, we consider that the growing gap between our domestic competitions and those in the larger European Union countries will continue to have a dramatic and increasingly detrimental effect on the continuity, quality and competitiveness of our competitions."

The clubs first outlined their solution, which would involve their withdrawal from respective domestic leagues to play one another weekly, in September. Uefa was initially unenthusiastic, preferring the option of an expanded Uefa Cup in a similar format to the Champions League, which would start in two years' time.

Coventry's defender Colin Hendry has completed a loan switch to Bolton. The Scotland international, 35, who has made only 10 first-team appearances for the Sky Blues since his move from Rangers in March, has agreed terms for a three-month loan.

The Brazilian striker Ronaldo was fined for drink-driving in San Sebastian early on Sunday morning, Spanish police confirmed yesterday. His breath test showed 0.29mg of alcohol per litre, and a spokesman said the legal limit is 0.25 mg but for new drivers such as Ronaldo the limit is 0.15mg. "A fine of 18,000 pesetas [£75] was imposed and paid on the spot," the spokesman added.

 The pressure on England's coach-elect Sven-Goran Eriksson increased last night when his Lazio side lost 4-1 at Udinese in the Italian Cup quarter-finals. Sinisa Mihajlovic and Pavel Nedved were both sent off for Lazio, who lost 5-3 on aggregate.

webTitle: Jones is snared by Foxes

fields.headline: Jones is snared by Foxes
fields.trailText: Leicester look set to sign Leeds midfielder Matthew Jones in a £3.25m deal.
fields.body:
Leicester look set to snatch the Leeds midfielder Matthew Jones from Blackburn Rovers' grasp after moving in with a £3.25m bid for the Wales international.

Jones had been poised to join Rovers after they agreed a fee of £2.75m with Leeds. But when Leicester's manager Peter Taylor heard of the 20-year-old's availability he swiftly gazumped Rovers by £500,000 in an attempt to bring him to Filbert Street.

Taylor has been given money to spend after selling Neil Lennon to Celtic for £5.75m, and had been linked with Chelsea's young midfielder Jody Morris.

Meanwhile, Leeds's goalkeeper Nigel Martyn is set to return from injury in tomorrow's reserve-team game against Sheffield Wednesday at Hillsborough.

Any involvement by Charlton's manager Alan Curbishley in the Football Association's new-look coaching set-up has been delayed until the end of the season even though the Addicks gave permission for him to speak to the FA.

Curbishley is recognised by Howard Wilkinson and the FA chief executive Adam Crozier as one of the country's brightest coaching talents and is wanted as part of the new team which will be headed by Sven-Goran Eriksson. But Curbishley, his club and the FA have agreed to put any move on hold until the end of the current domestic campaign to allow the FA further time to decide a precise role for the manager.

Liverpool's 20-year-old French defender Djimi Traore assured his long-term future at Anfield yesterday when he signed a new four-year contract.

The French Under-18 international made his debut for Liverpool in September 1999 after joining from his home-town club Laval for £500,000 the previous February.

webTitle: Sunderland angered by late call-off

fields.headline: Sunderland angered by late call-off
fields.trailText: Peter Reid was far from cheered up last night after arriving at Selhurst Park with his Sunderland team only to learn that the Worthington Cup tie against Crystal Palace had been called off because of a waterlogged pitch.
fields.body:
Peter Reid was far from cheered up last night after arriving at Selhurst Park with his Sunderland team only to learn that the Worthington Cup tie against Crystal Palace had been called off because of a waterlogged pitch.

The Sunderland team bus was soon on the way back to the airport for an early flight home with hopes of better luck with the rearranged game next Tuesday or Wednesday.

"The pitch was heavy," Reid said. "The referee was in a difficult position and I can understand why he's called it off, but something's not right somewhere. The first I got to hear there might be a problem was at 4.30 or 5pm.

"It's terrible for the supporters with the expense involved. In this day and age that surely shouldn't be happening."

But there was a bright side for the estimated 2,000 Wearsiders who had travelled to the match when Sunderland announced they would all be given a free ticket for their FA Cup third-round clash, also against Palace, at the Stadium of Light on January 6.

webTitle: Fast learner Saha makes striking progress

fields.headline: Fast learner Saha makes striking progress
fields.standfirst: Anfield holds no fears for Fulham in tonight's quarter-final
fields.trailText: Anfield holds no fears for Fulham in tonight's quarter-final
fields.body:
Louis Saha is still getting to grips with English, and you fear the worst when told that the dressing room is the setting for most of his linguistic learning. Yet his thoughts are not expressed in the depressingly familiar cliches of footballers, or come to that, the deputy prime minister, who recently described himself as "most gutted".

Instead, except for an occasional lapse into franglais, Saha speaks with refreshing purity, describing Fulham's visit to Anfield for tonight's Worthington Cup tie as "a pleasure for us because we can learn very quickly for next season.

"You have to have a mark for players and we can find that tonight," he goes on. "It is more a game to show what we can do, more a game for confidence than for us to believe we can win."

The Worthington Cup has become so debased by clubs such as Arsenal and Manchester United refusing to take it seriously that it is now a back-door route to Europe for the rest of the football clubs in the league.

Usually, there would also be little reason to assume that it would end in anything but a comfortable victory for Liverpool, who inflicted a club-record 10-0 defeat on Fulham in this competition in 1986.

This season, though, after the manner in which Fulham, under their manager Jean Tigana, have planted the beautiful game in the previously barren landscape of the First Division, it is an encounter which will intrigue the most jaundiced fan.

Sides leading the First Division at this stage of the season are normally favourites for relegation from the Premiership next term. But this Fulham side have played so many teams off the park that a growing number of them insist they will be a match not only for Liverpool but for Manchester United in next month's FA Cup third-round tie.

Certainly, says Saha, there will be no discernible increase in nerves in the Fulham dressing room at Anfield. "We can relax and play our game," he says. "It's easy for us to play a big match because they have great players and, if we lose, it is normal. Also the manager has given us so much confidence that it is possible to play football without pressure. We think only of the football."

In private, at least, Tigana is teasingly suggesting that he may rest some of his leading players, as he did against Derby in the previous round, which ended in a 3-2 win. But you have to believe that curiosity, not to mention a romantic streak, will get the better of him, aching to know, like everyone else, whether his team are genuine Premiership material or simply flat-track bullies.

Saha would be most gutted not to find his name on the team sheet, though he does not put it in those words, saying: "I would be disappointed and so would any of the other players. We all want to play in this one."

Saha, 22, who played five Premiership games for Newcastle on loan two seasons ago, joined Fulham from Metz in June for £2.1m. He was Tigana's first signing and in a matter of months he has been transformed from a hesitant winger to one of the deadliest strikers in the country, much like the metamorphosis of Thierry Henry at Arsenal.

Saha says: "It is similar to Henry because, like him, I started on the wing. To be changed into a central striker you have to have a good manager to give you confidence and progress you in the position. Mr Tigana said to me that I was a good player but that I did not have the confidence to play well all season and he would progress me mentally.

"When you have a good manager you have to trust him and I want to give him lots of things. I want to say to him by my play, yes, you were right."

The message to his highly regarded manager could not be clearer if he used a loud-hailer. Having set himself a seemingly wildly optimistic goals target of 20 for the season, Saha has already reached it, 15 coming in the league.

However Fulham do tonight, none of their vanquished First Division rivals doubts that their brilliant football will carry them into the top division for the first time in 32 years, completing a journey from the Third that will have taken five seasons and five managers.

Opposing sides' fans regular applaud Tigana's team off, leaving Saha bemused: "It's unbelievable and I think you only see that in England. In France, never."

Even when Fulham enjoyed a 10-year tenure of the old First Division between 1959 and 1968, their longest in the top flight, they were as much fodder for comedians as opposing sides. Now, fascinatingly, the borough of Fulham and Chelsea has two peacock football outfits, who next season will invite the country to compare their plumages.

Not that there will be any comparison between their work patterns. Imagine the reaction of dilettantes such as Chelsea's Frank Leboeuf and Marcel Desailly if asked to report for training at 7am, as Fulham were in pre-season, for what would be the first of three daily sessions.

Saha and co were not overjoyed by it at first. But the early birds have eaten plenty of worms since then, and tonight it is their own reputations which they are anxious should not be swallowed whole.

webTitle: Adebola scuppers soaking Sheffield

fields.headline: Adebola scuppers soaking Sheffield
fields.trailText: Birmingham City emerged triumphant from a night of auld acquaintances at St Andrew's to reach the League Cup semi-finals for the second time in six seasons.
fields.body:
Birmingham City emerged triumphant from a night of auld acquaintances at St Andrew's to reach the League Cup semi-finals for the second time in six seasons.

The last time City were there manager Trevor Francis was on a year's sabbatical after his services had ungratefully - and given Wednesday's subsequent decline possibly unwisely - been dispensed with at Hillsborough. Francis had taken the Owls to the final of the competition in 1993 and now Manchester City or Ipswich Town stand in the way of a repeat visit.

Francis was not the only one to lock horns with his former employers. The Northern Ireland midfielder Danny Sonner left them for St Andrews in the summer and, as is often the way of these things, scored the goal that put his new side on course for victory against his old. Even more piquantly Sonner beat Des Walker, the centre-back signed by Francis, en route to heading home his goal.

An all too familiar acquaintance of late, rain, made yet another unwelcome appearance. Stair-rodding down and sent every which way by swirling wind, it made life uncomfortable for the spectators. But, by way of compensation, its influence on the pitch provided thrills and spills aplenty.

Consequently St Andrew's was no stage for the fancy Dan, all of which suited Wednesday's direct approach.

That was how City had set about unhinging Premiership opposition Tottenham and Newcastle in previous rounds and on this occasion they initially found the tables turned.

Accustomed to teams coming to St Andrews and defending, City were taken by surprise as the visitors took the game to them. So much so that it was not until midway through the first period that the Wednesday keeper Kevin Pressman was first seriously inconvenienced.

Gerald Sibon served notice of Wednesday's intention as early as the first minute when he tried his luck from 35 yards after his side were awarded a free kick. The City keeper Ian Bennett remained untroubled because of the intervention of his side's defensive wall but he had to be at his best to stop the visitors taking the lead seven minutes later.

The City keeper was in action again in the 20th minute this time diving to his left to smother a long range cross shot from Owen Morrison.

By contrast Pressman was almost a peripheral figure at the other end as Wednesday's direct approach resulted in them almost continually occupying City territory.

Despite being untroubled Pressman remained alert, which was just as well when Ashley Westwood played him into trouble with a back pass that was almost brought to a halt by the saturated pitch.

The City striker Mark Burchill was first to the ball but Pressman was only seconds behind and had enough time to smother the shot. He was left helpless, however, when City had their first effort on target in the 28th minute.

Nicky Eaden delivered a square cross from the right and Sonner, nipping between Walker and Westwood, headed unerringly past Pressman to put City in front.

Their confidence boosted by the turn-around in their fortunes, City almost added two more before the break.

Centre-back Darren Purse had a shot cleared off the line by Lescott following a right-wing corner before, in stoppage time, Pressman saved brilliantly from close-range to thwart Dele Adebola.

An injury to skipper Martin O'Connor forced Francis to introduce Bryan Hughes for the second half and the midfielder was soon involved. His perfectly weighted-through ball set up Eaden but the defender-cum-midfielder, lacking a striker's sang froid, shot straight at Pressman. However, City ensured the miss did not prove costly 12 minutes after the interval when they constructed the best manoeuvre of the match and settled matters.

Burchill began it with a sweeping pass out to the left flank where it found Stan Lazaridis. Rather than embark on a trademark mazy run, the Australian winger opted for a first time cross which Adebola headed home at the far post.

 The referee Graham Poll had to abandon Manchester City's Worthington Cup tie with Ipswich Town after 20 minutes with the scores drawn 1-1.

webTitle: Liverpool 3 - 0 Fulham

fields.headline: Liverpool 3 - 0 Fulham
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Liverpool: Westerveld, Henchoz, Babbel, Smicer, Heskey, Fowler, Hyypia, Murphy, Gerrard, Carragher, Biscan. Subs: Owen, Barmby, McAllister, Nielsen, Vignal.

Fulham: Taylor, Finnan, Brevett, Melville, Coleman, Clark, Hayles, Goldbaek, Saha, Davis, Fernandes. Subs: Symons, Trollope, Hahnemann, Boa Morte, Stolcers.

Referee: D Gallagher (Banbury)

1 After scoring 12 goals in his last 13 games, Liverpool are glad to welcome back Heskey tonight, especially against a Fulham side that includes 20-in-23 Saha.

2 Fulham cross the halfway line for the first time (briefly) after working the ball down the right.

3 Brevett and Davis knock it around at the back in the Tigana style and but the rapid passing stops at keeper Taylor.

4 First chance to Liverpool as Smicer gets away from Brevett on the right - he crosses from the by-line for a back-peddling Heskey to head over from 10 yards.

7 Plenty of empty seats in the stands as Fulham again try to find a way through on the right

8 Gerrard and Biscan work the ball through the midfield but Fulham hold firm and the ball runs into space in front of keeper Taylor.

9 Biscan gets on the end of lay-off from Heskey and fires in a shot from 25 yards - wide

11 Fulham at last make a meaningful incursion into the Liverpool half as Hayles races forward to the edge of the area. The ball ends up with Goldbaek on the right before Finnan picks up possession, cuts inside and delivers a shot that gives Westerveld plenty of time to square up to.

13 Westerveld and Hyypia take leave of their senses when Hyypia sells his keeper short with a bad back-pass - Clark is wise to the chance, but the ball bounces off Westerveld and wide of the post.

17 Liverpool doing a good job of pinning Fulham back and denying Fulham freedom to move.

18 Babbel cuts into the Fulham area from the right and shoots to the near post to force a save from Taylor

19 Babbel delivers a fine cross-field ball to Heskey on the edge of the six-yard box, but the in-form striker can only direct his volley straight at Taylor.

21 Free-kick to Fulham 30 yards out - comes to nothing.

22 Fulham starting to make inroads into the Liverpool half. Finnan wins a throw deep on the right, which prompts Liverpool to pull everyone back bar Heskey.

24 Fowler and Heskey combine well on the edge of the Fulham area before Heskey crashes to the ground under an apparent challenge from Davis - no foul given.

25 Hayles leaves the Liverpool defence all at sea on the left of the area, but he blows it when he fails to pick out either Clark or Saha who have come up with him.

27 Corner to Fulham. Comes to nothing.

29 Fowler tries and fails to chip Taylor from the edge of the area.

33 The first glimmer of an opening for Saha is short-lived as he is brought down on the edge of the Liverpool area - no foul given, much to Saha's annoyance.

39 Smicer feeds Babbel on the right before picking up the return for a dangerous cross that Fulham defend with calm efficiency.

42 Hayles again is the man to probe Liverpool's defences as he charges upfield past Carragher and Hyypia before Carragher recovers well to dispossess him just inside the area.

44 Taylor makes a great save to deny Heskey after the Liverpool striker races onto a deflected pass from Murphy and shoots from just inside the area.

webTitle: Dance critic Judith Mackrell reviews Spectacular Bodies

fields.headline: Too, too solid flesh
fields.standfirst:
Our dance critic Judith Mackrell visits Spectacular Bodies at the Hayward Gallery

TV critic Gareth McLean reviews Madame Butterfly
fields.trailText: Our dance critic Judith Mackrell visits Spectacular Bodies at the Hayward Gallery.
fields.body:
Every time I write as a dance critic I work on the assumption that the rhythms, shapes and postures of bodies have significant meaning. Yet we tend to imagine that doctors and scientists take a different view. For them, surely, the ghost has abandoned the machine, leaving an abstract puzzle of tissue and organs laid out on a table. For them, surely, bodies have no poetry, no stories to tell other than the physiological.

Certainly, that's the first impression delivered by Spectacular Bodies, the sometimes bizarre, often wonderful history of the art and science of the human body at London's Hayward Gallery. The first room is hung with 17th and 18th- century portraits portraying a powerful scientific establishment wielding its scalpels over the inert, defenceless flesh of the dead. As the all-male surgeons gaze from the walls, sleek and smug with their own well-being, they graphically disclaim any human alliance with the pallid lumps of meat they're carving up.

But another view has been left behind by the artists who often worked for the medical profession from the Renaissance onwards, sketching and modelling organs, severed limbs and bones for research and education. These beautiful, efficient objects present the body alive or dead as an object of awe: here are minutely fashioned skeletons displaying the exquisite architecture of bones, sculptures exposing the abstract patterns of musculature beneath flayed skin, organs and blood vessels reproduced with gaudy waxen realism. Many of the modellers crafted one half of a handsome physique or a pretty face while exposing the often gory substructure of the other half, and this double vision was infectious. Half the time I found myself distracted by the other punters - visualising the gangling bone structure of an adolescent schoolboy or guessing the size of the foetus in a pregnant woman's belly.

This is also how I while away time at dance shows. Even though professional dancers tend to have unnaturally beautiful bodies, and their work defies the limits of normal physiology, the best ones alert us vividly to the nuts and bolts that function beneath their perfect flesh. They also make us feel the raw guts of the emotion they're expressing. When we read bodies, we empathise with the sensations inside.

Because of this, it's no surprise that some of the most anatomically ambitious models at the Hayward turn out to be violently expressive. Thomas Banks's 1801 plaster cast crucifix details every muscle group of Christ's flayed body with a precision that's not only technically astounding but also profoundly dramatic - the stretched, distorted tissues showing God made wincingly flesh. Other statues of this kind often display a heroic athleticism, an urge to idealise and romanticise, which John Isaacs brutally subverts in his 21st-century version of the genre. In A Necessary Change of Heart, Isaacs's recumbent, semi-flayed wax figure is as inert and bloody as a side of beef. Yet such is the perverse seductive power of the anatomical aesthetic, I still caught myself noting tenderly the elegant curved muscle of its exposed buttock.

Among the handful of contemporary works on show, by far the most empowering is Katherine Dowson's huge blown-glass sculpture of the human spine, a spun enchantment of light, space and air whose energy you can feel scintillating down your own backbone. It makes you leave the gallery feeling supercharged and a few inches taller.

 In the big shuffle tomorrow: art critic Adrian Searle goes to the Smash Hits Poll Winners Party and classical music critic Andrew Clements sees the farce Noises Off.

webTitle: Council's disabled adaptations 'scandal'

fields.headline: Council's disabled adaptations 'scandal'
fields.standfirst: Authority's refusal to pay £4,500 compensation highlights ombudsman's lack of enforcement power
fields.trailText: Authority's refusal to pay £4,500 compensation highlights ombudsman's lack of enforcement power, writes Alison Benjamin
fields.body:
Local government ombudsman Jerry White has branded North Warwickshire council's behaviour "scandalous" following the authority's refusal to pay £4,500 compensation to a couple whose home it failed to provide with mandatory disabled adaptations. The case highlights the ombudsman's lack of power to enforce findings.

Six months after his initial call for compensation was ignored by North Warwickshire, a second report from Mr White is calling on the council to fulfil his recommended remedy for the injustice.

Mr White upheld the couple's initial complaint that the council failed to comply with its statutory duty when dealing with their application for adaptations to their council property to enable the wife, who is registered disabled, to continue living there. As a result of the failure, the couple spent more than two years living in unsuitable conditions.

The ombudsman found maladministration causing injustice, and recommended the council pay the complainants £4,500, offer them the choice of adaptations or suitable rehousing, and review its procedures for disabled adaptations for council-owned properties.

The Labour-run council agreed to carry out the adaptations as soon as possible, but declined to pay compensation on grounds that the couple had refused an offer of alternative accommodation and that compensation would have to come from its disabled facilities budget.

In a further report, Mr White said: "It was for Mr and Mrs North [not their real names] to be persuaded that any offer of alternative accommodation, given their personal circumstances and given Mrs North's needs as a disabled person was acceptable ... and I see no reason why the compensation should be met from the budget set aside for people with disabilities. The council's intentions to do so adds insult to injury and is further discrimination against disabled people in its area."

North Warwickshire is declining to respond. Peter Oliver, director of administration, said: "We will be considering the report at a meeting of housing services in January which will make recommendations to full council."

Should the council stick to its guns, the ombudsman will be powerless to make it cough up. While the couple may be able to challenge the council through a judicial review, on the rare occasions when councils refuse to accept the ombudsman's recommendations - four cases out of 33,000 in the past two years - the ombudsman cannot legally force them.

Surprisingly, Mr White is the first to jump to the defence of what amounts to a voluntary system. "Lots of people would like our decisions to be legally binding, but I believe it would make the investigative process much harder if elected members felt they had no choice but to abide by our decisions," he said. "Currently most councils willingly comply with our investigations and the vast majority comply with the recommendations. If it were more legalistic, we would not have a such a high success rate."

White says that councils have a change of heart in half of all cases where a second report is issued. To assist North Warwickshire's thought process, he has sent copies of his further report to the minister for disabled people and the disability rights commission.

If all else fails, the ombudsman can require the council to publish a statement in a local newspaper setting out why he considers the authority's response to be unsatisfactory. Mr White said: "The anger of local people is often the best means to get a democratically elected body to change their minds."

webTitle: Week 2: Washington DC to the Rockies

fields.headline: All American boy
fields.trailText: "I visited the National Museum of American History which had a ridiculous assortment of kitsch items, including my personal favourite: Evel Knievel's white leather jumpsuit. They also had an original 50s ice cream parlour serving food. I ordered meatloaf." From the finest cuisine to heckling outside the Supreme Court, Sam immerses himself in American culture.
fields.body:
Washington DC is full of museums and monuments. Some pretty impressive ones too.

My top tip for anyone who's thinking of coming here is the Holocaust Museum. It's brillantly set out and full of very moving images and exhibits. I could have spent the whole day there.

I also went to the National Museum of American History which had a ridiculous assortment of kitsch items, including my personal favourite: Evel Knievel's white leather jumpsuit. They also had an original 50s ice cream parlour serving food. It was lunchtime so I ordered meatloaf. I've always read about this as the staple middle American meal, but I've never really known what it is. I wasn't expecting much - after all it was only a glorified museum cafeteria. But it was delicious, with creamy mashed potato and onions and there was lots of it. I thought travel would make me lithe and lean, but not at this rate.

Thanks again for your emails. Michele suggested I go to the Supreme Court on Monday as the judges were considering the recount in the US elections that day. It was chaos. There were Bush and Gore supporters lining the street outside, waving placards and heckling each other (have a look at the photo). Big police presence too (I got told off for crossing the road in the wrong place or something).

I checked out of the Hostel International I had been booked into as soon as I walked into my dorm room and found a down-and-out guy asleep in my bunk. I wouldn't have minded, but all his belongings were on the only other free bed. So I moved onto Simpkin's, an independent hostel just off the Dupont Circle, really close to the Metro. It's much more welcoming than the sterile official hostels (and has free internet access which has made writing this report a lot easier). I've met some excellent people staying here including some guys who I should be able to meet up with again later in Australia and New Zealand.

Thanks also for your advice on where to go skiing. I've decided to stick with staying in Glenwood Springs, but will maybe get the bus onto Aspen or Breckonridge sometime during the week. This makes it an awful lot easier as the Amtrak station is in Glenwood Springs. I'm really looking forward to the journey - it's one of the things I said I wanted to do in the piece that won me this trip.

It's a 24-hour trip to Chicago. I get six hours there to stretch my legs and have a look round then it's 30 hours to the Rockies. I've stocked up on provisions. Sabine, who seems to have travelled all across the US by train, gave me some excellent tips on what to take, including some of those pots of soup which you just have to add hot water to as the dining car is pretty expensive.

Sabine also said that delays are quite common when the weather's rough - even up to eight hours. As Chicago had a storm last night and got 10 inches of snow, closing the airport and local roads, I'm expecting there will be a few problems. It's going to be great. Slowly rolling through the countryside, seeing all the rural American towns and some fantastic winter scenery when you get up into the mountains. I can't wait.

fields.headline: Managing your grant
fields.standfirst: Can charities adjust and manage the changes that come with a large injection of funds? Kate Wilkinson reports
fields.trailText: Can charities adjust and manage the changes that come with a large injection of funds? Kate Wilkinson reports.
fields.body:
When people suddenly come into large amounts of money, they often find it difficult to adjust to their new lifestyle. Does new funding have the same effect on voluntary organisations? Two small charities have recently received large grants and now have to manage the changes the money has made possible.

How many organisations could double their membership in less than two years? Registered charity Unique has done just that and is now an employer for the first time, following a National Lottery Charities Board grant last April, worth nearly £140,000 over three years.

Unique was formed in 1989 by parents of children with rare chromosome disorders. They experienced an acute need for better information about their children's conditions and for contact with other families. "The conditions are individually very rare," trustee Nigel Barrett explained, "they may only affect five children in the world - but there are lots of them." Just how many there are is now becoming clear. Details of more than 2,300 families have so far been registered on Unique's confidential database, and the charity is certain there are many more. But it decided to pace its rate of growth to ensure it offers members the maximum level of support.

"I was originally against us having a website," admitted Mr Barrett, "because I knew what it would mean in terms of demand." Beverly Searle, the database manager and Unique's first paid staff member, agreed: "We have had to be very targeted in our advertising, to avoid being flooded with requests for information."

Mr Barrett, a chartered accountant, compared Unique's growth with a business's development from cottage industry to factory, and insisted that a successful transition depends above all on "the quality of the people". They need the life experience, he believed, to take the charity's changing management requirements easily in their stride. "It's an important point that mustn't be underplayed," he stressed. "You've now got thousands coming in every quarter and you need people who can do the salaries, do the PAYE."

Trevor Wilson, a founding member of the Prism Project, agreed that the business skills already within the group have been crucial following the award last year of a lottery grant of more than £160,000 over three years, which trebled the group's turnover at one stroke. Many of the charity's 15 volunteer members have held managerial positions for many years. "Their expertise has helped to put the project on a more professional footing," said Mr Wilson.

The Prism Project supplies books and tapes to 147 of the country's 165 prisons, aiming to provide inmates with self-help and spiritual material. Its national distribution operation was run from a garage for almost 10 years, before the grant helped to secure dedicated premises and fund a paid coordinator's post.

"As a much bigger operation now, we have a new responsibility for allocating and managing funds," said Mr Wilson. The funding has also created new opportunities to raise Prism's profile within the prison system, with an emphasis on professional networking, something that was not previously possible.

The challenge facing both charities for the next 18 months will be to secure funding to continue developing their work when the lottery grants end. Prism is aiming to develop workshops and business skills training for inmates, while Unique is currently exploring potential partnerships with universities in the United States.

Both organisations stress the need to hold tight to their founders' original focus throughout the current change process and in all future plans. "A key cornerstone of Unique has been its human face," said Mr Barrett. "It's absolutely critical and we must never lose that."

 Kate Wilkinson is a communications consultant

webTitle: How charities can end cash worries

fields.headline: How charities can end cash worries
fields.standfirst: As the funding climate for many groups becomes more uncertain, and local authorities continue to cut grants, more voluntary organisations are looking at the role of loans. Patrick McCurry reports
fields.trailText: as the funding climate for many groups becomes more uncertain, and local authorities continue to cut grants, more voluntary organisations are looking at the role of loans. Patrick McCurry reports
fields.body:
Charities have, understandably, always avoided borrowing. After all, why borrow when you can get a grant? But as the funding climate for many groups becomes more uncertain, and local authorities continue to cut grants, more voluntary organisations are looking at the role of loans.

The government, too, is keen to see charities take a more entrepreneurial approach to their work and for more private capital to be channelled into under-invested communities.

This was illustrated by the chancellor's decision, last month, to commit £10m to a new community development venture fund and his willingness to explore the introduction of a community investment tax credit - two recommendations put forward by the social investment task force.

But there are still significant obstacles to the development of loan finance, with banks often ignorant about how voluntary organisations work and with many charities lacking the proper financial systems to reassure lenders. As a result, several specialist loan funds have been set up to act as intermediaries between commercial lenders and charities.

The Brighton community arts group, Same Sky, turned to community loan fund Investors in Society last summer when it needed funds to complete a financing package for its expansion plans. "After years of having to move around and operate from a variety of sites, we'd been offered a permanent home but had only been able to raise £60,000 in grants to refurbish the building and we needed a further £40,000," said Same Sky general manager Iain Cartwright.

The only option was seeking a loan, but Mr Cartwright found the local high street banks unhelpful. He says: "They agreed to lend us the money in principle but wanted our board of trustees to be personally liable for any borrowing, and they didn't seem to understand that we were a voluntary organisation, not a limited company."

The expansion plan was saved when Investors in Society, a loan fund for the sector set up four years ago by the Charities Aid Foundation, agreed to step in. The fund, which has received interest-free loans from sources such as the Woolwich building society to lend on to charities, specialises in supporting voluntary organisations that have been turned down by the mainstream banks.

"I don't know what we'd have done otherwise," says Cartwright. "It's a common situation for charities that want to expand, but lack the funds. It would have taken us several years to find the money we needed."

As well as specialist loan funds for charities, "social banks" such as Dutch-owned Triodos have significantly increased their lending to community organisations and social business. Last year its loans in the UK increased 89% to £28m. One of the bank's innovations is allowing charities to use their supporter base to guarantee loans.

When Christian Action and Resource Enterprise, a charity working with the homeless in Cleethorpes, Lincolnshire, ran into problems with the mainstream banks, Triodos agreed to come up with the deposit it needed to buy its premises if the charity could find 29 supporters each willing to guarantee £2,000. It did, and the charity was able to buy the building and expand its operations.

But loan finance is still a fraction of overall finance for the sector, one problem being that voluntary organisations rarely consider borrowing until it's too late.

Roger Broklehurst, director of the Local Investment Fund (LIF), a community loan fund, says there is a lot more awareness in the sector of the need to break away from grant dependency. But there is still far too little focus by charities on business planning.

"We had a loan inquiry from a Liverpool community cinema that had had its grant from the council halved," said Mr Brokleshurst. "But when we asked them about their business plan, they said they'd never needed one because they relied on grants."

A growing use of loan finance would benefit the voluntary sector in terms of increased efficiency, according to Martin Hockly, who heads Street UK, a new loan fund for entrepreneurs in under-invested communities. He said: "I've seen an awful lot of sloppy thinking, weak management and poor use of resources in the voluntary sector over the years, but when an organisation has a loan it is forced to think much more clearly about its activity and where it is going."

Andrew Robinson, head of community development banking at Royal Bank of Scotland-NatWest, compares the current under-developed loans market in the voluntary sector with that of housing in the past. "In the 70s, there was no private capital in social housing, but now it makes up the majority of finance," he said.

What is needed, argues Robinson, is for the emergence of intermediaries which can operate between the banks and private financiers on one side, and the voluntary sector or social businesses on the other. The two sides often do not understand each other, he maintains, arguing that it is not fear of bad risks that has put off mainstream banks from lending to charities, but lack of understanding about what the risks are.

Loan funds, while still small, are pioneering the role of intermediary. The market could also be boosted by social investment initiatives like NatWest's community bond, which allows investors to put their money into social projects, and the London Rebuilding Society, a credit union-style community investment fund.

webTitle: Clinton makes Ulster farewell

fields.headline: Clinton makes Ulster farewell
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton today told a packed auditorium in Belfast that the Northern Ireland peace process should be held up as an example to the rest of the world.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton today told a packed auditorium in Belfast that the Northern Ireland peace process should be held up as an example to the rest of the world.

The US president, speaking to 8,000 people at a Belfast ice hockey venue, urged Northern Ireland to "celebrate with pride and defend with passion" the two-year-old Good Friday accord.

"I believe in the peace you are building. There can be no turning back," he said.

Mr Clinton was heckled when he asked how many children were alive today because deaths from sectarian violence are a fraction of what they were before the Good Friday accord.

But the president hit back and was cheered by the crowd as he told them: "Tell you what, I'll make you a deal. I'll listen to you if you let me finish."

A crucial round of talks at Stormont today failed to end the deadlock on disarmament, policing reform or demilitarisation, but Mr Clinton insisted the days of the men of violence were over.

"The difficulties of sharing power in a free, peaceful, democratic system are nothing compared to the difficulties of not having any power at all, or living with constant insecurity and violence," he said.

Mr Clinton said the Good Friday accord had replaced border checkpoints and the fear of terrorism with local government that represents all the people. However, he warned it could crumble if ordinary citizens allow their elected leaders to give up on making the peace work.

"The enemies of peace don't need your approval. All they need is your apathy," he said.

"I do not believe that you want Northern Ireland to ever again be a place where tomorrow's dreams are clouded by yesterday's nightmares."

"The children of Northern Ireland deserve the chance to be part of the future," he said. "What really matters is what you do and whether you decide to give your children not your own yesterdays, but their own tomorrows."

webTitle: Number of jailed women doubles

fields.headline: Number of jailed women doubles
fields.trailText: The number of women in prison in England and Wales has more than doubled in the last six years, according to Home Office figures published yesterday.
fields.body:
The number of women in prison in England and Wales has more than doubled in the last six years, according to Home Office figures published yesterday.

Home Office ministers admitted that the increase from an average daily female prison population of 1,560 in 1993 to 3,392 in 1999 indicated there was discrimination against women within the criminal justice system.

This rise compares with an increase of 43% in the numbers of male prisoners over a similar period.

The official report, Women and the Criminal Justice System, says that women tend to have shorter criminal histories than men and "grow out" of crime earlier, but were more likely to be arrested for less serious offences.

It confirms overwhelmingly that the reason why women are sent to prison is for shoplifting and other forms of minor theft. In 1999, some 2,100 women were imprisoned for shoplifting, 440 for wounding offences and 360 for drug dealing.

The report also confirms that the sharp rise in the number of women in prison is mainly a result of the courts passing tougher sentences, and particularly highlights the fact that teenage girls are less likely to be given a community sentence, such as probation, than teenage boys.

The new figures challenge the idea that many women are in prison for failing to pay court fines. More than 200 women were sent to jail for defaulting on fines last year but the average sentence only lasted five day. In the overall daily prison population, fine defaulters accounted, on average, for five out of the 3,392.

The research also reveals that more than half of the women in prison, 55%, have a child under the age of 16, and more than a third have a child under five, while a higher proportion of the women prison population comes from minority ethnic groups (25%) compared with male prisoners.

The report confirms that men are much more likely to be involved in crime and the proportion of known criminals who are women stayed at about 17% throughout the 1990s.

The Home Office minister Charles Clarke said: "Lack of knowledge about child care provisions may exclude women from consideration for a community sentence. Research also shows that the provision of safe and secure accommodation for women pre- and post-trial is patchy.

"We need to investigate these types of inequalities and look at ways of providing better provision for the future." He said that a new think-tank was being set up with the Fawcett Society, which campaigns for women's equality, to investigate the problem.

The Howard League for Penal Reform said: "Women haven't got worse, the system has got more punitive towards them...We would like to see all women's prisons closed down."

webTitle: Health watchdog's vision for future

fields.headline: Health watchdog's vision for future
fields.standfirst: Some still fear that the commission for health improvement is a 'hit squad'. But as its first hospital reviews come out today,  Peter Homa, head of the new watchdog, argues that only good can come of closely examining the NHS
fields.trailText: Some still fear that the commission for health improvement is a 'hit squad'. But as its first hospital reviews come out today, Peter Homa, head of the new watchdog, argues that only good can come of closely examining the NHS
fields.body:
I have a vision where, in four years' time, when a patient is sent by a GP for a hospital appointment, they will know that an independent assessment has been made of that hospital and that the report is available to the public.

For hospitals in Chesterfield, Southampton and Sunderland, that vision is a now a reality.

Today, the commission for health improvement publishes the reports of its reviews of those hospitals - the beginning of a four-year programme of reviews that will cover every hospital, health authority, primary care trust and NHS trust in England and Wales.

The reports look at the issues that affect the quality of care patients receive, asking key questions. Are staff up-to-date with the latest clinical developments? Are junior staff properly supervised? Do the hospitals know how well they treat patients - and are they comparing themselves with similar hospitals? Do patients feel fully informed about their treatment?

These may seem obvious issues, but it is only recently that the NHS has had a legal duty to guarantee the quality of care it provides. For a long time, trust boards concentrated on how much treatment they were providing and what it was costing, with an assumption that quality was being looked after.

The three hospitals we report on today are well run; they all have areas that demonstrate very good practice in the health service; and they all have aspects that need improvement. In writing the reports, we have tried to present a picture of the hospitals that their local communities and staff would recognise.

Unsurprisingly, these pictures are a blend of strength and areas for improvement. My hope is that, in conveying our reports to local communities, local news and broadcast journalists will reflect that balance.

Each of the hospitals we report on today has produced a comprehensive action plan to address the issues the report raises. These action plans are very important. They give local people a way of being sure that the hospitals have taken our reports seriously and are doing something about them.

But it should not only be the staff of those hospitals and their communities who are interested in today's reports.

I hope that people everywhere will read them and use them to ask questions about their local health services and what they are doing to improve the quality of care they offer to patients. I also hope that health service staff across the country use them to help assess their own care of patients.

The commission has set out a bold aim - to bring about demonstrable improvement in patient care in the NHS. Our first three reports represent a major force for that improvement.

&#149: Peter Homa is chief executive of the commission for health improvement

webTitle: Housing associations win rent rise battle

fields.headline: Housing associations win rent rise battle
fields.trailText: Ministers have bowed to pressure from housing associations and upped the rent increases they will be allowed to set from 2002.
fields.body:
Ministers have bowed to pressure from housing associations and upped the rent increases they will be allowed to set from 2002.

The government's housing green paper earlier this year proposed that registered social landlords (RSLs) should only be allowed to increase rents in line with inflation.

After lobbying from housing associations, however, a government housing policy statement unveiled today promises increases of 0.5% above inflation, a figure that could prove crucial in keeping some landlords out of the red.

By reigning in rents, ministers hope to bring housing association and council charges more closely into line. At present, local government rents are around 15% lower than those of social landlords.

Council charges will rise at a "slightly quicker" rate than those allowed to RSLs, the policy statement says.

This will give authorities the chance to catch up with housing associations, although ministers say a gap of between 5-10% is likely to remain between association and council rents.

The government's housing policy statement also contains a new formula for setting social rents, replacing the currently inconsistent range of charges across the country.

This will place a 30% weight on local property prices, a 70% emphasis on local earnings and take into account the size of properties. This is likely to mean decreasing rents in the north, and an increase in London and the south.

The government proposes to dampen the effect of the changes by limiting rent changes to an annual £2 a week above inflation and compensating tenants through housing benefit.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott said this would help secure a "fairer, more coherent system for setting rents in the social housing sector, complementing our drive to improve the quality and supply of affordable housing".

The policy statement is, says the government, a result of the most comprehensive review of housing policy for 23 years. It was published alongside a new homes bill, which introduces "sellers' packs", designed to make homebuying easier, and includes measures to ensure local authorities will no longer be able to force accommodation on the homeless on a "take it or leave it" basis.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott also announced that £250m will be ploughed into the government's starter home initiative over the next three years to help at least 10,000 nurses, teachers, police and other key workers buy homes in places of high-cost housing such as London.

The package was welcomed by the Chartered Institute of Housing. Chief executive David Butler said: "We have been calling for a long term vision for housing, backed by funding, and believe that we are now at the beginning of seeing this become a reality."

The government's housing green paper earlier this year proposed that registered social landlords (RSLs) should only be allowed to increase rents in line with inflation. After lobbying from housing associations, however, a government housing policy statement unveiled today promises increases of 0.5% above inflation, a figure that could prove crucial in keeping some landlords out of the red. By reigning in rents, ministers hope to bring housing association and council charges more closely into line. At present, local government rents are around 15% lower than those of social landlords. Council charges will rise at a "slightly quicker" rate than those allowed to RSLs, the policy statement says. This will give authorities the chance to catch up with housing associations, although ministers say a gap of between 5-10% is likely to remain between association and council rents. The government's housing policy statement also contains a new formula for setting social rents, replacing the currently inconsistent range of charges across the country. This will place a 30% weight on local property prices, a 70% emphasis on local earnings and take into account the size of properties. This is likely to mean decreasing rents in the north, and an increase in London and the south. The government proposes to dampen the effect of the changes by limiting rent changes to an annual £2 a week above inflation and compensating tenants through housing benefit. Deputy prime minister John Prescott said this would help secure a "fairer, more coherent system for setting rents in the social housing sector, complementing our drive to improve the quality and supply of affordable housing". The policy statement is, says the government, a result of the most comprehensive review of housing policy for 23 years. It was published alongside a new homes bill, which introduces "sellers' packs", designed to make homebuying easier, and includes measures to ensure local authorities will no longer be able to force accommodation on the homeless on a "take it or leave it" basis. Deputy prime minister John Prescott also announced that £250m will be ploughed into the government's starter home initiative over the next three years to help at least 10,000 nurses, teachers, police and other key workers buy homes in places of high-cost housing such as London. The package was welcomed by the Chartered Institute of Housing. Chief executive David Butler said: "We have been calling for a long term vision for housing, backed by funding, and believe that we are now at the beginning of seeing this become a reality."

webTitle: From: Paul (13 Dec)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Paul
fields.trailText: Bhaktapur, to the east of Kathmandu, is amazing if touristy. Great view of Everest at dawn at this time of year. Not to be missed: a cup of tea with a blanket round your shoulders at 4am, at 4000 feet; then a bike descent into the valley at 5am and into Kathmandu at 6am for breakfast.
fields.body:
Sue,

Just thought I'd take a minute from a late nighter in a Liverpool office to travel a bit in spirit. You may now be on your way to Kathmandu. A few thoughts on there...

I disagree with other views on Kathmandu Guest House. It's in the main tourist area of Thamel, certainly, but can be a bit lads-on-the-Costa-Brava-but-got-the-wrong-plane. As you face the Kathmandu Guest House, go right and round the next left and a few yards down on the right is another smaller guest house run by Tibetans. Can't remember what it's called, but it's whitish coloured and the name may have something to do with religion, which is wholly irrelevant to the nature of the place. I've stayed there a couple of times and it's cheap and very friendly.

While in Nepal, you may go off trekking. I didn't, because my back's a mess, so I'll say nothing. But don't miss the Kathmandu Valley outside the city itself. It's all manageable in a day, either by bus, bike or taxi at a bit more cost, and it's incredible how quickly you are away from it all and into villages untouched. Bhaktapur to the east, 20km or so from Kathmandu, is amazing if touristy, and that's a staging post for a great climb to Nargokot on the east of the valley. Great view of Everest at dawn at this time of year. Not to be missed... a cup of tea with a blanket on shoulders at 4am, at 4000 feet; then a bike descent into the valley at 5am and into Kathmandu at 6am for breakfast and on to temples etc etc. Ah, it's all coming back....

In fact, I think the guest house is called the Catholic Guest House - as I said, nothing to do with Catholicism - the name is just used for marketing to westerners. Anyway, enough of Nepal. The main reason I email is that you may be looking at travel beyond Nepal. Not sure what time you have before you go to south east Asia and where you will go from. However, if you do have a week or so spare, here's a trip which will really set the travel juices flowing...

Go overland by bus from Kathmandu to the eastern border of Nepal with India. Take a bus to Siliguri in India from the border, then a bus to near the Bangladesh border. Take a rickshaw or a long walk to one of the borders least used by non-nationals in the world, into Bangladesh, walk for a few miles to the train station, jump on a train if it comes, otherwise get a bus to Saidpur, then a bus to Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh. Spend a couple of days in Dhaka (don't miss the extraordinary 17th century Armenian church run by the very last Armenian in Bangladesh (hope he's still alive)). Then paddle steamer from Dhaka for 36 hours though the Ganges delta to mangrove tiger-hiding swamp and on to Khulna in western Bangladesh. Then bus to the Indian border, then train to Calcutta. You can bus or fly back to Nepal from there if that's where your flight is from. Off the beaten track, I know, and possibe against Netjetter rules to take in another unplanned country. But hell, rules... what rules?

If you want details of the trip (eg what border, and how to get to it etc), let me know.

Anyway, must get back to work. In the meantime, go well.

webTitle: The Grinch continues to rule at UK box office

fields.headline: The Grinch continues to rule at UK box office
fields.trailText: Jim Carrey's Christmas blockbuster continues to draw the crowds, while John Waters' savage attack on Hollywood in Cecil B Demented fails to find an audience
fields.body:
Jim Carrey's The Grinch is proving as popular in the UK as in the United States (see earlier story) and it has held on to the number one spot at the box office in Britain for the second week running.

Against stiff competition from that other kiddie costume extravaganza, 102 Dalmatians, the Ron Howard directed adaptation of the Dr Seuss novel grossed a further £2m this weekend. The doggie sequel, starring Glenn Close and Gerard Depardieu, took just over £1m to claim the number three position, while Charlie's Angels held on to the number two spot and is still pulling in the crowds after three weeks on release.

The other big opener of the week, the much hyped John Waters film, Cecil B Demented, starring Melanie Griffith and Stephen Dorff, could only manage a disappointing £18,267 in ticket sales. By contrast, Sally Potter's period drama The Man Who Cried, which features Johnny Depp, Christina Ricci, Cate Blanchett and John Turturro, achieved a more respectable £26,181.

According to Screen Daily, it is unlikely The Grinch will hold on to the top spot in the UK for a third week. Next weekend sees the release of the biggest Stateside sleeper hit of the year, Meet the Parents. Although the comedy starring Robert De Niro and Ben Stiller has been on release for nearly three months, it is still going strong in the US top 10 and is likely to end the year as one of the five most successful films.

webTitle: Pratley reveals reasons behind Sunday Business move

fields.headline: Pratley speaks out about Sunday Business move
fields.standfirst:
Dec 13: Pratley to edit Sunday Business
Dec 13: Ex-director of thestreet.co.uk hired by Rivals.net
fields.trailText:
5.30pm update: Nils Pratley has said joining Sunday Business as editor was "like coming home". By Jessica Hodgson.

1.30pm: Pratley to edit Sunday Business

3pm: Ex-director of thestreet.co.uk hired by Rivals.net
fields.body:
Nils Pratley has said joining Sunday Business as editor was "like coming home".

"I never really mentally left," he said.

Mr Pratley had worked at Sunday Business as City editor since the relaunch in 1998, before being lured to join the street.co.uk by big salaries and share options, along with former editor Martin Baker.

He replaced Mr Baker, who left his job as editor, in April.

He will join Sunday Business in mid-January, when the editor of two years. Jeff Randall stands down to join the BBC as its new business supremo.

He joins just weeks after the financial internet service, thestreet.co.uk, he headed was closed down.

Mr Pratley said it was too early to outline his plans for the newspaper, but said he would be having discussions with Andrew Neil, editor-in-chief of Sunday Business, in the New Year.

As the new editor, he will be under pressure to cut the cover price of the newspaper, which has seen an increase in the number of bulk sales. But he told MediaGuardian: "It's a premium product and I'm not keen to cut the cover price."

He added that Mr Randall "has done a fantastic job of getting [the paper] up and running", since it was relaunched two years ago.

But the company closed following the collapse of theStreet.com, the American parent group, after consuming nearly £10m of venture capital funding.

Although Mr Pratley has worked on Sunday Business and the Daily Telegraph, he noted that the news "shows the way that the skills needed for online are not fundamentally different from the skills needed on paper".

"It's all journalism," he said.

webTitle: Nasdaq hatches secret plan for LSE takeover

fields.headline: Nasdaq hatches secret plan for LSE takeover
fields.standfirst:
Americans set one-month deadline before switching sides

Net news
fields.trailText: Nasdaq, Wall Street's hi-tech stock market, is understood to have set a one month deadline to break the impasse in negotiations to take over the London Stock Exchange before switching its allegiance to Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse in the race to create a pan-European stock market.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Nasdaq, Wall Street's hi-tech stock market, is understood to have set a one month deadline to break the impasse in negotiations to take over the London Stock Exchange before switching its allegiance to Frankfurt's Deutsche Börse in the race to create a pan-European stock market.

According to documents obtained by the Guardian, Nasdaq wants to turn London into an "agile, flexible" exchange with links to the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange and as the platform from which it would take over other exchanges in Europe.

However, Nasdaq's highly detailed "business case", dated November 27, which uses the code words "Nottingham" for the American exchange and "Lincoln" for London, is believed to have been rejected by the LSE chairman, Don Cruickshank, who does not believe his shareholders and members would countenance ownership by Nasdaq.

The LSE is thought to have tabled an alternative plan whereby Nasdaq would take a substantial minority stake in the LSE. But this in turn has been met with a cool response from the Americans.

Neither camp would comment last night, but broking sources believe Nasdaq is in a position to move quickly with Deutsche Börse if it believes negotiating with London is futile.

Any proposal to the Germans is likely to follow the blueprint set out in the business case drawn up by Nasdaq's investment bankers Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

This describes London-Nasdaq as the third hub in Nasdaq's grand plan to create a 24 hour global equity market, linking its existing business in Asia and the US. It proposes a drive across Europe to get companies to float through the revamped exchange and promises investors across the continent the ability to trade stocks around the world via an automated system.

The documents do not contain any details of the price Nasdaq is prepared to offer for the LSE. But this is not thought to have been a major factor in the discussions with the LSE, which defended itself against a hostile £800m bid from Sweden's OM Gruppen earlier this year.

But the high level of operational detail in the documents - covering everything from marketing to details of a new high-speed network - underline the advanced state of Nasdaq's plans.

The American exchange is known to have the tacit support of chancellor Gordon Brown, who has made no secret of his respect for Nasdaq's ability to encourage growth of new, start-up companies. But the Treasury has yet to apply any direct pressure on the LSE to agree terms.

Under the Nasdaq plan it is claimed that market participants will see their spending on technology - a key stock market issue - fall 50% within three years. The Americans are also proposing a new "hybrid" trading system, amalgamating Nasdaq's traditional "quote driven" market making approach with the "order driven" approach which has been progressively introduced in London over the past four years with the Sets trading system.

The management structure of the LSE would also be completely overhauled, ending the current stranglehold over the exchange enjoyed by the biggest investment banks. The board, comprised of stockbrokers, would include 12 members from financial and non-financial backgrounds, including fund managers and companies whose shares are traded on the exchange.

Driving force quotes v orders

Members of the London Stock Exchange have spent 14 years arguing over the respective attractions of two approaches to dealing in shares: "quote-driven" and "order-driven" trading.

The first, where market makers quote firm prices at which they will buy or sell a particular stock, was introduced with Big Bang in 1986. It was superseded four years ago by the Sets system in London, where market participants post individual orders to buy and sell shares on an electronic order book for everyone to see. Sets was first introduced for FTSE 100 companies and has been slowly extended to medium-sized firms since then.

Proponents of quote driven trading - the approach traditionally followed by Nasdaq in the US - say it creates greater liquidity, allowing investors the certainty of being able to buy and sell at any time the market is open at clear prices. But critics point out that the system can create artificially wide "spreads" between prices at which shares are bought and sold.

Order driven trading is said to produce keener pricing but can produce liquidity problems when trading is thin, leading to erratic movements in share prices.

Nasdaq's draft business case says a hybrid of order and quote driven trading is the way forward. Trading screens would consist of a "top of the book" for posting orders anonymously and a "montage" where market makers would publicly quote their two-way prices.
