webTitle: Bellow by James Atlas

fields.headline: Atlas's Bellow: masterpiece  or muck-raking?
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss on James Atlas's ambiguous biography of America's great man of letters, Saul Bellow
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Stephen Moss on James Atlas's ambiguous biography of America's great man of letters, Saul Bellow
fields.body:
Frankly, I give up. This column attempts to make sense of the critical reception given to new books. In the case of James Atlas's long-awaited biography of Saul Bellow (Faber, £25), that is almost impossible. The reviews were not just discordant, they were flatly contradictory: while some hailed a masterpiece, others castigated a piece of muck-raking.

Adam Mars-Jones, in the Observer, condemned the book as a literary hatchet-job. "Saul Bellow, like any biographical subject, has feet of clay, knees of clay, hips of clay, but there is an incongruous element of resentment in Atlas's recording of his flaws," wrote Mars-Jones. "Balanced literary judgments alternate with a sort of character assassination by degrees."

Nor was he convinced by Atlas's explanation for Bellow's philandering: "Bellow's private life is spectacularly messy, with four failed marriages, three compromised relationships with sons, periods of cranky therapy and plentiful adulteries. A fair-sized volume could be compiled exclusively from his vengeful fictional versions of ex-wives ... Atlas has a simple explanation for his subject's failures as a husband: the early death of Bellow's mother, before he had achieved independence from her, prevented him from forging mature relationships. This is a peculiarly reductive analysis, quite apart from the fact that the death of a boy's parent when he's 17 doesn't exactly qualify as childhood trauma."

Mars-Jones's best putdown concerned Atlas's methodology: "In his acknowledgements, Atlas thanks his assistant, Adam Kirsh, for having 'laboured to make my somewhat impressionistic citations credible'. 'Impressionistic' in a biography sits next to 'citations' as comfortably as 'juggling' next to 'nitroglycerine'." A neat aphorism.

There was an equally explosive attack on the book by Richard Poirier in the London Review of Books. "[Atlas's] sense of the life is on the whole censorious, flat-minded and peremptory," insisted Poirier. "Errors and confusions abound, as do misreadings of passages from Bellow's correspondence, while passages from his novels never receive the benefit of close interpretation or stylistic commentary."

The timing of the review was interesting: the LRB is usually happy to produce its lengthy critiques some months after books have appeared, but in this instance they leapt in ahead of the national press with a pre-emptive strike by an American critic who spent a large part of his review explaining his own relationship to Bellow and arguing that Atlas's mistaken belief that he (Poirier) was Jewish demonstrated just how hopeless the book was.

In the following issue, Atlas made a terse reply in the magazine's letters column suggesting that an unflattering portrait of Poirier in Herzog, Bellow's best-known book, might have influenced the review and should, at least, have been declared. All mildly entertaining in showing up the interminable squabbles of literary critics (the Herzog spat dates back 35 years), but not terribly helpful in determining whether Atlas had faithfully mapped Bellow's life and work.

Paul Bailey, in the Sunday Times, believed he had. "This biography is not a book designed for the prurient," argued Bailey. "Atlas is a serious writer, not some dabbler in tittle-tattle. He understands that the novelist's strained relationships with the chosen 'girls' have provided Bellow with much necessary material ... Atlas never loses sight of the fact that he is dealing with the complex life of a writer of genius."

Hywel Williams, in the Guardian, agreed. "Atlas combines scholarship with empathy," wrote Williams. "No life can 'explain' art, but the fiction of the 'dangling man' has been so insistently biographical that it cries out for an account as lucid as this. The making of Bellow is a many-layered thing, and it's all here: the Talmudic ancestors in Tsarist Russia; Abraham reading Chekhov's stories in Yiddish to his sons; Montreal, where the child of the immigrant family spoke French on the streets and read Genesis in Hebrew at home. And, of course, Chicago, where the family finally settled."

George Walden, in the London Evening Standard, went further, calling the book "a biographical tour de force, a sustained literary treat untainted by sensationalism". "Bellow has had a rich and motley life, especially sexually," wrote Walden. "Atlas charts it with great intellectual verve, and few biographies pull you along with the force of this one. The book sparkles with incident and intelligence. Atlas's prose is lively yet reflective, and the text is studded on almost every page with some superbly crafted Bellovian sentence or casual witticism."

Ian Hamilton, in the Sunday Telegraph, managed to occupy the middle ground: admiring Atlas's attempt to portray both man and novelist, while doubting whether he had squared the circle of Bellow's complex character. "Some Bellow traits he finds impossible to fathom," wrote Hamilton. "How can it be, for instance, that this lauded and prize-laden writer cannot rid himself of the belief that he is underrated? How can such a street-smart, free-style humorist be bothered to sustain so many life-long enmities, go to such lengths to avenge himself in print? And what about the life-long friends who regularly turn up in his novels, but in unflattering portrayals? Does this author have no loyalties, no qualms?

"One of the chief strengths of Atlas's shrewd and readable biography is that he allows so many of the novelist's real-life models to speak up for themselves. This testimony tends to be resentful. At the same time, though, much of it is simply glum and baffled. Trying to understand Saul Bellow has proved too much for most of his associates, it seems, and James Atlas, we suspect, knows how they feel."

A cleverly ambiguous conclusion. As the biographer of JD Salinger, Hamilton understands better than most how difficult it is to connect the strands of art and life.
fields.bodyText: Frankly, I give up. This column attempts to make sense of the critical reception given to new books. In the case of James Atlas's long-awaited biography of Saul Bellow (Faber, £25), that is almost impossible. The reviews were not just discordant, they were flatly contradictory: while some hailed a masterpiece, others castigated a piece of muck-raking. Adam Mars-Jones, in the Observer, condemned the book as a literary hatchet-job. "Saul Bellow, like any biographical subject, has feet of clay, knees of clay, hips of clay, but there is an incongruous element of resentment in Atlas's recording of his flaws," wrote Mars-Jones. "Balanced literary judgments alternate with a sort of character assassination by degrees." Nor was he convinced by Atlas's explanation for Bellow's philandering: "Bellow's private life is spectacularly messy, with four failed marriages, three compromised relationships with sons, periods of cranky therapy and plentiful adulteries. A fair-sized volume could be compiled exclusively from his vengeful fictional versions of ex-wives ... Atlas has a simple explanation for his subject's failures as a husband: the early death of Bellow's mother, before he had achieved independence from her, prevented him from forging mature relationships. This is a peculiarly reductive analysis, quite apart from the fact that the death of a boy's parent when he's 17 doesn't exactly qualify as childhood trauma." Mars-Jones's best putdown concerned Atlas's methodology: "In his acknowledgements, Atlas thanks his assistant, Adam Kirsh, for having 'laboured to make my somewhat impressionistic citations credible'. 'Impressionistic' in a biography sits next to 'citations' as comfortably as 'juggling' next to 'nitroglycerine'." A neat aphorism. There was an equally explosive attack on the book by Richard Poirier in the London Review of Books. "[Atlas's] sense of the life is on the whole censorious, flat-minded and peremptory," insisted Poirier. "Errors and confusions abound, as do misreadings of passages from Bellow's correspondence, while passages from his novels never receive the benefit of close interpretation or stylistic commentary." The timing of the review was interesting: the LRB is usually happy to produce its lengthy critiques some months after books have appeared, but in this instance they leapt in ahead of the national press with a pre-emptive strike by an American critic who spent a large part of his review explaining his own relationship to Bellow and arguing that Atlas's mistaken belief that he (Poirier) was Jewish demonstrated just how hopeless the book was. In the following issue, Atlas made a terse reply in the magazine's letters column suggesting that an unflattering portrait of Poirier in Herzog, Bellow's best-known book, might have influenced the review and should, at least, have been declared. All mildly entertaining in showing up the interminable squabbles of literary critics (the Herzog spat dates back 35 years), but not terribly helpful in determining whether Atlas had faithfully mapped Bellow's life and work. Paul Bailey, in the Sunday Times, believed he had. "This biography is not a book designed for the prurient," argued Bailey. "Atlas is a serious writer, not some dabbler in tittle-tattle. He understands that the novelist's strained relationships with the chosen 'girls' have provided Bellow with much necessary material ... Atlas never loses sight of the fact that he is dealing with the complex life of a writer of genius." Hywel Williams, in the Guardian, agreed. "Atlas combines scholarship with empathy," wrote Williams. "No life can 'explain' art, but the fiction of the 'dangling man' has been so insistently biographical that it cries out for an account as lucid as this. The making of Bellow is a many-layered thing, and it's all here: the Talmudic ancestors in Tsarist Russia; Abraham reading Chekhov's stories in Yiddish to his sons; Montreal, where the child of the immigrant family spoke French on the streets and read Genesis in Hebrew at home. And, of course, Chicago, where the family finally settled." George Walden, in the London Evening Standard, went further, calling the book "a biographical tour de force, a sustained literary treat untainted by sensationalism". "Bellow has had a rich and motley life, especially sexually," wrote Walden. "Atlas charts it with great intellectual verve, and few biographies pull you along with the force of this one. The book sparkles with incident and intelligence. Atlas's prose is lively yet reflective, and the text is studded on almost every page with some superbly crafted Bellovian sentence or casual witticism." Ian Hamilton, in the Sunday Telegraph, managed to occupy the middle ground: admiring Atlas's attempt to portray both man and novelist, while doubting whether he had squared the circle of Bellow's complex character. "Some Bellow traits he finds impossible to fathom," wrote Hamilton. "How can it be, for instance, that this lauded and prize-laden writer cannot rid himself of the belief that he is underrated? How can such a street-smart, free-style humorist be bothered to sustain so many life-long enmities, go to such lengths to avenge himself in print? And what about the life-long friends who regularly turn up in his novels, but in unflattering portrayals? Does this author have no loyalties, no qualms? "One of the chief strengths of Atlas's shrewd and readable biography is that he allows so many of the novelist's real-life models to speak up for themselves. This testimony tends to be resentful. At the same time, though, much of it is simply glum and baffled. Trying to understand Saul Bellow has proved too much for most of his associates, it seems, and James Atlas, we suspect, knows how they feel." A cleverly ambiguous conclusion. As the biographer of JD Salinger, Hamilton understands better than most how difficult it is to connect the strands of art and life.

webTitle: Health watchdog unveils first assessments

fields.headline: Health watchdog unveils first assessments
fields.trailText: The first official assessments of the quality of care in NHS hospitals has revealed a mixture of both excellence and underachievement.
fields.body:
The first official assessments of the quality of care in NHS hospitals has revealed a mixture of both excellence and underachievement.

The inspections of three English hospitals, by the commission for health improvement (CHI), found that all were generally well run, despite isolated pockets of poor performance.

The findings will come as a relief to ministers battling to retain public confidence in the NHS against a backdrop of intense media scrutiny of health service performance.

The CHI reports examined the quality of care, what steps hospitals had taken to improve care and reduce clinical risks, how staff treat patients and the level of information provided to patients.

The three hospitals studied were Chesterfield and North Derbyshire Royal Hospital NHS trust, City Hospitals Sunderland NHS trust, and Southampton University Hospitals NHS trust.

CHI chief executive Peter Homa said: "The three hospitals we report on today are well run, they all have areas that demonstrate good practice in the health service and they all have aspects that need improvement."

"Each of the trusts has produced an action plan in response to our report. If the action plans are carried out, the quality of care for patients at these hospitals will be even better that it is now."

"Everyone knows that standards vary across the NHS. CHI will raise standards across the board by highlighting excellence and not just pulling its punches where improvement is needed."

Chesterfield and North Derbyshire Royal NHS trust
According to the report, the trust has a "significantly higher mortality rate than the national average". It has the highest death rate of large acute trusts in England for emergency admissions and the second highest for non-emergencies. But CHI says the trust "has a number of strengths to build on", and although it is not able to explain its high death rates, it has instituted a internal review.

City Hospitals Sunderland NHS trust
The trusts's urology service is experiencing "serious difficulties" as a result of the departure of several members of senior medical staff, says the report. CHI also found evidence that some senior clinical staff felt "excluded" from decision making. But the report also found a "high commitment to patient care" at the trust, and a "strong performance culture". Many of its clinical services compare well to those of similar trusts in England.

Southampton University Hospitals NHS trust
CHI says it has "strong concerns" over the quality of care given to patients on trauma and orthopaedic wards, which suffered from nurse shortages, bed closures, long treatment waiting times and delays once patients were in hospital for treatment. The report also found, however, that trust performance in six out of seven clinical areas was "better than average", that it had a good record of developing innovative clinical practice, and that "most" of the trusts patients were "satisfied" with the quality of care they receive.

CHI was set up in 1999 to monitor standards of patient care in the NHS, and began its work in April this year. It aims to examine standards in every trust, health authority and primary care group or trust in England and Wales over the next four years.

It also investigates failing health services at the request of the secretary of state for health. It recently published two reports into poor care at hospitals in Carlisle and Carmarthenshire.

webTitle: Gore 'to stand down'

fields.headline: Gore 'to stand down'
fields.standfirst:
 Senior advisers say the race is over
 Gore suspends recount battle in Florida
 Vice president to address American public
fields.trailText: Al Gore will concede the presidential election to George W Bush early tomorrow morning, according to two of his most senior advisers.
fields.body:
Al Gore will concede the presidential election to George W Bush early tomorrow morning, according to two of his most senior advisers.

The Democrats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mr Gore will make his announcement in a televised address to the American public at 2am GMT. "The race is over," said one. "We're done."

Mr Gore today called a meeting of his campaign team in Florida and told them to suspend the legal fight to win a recount in the state.

"The vice-president has directed the recount committee to suspend activities," said Mr Gore's campaign chairman, William Daley, 12 hours after the US supreme court closed the door to further recounts in Florida's contested election.

Senior members of Mr Gore's own party have urged him to concede the race. But the vice-president went to bed after the supreme court ruling without telling aides what he would do.

After meeting with his wife, Tipper, and several advisers Mr Gore said he would not press the recount any further for Florida's pivotal 25 electoral votes.

Aides said the vice-president would telephone Mr Bush before his address.

The speech will make clear that he has conceded to Mr Bush and urge the country to unite behind the next president, according to a confidant. Mr Gore will also explain why he fought for five weeks after the election, returning to his theme that every vote should be counted.

Though Mr Gore has told advisers he considers the 5-4 ruling the act of a partisan high court it is understood the vice president will not criticize the justices in his speech.

In Tallahassee, Florida, the court ruling and the vice president's decision seemed to render the action by the Florida legislature to appoint a slate of presidential electors loyal to Mr Bush unnecessary.

Mr Gore, who won the national vote by more than 300,000 ballots, will become only the fourth presidential candidate to win the popular vote but succumb to a loss in the electoral college.

webTitle: University teaching body faces new rival

fields.headline: University teaching body faces new rival
fields.trailText: The body established by ministers and academic leaders to improve and regulate university teaching received another blow yesterday, when the largest university lecturers' union decided to develop its own professional arm to protect the status and standards of teaching in the higher education sector.
fields.body:
The body established by ministers and academic leaders to improve and regulate university teaching received another blow yesterday, when the largest university lecturers' union decided to develop its own professional arm to protect the status and standards of teaching in the higher education sector.

While stopping short of completely boycotting the Institute of Learning and Teaching, the Association of University Teachers has formally distanced itself from the institute. At the AUT Winter Council meeting, officials decided that the union is now unwilling to recommend academic staff to become members.

The Council put its weight behind proposals to create "an alternative system of accreditation which would embrace all of our members and be capable of becoming a respected and influential defender and promoter of professional standards of higher education teaching".

The creation of a rival body to promote and protect teaching standards in universities spells further trouble for the ILT, which has been bedeviled by criticisms since its creation 18 months ago.

By mid-October, the institute had only recruited 3000 academic members. It was hoped that the institute would help to raise the status of university teaching, often a second priority to research in university departments.

AUT has voiced a number of reservations about the institute, from under-recruitment of academic members, to problems publicising its role.

"We should be careful not to confuse our belief in the principle of professional accreditation and professional standards with our deep disappointment with the ILT, argued a paper presented to the AUT Council. "If the ILT fails it is absolutely clear that it will be replaced by something else, which may be even less palatable to us. Sitting back and allowing [inspection bodies such as] OFSTED or the QAA to fill the vacuum left by the demise or marginalisation of the ILT would be an abdication of our responsibility to our members and to the profession."

The Council also reaffirmed its support for academic pay in universities to be negotiated nationally.

webTitle: View from Austin, Texas: Money talks for Bush and the Rangers

fields.headline: Money talks for Bush and the Rangers
fields.standfirst:
Bush made a packet when in 1989 he sold shares in the baseball club that has just signed up a player for $252m over 10 years, writes Duncan Campbell

US election race
fields.trailText: Bush made a packet when in 1989 he sold shares in the baseball club that has just signed up a player for $252m over 10 years, writes Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
When George W Bush and a group of wealthy associates bought the Texas Rangers baseball club in 1989, he made a point of asking the team scouts to look out for Christian athletes and not the kind of players - drink drivers, dope smokers, that kind of chap - whose off-the-pitch antics would give the club a bad name.

His devotion to such principles clearly paid off. When he sold his 11% share in the club in 1998 he came away with $15.4m (£10.5m) on an original investment of $600,000, clearly demonstrating that his reward was to be on earth as well as in heaven.

Now Mr Bush and the Rangers are sharing the front pages again, and once again it is money that is talking. The Rangers have just signed the baseball player Alex Rodriguez for an astonishing $252m, for 10 years service from the 25-year-old. This is big money even by the standards of the golfer Tiger Woods and the tennis star Pete Sampras and surpasses deals done with the basketball players Kevin Garnett ($126m for six years) and Shaquille O'Neal ($120m for seven years).

Some fans claim that such enormous sums will be the death of baseball, just as many fans have seen the vast transfer fees killing off the poorer football clubs in Europe. They have attacked Scott Boras, the agent who negotiates such fees, as the Great Satan, just as football managers loathe the wide-boy agents who negotiate much more modest deals for their clients.

Rodriguez, who wept as he played his last game for the Seattle Mariners, will pick up a $10m signing-on fee and an annual salary of between $21m and $27m, better even than the deal Governor Bush got from the Rangers club - even if Rodriguez does have do some running around for it.

But the deal does draw attention back to the way Mr Bush made his big money out of the club. In her unauthorised biography of him, entitled Shrub, the Texas journalist Molly Ivins demonstrates how he and his associates benefited from a land deal that gave the club its park.

"Hillary Clinton had done a far smaller deal on commodities futures in the 1970s," writes Ms Ivins, "and the east coast press stopped just short of appointing its own special prosecutor to look into allegations that she was trading on her influence as the wife of the governor of Arkansas."

How different, she suggests, was the way that Mr Bush benefited from the assistance of Texas taxpayers to come home with his remarkable windfall.

Mr Bush has had a remarkably easy ride in the race for the presidency, considering his record in Texas, his dodging of active service when other young men were dying in Vietnam, his dissembling about his drink driving and the "lost years" about which he said: "When I was young and foolish, I was young and foolish."

This is the man who says Jesus is the political philosopher he admires most, and who has executed a record number of Texans and even mocked the clemency pleas of one, Karla Faye Tucker.

But as Ms Ivins suggests, "our boy is always hurt, surprised and indignant when others attack him. Hes such an affable fellow, ever uttering anodyne platitudes, the only way to get any real sense of him is through his record."

webTitle: Wobbly Bruce Grobbelaar, Backless Christian Lacroix, and Shaking Bixente Lizarazu

fields.headline: Wobbly Bruce Grobbelaar, Backless Christian Lacroix, and Shaking Bixente Lizarazu
fields.trailText: LIVERPOOL'S VASE RUNNETH OUT
fields.body:
LIVERPOOL'S VASE RUNNETH OUT

Pretty soon, you're going to be thoroughly sick of seeing that footage where Bruce Grobbelaar wobbles his legs in the final of the 1984 European Cup (a precursor to Big Cup, kids) like the great big crazy charactaar he is. That's because today's draw for Euro-Vase paired together the two teams who contested that final, and the BBC aren't suddenly going to start making imaginative trailers, you know.

"Roma were the side we most wanted to avoid. It is the most difficult draw we could possibly have had and it will be a massive task for us to overcome them," Liverpool manager Gerard Houllier whined through gritted teeth as his club were paired with the current leaders of Serie A. "Roma are certainly one of the best teams in Europe at the moment with their Gabriel Batistuta - Francesco Totti attack the best on the continent," chief executive Rick Parry chimed in, using phraseology which wouldn't be out of place in a regional newsreader's screen test.

But it wasn't all bad news for the crisis club, even though Roma sporting director Antonio Tempestilli was heard yelling "Revenge for 1984!" like a murderous nut. The crucial second leg should have been played in the Olympic Stadium in Rome on February 22, but because Lazio are playing Real Madrid there in Big Cup the day before, the ties had to be switched. And should Gerard Houllier's men fluke a result against the Serie A leaders, they'll have an easier match against Porto or Nantes in the quarter-finals! OK, granted, as bright sides go, this one's pretty dark.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 13: click here

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WEIRD, WEIRDER, WEIRDEST

Which is weirder: your mum dressing up in a backless Christian Lacroix number, taking you out for dinner and attempting to seduce you in front of the Pope (take your time and think about it, ladies); or catching a golden fish with a trowel in the middle of B&Q? The Fiver can testify that catching the fish is definitely weirder, as the Pope is often at a loose end on weeknights. But neither, and we mean neither, is as weird as listening to a high-ranking Uefa executive going on about how Big Cup is too big. Yet that is exactly what has happened.

"I'm convinced [Big Cup] is too long and the fixture list is saturated. We don't want people to get bored and it's important the competitions are interesting." Those are the words of Gerhard Aigner, director general of Uefa, ahead of a meeting of their executive committee tomorrow. "We aren't going to immediately reform [Big Cup] or [Euro Vase] but must consider it at some time," he went on as the assembled crowds swooned. Aigner, after a quick whiff of his armpits just to check, disappeared swiftly inside.

The cynic in the Fiver is of the mind that, if Uefa are openly willing to talk about reforming something they only created last year, then it must be seriously bell-ended. Aigner's remarks come on the back of figures that show that 1.5m fewer people watched Big Cup groupmatchstagealpha matches this season than last, a decline mirrored in attendance figures. It's almost as if we might see the old European Cup coming back. Until you take into account that silly sorts like Rangers are also using this meeting to complain that being rubbish stops them from earning as much money as Real Madrid. Put the two concerns together and, weirdly enough, you might just get a Super League. Which puts your mum in perspective.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Perhaps it should be renamed Best player in the European Championship" - Luis Figo kicks off another debate about the Fifa awards, suggesting that a certain French baldie might not have been the most consistent candidate for the accolade of World Player of the Year. But who would Figo have voted for?

"I would have voted for Figo."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TAKING THE LIZ

When French international Bixente Lizarazu received a letter from Paris last week, which started by congratulating him "on his football ability", his first thought was probably to sign another photo for another grateful fan. And his second was probably: "Oh my God, I'm going to die." Because this was no ordinary letter, coming as it did from Basque separatists (we'd call them terrorists but we're too young to be car bombed) ETA, who warned Lizarazu of dire consequences if he didn't pay their Revolutionary Tax.

webTitle: Bergg leaves Sky

fields.headline: Sky One chief in shock departure
fields.trailText: 3.15pm update: BSkyB has parted company with David Bergg, general manager of its flagship entertainment channel, Sky One. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BSkyB has parted company with David Bergg, general manager of its flagship entertainment channel, Sky One.

The shock departure of the former ITV golden boy comes less than a year after he was poached by the satellite broadcaster.

Mr Bergg joined BSkyB from ITV, where he was director of planning and strategy.

The hiring was seen as a major coup, with Mr Bergg widely regarded as the best scheduler in the country.

Mr Bergg saw the move as fulfilling his desire to become a bone fide channel controller, commissioning programmes as well as scheduling.

But he is thought not to have fit in to BSkyB's corporate culture, which is regarded to be more commercial and aggressive than ITV.

Earlier in the year he had talked of plans to poach BBC1 and ITV stars and reposition Sky One's programming to target the two mainstream entertainment channels' broad audience profiles.

Mr Bergg spoke of targeting the "Sunny Delight audience - families with parents in their 30s or 40s who read Nick Hornby and Bridget Jones".

He previously worked as a scheduler at Channel 5, BBC1 and GMTV before moving to ITV.

It is understood that severance terms are currently being negotiated with an announcement expected to follow.

Neither Mr Bergg or Sky were available to comment.

webTitle: MPs criticise Railtrack in scathing report

fields.headline: MPs criticise Railtrack in scathing report
fields.standfirst: Transport committee report on Railtrack
fields.trailText: Railtrack's troubles deepened today after it was accused by MPs of having lost sight of its "core responsibility" to run a safe and efficient railway in the run up to the Hatfield crash.
fields.body:
Railtrack's troubles deepened today after it was accused by MPs of having lost sight of its "core responsibility" to run a safe and efficient railway in the run up to the Hatfield crash.

The Commons Environment, Transport and Regional Affairs Committee castigated the management of the beleaguered rail infrastructure company for "systematic, often-repeated failings" which had led to one crisis after another.

In a scathing report, it warned that the "cosmetic re-shuffling" of the board, following the resignation of the chief executive, Gerald Corbett, in the wake of Hatfield, would not solve Railtrack's deep-seated problems.

The report, one of the most searing indictments of a private company by a Commons committee, highlighted failings at every level of the organisation and called for a radical shake-up of the senior management.

It followed remarks from the prime minister, Tony Blair, last night which described travelling on the railways at the moment as "absolute hell".

The report said: "Railtrack has, it seems, staggered from one crisis to another in recent years. "As a private company, Railtrack, and ultimately its shareholders, should acknowledge that crises are not simply the result of unforeseen outside events such as accidents or 'local failures', but are indicative of systematic, often-repeated failings in the company's management systems and leadership which the resignation of the chief executive and the cosmetic re-shuffling of the board will not resolve."

The MPs strongly criticised the composition of the Railtrack board, with only two of the seven executive directors having had significant experience of working in the rail industry, while just one was a qualified engineer.

"It suggests that the company had previously lost sight of the fact that its core responsibility is to run a safe and efficient railway, and that to do so requires directors and managers with appropriate experience," the report said.

It said the appointment of the only engineer on the board, the commercial director, Richard Middleton, to the new post of technical director did not go far enough and that more senior people were needed with "knowledge and experience appropriate for running the railway".

Railtrack's management of the contractors, Balfour Beatty, who were responsible for maintenance on the East Coast Main Line where the Hatfield crash occurred, had been "totally inadequate", the report said.

The decision to institute such an extensive programme of track inspections after the Hatfield crash, leading to widespread line closures and speed restrictions, suggested that Railtrack lacked confidence in the way its system of outside maintenance contractors had been managed.

Even now, the report said, there were still concerns that some contractors had proved either unable, or unwilling, to adopt best practice in maintaining the railway.

The MPs said Railtrack had failed to ensure that the new safety culture now espoused by its senior management was shared by its contractors, sub-contractors and frontline workers on the railway.

The report also strongly criticised the way Railtrack managers shut down the whole of the West Coast Main Line from Carlisle to Glasgow, without warning, leaving thousands of commuters stranded.

"The decision to close the West Coast Main Line on October 25, and the way in which that decision was reached, are indicative of poor communications between layers of management in Railtrack, an inability on the part of the company to see its activities and responsibilities in a wider context and shows scant regard for public interest," it said.

webTitle: Luton University faces funding cuts following Vauxhall closure

fields.headline: Luton University faces funding cuts following Vauxhall closure
fields.trailText: Luton University would suffer a short-term loss of several hundreds of thousands of pounds from the closure of the Vauxhall motor manufacturing plant, said vice-chancellor Dai John today. But the university would get involved in retraining members of the 2,000-strong workforce and in helping to diversify the town's economy.
fields.body:
Luton University would suffer a short-term loss of several hundreds of thousands of pounds from the closure of the Vauxhall motor manufacturing plant, said vice-chancellor Dai John today. But the university would get involved in retraining members of the 2,000-strong workforce and in helping to diversify the town's economy.

The university which with 1,200 staff is among the largest employers in the town, has work-based learning programmes in IT training and business degrees and is a partner in the Vauxhall sports centre.

"It has been a sudden shock to the system but I have no doubt that situated where we are, close to London with good transport links, that the basis for an economic revival in the town is there. We like to think we are the kind of university that can help retrain the workforce and improve their qualifications and expertise. We have large numbers of work-based and part-time students and we are open all year round, " said Dr John.

webTitle: Why would teenagers kill themselves?

fields.headline: Life or death decisions
fields.standfirst: After the death of two girls in a suicide pact, Dorothy Rowe asks: why would teenagers kill themselves and what can we do to stop them?
fields.trailText: After the death of two girls in a suicide pact, Dorothy Rowe asks: why would teenagers kill themselves and what can we do to stop them?
fields.body:
The recently reported death of two teenage girls in a gas-filled car is deeply shocking. Why would two young women, we wonder, choose to die in a suicide pact? Sadly, though, teenage suicide is not rare. After 1945, the rate of teenage suicide around the world began to rise significantly. In more recent years, the rate for young women has levelled out. The rate for young men, however, has continued to rise, possibly because many, faced with a dearth of traditional jobs and roles for men, have felt that society had no place for them.

The legal tradition has been to regard suicide as an act committed when the balance of the mind is disturbed - that is, as a permanent or temporary madness. This formulation does not, of course, explain why a person commits suicide. Suicidal thoughts are considered to be a symptom of depression, but while all depressed people contemplate suicide as a way of escaping their misery, not all depressed people even attempt suicide; and it is by no means certain that everyone who commits suicide is depressed. What is possible is to explain suicide in terms of what it is to be a person.

Each of us is keenly aware of being a person, that which we each call I, myself. This sense of being a person is made up of a structure of all our ideas, attitudes, opinions, memories and feelings. Within this structure are some central ideas about who we are and what our moral stance must be. Our sense of being a person is what we hold most dear, and our every decision and action is aimed in part at preserving our being that person.

But we also strive to survive as a physical body. For most of our lives, surviving as a person and as a body go together. A situation can arise, though, where we have to sacrifice one or the other. Suppose, as a loving parent, you find yourself and your child in some dangerous situation where only one of you can survive. Do you sacrifice yourself or your child? Your choice is simple. You die in order that your child will live. You sacrifice your body in order to continue being what you value most, a loving parent. You know that if you chose otherwise and lived while your child died, you would have failed yourself. This may seem an extreme example, and yet the mechanism is common: many of the people who suffer depression or post-traumatic stress disorder after a disaster believe that the only way they could have continued to be the person they once valued would have been to have died in the disaster.

Some people abandon their bodies when they realise that the world no longer offers them the supports they know are essential to the maintenance of themselves as a person. Some of them simply lose the will to live. Others contract a survivable illness and yet die. Research shows that a significant number of widowers (though, curiously, not widows) die within a year of their wives' deaths.

The will to live can be very strong, and so some people who feel that their situation will not allow them to be themselves choose to kill their body in order to be the person they know themselves to be. If they cannot live as themselves, they will die as themselves. In killing themselves, they leave a message to the world at large and to some, if not all, of their nearest and dearest. Their written message might be: "You will be better off without me." But the subtext is: "You have failed to be what I wanted you to be." Many of the parents of teenage suicides understand that this is the message and torture themselves with guilt.

Guilt is very familiar to parents, aware that none of us is perfect. Teenagers, suicidal or not, make life difficult for parents precisely because children are reluctant to accept that they have less than perfect parents. Part of the process of growing up is learning to accept the fallibility of our parents and the impossibility of the world ever being what we want it to be. When we are teenagers everything matters enormously. Yet in life things rarely turn out the way we expect. We come to accept compromise as wisdom, rather than as a betrayal of ideals. Adults can help teenagers arrive at such wisdom by listening and discussing, while refraining from criticism and instruction.

One common feature of teenage suicide is that the young person felt that there was no one who would listen. The Samaritans offer a special service to teenagers who find they have no one to talk to. Listening to your children is not easy, because you will hear a great deal that you may wish you had not heard, chiefly accounts of your shortcomings. But if you find you can, then you will have given your children the greatest gift: the gift of being listened to and accepted.

 Dorothy Rowe is the author of Breaking the Bonds: Understanding Depression and Finding Freedom (HarperCollins, £9.99).

Sadly, though, teenage suicide is not rare. After 1945, the rate of teenage suicide around the world began to rise significantly. In more recent years, the rate for young women has levelled out. The rate for young men, however, has continued to rise, possibly because many, faced with a dearth of traditional jobs and roles for men, have felt that society had no place for them. The legal tradition has been to regard suicide as an act committed when the balance of the mind is disturbed - that is, as a permanent or temporary madness. This formulation does not, of course, explain why a person commits suicide. Suicidal thoughts are considered to be a symptom of depression, but while all depressed people contemplate suicide as a way of escaping their misery, not all depressed people even attempt suicide; and it is by no means certain that everyone who commits suicide is depressed. What is possible is to explain suicide in terms of what it is to be a person. Each of us is keenly aware of being a person, that which we each call I, myself. This sense of being a person is made up of a structure of all our ideas, attitudes, opinions, memories and feelings. Within this structure are some central ideas about who we are and what our moral stance must be. Our sense of being a person is what we hold most dear, and our every decision and action is aimed in part at preserving our being that person. But we also strive to survive as a physical body. For most of our lives, surviving as a person and as a body go together. A situation can arise, though, where we have to sacrifice one or the other. Suppose, as a loving parent, you find yourself and your child in some dangerous situation where only one of you can survive. Do you sacrifice yourself or your child? Your choice is simple. You die in order that your child will live. You sacrifice your body in order to continue being what you value most, a loving parent. You know that if you chose otherwise and lived while your child died, you would have failed yourself. This may seem an extreme example, and yet the mechanism is common: many of the people who suffer depression or post-traumatic stress disorder after a disaster believe that the only way they could have continued to be the person they once valued would have been to have died in the disaster. Some people abandon their bodies when they realise that the world no longer offers them the supports they know are essential to the maintenance of themselves as a person. Some of them simply lose the will to live. Others contract a survivable illness and yet die. Research shows that a significant number of widowers (though, curiously, not widows) die within a year of their wives' deaths. The will to live can be very strong, and so some people who feel that their situation will not allow them to be themselves choose to kill their body in order to be the person they know themselves to be. If they cannot live as themselves, they will die as themselves. In killing themselves, they leave a message to the world at large and to some, if not all, of their nearest and dearest. Their written message might be: "You will be better off without me." But the subtext is: "You have failed to be what I wanted you to be." Many of the parents of teenage suicides understand that this is the message and torture themselves with guilt. Guilt is very familiar to parents, aware that none of us is perfect. Teenagers, suicidal or not, make life difficult for parents precisely because children are reluctant to accept that they have less than perfect parents. Part of the process of growing up is learning to accept the fallibility of our parents and the impossibility of the world ever being what we want it to be. When we are teenagers everything matters enormously. Yet in life things rarely turn out the way we expect. We come to accept compromise as wisdom, rather than as a betrayal of ideals. Adults can help teenagers arrive at such wisdom by listening and discussing, while refraining from criticism and instruction. One common feature of teenage suicide is that the young person felt that there was no one who would listen. The Samaritans offer a special service to teenagers who find they have no one to talk to. Listening to your children is not easy, because you will hear a great deal that you may wish you had not heard, chiefly accounts of your shortcomings. But if you find you can, then you will have given your children the greatest gift: the gift of being listened to and accepted.  Dorothy Rowe is the author of Breaking the Bonds: Understanding Depression and Finding Freedom (HarperCollins, £9.99).

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: Several recent surveys show that more an more teenagers want cosmetic surgery. How should parents respond to their pleas?
fields.trailText: The question: Several recent surveys show that more an more teenagers want cosmetic surgery. How should parents respond to their pleas?
fields.byline: Interviews by Diane Taylor and Amy Fleming
fields.body:
Mary Mason Popular singer and mother
My 13-year-old daughter, Jamie Lee, has inherited her looks from me. I didn't like my nose and had it improved with plastic surgery, which absolutely changed my life. She has inherited my nose and is very keen to have plastic surgery on her nose, too. She is already on the stage and looks are so important in the entertainment business. She goes to stage school and all the girls want plastic surgery for Christmas. If her skeleton is mature enough at 16 I won't stop her having her nose done. I could not live with my nose so why should I expect her to live with hers

Verdict: Permit surgery

John Pickering Clinical director at the Transform Clinic

Many teenagers do come to us but it's not appropriate if they haven't finished growing. Young people have rhinoplasty (plastic surgery of the nose) or have their ears pinned back after years of being bullied and it makes a huge difference to their self-esteem. But recently a young woman with 34C breasts wanted to become a 34E so she could earn money as a glamour model. We would not perform an operation like that on a teenager. It is important to involve a young person's parents and their GP, if surgery is being considered, and not to make a snap decision.

Verdict: Consult carefully

Dee Dawson Director of centre for children with eating disorders

If one of my children came to me and said they wanted to have plastic surgery, I'd want to know what was contributing to that child's lack of self-confidence and self-esteem. I would see if there were any problems at home or at school because something must have happened to make a child want to do something so radical as that at such a young age. I would view it as unnecessary mutilation and tell her she's perfectly OK as she is, that we're all meant to be different and not look like one person. I think it's very important to boost a child's self-confidence in these situations.

Verdict: Boost self-esteem

Jane Frances Schools counsellor with Changing Faces

Changing Faces provides support for people with disfigurement and I work with children in school who are bullied because of their looks. I run sessions that aim to encourage pupils to talk about things which make them feel different from each other and to look beyond physical appearance. If a child is worried about their appearance, it's important to acknowledge that worry but never miss a chance to highlight a positive inner quality like being fun to be with. Unfortunately, what counts as normal is narrowing because we have lost a lot of social intimacy.

Verdict: Use counselling

David Sharpe Ex-president, Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons

I do get young girls requesting liposuction, but I would be very nervous about doing it for anyone under 21. Rhinoplasty is the commonest procedure for teenagers, but they have to be over 16. Breast surgery is rarely appropriate. More and more children are unhappy about their body image. I have sometimes performed a rhinoplasty on someone who turns out to be anorexic: the problem isn't their nose but their body image. It is often important to involve a clinical psychologist to have an assessment made before deciding on surgery.

Verdict: See a psychologist

Alison Mansfield Mother of three

It would depend on what they wanted to change, how long it had been a problem and how necessary it was. For a serious, long-standing problem I'd agree. But I'd say no to things like liposuction and breast enlargement. If my daughter were over 16 and wanted either of those, I'd tell her that her body will change shape during her life and that having fat removed is temporary. I'd certainly take her wishes seriously and try to understand why she was considering it. But I'd try to deal with what might be the root of the problem, such as self-esteem, healthy eating or exercise.

Verdict: Be sympathetic

webTitle: All about my father

fields.headline: All about my father
fields.standfirst: If your parents died tomorrow, how much would you really know about them? In the weeks before his father's death, James Runcie decided to make an intimate film portrait of his life. Joanna Moorhead reports
fields.trailText: If your parents died tomorrow, how much would you really know about them? In the weeks before his father's death, James Runcie decided to make an intimate film portrait of his life.
fields.body:
Parents do not live for ever. That is the plain truth, but somehow, no matter how old we grow ourselves, as their children we always hoodwink ourselves into believing the opposite. Mum and Dad: always there, part of the furniture. We never get round to telling them how much we appreciate all they have done because, well, there will be another opportunity. And we never bother to ask much about their past, because, after all, the subject is bound to crop up one day.

Except that it never does. And then . . . bam! They die, and it always comes as a shock. (Though why it should be so is mysterious. After all, the deaths of our parents must be among the most predictable events of our lives.) Such a loss, too: more than we had ever imagined. Often there is no one to share that loss with; these days, you are expected to take, at most, a week off work and then return, ready to accept a few words of condolence and take up where you left off. Only it is not so easy, because suddenly you apprehend how much you have lost and where it has left you.

"Guilt, anger, despair, shock, sorrow, relief - it's all there, in this wildly swinging emotional turmoil. People seem to think you'll get over it within a few days, but it's a huge rite of passage as well as a loss."

So says James Runcie, whose dad died five months ago. When most people's parents die, you don't necessarily hear about it, but Runcie's father was famous: he was the former Archbishop of Canterbury. One consequence is that friends make a beeline for Runcie to share their experiences of parental bereavement. "I was at a Christmas party last night," he says, "and so many people came up to me to talk about their grief at losing their parents. When it happens to you, you suddenly find yourself part of this big club you didn't even realise existed.

"Basically, the world is divided into people who have lost a parent and people who haven't. The latter are a bit scared of you: they're not sure what to say. But the former are falling over themselves to come and talk to you, to open up about their grief, to share it all with someone else who understands."

Like everyone who has been bereaved, Runcie must have his regrets. But one thing he doesn't regret is having taken the opportunity to talk, really talk, to his father, about his life, about his marriage, about what he believed in and what he didn't, about what he wished he had done and what he wished he hadn't. In the weeks leading up to Lord Runcie's death from cancer, his son - a television film-maker - spoke to him on camera. The result is a portrait so intimate that at times you feel you are eavesdropping upon the most important conversation this father and son ever had.

Runcie is grateful that his father's status provided the pretext to make his film. He was motivated by the desire to show that his dad was more than his Spitting Image puppet; that he was a funny, human, entertaining person (and in this intention, his film succeeds admirably). But he believes that such testimonies should not be reserved for the great and good, or for those who need to set a public record straight.

"Buy a camcorder, get out the camera, record them talking," he says. "We spend so much time pointing the lens in the direction of the next generation, our own children, that we hardly ever think to turn it back towards grandad in the corner. But when they're gone, you really regret not having film and pictures of them. So many of my friends have said they wish they'd done something like this when their parents were still alive."

Losing your parent's history with their death is a common experience. When they were alive, it was so easy to ask but you never did; and when they are not, there are gaps that are almost impossible to fill. As a public figure, Lord Runcie's career was well chronicled, so it was not so much a factual account that his son required as the personal flavour he had missed out on because his dad was busy ministering to a flock as well as supporting a family (often in that order, it seemed). Why, Runcie asks in the film, did his father marry his mother? What was it like growing up in Liverpool in the 1920s and 30s? And how on earth did the clergyman come to be president of the Cuddesdon Angling Society?

A friend had advised Runcie that he should do everything he could to prepare for his father's death. He took the advice and believes that it has helped in the aftermath. But despite all that, nothing could prepare him for the terribleness of the actual event and the searing pain of the immediate loss. "When it eventually came, my father's death was like nothing I had expected at all," he says. "It was just too shocking to accept or accommodate."

Runcie's mother-in-law also died this year. "Her husband had died 10 years before," he says, "so for my wife this was the death of her only surviving parent, which was a different kind of loss from the one I experienced.

"The death of your last parent strips away all sense of your childhood. It exposes you: it means there's no one left to mother you or father you any more. In some ways it's even more shocking than the first death."

And yet, says Runcie, there is another complex emotion experienced on the death of a parent: relief. "We never talk about it," he says. "But there is relief. If the parent has been suffering, it's in the sense that they're not suffering any more. But there's another type of relief, too: it's to do with this sense that you can be yourself, that now you have to work out where your parent stops and you begin."

The death of a parent also leaves a vacant role to be filled, Runcie observes. Every family has its peacemaker and its entertainer, its storyteller and its organiser. "Some of what's gone has to be taken over, and the role can either be fragmented within the family or someone can seize the initiative and take on the part the parent played," says Runcie. "In some ways, you are both becoming your parent and trying to escape him."

In the film, Runcie pays his father this tribute: "Although he had his faults, he taught me, by example, so much of what it is to live and, in the end, what it is to die." In the final shot, in an interview recorded just a week before the former archbishop died, the camera pans from father to son, as if to suggest the passing of a baton from one generation to the next. The last words belong to the younger Runcie: "I don't think I can ask any more."

 My Father will be shown on Channel 4 on Saturday at 8pm.

webTitle: Do computers help children learn?

fields.headline: Mind games
fields.standfirst: Computers will top the shopping list of many families this Christmas. But, asks Bruce Millar, do they help children learn or simply rot their brains?
fields.trailText: Computers will top the shopping list of many families this Christmas. But, asks Bruce Millar, do they help children learn or simply rot their brains?
fields.body:
This Christmas, parents in Britain are lined up to spend nearly £1bn on computers and computer games for their children. With this year's sales breaking all records even before the gift-buying season, the European Leisure Software Publishers Association predicts sales of £370m in the UK on games alone in the final quarter of 2000, and many families will invest more than £800 in a computer for their children.

Some of these parents will be buying a second computer because they are fed up with sharing their own: according to research just published by Microsoft, one in four have had a PC crashed by the children overloading the hard drive with games. But many others will have been simply unable to withstand the onslaught of pester power. "It's educational," a child will insist, coming over all PC at the prospect of owning a PC. "My teacher says I'll get better marks if my homework is done on a computer."

This might well be a bluff, of course. On the other hand, it could be true. At one primary school in Wandsworth, south London, a fourth-year class of eight- and nine-year-olds was told precisely this by a teacher who said the use of computers by pupils made it easier for her to read their projects. The class rep promptly booked an appointment with the head and put an end to that.

From the Department for Education and Employment down, however, most of those involved in teaching children believe wholeheartedly in the educational value of computers. A key Labour pledge at the 1997 election was to connect every classroom to the internet; so far, 98% of secondary and 80% of primary schools have made the link. A further £1bn has been pledged to UK online, a scheme to set up 6,000 centres providing free or cheap internet services to the public in the next two years.

Richard Millwood, the deputy director of Ultralab, a research team at Anglia Polytechnic University in Cambridge that advised the Labour party on its election pledge, is clear on the benefits of computers to children. "Computers empower," he says. "They provide new ways to think about things which are mind-expanding."

Even young children, he maintains, have little trouble manipulating programs that can seem daunting to adults - from word processors and spreadsheets to movie-making packages. He is also clear that popular computer game consoles such as the PlayStation can be educational, developing problem-solving abilities and physical skills. "The truth is that games are all about learning," he says. "The question is: can these skills be transferred? And I think the answer is yes."

The Parents' Information Network (Pin), an independent organisation that offers advice and support on computers and education, is equally enthusiastic. "Children are very confident about computers, and find them very motivating towards their own work," says Pin's communications director, Maggie Holgate. "And a child that doesn't have some level of access to computers is unfortunately going to be disadvantaged - this is the way the world is moving."

Both Pin and Ultralab are, however, alive to the dangers posed by unsupervised access to computers, whether as a result of parental ignorance, apathy or complacency. Both recommend that computers should be in the living room or kitchen, and games should be set up for two or more players, with the parents taking an active role. "In most cases, best practice isn't happening," Holgate admits. "Many parents use the computer as a child-minding device; others lack confidence and feel inhibited about taking part; and some think they've done their bit just by buying it. But the downside of computers is very serious and potentially dangerous."

The dangers include access to violent and pornographic material on the internet or in games; physical problems such as repetitive strain injury and postural complaints; the isolating effects of using a computer alone; and the addictive nature of computers, which may result in compulsive behaviour and neglect of schoolwork, exercise and social interaction.

Few children are capable of regulating their computer use, and this is where parents must be active and vigilant. "It is madness to give a child a computer which they keep in their bedroom," says Millwood. "There must be engagement and a social context to computer use. You also need a printer so the child is doing something with an outcome, rather than just taking part in a passive and ephemeral process."

Pin provides information sheets, website information and a telephone service to parents seeking advice on computer safety, filtering internet content, educational software and games, as well as information on how to improve their own IT skills.

"Buy the best computer you can afford," advises Pin's Jackie Disney. "You will at least be able to keep up with the advances for a couple of years, and the cheaper models are less forgiving of mistakes by novices."

You may decide as parents that these prices are beyond you; that with the government investing so much in computers at school and the new online centres, there is no need for your children to have one at home as well; or you may simply refuse to buy into the technological boom. Nick Seaton, the chairman of the Campaign for Real Education, a traditionalist pressure group, is cautious about being seen as anti-computer and out of touch, but he believes that new technology is not appropriate to children of primary school age.

"While they're spending time fiddling around with computers, other things are having to fall by the wayside," he argues. "I also worry that a lot of this emphasis on computers is really to prepare youngsters for work in telephone call centres - basic, low-pay jobs - but it is not preparing them to do anything more constructive and challenging."

The National Association for Primary Education also has strong reservations about computer use before key stage two. Although educational software exists for children as young as nine months, some reason that, because the brain cells are still forming physical links up to six or seven years, it is unwise to introduce computers to this age group. The neuroscientist Susan Greenfield recently presented this argument, warning that the standardised information received from computers could lead to "standardised brain connections" and a stifling of individuality and creativity. "Of course, people get information from the internet," said Greenfield in an address to the Royal Institution, "but you can't necessarily get a framework into which to put the facts. That has to come from thinking, walking and living."

This echoes the warnings from computer enthusiasts at Pin and Ultralab: if you do invest in a computer for your family, it must not become the centre of your child's life, and you must be prepared to find out how it works and keep its use under your control. Perhaps it is time to adapt the old RSPCA slogan: a computer is not just for Christmas.

From the Department for Education and Employment down, however, most of those involved in teaching children believe wholeheartedly in the educational value of computers. A key Labour pledge at the 1997 election was to connect every classroom to the internet; so far, 98% of secondary and 80% of primary schools have made the link. A further £1bn has been pledged to UK online, a scheme to set up 6,000 centres providing free or cheap internet services to the public in the next two years. Richard Millwood, the deputy director of Ultralab, a research team at Anglia Polytechnic University in Cambridge that advised the Labour party on its election pledge, is clear on the benefits of computers to children. "Computers empower," he says. "They provide new ways to think about things which are mind-expanding." Even young children, he maintains, have little trouble manipulating programs that can seem daunting to adults - from word processors and spreadsheets to movie-making packages. He is also clear that popular computer game consoles such as the PlayStation can be educational, developing problem-solving abilities and physical skills. "The truth is that games are all about learning," he says. "The question is: can these skills be transferred? And I think the answer is yes." The Parents' Information Network (Pin), an independent organisation that offers advice and support on computers and education, is equally enthusiastic. "Children are very confident about computers, and find them very motivating towards their own work," says Pin's communications director, Maggie Holgate. "And a child that doesn't have some level of access to computers is unfortunately going to be disadvantaged - this is the way the world is moving." Both Pin and Ultralab are, however, alive to the dangers posed by unsupervised access to computers, whether as a result of parental ignorance, apathy or complacency. Both recommend that computers should be in the living room or kitchen, and games should be set up for two or more players, with the parents taking an active role. "In most cases, best practice isn't happening," Holgate admits. "Many parents use the computer as a child-minding device; others lack confidence and feel inhibited about taking part; and some think they've done their bit just by buying it. But the downside of computers is very serious and potentially dangerous." The dangers include access to violent and pornographic material on the internet or in games; physical problems such as repetitive strain injury and postural complaints; the isolating effects of using a computer alone; and the addictive nature of computers, which may result in compulsive behaviour and neglect of schoolwork, exercise and social interaction. Few children are capable of regulating their computer use, and this is where parents must be active and vigilant. "It is madness to give a child a computer which they keep in their bedroom," says Millwood. "There must be engagement and a social context to computer use. You also need a printer so the child is doing something with an outcome, rather than just taking part in a passive and ephemeral process." Pin provides information sheets, website information and a telephone service to parents seeking advice on computer safety, filtering internet content, educational software and games, as well as information on how to improve their own IT skills. "Buy the best computer you can afford," advises Pin's Jackie Disney. "You will at least be able to keep up with the advances for a couple of years, and the cheaper models are less forgiving of mistakes by novices." You may decide as parents that these prices are beyond you; that with the government investing so much in computers at school and the new online centres, there is no need for your children to have one at home as well; or you may simply refuse to buy into the technological boom. Nick Seaton, the chairman of the Campaign for Real Education, a traditionalist pressure group, is cautious about being seen as anti-computer and out of touch, but he believes that new technology is not appropriate to children of primary school age. "While they're spending time fiddling around with computers, other things are having to fall by the wayside," he argues. "I also worry that a lot of this emphasis on computers is really to prepare youngsters for work in telephone call centres - basic, low-pay jobs - but it is not preparing them to do anything more constructive and challenging." The National Association for Primary Education also has strong reservations about computer use before key stage two. Although educational software exists for children as young as nine months, some reason that, because the brain cells are still forming physical links up to six or seven years, it is unwise to introduce computers to this age group. The neuroscientist Susan Greenfield recently presented this argument, warning that the standardised information received from computers could lead to "standardised brain connections" and a stifling of individuality and creativity. "Of course, people get information from the internet," said Greenfield in an address to the Royal Institution, "but you can't necessarily get a framework into which to put the facts. That has to come from thinking, walking and living." This echoes the warnings from computer enthusiasts at Pin and Ultralab: if you do invest in a computer for your family, it must not become the centre of your child's life, and you must be prepared to find out how it works and keep its use under your control. Perhaps it is time to adapt the old RSPCA slogan: a computer is not just for Christmas. webTitle: Trying: Leah Wild's IVF diary

fields.headline: Love, hate and ambivalence
fields.standfirst: Trying: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.trailText: Trying: Leah Wild's IVF diary
fields.body:
I have received my first hate mail. To be frank, I had been expecting it for some time. I've been writing this column for seven months, and I know that IVF and preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD), in which embryos are tested for an inherited condition and any unaffected ones are inserted back in the womb, are contentious issues.

Last month's announcement by the government that it was reviewing IVF funding, enabling more couples to have infertility treatment on the NHS, provoked outrage. The claim was that cancer patients would be pushed out of hospital beds to make room for selfish late-middle-aged women determined to defy their biology and have a child. At the same time, parliament debated the chief medical officer's cloning report, and so-called designer babies were headlines again. So convinced was a friend by this misrepresentation that when I told her my forthcoming twins are a boy and a girl, she said: "Oh, so that's what you chose!" - as though PGD was rather like going to Sainsbury's. All I chose is embryos that wouldn't have a catastrophic chromosomal disorder and die.

So I knew that hate mail would come soon. But, when it did, I was surprised by its source. It was not from those who are competing for NHS funds, nor from those who hold religious objections, nor from the anti-designer-baby lobby. It was from another barren woman whose fourth IVF attempt had just failed. It was a very angry letter and she was angry because I had become pregnant. "I thought, at last, someone was going to tell it how it is for 90% of us. But no. You were pregnant. You had inexplicable bleeding, but there you were, still pregnant despite it. I was absolutely furious . . . Won't some journalist write the real story," she wrote.

Of course, she is right. We only hear the stories with happy endings - although I could have had no idea when I started this column that I would be in the fortunate 10%. But why does she aim her anger at me? Why does she not attack those who make us pay through the nose for our procedure, jump through moral hoops to prove we will be perfect parents, and then condemn us as selfish. "I am saddened that you feel I should be the target of your anger," I wrote back, "and not a world that is ignorant of and often indifferent to the agonies of IVF."

As if one had bred the other, a second upsetting letter arrived from another woman. She was pregnant after her sixth attempt at IVF. Her message, however, was very different from the first. "We are filled with unalloyed joy at our good luck," she declared. I, on the other hand, had displayed all the wrong responses, admitting that I was as ambivalent about pregnancy as any other woman, barren or otherwise. Just because I went through a lengthy medical procedure to get there does not mean I haven't often asked myself whether I've made the right choice to have a child. But I should be celebrating my "good fortune". "You are wallowing in self-pity," she wrote. "Stop feeling sorry for yourself."

I replied to this second correspondent, too: "There is no appropriate response for any woman to feel when they become pregnant through any method . . . Your unalloyed joyfulness is wonderful, but most women feel nothing like you. Most are anxious, unsure . . ."

These are just two correspondents among more than 100 supportive messages, so I really should not take it so personally. And with the first woman, who is not pregnant, I have now reached an understanding. She responded: "My point is: where is the writing about the agonies of IVF? Maybe no one wants to read it." Again, she is right. Most letters relate their authors' stories of unsuccessful attempts; I hope soon that there will be more people willing to listen.

I know how this woman feels. I have never thought of myself as angry or bitter. But there was a time, before I was pregnant, when I was going through the heavy swing doors of a shop and turned to hold them open for whoever was behind. It was a pregnant woman. I let the door slam in her face.

The second correspondent and I have reached no such understanding. Her last communication asks: "If you were so ambivalent about pregnancy and fertility treatment, why on earth did you undergo it?" Well, because - despite what is said by those who hold religious beliefs that I don't share, and despite the misinformation that designer babies are picked merely for their physical attributes, and despite what you say - I had no choice.

webTitle: Saxby's £1.5m for university is of more than academic interest

fields.headline: Saxby's £1.5m for university is of more than academic interest
fields.trailText: Robin Saxby, chief executive of microchip designer ARM Holdings, will take the stage at Liverpool university today and attempt to persuade the audience of undergraduates that engineering can be a "sexy" career.
fields.body:
Robin Saxby, chief executive of microchip designer ARM Holdings, will take the stage at Liverpool university today and attempt to persuade the audience of undergraduates that engineering can be a "sexy" career.

Given that most people, not just students, believe that engineers are nerds and that life in a laboratory is not half as much fun or as lucrative as one in marketing or law, it will not be an easy job.

But someone has to do it and Mr Saxby is well placed to bang the drum.

In the past nine years he has taken Cambridge-based ARM from a start-up into the FTSE 100, making millionaires of about 150 of his staff in the process.

Graduates are recruited with the promise of stock options and the chance to carry out cutting-edge work in ARM offices around the world. Few leave for other jobs. It is an approach that has helped transform ARM into a multinational corporation and one of the flag bearers of the British technology sector.

Yet Mr Saxby is back in town not just on a corporate marketing trip. He is returning to the university where he studied electrical engineering in the 1960s to cement ARM's developing commercial relationships with Britain's leading universities.

He has pledged £1.5m of his personal fortune to the university. The result: refurbished science labs called the Robin Saxby Laboratories.

Cynics may look for a profit motive but Mr Saxby believes that educational institutions need to develop closer links with businesses if the domestic hi-tech sector is to remain competitive on a world stage.

Like much of his thinking, it is inspired by the experience of America and particularly Silicon Valley. Entrepreneurs such as Microsoft founders Bill Gates and Paul Allen, PC magnate Michael Dell and internet entrepreneur Jim Clark have donated significant sums to universities such as Stanford, Harvard and MIT.

The benefits are clear. Companies that started out at Stanford account for 60% of Silicon Valley's revenues.

Mr Saxby believes that, if business and education can be fused, cash-strapped British universities are more likely to grow and prosper, and a higher quality of worker will filter through to the domestic commercial sector.

ARM has initiated partnerships with several other universities, sponsoring students and funding courses, to move the process along.

Few of the UK's other wealthy entrepreneurs appear to have followed suit, even though legislation has made donations more tax efficient. One explanation is that the culture of philanthropy here is less strong than in the US, with many donations being made anonymously or in memory of a friend or colleague.

Corporate donations and sponsorship of universities raise important ethical questions about the influence of business over education.

Bill Gates has been accused of "buying Cambridge" through a $200m donation that will see dozens of US students taught at the university.

At a time of decreasing university budgets and increasing student costs, further mega-grants seem likely. British businessmen should adopt the US approach before they adopt us.
