webTitle: Asylum seekers are worse off, 2,000 years on

fields.headline: Asylum seekers are worse off, 2,000 years on
fields.standfirst: Joseph and Mary may have been the first asylum seekers, says Jeremy Hardy; at least the Egyptians took a more humanitarian approach than our government
fields.trailText: Joseph and Mary may have been the first asylum seekers, says Jeremy Hardy; at least the Egyptians took a more humanitarian approach than our government
fields.body:
And when they [the Wise Men] were departed, behold the angel of the Lord appeareth to Joseph in a dream, saying, "Arise, and take the young child and his mother, and flee to Egypt, and be thou there until I bring thee word: for Herod will seek the young child to destroy him." (Matthew 2:13).

I have no figures about Egyptian asylum policy at the dawning of the first millennium, but nowhere can I find evidence of Joseph being held in detention. Nobody appears to have interrogated him, with or without an interpreter, about the family's reasons for flight. No one questioned him as to whether they had a well-founded fear of persecution or whether the carpentry trade was just slack in Judaea. No one wrote in the Cairo Advertiser that the slaughter of the innocents had been greatly exaggerated or that it was a civil war in which the babies were as much to blame as the Romans.

It seems that the Egyptians of 2,000 years ago had a more humane approach to refugees than does New Labour. What Jack Straw thinks of Herod's crackdown on potential young offenders is harder to assess. One might hope that, as a Christian of Jewish descent, Straw would be wary. But Herod was reacting to the possible emergence of a national liberation leader, so it seems likely that Straw would view the targeting of all boys under two as an imaginative piece of anti- terrorist legislation.

One thing we do know about the birth of Jesus was that he was given extremely boring presents by the so-called wise men. Joseph's tax affairs (his whole reason for schlepping his emergent family to Bethlehem) must have been thrown into disarray by the sudden acquisition of gold that would be very hard to account for. But Mary must have been a bit new age to favour a straw birth, so probably believed in aromatherapy and enjoyed the frankincense. Whether myrrh guards against nappy rash I don't know. The shepherds appear only in Luke and don't appear to have brought anything, but they were sore afraid by the angel of the Lord and probably a bit freaked out by the whole thing.

Two millennia on, we know that children need to be stimulated, to play. I say, "we" but apparently there are some who doubt this. The national asylum support service, a shadowy Home Office agency charged with making refugees' lives as miserable as possible, defines toys as "non-essential items". It is commendable, therefore, that the TUC is collecting and distributing toys to refugee children this Christmas. It is regrettable that union leaders were persuaded not to humiliate the government over the voucher scheme at the Labour party conference.

Many of us will be sending vouchers to nieces, nephews and godchildren at the moment, expressly because we want them to be able to buy a toy. It might be unimaginative in our time-poor culture merely to weigh up whether Smiths or Woolworths is the more festive place to spend a gift token, but at least we are hoping that the kids end up with something fun. Barbara Roche appears to consider toys to be frivolous trifles. Perhaps she distributes small boxes of fish fingers to the younger members of her family.

Roche is currently engaged in a "review", not of the principle of forcing refugees to live on vouchers with a value substantially lower than the level of income support, but of the way the scheme operates. This is less than was hoped for when the union revolt was headed off, and perhaps means that, after the deadline for submissions on the 22nd, an announcement will be slipped out over Christmas to the effect that supermarkets will no longer be able to pocket the change. The supermarkets are being canvassed for their views and I'm sure are heartily in favour of pocketing the change, but will still be glad of the captive market the vouchers assure them. Perhaps the review is actually a look at extending the scheme to other benefit claimants.

Meanwhile in this season of goodwill, the government is busily jailing as many refugees as it can. It has quietly ordered 500 new prison places to be set aside for them in the run-up to Christmas. There are now 75 places in HMP Belmarsh, with its 23-hour lock-up regime, and 60 in the notorious Wandsworth.

And 38% of asylum decisions are now refusals for "non-compliance" - meaning that refugees failed to fill in the 20-page standard evidence form on time, complete in every detail and in English. This figure has increased fourfold since January, and means people can be banged-up pending deportation without their cases even being considered.

No toys, then, but perhaps a visit to Daddy in jail will be a Christmas treat for the children of those who flee to Britain.

webTitle: PeopleNews.com loses deputy editor to Independent on Sunday

fields.headline: PeopleNews.com loses deputy editor
fields.trailText:
2.30pm: PeopleNews.com has lost its deputy editor to the Independent on Sunday. By Amy Vickers.

Nov 20: PeopleNews.com axes staff
fields.body:
PeopleNews.com, the showbiz website set up by former Tatler editor Jane Procter and Andrew Neil, has lost its deputy editor to the Independent on Sunday.

Sasha Slater, who has been poached by the newspaper to edit Reality magazine, stressed that there was nothing suspicious about her departure from PeopleNews.

She said: "I am totally grateful to Jane [Procter] and Catherine [Ostler] and have had an amazing year on PeopleNews.

"I would certainly work with both of them again like a shot. I was poached by another title and there is nothing negative about my departure."

Ms Slater will replace Hero Brown, who was promoted from deputy editor to editor in July this year. Ms Brown could not be reached for comment and her next move is unclear.

Reality recently underwent a revamp to give it a more 'mature voice' and add gravitas.

Ms Slater has worked alongside Catherine Ostler, now PeopleNews editor, for three years on three different publications: the Express's Saturday magazine, Times Weekend and PeopleNews.

Her departure leaves a gap at three-month-old PeopleNews, which laid off staff at the end of November.

It is uncertain at this stage as to whether she is to be replaced.

webTitle: Analysis: what the supreme court said

fields.headline: A court divided: what the supreme court said
fields.standfirst:
Today's ruling makes no preference for Bush or Gore, and in theory Gore could make one last push for Florida, writes Derek Brown

Special report: America decides
fields.trailText: Today's ruling makes no preference for Bush or Gore, and in theory Gore could make one last push for Florida, writes Derek Brown.
fields.body:
It is widely believed that the US supreme court has decided that George W Bush should be the next president. A closer look at the densely packed ruling - six opinions expressed in 65 pages - reveals that the court decided nothing of the sort.

The ruling expresses no preference for Mr Bush, or for Vice-President Al Gore. It merely makes it virtually impossible for Mr Gore to win. There is a theoretical possibility that the Democrats will send in their legal cavalry for one last charge.

For the supreme court has, in effect, tossed the final decision on a vote recount back to the supreme court of Florida in Tallahassee. That court ordered a statewide manual recount of all so-called undervotes - ballot papers on which mechanical counting devices could not detect a presidential choice.

The state court ruling was Al Gore's last hope of overtaking Mr Bush's slender lead in Florida and snatching from him the state's 25 electoral college votes. But when Mr Bush appealed to the supreme court in Washington, the justices there ordered the recount to be halted. Last night's 5-4 ruling confirms the court's judgment that the recount breached the constitutional requirement for all votes to be treated equally.

However, the supreme court has dangled a tantalising last hope before the Gore lawyers: if the Florida court can come up with a standard procedure for the recount then it may in theory resume the process.

But the phrase "in theory" is crucial. The supreme court issued its convoluted ruling at 10pm last night, local time - only two hours before the deadline for Florida to name its 25 electoral college voters.

Hours before the ruling, the Florida House of Representatives, dominated by Republicans, endorsed an electoral college slate which is bound to vote for Mr Bush in the college poll on December 18. The Democrats could, in desperation, dispute the validity of the deadline and try to field an alternative slate of electoral college voters, based on a recount, but that would risk a full-scale constitutional crisis.

For many Americans, the legal drama has thrown up uncomfortable questions about the bedrock of their constitution, based on the clear separation of powers of the three pillars of government: executive, legislative, and judicial.

Also at issue is the fundamental relationship between federal and state government. As a broad principle, the US supreme court defers to the state courts where issues of state law are involved. In its latest ruling, however, the Washington jurists have overruled their Tallahassee counterparts, raising intriguing and perhaps disturbing questions about the essence of US governance.

Never before has the supreme court intervened in the electoral system to decide who shall have the highest office in the land. Usually, of course, it is the president who chooses the nine justices, not the other way round. Of the current justices, seven were nominated by Republican presidents, and only two by President Clinton. That raises the queasy doubt that the system has moved from patronage to blatant partisanship.

One of the four dissenting judges, Justice John Paul Stevens, has included in his written opinion a lament for the system itself. The court's action, he wrote, "can only lend credence to the most cynical appraisal of the work of judges throughout the land."

He went on: "It is confidence in the men and women who administer the judicial system that is the true backbone of the rule of law. Time will one day heal the wound to that confidence that will be inflicted by today's decision.

"One thing, however, is certain: although we may never know with complete certainty the identity of the winner of this year's presidential election, the identity of the loser is perfectly clear. It is the nation's confidence in the judge as an impartial guardian of the rule of law."

webTitle: BBC correspondents speak out over BBC reshuffle

fields.headline: BBC correspondents lash out at social affairs reshuffle
fields.trailText: BBC correspondents are fuming at news chiefs' handling of the reorganisation of the social affairs unit. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
BBC correspondents are fuming at news chiefs' handling of the reorganisation of the social affairs unit.

The reorganisation, focused mainly on BBC newsgathering's health and science "cluster", has relegated some long-term correspondents to radio-only or News 24-only patches.

Home affairs correspondent Jon Silverman; technology correspondent Christine McGourty; technology and science correspondent Pallab Ghosh and education and family correspondent Kim Catcheside have been relegated to radio-only. Mr Ghosh will work for Newsnight as well as radio.

Sue Nelson, who was tipped for the chief science correspondent's job, is going to work part time on Breakfast News and the One O'Clock News.

But Fergus Walsh, the BBC's former health and science correspondent, who is having most of the health part of his brief given to Karen Allen, claims that there are some clear winners in the reshuffle. "I'm delighted," he said. "Science is a difficult subject to do well."

Mr Walsh pointed out that some BBC correspondents had done "really well" in the reshuffle.

Some younger correspondents, including James Westhead and Karen Allen, will now have prominent reporting jobs on television bulletins, which has prompted the "beauty contest" claims.

But a BBC News insider rejected the claims. He said there was a feeling of general unhappiness among reporters about the way the changes had been handled.

"It was never about aesthetics. It's more to do with the perception that certain people don't know how to do a TV package," he said.

Other sources have pointed to the fact that the reshuffle signals an end to the BBC's much-trumpeted principle that journalists should work across both television and radio.

One said: "It's the final death-knell for bi-media."

fields.standfirst: George W Bush is to be the next man in the White House. Here's our guide to the best sites on the man they call Dubya
fields.trailText:
NetNotes: George W Bush is to be the next man in the White House. Here's our guide to the best sites on the man they call Dubya.
More NetNotes
fields.body:
1. On December 12 the US supreme court all but handed the US election to one George W Bush.

2. Dubya was born to George and Barbara on July 6, 1946, in New Haven Connecticut, under the sign of Cancer. He moved to Texas aged two, and grew up being called "Junior" and dreaming of baseball hero Willie Mays.

3. Like his father before him, he became a member of the Skull and Bones, Yale's oldest secret society - and soon developed close ties to the oil industry.

4. Unlike his father, he also developed a reputation for getting well-oiled, on one occasion while behind the wheel of a car. Here's a video of him years later, looking rather the worse for wear.

5. The fascination for baseball didn't wear off either: he liked it so much he bought the team, a success that put him on the presidential path.

6. Little-known fact: Dubya's other favourite sport is bass fishing.

7. Some say Bush is too stupid to be president. Others think he's just got a way with words. What do you think?

8. While he was governor of Texas, more prisoners were executed than in any other state - but the American people didn't want to make a song and dance about it.

9. The media have not been kind about the outlook for the presidency. Here's his inauguration speech and a diary of his first 100 days.

10. Punch him. You know you want to.

webTitle: Ex-director of thestreet.co.uk snapped up by Rivals.net

fields.headline: Ex-director of thestreet.co.uk snapped up by Rivals.net
fields.standfirst: Dec 13: Pratley takes up Sunday Business editorship
fields.trailText:
2.30pm: Rob Avis, a former director of thestreet.co.uk has joined Rivals.net, reports Amy Vickers.
Dec 13: Pratley takes up Sunday Business editorship
fields.body:
A former director of the now-deceased theStreet.co.uk has been snapped up by a Chrysalis Group joint venture.

Rob Avis, former sales director of thestreet.co.uk, which closed last month, has joined Rivals.net, a network of independent sports websites, as its first commercial director.

Mr Avis previously worked for Emap Business Communications between 1991 and 1999, latterly as publisher of Emap Finance.

At Rivals.net, Avis will be responsible for boosting commercial revenues across the network, managing its growing in-house sales, sponsorship and traffic department.

He will work closely with marketing director Chris Reed to build partnerships.

Marcus Leaver, Rivals.net chief executive, said: "Rob has bags of integrity and exceptional client service experience - something that is lacking in this industry.

"His success at theStreet.co.uk and previous experience will help Rivals.net maximise the potential of its network."

webTitle: Nick Brien to leave Leo Burnett

fields.headline: Nick Brien to leave Leo Burnett
fields.trailText: Nick Brien, one of the advertising industry's most important figures is quitting Britain for a top US job. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Nick Brien, chief executive of Leo Burnett and one of British adland's best-known names, is leaving London for a top US job.

Mr Brien has been named as president of Starcom MediaVest, the media division of the global marketing group Bcom3. He joins at the end of April next year and will report directly to Starcom MediaVest chief executive Jack Klues.

Mr Brien joined Leo Burnett as executive media director in 1992, but is most famous in the industry for having founded the media agency BBJ Media Services. He set up the agency in 1989 with co-founders Jerry Buhlman and Colin Jelfs to service the Bass account.

"In an era of exploding consumer choice and profound media fragmentation, the process of connecting the right message to the customer has become very complex and challenging," said Mr Brien. "I'm confident that my general advertising management experience over the last five years together with my traditional media background will serve me well in my new role."

No decision has yet been made about Mr Brien's successor at Leo Burnett, although an appointment is expected next year.

webTitle: Premiere Group acquired by WPP

fields.headline: WPP acquires Premiere Group
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: WPP has acquired the Premiere Group, a sports marketing and sponsorship consultancy. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
WPP has acquired the Premiere Group, a sports marketing and sponsorship consultancy whose clients include Manchester United and Procter & Gamble.

Premiere, which employs 14 people, will come under the branding and identity division of WPP.

It is split into two companies with one, Premiere, handling the sale of commercial rights for sports and arts organisations and the other, Premiere Consulting, providing advice on sponsorship for major companies including Barclays, Guinness and Procter & Gamble.

webTitle: Scots pursue exams case

fields.headline: Scots pursue exams case
fields.trailText: Thirty-six Scottish pupils may bring a test case under the Human Rights Act over the summer exam results fiasco that saw incomplete or inaccurate results issued to thousands of teenagers.
fields.body:
Thirty-six Scottish pupils may bring a test case under the Human Rights Act over the summer exam results fiasco that saw incomplete or inaccurate results issued to thousands of teenagers.

Unhappy with the appeals procedure after the debacle, the students have been taking legal advice. Many had expected good passes but got disappointing results that were not upgraded on appeal. Last week, a report by the Scottish parliament's education committee said the entire exam system had come close to collapse through the serious failures at the Scottish qualification authority.

The students allege their appeals were not properly heard by the exams body, and that the Scottish executive failed to sort it out. Cameron Fyfe, a Glasgow lawyer acting for the pupils, said he was asking for the exam papers to be assessed by an independent body.

webTitle: Clinton 'pushes peace process forward'

fields.headline: Clinton 'pushes peace process forward'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Talks today between the US president, Bill Clinton, and party leaders in Belfast have raised hopes of possible progress.
fields.body:
Talks today between the US president, Bill Clinton, and party leaders in Belfast have raised hopes of possible progress.

The prime minister's official spokesman said: "There is a feeling that there is a possibility of moving forward on some of the issues. I would not put it any stronger than that."

Mr Clinton and Mr Blair met the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, Sinn Fein president Gerry Adams and the SDLP deputy leader Seamus Mallon.

The private talks were held separately in a bid to rescue the Good Friday Agreement because of the deadlock over unionist demands for IRA disarmament, republican calls for quicker demilitarisation and uncertainty over plans for future policing arrangements.

As Mr Clinton prepared to address a crowd of 8,000 at Belfast's new £93m Odyssey centre, Mr Blair's spokesman added: "We have got Clinton here and given his reputation on the issue, give his energy, given his commitment, he could be helpful in turning this around."

Earlier, Mr Blair and Mr Clinton, were accused of snubbing hardline Unionists. Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist party claimed that the two leaders had refused to meet its representatives at parliament buildings, Stormont.

Mr Clinton arrived at Stormont by midmorning after staying at the Hilton hotel in Belfast, where he is understood to have talked to the vice president, Al Gore, by phone regarding the latest ruling on the US elections.

At Stormont the president mingled with local politicians alongside Mr Blair in the lobby and talked to unionist, republican and nationalist representatives before the crucial meetings.

Even though all sides believe there is little chance of a breakthrough over policing and decommissioning, which is threatening the Good Friday agreement, Ian Paisley Jnr of the Democratic Unionists said: "The prime minister and President Clinton both had the opportunity to meet the DUP but they have ignored that opportunity.

"They talk about inclusivity in this process, but they have not shown any willingness to meet the Democratic Unionists and will only be meeting the pro-agreement parties separately. That is their choice and it is their loss."

Before Mr Clinton met Mr Adams, a Sinn Fein spokesman said: "I would not be hopeful of any progress. The British have not honoured their commitments, and it's difficult to see how we can get anywhere today."

The SDLP spokesman Alex Attwood said: "The sense is that this visit creates opportunities, but it is too premature to say that the game is on. What Clinton's visit enables us to do is lift our eyes above the current problems and see future possibilities."

Mr Trimble has already warned that the process could collapse by the middle of next month unless the IRA starts emptying its secret arms dumps.

Republicans today repeated their demand that British military surveillance posts must be cleared from the south Armagh countryside, and that the proposals of Chris Patten's inquiry into policing reform in Northern Ireland has to be implemented in full.

The government's timetable for implementing those changes may be announced by the end of the week, but with Sinn Fein preparing to go to the high court on Friday to challenge Mr Trimble's ban on the party's two ministers, Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun, from attending north-south ministerial meetings, the parties at Stormont predicted little chance of agreement on a formula for the way ahead.

Ahead of Mr Clinton's speech, Mr Trimble told the crowd at the Odyssey arena that real peace in Northern Ireland cannot be achieved until the IRA disarm.

He said there could be no moral vacuum at the heart of the process and that "justification lies in there being a transition from a violent past to a peaceful democratic future. That is why I stand firm on the need for decommissioning."

Meanwhile, Mr Clinton was today given a great degree of credit for Northern Ireland's falling unemployment rate and economic recovery.

The latest unemployment figures were released showing the number out of work had dropped 10,000 over the past year to 45,000 or 6%.

Sir Reg Empey, the Stormont minister for enterprise, trade and investment, said the Northern Ireland economy had grown steadily over the five years since the president's first visit to the province in 1995.

He said: "While this growth cannot be wholly attributed to the US, it is a fact that the involvement of the largest industrial power in the world has had a far-reaching influence on the Northern Ireland economy."

webTitle: December 13 ratings

fields.headline: Just one in four tune into Blair
fields.trailText: TV overnights: Predictions that ITV's Q&A with Tony Blair could pull in 10m viewers proved wide of the mark last night. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Predictions that ITV's Ask the Prime Minister Q&A with Tony Blair could pull in 10m viewers proved wide of the mark last night, with the controversial political special attracting an audience of barely half that number.

Ask the Prime Minister, which provoked a storm of protest from the Tories and Lib Dems, who claimed that ITV was giving Labour preferential treatment, was watched by an average of 5.2m viewers.

The programme pulled in just under one in four viewers over 60 minutes from 7pm, according to unofficial overnights.

But ITV bosses were insisting the programme met internal expectations.

A spokeswoman said: "We knew it would get around 5m. Prince William only got 5.1m on Monday night so we've done pretty well." Holiday 2000 on BBC1 benefited from ITV's flirtation with peak-time political programming, averaging 8.2m from 7pm. Last week the 30-minute dose of escapism took just 6.1m against much stiffer competition from Emmerdale.

EastEnders pulled in 11.6m viewers from 7.30pm.

Last week in the same slot, Emmerdale averaged 10.1m from 7pm, while ITV regional programming had 4.6m from 7.30pm.

Later in the evening, BBC2's Trevor Nelson interview with Scary Spice, Mel B - the Players Club, pulled in 3.2m and a 14% share from 9pm.

From 9.10pm, the concluding episode of a BBC1 Silent Witness two-parter tied in the ratings with ITV's Peak Practice. Both dramas averaged 6.9m and a 29% share.

On Channel 4 from 9pm, a disappointing audience for a Cutting Edge documentary on three internet start-ups proved once again how interest in dot.coms has waned. Easy Money averaged just 1m and a 4% share.

webTitle: Hunt ban 'breach of rights'

fields.headline: Hunt ban 'breach of rights'
fields.standfirst: Countryside group ready to launch legal challenge
fields.trailText: The Countryside Alliance is poised to launch a challenge under the Human Rights Act to the government's bill banning hunting if, as expected, MPs vote for an outright ban.
fields.body:
The Countryside Alliance is poised to launch a challenge under the Human Rights Act to the government's bill banning hunting if, as expected, MPs vote for an outright ban.

A leading human rights barrister, Edward Fitzgerald QC, said there was a "strong case" for arguing that a ban on hunting would breach rights to enjoyment of property and respect for private life guaranteed by the European convention on human rights.

The alliance, the main pro-hunting lobby group, plans to challenge the statement by the home secretary, Jack Straw, that the bill complies with the convention.

Since October, when the Human Rights Act came into force, making the convention part of UK law, new bills must include either a "statement of compatibility" with the convention, or a statement that the government wants parliament to proceed without one.

The Home Office said: "The home secretary made his statement on the basis of the best legal advice available. If the Alliance wants to challenge it, that's a matter for them."

The bill, which will have its second reading in the Commons next Monday, will allow MPs a free vote on three options: a ban on hunting with hounds, a "middle way" under which hunting would be regulated by statute, or a system of self-regulation put forward by the Countryside Alliance.

Labour MPs are expected to vote for a ban. The Commons voted for a ban three years ago when a Labour member put forward a private member's bill which ran out of time.

An alliance spokesman said: "If MPs are unwise enough to try to vote through an outright ban on hunting with dogs it is highly likely that we will be challenging the government's awarding of that certificate to that bill."

An inquiry under the former senior treasury official Lord Burns, set up by the government to look into a possible ban on hunting, warned that any ban could face challenges under the Human Rights Act.

Mr Fitzgerald said: "There is a strong case that a ban on hunting, backed by criminal sanctions, interferes with the right to the peaceful enjoyment of property, protected by article 1 of protocol 1 [of the convention] and the right to respect for private life guaranteed by article 8."

Interference can be justified, but in the case of enjoyment of property the state would have to show that it struck a balance between the interests of the community and the protection of the right to peaceful enjoyment of property.

In the case of the right to private life, the state can only interfere to protect morals, prevent crime or disorder, or prevent offence to religious or other sensibilities. It would also have to show the ban was proportionate and necessary.

Mr Fitzgerald said protecting animals from unnecessary suffering could come under the protection of morals. But the onus would be on the state to show hunting caused more suffering than other means of killing and the court, Mr Fitzgerald said, would expect to see some legitimate scientific findings before criminalising conduct that was otherwise lawful.

Deadline 2000, a coalition of animal rights groups which supports a ban, has obtained an opinion from three human rights lawyers arguing that hunting is a public activity and therefore not covered by the right to respect for private life.

Even if it is covered, they say, the courts will accord a "discretionary area of judgment" to parliament, particularly if the matter has been decided by a free vote.

webTitle: Act will blow away aloof and archaic judges

fields.headline: Act will blow away aloof and archaic judges
fields.standfirst: The Human Rights Act will shake up the judiciary. They should have to explain themselves, says Conor Gearty
fields.trailText: The Human Rights Act will shake up the judiciary. They should have to explain themselves, says Conor Gearty
fields.body:
It is obviously wrong that any judges should be in the Lords at all. What business do those who must later apply the law in particular disputes have in participating in the formulation of the very rules which they are later required dispassionately to apply?

Are there things that the judges can say in the Lords that are so valuable that they must be said as part of the legislative process itself rather than as an attempt to influence it from the outside - which is where every other profession and group in our society finds itself?

I doubt it: the judges are not a weak group of marginalised persons in need of this special treatment. Their participation in the Lords is a Victorian anachronism which surely need not survive the further reform of the chamber.

(This is not to say that they should be given some new "dome"-like structure or some grand new title such as supreme court by way of consolation; the judicial committee of the privy council could be developed into a review court or the appellate committee of the Lords be reconstituted as a final court of appeal.)

Post Human Rights Act the presence not just of the lord chancellor but of all the law lords in the legislative chamber will no doubt be raised sooner rather than later.

For no one could have expected that the legislative branch itself would invite the judiciary to exercise legislative power of a far more general and pervasive nature than has ever hitherto been countenanced. This is the effect of the new Human Rights Act. The act positively mandates the judiciary to transform its function.

One challenge will be to guide the measure away from the kind of constipated legalism with which the adversarial system invariably seeks to both swamp and destroy all novel laws. Here the signs are not good. There have been some decisions in Scotland which have adopted a highly legalistic and very narrow approach to the act.

We also need now to work out the best way of getting the full facts before a court so that when it makes a ruling under the Human Rights Act, it does so explicitly acknowledging its legislative character and with a clear understanding of its widespread implications. This goes further than the occasional amicus brief or the importation, without more, of American ideas drawn from a different constitutional culture.

The higher courts should have appointed to them a "public interest officer" with a small team of officials, to prepare reports on the effects of possible rulings not just on the law but on the wider public and on society as a whole.

Such an officer is absolutely necessitated by parliament's insistence that the effectiveness and continuing operation of legislation not be irreparably damaged by judicial interpretation.

How can judges know about such operational matters? How can the lawyers for the litigants know? How can the court be sure that an amicus brief that has been filed is authoritative? The advantage of a "public interest statement" filed by a court officer would be that it would take such huge issues out of the narrow and artificial confines of the adversarial process, and it would also open up the process to persons other than lawyers.

In the new era the judges are going to have to gird themselves to be treated far more politically than in the past. The main opposition party in Ireland has recently published proposals under which the judges would be overseen by a judicial board and individual judges subjected to penalties where the board thought they had got things wrong.

The UK pressure for appointment only after a process of selection involving parliament should not be resisted. There will soon be in the select committee on human rights an ideal forum for such (let us call them) "confirmation hearings".

Now everybody recoils from this because of the US experience. But there are not nearly so many controversial candidacies in the US as is widely believed, and the main ones we know about - those involving Robert Bork and Clarence Thomas - were rightly controversial in my view. US federal judges have, in the main, drawn a degree of comfort from their confirmation hearings, feeling that it has given them at least a degree of democratic legitimacy in relation to their subsequent judicial work.

I also think senior UK judges will have to be prepared to meet parliament to explain in general terms what is happening in the courts under the Human Rights Act and to defend - not specific decisions but general policy developments.

The committee might quite legitimately want to investigate, for example, what has happened to parliament's criminal statutes under the Human Rights Act. Or it might want to assess the cost of particular decisions, or the rationale behind some particularly controversial declaration of incompatibility.

All this will be very new for the judges. But far from being antagonistic about such developments, they should welcome them.

 Extracted from a lecture on Monday by Conor Gearty, professor of human rights law at King's College London

webTitle: Pratley to edit Business

fields.headline: Pratley to edit Business
fields.trailText:
1.15pm: Nils Pratley, editor of thestreet.co.uk which closed last month, has been appointed as the new editor of Sunday Business. By Jessica Hodgson.
Dec 13: Ex-director of theStreet.co.uk snapped up by Rivals.net
fields.body:
Nils Pratley, former editor of thestreet.co.uk, has been appointed as the new editor of Sunday Business.

He replaces Jeff Randall, who is to join the BBC as its new business editor.

Mr Pratley, who replaced Martin Baker at the online financial news site, which closed last month, is a former journalist at Sunday Business and the Daily Telegraph.

The appointment will be the first time a former online journalist has been appointed to head a national newspaper.

More to follow...

webTitle: The day America's judges became politicians

fields.headline: The day America's judges became politicians
fields.standfirst:
The US supreme court have undermined American democracy, writes Jonathan Freedland, the Guardian's policy editor.
Special report: US election
fields.trailText: The US supreme court have undermined American democracy, writes Guardian policy editor Jonathan Freedland.
fields.body:
The blood of anger is rising. Democrats in America, those with both a large and small 'd', are boiling with rage at a verdict from the US supreme court which they believe has stolen the presidency from them - and undermined American democracy in the process.

The implications of the supreme court's verdict are enormous. First, they have all but handed victory to George W Bush by blocking a full count of all Florida's votes. Those ballots will not now be tallied, but remain under lock and key in a Tallahasee courthouse.

Second, they have guaranteed that Bush will never be seen as a legitimate president. If they had allowed a full count under a common standard, then both sides could have lived with the outcome - no matter who won. But the court has ensured that Democrats will always believe Bush's victory was tainted. "He wasn't elected," one senior Clinton administration official told me this morning. "The word "elect" should never be associated with George Bush."

Third, the Supreme Court has unleashed what could be a legal, and ultimately racial, war in America. Central to the judges' ruling was their fear that any Florida recount lacking a common standard would violate the constitution's promise of "equal protection" for every US citizen. If different counting procedures operated in different areas, then some voters would count while others would not, which would be "unequal" and unfair.

But that same logic could now be used by voters anywhere in America, complaining that different counting standards applied within their states - and indeed have always applied between different states. Citizens in poor or mainly-black areas could complain that their votes are counted using aged, creaky machines while voters in richer districts use state-of-the-art technology - and that therefore their constitutional right to "equal protection" has been violated.

The supreme court, using last night's ruling as a precedent, would have to agree. By declaring that a lack of uniformity in vote-counting amounts to unequal protection, the high court may have done nothing less than invalidate the entire US electoral system.

The more immediate victim however, besides Al Gore and the system, is the supreme court itself. As the liberal lion of the bench, John Paul Stevens, put it in his strident, dissenting opinion: "Although we may never know with complete certainty the identity of the winner of this year's presidential election, the identity of the loser is perfectly clear. It is the nation's confidence in the judge as an impartial guardian of the law."

He's right. Americans will now regard the judges as politicians just like everyone else - with five Republican appointees who were prepared to stage what that Clinton official calls "a raw seizure of power" just to install their man in the White House. It is a sorry day for America.

webTitle: What the US papers say

fields.headline: What the US papers say
fields.standfirst:
The big guns of the US press are blazing this morning
Special report: US election
fields.trailText: Veteran New York Times commentator Bob Apple is scathing about the Supreme Court judgement which, he says, provides no clear validation of the electoral process: "If, as seems sure, Gov. George W Bush has won, he has won a narrow victory - narrow in Florida, narrow in the Electoral College and narrow in the Supreme Court. He will have only a shaky platform from which to begin his presidency in January, and it will require immense skill to remove the questions about his legitimacy that were left hanging by tonight's decision."
fields.body:
Veteran New York Times commentator Bob Apple is scathing about the Supreme Court judgement which, he says, provides no clear validation of the electoral process: "If, as seems sure, Gov. George W Bush has won, he has won a narrow victory - narrow in Florida, narrow in the Electoral College and narrow in the Supreme Court. He will have only a shaky platform from which to begin his presidency in January, and it will require immense skill to remove the questions about his legitimacy that were left hanging by tonight's decision."

The paper's leader writer notes the huge burden of responsibility now resting on both candidates: "Mr Bush needs to be gracious and unifying in victory, and Vice President Gore must master the difficult task of placing the national need for continuity ahead of any bitterness he may feel."

The tabloid New York Post has no doubts or quibbles about the court decision. It occupies almost its entire front page with the headline "Dubya's Big W", while the gloating leader column is headed "Time's up Mr Gore".

David Broder, writing in the Washington Post, believes that the Supreme Court may have handed the keys of the White House to the Republicans, but it has also given the Democrats an issue they can trumpet for months and years ahead.

He goes to the heart of the issue thus: "Republicans have won full control of the federal government - the White House, the Senate and the House of Representatives - for the first time in the almost half-century since Dwight D Eisenhower was elected in 1952. But, on the other hand, the Democrats have an exceptionally strong base from which to launch a comeback drive in 2002 and 2004. And now they have an issue that can motivate their constituents to action - the claim that Bush won the White House by questionable means."

The Boston Globe urges its readers to resist the temptation to put the election behind them and move on: "Better to move on, some will surely say, for the sake of national unity. This would be a mistake. Anything that appears to be dirty laundry should be aired. This is a step away from dark conspiracy theories and toward justice and a better voting system... The country will need to unite and heal. The best way to do this - no matter who becomes president - is to deliberately expose dysfunctional voting systems and fix them."

The Dallas Morning News, which has strongly backed Bush's campaign in his home state of Texas, is surprisingly subdued in its reaction to the Supreme Court ruling. Still, it looks ahead with optimism: "Some questioned last night whether George W Bush would have legitimacy with such a narrow victory, but history shows that presidents such as John F Kennedy, who arrived in office with a razor-slim margin amidst allegations of vote fraud, can move quickly to establish a popular standing. In the often mentioned 1800 election, where emotions were so high a civil war was feared, Thomas Jefferson gave a stirring inaugural address that helped bring the country back together. As he said then, our nation may have differences of opinion, but no differences of principle. This country will recover from even this botch of an election and a hard-to-digest judicial ruling."

At the epicentre of the legal circus, in the Florida state capital, the Tallahassee Democrat reports raucous partisan rallies in the state capital. The account includes the funniest line of the day: a Democrat demonstrator with a placard reading: "George Bush: Daddy, has Jeb electorated me yet?"

webTitle: World Gold Council plans to rebrand gold

fields.headline: World Gold Council plans to rebrand gold
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: The World Gold Council is planning a huge ad campaign to give gold a more sophisticated image, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The World Gold Council is planning an ambitious advertising campaign to rebrand gold in an attempt to give it a more sophisticated image.

The council, which is funded by the world's biggest gold producers, is concerned that traditional yellow gold has lost its prestige and is no longer seen as the sophisticated choice.

As gold has become more affordable through high street jewellers, it has lost its rarity value and anecdotal evidence suggests westerners are increasingly favouring platinum or white gold over the more commonplace yellow gold.

The move comes as gold is enjoying a major fashion revival, with style bible Vogue devoting its entire December edition to all things gold.

But sources say the World Gold Council is trying to create a more sustainable positive image for the metal.

Several international ad agencies have been approached to pitch for the account.

The council will focus on Europe and north America where the potential for growth is greatest. Gold is still enormously popular in Asia, but the Asian market is considered to be saturated.

The World Gold Council was today playing down the importance of the campaign, but sources said it could be worth up to $50m.

Haruko Fukuda, chief executive of the council, said: "We are doing a selection process at the moment, but we talk to ad agencies all the time.

webTitle: China jails US-based sect member

fields.headline: China jails US-based sect member
fields.trailText: Beijing has sentenced a Chinese citizen who is a US resident to three years in prison for "spying" on behalf of the banned Falun Gong sect. The move came as more tough measures were being taken against religious dissent elsewhere in China.
fields.body:
Beijing has sentenced a Chinese citizen who is a US resident to three years in prison for "spying" on behalf of the banned Falun Gong sect. The move came as more tough measures were being taken against religious dissent elsewhere in China.

Teng Chunyan, a sect member who works as an acupuncturist in New York, had entered China under a pseudonym and tipped off foreign reporters about protests by Falun Gong members.

Ms Teng is said to have smuggled a digital camera into a centre outside Beijing where members of the sect were being detained.

She was accused of collaborating with 50 practitioners from a rural district in Beijing who had allegedly been locked in a mental hospital to prevent them from demonstrating in Tiananmen Square.

A spokesman for the US state department, Richard Boucher, last week called Ms Teng's case "deeply disturbing", but her sentence is regarded as relatively light.

Mr Boucher urged China to uphold the internationally recognised right of citizens to take part in "peaceful spiritual pursuits."

The Falun Gong is an embarrassment to Washington partly because the sect's leader, Li Hongzhi, has lived in the US for some years. This has given ammunition to Chinese hardliners who accuse the US of fomenting subversion against the Chinese Communist Party.

President Clinton said last December that the detention in China of Falun Gong members was a "troubling example" of Beijing's response to those who "test the limits of freedom."

China has accused Mr Li of trying to organise a political conspiracy against the state. His doctrines are said to have led some adherents to become mentally ill and even to commit murder. President Jiang Zemin became enraged in April 1999 when the sect organised a mass silent demonstration outside his place of work in Beijing, protesting at alleged maltreatment.

China's concern over the sect has heightened repression against other sects which are not officially approved. Authorities in the eastern province of Zhejiang were reported to have shut down or blown up more than 400 "unregistered" churches, temples and other "illegal places" in Wenzhou City.

webTitle: Channel 5 picks Stayt as main news anchor

fields.headline: Channel 5 picks Stayt as main news anchor
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Charlie Stayt is to replace Andrea Catherwood as the main anchor for Channel 5's flagship news bulletin, 5 News. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Charlie Stayt is to replace Andrea Catherwood as the main anchor for flagship Channel 5 news bulletin 5 News.

Mr Stayt, who was part of the 5 News launch team in 1997, will take over as the 5 News presenter from the new year.

Ms Catherwood is returning to ITV to work as a special reporter.

Mr Stayt has been a regular front man for Channel 5's weekend evening bulletin 5 News and Sport and also presented Channel 5 current affairs show It Happened to Me and reality game show Jailbreak.

5 News editor Gary Rogers said: "Charlie is one of the most recognisable faces of 5 News. Viewers find him authoritative, reassuring and approachable."

Mr Stayt joined 5 News producer ITN in 1995, after 10 years working in commercial radio news.

webTitle: Knowledge Unlimited

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk. We'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: WORST TEAM EVER
fields.body:
WORST TEAM EVER

Real Oviedo from Spain's Primera Division seem to have settled in well at their new stadium this season with six wins from seven starts. But they have gained just one point and remain goalless away from home. I guess it's unlikely that they will go all the way to June like this, but has any team ever finished a season without scoring away from home? asks John Murphy.

We doubt it. Belgian provincial team SSA Antwerpen had probably the worst season in history back in 1995-96. Their record was:

Played 30, won 0, drew 0, lost 30, goals for 12, goals against 271, points 0.

But even these jokers managed to score four goals away from home. So unless someone knows otherwise, we're fairly sure the answer is no.

TRAGEDY ON THE PITCH

I was asked the other day by a person I wouldn't mind impressing if there have been any records of footballers dying during a game or after it from injuries. Can you help? asks Vidar Hrafn Steingrimsson.

The most famous death in world football occurred in September 1931, during a game at Parkhead between Celtic and yes, you guessed it.

Five minutes into the second half of the Old Firm match, the ball was sent swinging into the Celtic box. A 50-50 race between Celtic keeper John Thomson and Rangers forward Sam English ended in a sickening clash, and Thomson, whose skull had been fractured, lay still.

The brave keeper was carried off and whisked away to the Victoria Hospital, Glasgow, but he died from his injuries that evening. Over 30,000 mourners attended Thomson's funeral in his home village of Cardenden, Fife the following Monday.

As for English? The mild-mannered Irish international was predictably taunted by crowds wherever he played. He eventually fled to England, hoping to shake off his dark past, but an £8,000 move to Liverpool proved as unhappy as his time in Glasgow, despite scoring 27 goals in 50 games.

By the way, Vidar, who are you exactly trying to impress with this? Your boss? Your mother? Not a romantic interest, surely?

DID MY MATE'S GRANDFATHER PLAY FOR WALES?

An old schoolmate of mine used to claim that his grandfather, Smart Arridge, played for Everton and was capped by Wales at the turn of the last century. Given my friend's astonishing lack of athleticism I find this a little difficult to believe. Can you help? asks Mick Stead.

Yes we can, Mick. Your mate's grandfather did play for Wales - between 1892 and 1899 he notched up eight full caps. What's more he was a clever lad too - hence the nickname.

Arridge first started playing football at Friars Grammar School in Bangor, and went on to join Bangor FC, where he was a member of the team that won the inaugural North Wales Coast Senior Cup Final in 1895. Arridge later moved to Merseyside and went on to play for Bootle, Everton, New Brighton and Stockport.

FASTEST HAT-TRICK EVER

Who holds the record for the fastest-ever hat-trick? asked Mark McKenna last week.

"Robbie Fowler must be a contender for the fastest hat-trick ever," reckons Will Sturgeon. "In the 1994-95 season, Robbie took just 4 minutes and 32 seconds to rattle off three goals against Arsenal. If this isn't the overall winner then it must at least claim the title of fastest Premier League or domestic hat-trick."

It is the fastest Premiership hat-trick, but as Matthew Sturgeon points out, Robbie's efforts have been bettered by Nigel Clough, who scored a hat-trick in exactly four minutes during Nottingham Forest's 4-0 win against QPR in the 1987-88 season. "I am not a fan of either club, but being an impressionable 12-year-old at the time, events like that stick in the old mind and you try and emulate them in the playground," he says, not unreasonably.

STONEWALL - WHERE DID IT COME FROM?

What is the first recorded use of the word "stonewall" to mean "absolutely certain", as in "it was a stonewall penalty"? The Chambers Dictionary lists "stonewall" as a verb, not an adjective. asked Seamus McCann last week.

"I believe that stonewalling was originally an Australian term used by politicians for delaying tactics," says Ray Routledge. "There was also an American Civil War general, Thomas Jackson, who was nicknamed Stonewall because during the Battle of Bull Run in 1861 he stood firm, 'like a stone wall'. In a sporting context I think it was first applied in cricket when a batsman would play constant defensive shots, blocking every delivery so as to minimise the risk of getting out."

But Mark Power claims: "Chambers is right: "stonewall" is a verb, as in "to block obdurately, or Defensively". I suspect what Seamus or Ron have seen is a stone-cold penalty, as in "dead obvious", or "a no-brainer".

LOCAL HEROES

Which team has the most support within their own town or city? asked Richard Yorke last week.

Last week we quoted data from the Sir Norman Chester Centre for Football Research at the University of Leicester, which showed that Newcastle enjoy the largest local support of any British club, while Southampton had the lowest in the Premiership. Not all of you were impressed, however.

Mr Fraser reckons: "These statistics are fairly irrelevant unless the population of that area (and other factors such as if the ground has moved recently, whether the area is urban, suburban, industrial, etc.) are taken into consideration. Surely a slightly better statistic would have been the number of members within a 20-mile radius as a percentage of the population of that area?"

Meanwhile, Chris Sato says: "You were surprised that Southampton had the lowest ratio of local season-ticket holders compared to other clubs. However, since the definition of "local" is within 20 miles of the ground this is actually hardly surprising. For people living all along the south coast and even as far north as Bristol, Southampton are the nearest Premiership side. With a potential fan base covering such a wide area it is only logical that many season ticket holders should come from Taunton, Bognor or the New Forest."

CAN YOU HELP?

"I have no statistical information to support my hunch but I believe that more top class goalkeepers are left-footed and left-handed than the 10% you would expect from the general population. Can anyone help me here?" asks Jan Hellriegel

"Have ever been any European players of note who have moved to any of the South American leagues and made it big?" asks Vikram Karekatte

"What is the highest shirt number that has been used in the Premiership or Nationwide League? I have seen in the Italian League that somebody wears the number 99 shirt, but has the trend for crazy numbers spread over here yet? Or do those doddering gentleman at the FA insist that we don't go higher than 50?" asks Matthew Gerrard

Anyone who knows can mail their answer to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can use the same address to send your questions: we'll do our best to answer them.

webTitle: Casting news: Kirsten Dunst beats American Beauty to Spider-Man

fields.headline: Kirsten Dunst beats American Beauty to Spider-Man
fields.trailText: Plus: Scream star David Arquette gets ready for some spider squashing in new comedy thriller
fields.body:
 Kirsten Dunst (pictured) is reported to have signed on as one of the last big pieces in the Spider-Man puzzle. According to the Coming Attractions website, the star of The Virgin Suicides and Drop Dead Gorgeous will play the feisty Mary Jane Watson, love interest to our web-spinning superhero. The role had previously been linked to Mena Suvari, from American Beauty, and Alicia Witt, who appeared in TV's Cybill. Dunst joins Tobey Maguire (who plays Spiderman) and Willem Dafoe (the Green Goblin) in Sam Raimi's film.

 David Arquette is in final negotiations to take the lead role in Warner Bros' comedy-thriller Arach Attack, to be directed by Ellory Elkayem. Best known as the gawky cop of the Scream series (and off-screen husband of Friends star Courtney Cox), Arquette will play an everyman hero battling to stave off an invasion of giant mutant spiders.

webTitle: £1.5m boost for families' disability support

fields.headline: £1.5m boost for families' disability support
fields.trailText: Parents of disabled children will today be given a boost by an announcement that the government is to provide £1.5m for a national information centre and helpline.
fields.body:
Parents of disabled children will today be given a boost by an announcement that the government is to provide £1.5m for a national information centre and helpline.

The service will be run by Contact A Family (CaF), the only charity which provides support and advice to parents whatever the medical condition of their child.

Families who are given devastating news of a child's disability often complain of feeling isolated at a time when they are most vulnerable. Every day, more than 60 children in the UK are born or diagnosed with a serious disability, and the vast majority are cared for at home. Parents may be told their child has Down's syndrome, is autistic, or suffers from one of the 1,000 rare syndromes and disorders.

Yet it is rare that families are given the support they need. The feelings of isolation, both emotional and physical, can often be acute. Helen and Gary Cumberland were devastated on learning from a geneticist that their two-year-old daughter, Alex, was suffering from Coffin Siris syndrome - a genetic disorder so rare that there are only 79 known cases worldwide.

The family was in desperate need of support. Sufferers of the syndrome are distinguished by small stature, mental retardation, pronounced facial features and feeding difficulties. They also have a short life expectancy. But the only information the Cumberlands were given was the address of a website giving details of the condition, and an appointment to see the geneticist again - in two years' time.

Cases like this have prompted ministers to provide extra funding for services. For the first time, there will be a new national telephone advice and helpline, which will include an 0800 number for disabled children, their parents and carers.

The national information centre will also be able to provide information on all medical conditions affecting children, as well as putting families in touch with support groups or other families who have experienced a particular disabling condition. It is hoped that the funding, to be phased in over the next three years, will enable the charity to provide support to 21,000 families of newly-diagnosed disabled children annually.

Francine Bates, chief executive of CaF, believes the cash will make a huge difference to thousands of families. "All too often, parents are left to stumble on information about their child's condition without knowing what support groups are around or what benefits they are entitled to," she said.

"We have a fantastic database with all the information about the medical conditions and support groups that exist. But, up until now, our resources have been very limited.

"We know that parents feel very isolated and vulnerable. Many want to talk to someone, as well as get information about their child's condition. They can find it very useful talking to other families who are in a similar situation. Now we should be able to provide that kind of service to everyone."

For the Cumberlands, the pressures of coping alone with Alex, while looking after their two other children and a seriously ill relative, put their marriage under an enormous strain.

"It was only when our marriage started cracking up that we received help. I rang a social worker and she put us in touch with Contact A Family," said Mrs Cumberland.

That was in June last year. Over the next few months, the Cumberlands, who live in Blackburn, Lancashire, made contact with four other families with children suffering Coffin Siris syndrome. "Being able to talk to families in the same situation as yourself really does help," said Mrs Cumberland. "You need it otherwise you really would go to pieces."

Alex is now three-and-a-half. Mrs Cumberland is setting up the Coffin Siris Support Network in the hope that other families will not have to go through her and Gary's experience. Ms Bates said: "Having a dedicated freephone helpline should make a terrific difference. But our work has only just begun".

 Contact A Family is on 020-7383 3555; the Coffin Siris Support Network is on 01254-727101

webTitle: IOC warns: diet supplements can cause positive drug tests

fields.headline: IOC warns: diet supplements can cause positive drug tests
fields.trailText: The International Olympic Committee has warned athletes to steer clear of food supplements, which have been blamed for a spate of positive drug tests indicating the banned steroid nandrolone.
fields.body:
The International Olympic Committee has warned athletes to steer clear of food supplements, which have been blamed for a spate of positive drug tests indicating the banned steroid nandrolone.

The supplements were described as "wholly unnecessary" by Johan Olav Koss, head of the IOC's athletes commission. "They don't help. They certainly give the opportunity for a positive sample. Why should they use this, so-called healthy athletes?"

The IOC's hardline approach has already been seen in the cases of Linford Christie, Dougie Walker and Mark Richardson, the British athletes who have blamed their nandrolone positives on supplements they took.

Koss, a former Norwegian Olympic speed skater, said that those using supplements did so at their own risk. "We would like to caution the athletes of the world that recent findings show that such supplements may contain drugs that will cause the athlete to test positive."

In Germany this month a junior javelin thrower and third division footballer escaped bans after it was discovered that the US-manufactured creatine supplement they had been taking was spiked with nandrolone. But the IOC's stance confirms that it will maintain its policy of strict liability, which means that athletes are wholly responsible for what they ingest.

To underline this, the IOC revealed yesterday that Switzerland's supreme court had rejected an appeal by the Romanian gymnast Andreea Raducan to reclaim her Olympic gold medal.

Raducan was stripped of her all-round title in the Sydney Olympics after testing positive for the stimulant ephedrine, contained in a cold remedy. "The court decided that there were no grounds for the Raducan case and rejected it," said François Carrard, the IOC's general secretary.

The IOC has also taken action against 11 of its 25 accredited laboratories in an effort to restore confidence in them after complaints from competitors that the correct procedures had not been followed.

In what was described by the IOC as showing "the yellow card", labs in Bangkok, Ghent, Lausanne, Lisbon, Madrid, Montreal, Moscow, Paris, Penang, Prague and Rome were warned that they might be downgraded and stripped of their IOC accreditation if they did not improve.

· The Italian cyclist Marco Pantani has protested his innocence after being sentenced on Monday to a three-month suspended prison sentence for "sporting fraud", namely manipulating results by the use of drugs. "I'll follow this right through to the end to prove my innocence," he said. "They're making a big mistake."

webTitle: In brief: Carry On team back in cartoon form

fields.headline: Carry On team back in cartoon form
fields.standfirst: Plus: Whoopi charms her way out of speeding ticket; Jack Lemmon in hospital - but picks up a second major award in weeks; TV presenter accuses Arnie of letting his hands do the talking
fields.trailText: Plus: Whoopi charms her way out of speeding ticket; Jack Lemmon in hospital - but picks up a second major award in weeks; TV presenter accuses Arnie of letting his hands do the talking
fields.body:
 A bygone piece of British film folklore looks set for a new lease of life with the news that the Carry On series is to make a return - in cartoon form. Dubbed The Carryoons, the series which repackages characters from the film series which dominated British cinemas between 1959 and 1977, will air on television in 26 half-hour episodes. The show is to be masterminded by original producer Peter Rogers, now 86, and will feature voices from some of the surviving Carry On members. Describing the project, the show's producer Ken Burns said: "I thought it would be great to do something like The Simpsons. The series will be inspired by the original but will have completely new scripts."

 Whoopi Goldberg made a swift detour to the county jail when her driver was pulled over for speeding in Arkansas earlier this week. Fortunately for the perky actress, her stay was a short one. While the arrested speeder filled out forms, Whoopi posed for pictures, signed autographs and offered a pep talk to female inmates before being allowed to walk away scot-free. One can only assume that none of the officials had seen Sister Act 2.

 Just one week after being honoured with the Spencer Tracy award for his lifetime in acting, Jack Lemmon is in hospital suffering from an infection which is thought to be related to an ongoing colon condition called diverticulitis. The 75-year-old star of Some Like it Hot and The Apartment (which is re-released this week) is expected to leave hospital within a day or two. In the meantime he has found the time to scoop yet another award - the long-windedly titled Hollywood Women's Press Club Buddy Rogers Legend Award.

 In London to promote his latest action spectacular The Sixth Day, Hollywood stalwart Arnold Schwarzenegger has been pressing the flesh with what many regard as more than appropriate enthusiasm. The Austrian superstar may be happily married to Kennedy girl Maria Shriver, but that hasn't stopped him enjoying the company of a bevy of lady presenters. The fading star has been pawing the breasts of Big Screen presenter Anna Richardson, getting frisky on the Big Breakfast bed with Denise Van Outen and grappling Melanie Sykes. "The guy's a groper and is totally unprofessional," Anna Richardson told the Sun in a report illustrated by a sultry shot of the presenter sporting a natty leopard-skin bikini top.

webTitle: Liverpool draw Roma in last 16

fields.headline: Liverpool draw Roma in last 16
fields.trailText: Liverpool have landed perhaps the toughest tie in the last sixteen of this season's Uefa Cup. This morning's draw paired them with Fabio Capello's Roma, currently top of Serie A.
fields.body:
Liverpool have landed perhaps the toughest tie in the last sixteen of this season's Uefa Cup. This morning's draw paired them with Fabio Capello's Roma, currently top of Serie A.

The tie, which will replay the European Cup final of 1984, will see Liverpool at home in the first leg - due to be played on February 15. The second leg is a week later in Rome.

It'll be a very, very difficult match," said Antonio Tempestilli, Roma's sporting director. "Liverpool are one of the biggest clubs in Europe. We now will have to have our revenge from the European Cup final in 1984."

Liverpool chief executive Rick Perry was just just as enthusiastic. "They're a very difficult team," he said. "I don't think you could get bigger than this."

Liverpool had found themselves in the unenviable position of facing one of Barcelona, Roma, Porto or Celta Vigo after this year's competition was seeded at the half-way stage. Liverpool's recent European record left them ranked only as second seeds, and if they beat Roma, the Reds know they must face the winner of the tie between Porto and Nantes.

Liverpool will take heart from their last European encounter with the Giallorossi, however. The European Cup final of 1984 was played in Rome, but Phil Neal scored for the Reds in a 1-1 draw before Bruce Grobbelaar and his famously wobbling knees took the English champions to victory in a penalty shootout.

Elsewhere in the draw, AEK Athens were paired with Barcelona, Spanish minnows Alaves with Italian giants Internazionale and Dutch champions PSV Eindhoven with Parma.

Full draw: Porto v Nantes; AEK Athens v Barcelona; Stuttgart v Celta; Liverpool v Roma; Alaves v Internazionale; PSV v Parma; Slavia Prague v Kaiserslautern; Rayo Vallecano v Bordeaux

webTitle: BBC to leave Pebble Mill

fields.headline: BBC to leave Pebble Mill
fields.trailText: 12pm: The BBC has confirmed that it is moving from Pebble Mill after 29 years, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The BBC has confirmed that it is moving from Pebble Mill after 29 years.

The corporation closed two of the studios at its midlands headquarters this summer with the loss of 90 jobs.

The corporation will announce today that production and technical staff at Pebble Mill will move to the Mailbox, its central Birmingham office.

The BBC denied that there would be redundancies, saying the Mailbox had room for all 600 of the staff currently working at Pebble Mill.

But the corporation's regional base has seen a drop in production over the past few years.

Although programmes such as Top Gear, the Archers and a number of daytime and lifestyle TV and radio programmes are still made in Birmingham, the studio has declined since its 1970s heyday when it produced programmes such as Pebble Mill at One.

Andy Griffee, BBC controller of nations and regions, said that the move would make the BBC "more visible and accessible to our audience".

Last month BBC director general Greg Dyke announced that the corporation was pumping nearly £50m into an incentive to boost programme production from the regions, including new plans for a Scottish TV soap.

webTitle: New bill to improve social housing

fields.headline: New bill to improve social housing
fields.trailText: The government today unveiled a housing bill and policy strategy aimed at improving social housing and ensuring quality and choice in the market.
fields.body:
The government today unveiled a housing bill and policy strategy aimed at improving social housing and ensuring quality and choice in the market.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott said: "These are the first fruits of the most comprehensive review of housing for 23 years and we are backing these measures with housing investment which will rise to over £4bn in the next three years."

Key points for the public sector include:

For those in social housing, the documents:

  • Confirm the government's commitment to bringing all social housing up to a decent standard by 2010.
    • Propose to improve the supply of social housing by doubling capital investment.
    • Promote diversity and a wider range of landlords through stock transfer and new investment and ownership options for council housing.
    • Implement a 10-year plan to achieve fairer rents at affordable levels, well below those in the private sector, based on size, relative property values and local earnings.
    • Promote new approaches to letting social housing designed to extend tenant choice.

For those on housing benefit in England, Scotland and Wales the secretary of state for social security has announced measures for:

  • Taking urgent action to help councils reduce benefit delays.
    • Raising administration standards and simplifying housing benefits.

For those at risk of homelessness the government proposes:

  • Requiring councils to put in place strategies to prevent homelessness and measures to ensure more effective help and housing for those likely to lose their homes.
    • Tackling rough sleeping, fuel poverty and anti-social behaviour and ensuring a new supporting people programme is introduced to provide more effective support to the elderly and other vulnerable people.

webTitle: Archer denies perjury charge

fields.headline: Archer denies perjury charge
fields.trailText: Jeffrey Archer pleaded not guilty yesterday to perjury and perverting the course of justice at a hearing at the Old Bailey.
fields.body:
Jeffrey Archer pleaded not guilty yesterday to perjury and perverting the course of justice at a hearing at the Old Bailey.

Ted Francis, a TV producer and former friend of Lord Archer, also appeared before Judge Michael Hyam, the recorder of London, who set a trial date of May 14 next year for the pair to answer charges that they conspired to alter the course of Lord Archer's libel case against the Daily Star in 1987.

Lord Archer, 60, was awarded £500,000 over claims that he had slept with a prostitute, Monica Coghlan.

Last year Mr Francis, 67, who pleaded not guilty to perverting the course of justice, told the News of the World that he had provided a false alibi for Lord Archer during the run up to the libel case.

Mr Francis said that he wrote to Lord Archer's solicitor Victor Mishcon falsely claiming that he had dined with the then deputy chairman of the Conservative party on September 9 1986, the evening which the Daily Star claimed Archer had spent with Ms Coghlan.

Mr Francis's claims led to Lord Archer abandoning his attempt to become the Tory candidate in the London mayoral election. He was subsequently expelled from the Conservative party.

Lord Archer faces two counts of perjury, two of perverting the course of justice and one of using a false instrument. They were bailed to reappear on May 14 on condition that they do not attempt to contact witnesses.

Lord Archer is appearing at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket, in his own play, The Accused.

webTitle: 'Can we claim for workplace injuries?'

fields.headline: 'Can we claim for workplace injuries?'
fields.standfirst: Employees must be informed of health and safety risks and procedures taken to avoid them, writes Tom Jones
fields.trailText: Employees must be informed of health and safety risks and procedures taken to avoid them, writes Tom Jones.
fields.body:
Q. There have been several incidents at my workplace of people injuring themselves while lifting and carrying heavy boxes - I work in the stationery supplies department. There seems to be little or no training given to new members of staff and people are always going off sick with back strains. Should we be doing anything about it?

A. Ensuring that workplaces are safe is not just about employers staying on the right side of the law. The millions of pounds lost in productivity a year to back strains alone mean it is in an employer's interest to prevent them.

A recent TUC report found that small businesses, for example, were losing around 13m days every year and that nearly three-quarters of employees with back problems lift regularly as part of their job.

A local authority is unlikely to relish having to pay sick pay to people off work with bad backs.

But health and safety is not just the responsibility of the employer. Employees should also ensure that rules are being stuck to and must inform their employer and colleagues of any situation which might represent a serious danger to health and safety.

But before you do that, ensure that you are clear about what your employer's duties are. Preventive measures are the key to a safe workplace and the law should be a last resort when accidents have occurred.

There are a number of laws and regulations which place obligations on employers. The management of health and safety at work regulations which are part of six European Union health and safety directives issued in 1992.

The first principle of the regulations is that work should be adapted to the worker and not the worker to the work. Employers must conduct risk assessments to identify what needs to be done to comply with the law.

Risk assessments must be conducted by someone who is trained in workplace health and safety. Employees must be informed of health and safety risks identified and procedures to be taken to avoid them.

In your particular case it is the rules on lifting, known as manual handling, that need to be followed. The personal protective equipment at work (PPE) regulations oblige your employer to put in place effective controls and systems of work.

Consideration must be given to whether it is possible to avoid a task altogether. If this is not possible, then the employer has to devise a safe way of doing the lifting.

Training, for example, can be key to ensuring that the lifting of heavy boxes does not result in back strains. You and your colleagues must be trained in the safe way to lift and carry and there must be adequate supervision to ensure this continues.

Instructions on the safe way to lift should be clearly displayed in the workplace.

If these procedures are not followed and if a backstrain does occur, you may be able to claim compensation for the injury. There are time limits, so any injury must be reported to your trade union health and safety rep and to your employer as soon as possible.

 Tom Jones works for Thompsons Solicitors
