webTitle: Stay-at-home Bush no friend of foreign affairs

fields.headline: Stay-at-home Bush no friend of foreign affairs
fields.standfirst: The expected imminent announcement of a Republican victory in the presidential election could presage drastic changes to foreign policy and relations, says Guardian foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: Analysis: The expected imminent announcement of a Republican victory in the presidential election could presage drastic changes to foreign policy and relations says Guardian foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
If, as looks increasingly likely, George W Bush is finally declared the winner of the US presidential election, his victory will have far-reaching and unpredictable consequences for both close allies such as Britain and old enemies such as Iraq.

Tony Blair, a close political friend of Bill Clinton and the Democratic candidate, Al Gore, has never met Mr Bush. The same goes for the leaders of most western countries and Russia and China.

Mr Bush has shown little interest in getting to know the world beyond Texas, where he is governor, having travelled abroad only three times in his adult life, excluding visits to neighbouring Mexico. He has not even visited Canada.

This means that Mr Bush, if he takes the White House, will inevitably rely on more seasoned advisers in formulating America's future defence and foreign policy. This group includes Dick Cheney, his running mate, who is poised to become vice-president next month.

The hawkish Mr Cheney served as defence secretary at the Pentagon during the presidency of Mr Bush's father, George Bush Sr, from 1989-93. He helped mastermind the Gulf war against Iraq and is seen by some as the father of "Star Wars II", the national missile defence system that Mr Bush advocates and which is fiercely opposed by China, Russia and some Nato allies.

Another Gulf war "veteran", General Colin Powell, who at that time was chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, is widely tipped to become Mr Bush's secretary of state, in charge of America's global diplomacy.

The cautious Gen Powell is opposed, in broad terms, to involving the US military in overseas conflicts. He advised President Bush Snr to call a ceasefire in 1991, rather than order US forces in southern Iraq to advance on Baghdad and overthrow Saddam Hussein. Some analysts see this as a crucial mistake that has led to a decade of continuing problems.

Gen Powell, like other advisers around Mr Bush, is against placing US forces under UN command and is generally sceptical about the efficacy of UN peacekeeping and nation-building operations.

Condoleeza Rice, a Stanford university academic who also served under Mr Bush's father and who may become national security adviser, shares this tendency towards unilateralism and non-engagement.

Like the Republicans in Congress, who retained control of both the House of Representatives and the Senate and thus all the key decision-making committees in last month's polls, Ms Rice says the US should get involved abroad only if the country's vital national interests are at stake.

She recently suggested, for example, that a Bush presidency would seek to withdraw US forces from Kosovo and Bosnia, even though the situation in the Balkans remains far from stable.

On the other hand, America's new president will inherit a set of ongoing foreign policy problems which America is deeply committed to resolving.

These include the crisis in the Middle East, where the peace process between Israel and the Palestinians, Syria and Lebanon has broken down, and where the US is the lead mediator.

The UN sanctions regime against Iraq has all but collapsed - another instant headache for a Bush administration. Mr Bush's team espouses a hard line and does not rule out further military action - but it has so far offered no new solutions to the "Saddam problem".

Bush policies on national missile defence, on the environment (he opposes the Kyoto accord on measures to combat climate change), on global pandemics such as Aids, on development aid, on free and fair trade arrangements with the developing world, on treaties to curb weapons nuclear proliferation, and on relations with "rogue states" such as Iran, Libya and Cuba, all potentially place him at odds with British government positions, and on the policies espoused by many other western democracies.

A Bush presidency will mean that a lot of hard thinking and deft footwork in Downing Street and beyond will be required before he takes the oath of office on January 20.

 An earlier version of this article was published on November 8 2000

Some analysts see this as a crucial mistake that has led to a decade of continuing problems. Gen Powell, like other advisers around Mr Bush, is against placing US forces under UN command and is generally sceptical about the efficacy of UN peacekeeping and nation-building operations. Condoleeza Rice, a Stanford university academic who also served under Mr Bush's father and who may become national security adviser, shares this tendency towards unilateralism and non-engagement. Like the Republicans in Congress, who retained control of both the House of Representatives and the Senate and thus all the key decision-making committees in last month's polls, Ms Rice says the US should get involved abroad only if the country's vital national interests are at stake. She recently suggested, for example, that a Bush presidency would seek to withdraw US forces from Kosovo and Bosnia, even though the situation in the Balkans remains far from stable. On the other hand, America's new president will inherit a set of ongoing foreign policy problems which America is deeply committed to resolving. These include the crisis in the Middle East, where the peace process between Israel and the Palestinians, Syria and Lebanon has broken down, and where the US is the lead mediator. The UN sanctions regime against Iraq has all but collapsed - another instant headache for a Bush administration. Mr Bush's team espouses a hard line and does not rule out further military action - but it has so far offered no new solutions to the "Saddam problem". Bush policies on national missile defence, on the environment (he opposes the Kyoto accord on measures to combat climate change), on global pandemics such as Aids, on development aid, on free and fair trade arrangements with the developing world, on treaties to curb weapons nuclear proliferation, and on relations with "rogue states" such as Iran, Libya and Cuba, all potentially place him at odds with British government positions, and on the policies espoused by many other western democracies. A Bush presidency will mean that a lot of hard thinking and deft footwork in Downing Street and beyond will be required before he takes the oath of office on January 20.  An earlier version of this article was published on November 8 2000 Key rulings US supreme court rulings Florida supreme court rulings Related stories Florida moves to hand Bush victory Jonathan Freedland: a nation divided Timeline - when will America decide? webTitle: Murdoch appoints son James to board of NewsCorp

fields.headline: Murdoch appoints son James to board of NewsCorp
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Rupert Murdoch has promoted his youngest son James to the board of News Corporation, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch has appointed his son James to the board of News Corporation, leaving two of his children with a clear line to the throne.

James joins elder brother Lachlan, who is deputy chief operating officer of the media company, after serving his apprenticeship as chief executive of Asian satellite station Star TV.

The 27-year-old is unlikely to climb above Lachlan in the pecking order, as his 29-year-old brother holds the third most senior position in Mr Murdoch's global empire.

Mr Murdoch senior said: "James's outstanding leadership at Star TV and in our new media operations has given him a breadth of knowledge vital to News Corporation as we move our businesses into the interactive future."

NewsCorp's chief is shaking up the management at his global media empire to ensure a smooth succession after he retires.

Mr Murdoch has made clear that chief operating officer Peter Chernin is the first choice to succeed him, although he may be joined by one of his sons in five or eight years' time.

Daughter Elisabeth Murdoch, 31, dropped out of the running earlier this year when she resigned as managing director of Sky Networks, which runs BSkyB.

Ms Murdoch, who last month gave birth to a third daughter, Charlotte, has since taken up a boardroom post with magazine publisher Future Network.

New York-based News Corporation is the world's fifth-largest media company, with the Fox Entertainment Group and News International newspapers in its portfolio. About 70% of its revenue comes from the US.

Despite assurances to the contrary, News Corporation continues to stumble over the flotation of its Sky Global Networks subsidiary, which contains all of Mr Murdoch's satellite TV interests.

Wranglings over the shareholder structure of the company, which could include any company from Microsoft to Vivendi, have delayed the most eagerly awaited media share issue of the past few years.

webTitle: 'Am I allowed to walk out in support of a sacked colleague?'

fields.headline: 'Am I allowed to walk out in support of a sacked colleague?'
fields.standfirst: It is unfair to dismiss an employee for taking part in industrial action - but only if the action is lawful and your union follows the correct procedures, writes Stephen Cavalier
fields.trailText: It is unfair to dismiss an employee for taking part in industrial action - but only if the action is lawful and your union follows the correct procedures, writes Stephen Cavalier.
fields.body:
Q. The council I work for has sacked a colleague who was very active in the trade union. We think she was sacked because of this, even though personnel insist that she wasn't. Some of us walked out in support of her, but were threatened with the sack so went back to work. Could we have been sacked and how can we take action that would not lose us our jobs too?

A. If your colleague believes she has been sacked because of her trade union activities and her union official thinks so too, then she should be able to take a case against your employer for unfair dismissal.

The Employment Relations Act 1999 protects workers against "Being subjected to any detriment" because of their trade union membership or activities.

However, proving that an employer acted because of trade union activity can be tricky and most employers will have ensured that they have followed the disciplinary procedures by the book and cited reasons other than trade union activity for the dismissal.

In terms of what action you and your colleagues can take, you must make sure that it is legal in order to avoid being sacked yourselves.

Under the Employment Rights Act it is automatically unfair to dismiss an employee for taking part in industrial action if the dismissal takes place within the first eight weeks of action and if the employer has not taken reasonable steps to resolve the dispute - such as by refusing to negotiate or to go to conciliation.

But this is only the case if the industrial action is lawful and your union has followed the correct balloting procedures and adhered to the notice period that must be given to the employer of industrial action.

If you just walk out then your employer is within their rights to sack you and you will do your colleague little good that way.

 Stephen Cavalier is head of employment rights at Thompsons Solicitors

webTitle: Vauxhall hit by walkout after jobs axing

fields.headline: Vauxhall hit by walkout after jobs axing
fields.standfirst: Byers to make statement to parliament this afternoon
fields.trailText: Production of cars at Vauxhall's Luton plant was disrupted today when workers staged an unofficial walkout in protest at the company's shock decision to axe 2,000 jobs.
fields.body:
Production of cars at Vauxhall's Luton plant was disrupted today when workers staged an unofficial walkout in protest at the company's shock decision to axe 2,000 jobs.

Around 200 angry employees staged a demonstration at the factory, where car production is to end in 15 months time.

They demanded a meeting with Vauxhall chairman Nick Reilly, who emerged from his office to try to explain why the company had decided to pull the plug on production of the Vectra.

Workers shouted abuse at Mr Reilly as he stood on the steps outside the administration block for 15-minutes.

Vauxhall said it lost production today as a result of the walkout and because managers were explaining to production staff the implications of the announcement.

Local union officials were called to talk to the workers, who were still recovering from the shock of Vauxhall's decision. National union leaders continued to attack the announcement and called for urgent talks with Mr Reilly.

Some officials have warned that industrial action could be considered as an option in a campaign to maintain car production.

Workers suspected Vauxhall had timed the announcement to fall just before a four-week shutdown at the plant, which starts on Friday, said a spokesman for the Manufacturing Science and Finance union.

Staff believed the firm wanted to lessen the effect of any possible action by employees, he said, adding: "We were wondering why they had chosen to reveal this just before Christmas and this seems to be the reason. The shutdown has been planned for a while but the workers think the timing of the announcement was basically so they could do nothing about it, so that by the time they came back it would be a fait accompli."

The Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union said at least 100 workers protested at the plant this morning. "It is entirely expected," the spokesman said. "It is clearly an emotional reaction to a very difficult situation."

Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers is to make an emergency Commons statement today.

webTitle: Marketing round-up

fields.headline: Marketing round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 14.
fields.trailText: December 14: Nike is to put at least £10m behind the launch of its new Shox trainer.
fields.body:
Nike is to put at least £10m behind the launch of its new Shox trainer, making it the biggest launch since Nike Air was unveiled in the UK in 1987.

Nestle Rowntree is to make its sponsorship debut on Channel 4 after signing a £500,000 deal to link its Polo Supermint with Channel 4's dating game, Streetmate.

Freeserve has promoted its head of advertising and PR, Khim McCall, to the top marketing job after marketing director Neil Sansom left to join Shell.

The Prudential has appointed Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters as its first pan-European ad agency.

Microsoft is understood to have shortlisted Bartle Bogle Hegarty and Lowe Lintas for its X-Box console account.

Ireland's biggest bookmaker, Paddy Power, has hired Starcom Motive and specialist digital division Starcom IP to handle advertising for its UK launch.

Buena Vista Home Entertainment has appointed Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters to its £10m creative account.

The World Gold Council has asked six agencies to pitch for its advertising business.

The British Red Cross is looking for an advertising agency to build its brand in the UK.

fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 14.
fields.trailText: December 14: The World Gold Council is looking for an agency to create its first ever consumer advertising campaign.
fields.body:
The World Gold Council is looking for an agency to create its first ever consumer advertising campaign. Agencies will be briefed to highlight the fact that gold jewellery is generally more affordable than diamonds or platinum.

Egg has lost Tony Anderson, its high-profile retail marketing director.

Marks & Spencer is planning to offer a full range of food for home delivery by Christmas 2001.

James Lousada, the former European marketing director of Budweiser, has emerged in a senior role at the multi-access portal, Vizzavi.

The Open University has appointed Dr Andrew Hobbs as marketing and customer development director. The OU is trying to attract younger students to its courses.

The Advertising Association has criticised plans by the European Union to draw up a voluntary code of practice for the drinks industry. The association believes the existing codes are sufficient.

Freeserve has picked Khim McCall to be its group marketing director following the departure of Neil Sansom.

The Royal Mail is considering rolling out a new marketing campaign to encourage people to write more letters under the banner "Pen to paper".

Prudential has appointed Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters to handle its £10m advertising account.

webTitle: Tomb Raider trailer now on the net

fields.headline: Tomb Raider trailer now on the net
fields.trailText: As the Lara Croft movie hits the net, the stunt co-ordinator on the film praises the heroic efforts of Angelina Jolie to get into character
fields.body:
Millions of men the world over are already salivating at the thought of Angelina Jolie (pictured) as the ass-kicking artistocratic adventurer and virtual babe Lara Croft in the film version of Tomb Raider. The first taste of what looks set to be one of next year's blockbuster hits is about to hit cinema screens, and it is already available on the net.

Filming for the video game-cum-movie is still ongoing in London, but the first theatrical trailer is due to hit US cinemas later today, and is also available on the official site. CGI-effects aside, there are some spectacular stunts on display, most of which, it seems, Ms Jolie did herself. Speaking earlier this week, stunt co-ordinator Simon Crane told USA Today that the actress has some shocks in store for cinema audiences.

"We've done a couple of sequences that involve stunts you won't have seen a woman do before, and basically she is doing almost all of these stunts herself. We did a bungee-jumping sequence, and she went through three months training to be able to do it. She's just done all these somersaults for another sequence. I was very impressed."

Meanwhile, Brazilian site Set Online have four stills from the movie to whet your appetite.

webTitle: Hinduja brothers face allegations of corruption in India

fields.headline: Hinduja brothers face corruption allegations
fields.trailText: The Hinduja brothers, who lost the battle for the Express newspapers, are to face allegations of corruptions before an Indian court. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The billionaire Hinduja brothers, who lost the £125m bidding battle for the Express newspapers, are to appear before an Indian court in relation to allegations of corruption.

The brothers are accused of receiving £6m-worth of kickbacks form Swedish arms maker Bofors in 1986, after allegedly securing a government order for the company.

They have been ordered to appear before the court on January 19.

A spokesman for the brothers said: "The brothers will appear before the court and they see it as an opportunity to clear their name once and for all."

Srichand, Gopichand and Prakash Hinduja claim the money had nothing to do with the government deal and it was part of their business dealings with the firm.

It is a further blow for the brothers, who were furious that OK! tycoon Richard Desmond beat them to the Express titles. Mr Desmond came from nowhere to snap up the group, after the Hindujas had long been coinsidered favourites.

The Hindujas intended to add the newspapers to their global business empire, but claimed that owner Lord Hollick used them to effectively to flush out other bidders.

webTitle: Court rules in favour of Bush

fields.headline: Court rules in favour of Bush
fields.standfirst:
• US supreme court returns case to Florida
• Senior Democrats tell Gore to concede
• Ruling not unanimous - court votes 7-2

Special report: US election
fields.trailText:
• US supreme court rules in Bush's favour
• Senior Democrats tell Gore to concede
• Ruling not unanimous - court votes 7-2

Special report: US election
fields.body:
A divided supreme court has reversed a state court decision for recounts in Florida's contested election, effectively transforming George W Bush into the president-elect.

Some Democrats urged vice president Al Gore to give up his challenge in America's overtime election. Gore "should act now and concede," Ed Rendell, the chairman of the Democratic party, said less than an hour after the court issued its 5-4 late night ruling five weeks after the national election.

The vice president's campaign manager, William Daley, said Mr Gore and his running mate, Joseph Lieberman, were reviewing the ruling and "will address the court's decision in full detail at a time to be determined" today. But as the night wore on, some top advisers were privately telling the vice-president he had little choice but to drop his bid. "That's where every discussion is headed," said one.

Former secretary of state James Baker, representing Mr Bush, said the Texas governor and his running mate, Dick Cheney, were "very pleased and gratified; with the court's ruling. "This has been a long and arduous process for everyone involved on both sides," he added in remarks that stopped well short of either a declaration of victory for Mr Bush or a call for a concession from the vice-president.

In an extraordinary late-night decision, the justices said the recount ordered last weekend by the Florida supreme court could not be completed by a midnight deadline for selection of presidential electors and still pass constitutional muster. "It is obvious that the recount cannot be conducted in compliance with the requirements of equal protection and due process without substantial additional work," the justices wrote.

Its ruling came with exceptional haste for the court, the day after it heard arguments in the case. In a forceful dissent, Justice John Paul Stevens wrote, "Although we may never know with complete certainty the identity of the winner of this year's presidential election, the identity of the loser is perfectly clear. It is the nation's confidence in the judge as an impartial guardian of the law."

The court's unsigned opinion said seven justices agreed there were constitutional problems with the recount ordered by the Florida supreme court on Friday. The justices said that because Florida legislators intended to separately complete their own choosing of electors, perhaps today under pressure of a deadline for the electoral college, requiring a new recount "could not be part of an appropriate remedy".

The court agreed 7-2 to reverse the Florida court's order of a state recount and voted 5-4 that there was no acceptable procedure by which a timely new recount could take place.

In the majority were chief justice William H Rehnquist and justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia, Anthony M Kennedy and Clarence Thomas. Dissenting were justices Stevens, David H Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G Breyer.

Alongside the unsigned main opinion, justices Rehnquist, Scalia and Thomas went further in a separate opinion, saying the Florida supreme court also violated the constitution and federal law in ordering the recount.

Mr Gore's lawyers have scoured the opinion for any glimmer of hope, especially passages that identified the steps Florida needed to take to make the recounting constitutional. Some Gore lawyers were arguing the passages might give them some room to convince a Florida court to go beyond the 12 December date and allow more recounts before the electoral college meets next Monday.

webTitle: Is Robert Mugabe a dictator?

fields.headline: Is Robert Mugabe a dictator?
fields.standfirst: He was democratically elected three years ago, but many Zimbabweans are now wondering what their leader has become, writes Chris McGreal.
fields.trailText: He was democratically elected three years ago, but many Zimbabweans are now wondering what their leader has become, writes Chris McGreal.
fields.body:
There are not many, even among his opponents, who would compare Zimbabwe's president to Africa's most notorious rulers.

He is clearly no Idi Amin, Mobutu Sese Seko or Sani Abacha. Zimbabwe's press is still among the most vigorous and outspoken in Africa, as demonstrated by the newspapers' constant denunciations of Mr Mugabe.

And yet more and more Zimbabweans view their president as anything but a democrat.

Mr Mugabe's supporters ask how a man elected with an overwhelming majority of the ballot in an indisputably free election just three years ago can be called a dictator.

He may be unpopular, they say, but that is wholly different from being an illegitimate leader. And Mr Mugabe's opinion poll ratings, at somewhere around 25% support, may be low but they are no worse than Margaret Thatcher at her most disliked.

Mr Mugabe's critics point out that Mrs Thatcher, whatever her authoritarian tendencies, did not repeatedly defy the courts, give blanket amnesty to people who murdered her political opponents, order the police not to enforce the law and use a private army of thugs against an array of targets.

Such critical views of Robert Mugabe are relatively recent even if his abuses of power are not. In the early Eighties, the Zimbabwean army murdered tens of thousands of civilians in Matabeleland in a bid to suppress dissent. But over the years that crime came to be seen as the exception to Mr Mugabe's otherwise popular rule.

Now he has returned to the tactics of the past. His use of the self-styled independence 'war veterans' to seize white-owned farms and to harass dissidents inside the ruling party horrifies but does not surprise many Zimbabweans.

But it is Mr Mugabe's repeated defiance of the courts that has raised greatest concern because it opens the way to almost any abuse, including an attempt to cling to power beyond the 2002 presidential election that he is almost certain to lose.

When the high court ordered the police to remove 'war veterans' who illegally occupied white-owned farms, the president told his police chief to ignore the court.

Then Mr Mugabe granted amnesty to ruling party supporters who murdered 30 people during the run up to June's parliamentary election, and to the killers of a white farmer. The message was clear. Those who murder for the president will not be punished.

At the weekend, Mr Mugabe issued a decree ending any legal challenges to the results of the parliamentary ballot which, in some constituencies, was marred by violence, intimidation and rigging.

Mr Mugabe's actions have led to a widespread view at home and abroad that the Zimbabwean government no longer considers itself bound by the rule of law - that the president is, in effect, a dictator.

One of the ruling party's powerful politburo members and former cabinet minister, Nathan Shamuyarira, is dismissive of such charges.

"This government has been guided by the rule of law for the past 20 years. We have had the high court rule against us before and we have obeyed. But we don't think the land is a legal matter, we think it is a political matter and it should be dealt with between the farmers and the government. We have refused to send the police for that purpose because we believe they should be resolved in another way. There is a fundamental difference between us and the courts on this," he said.

And on the question of the weekend decree taking election disputes out of the courts, Mr Shamuyarira paints legal challenges to vote rigging as part of an international conspiracy against Mr Mugabe.

"The opposition is continuing to do this to harass us and tie us up in expensive legal processes so they can bankrupt us. They have a lot of money coming in from the British and American governments so they can afford to pay the lawyers. We can't afford to pay the lawyers," he said.

But the ruling party has not limited its scorn of the judiciary to defying court rulings. Senior officials have called for the expulsion from the country of white judges, who still dominate the higher reaches of the judiciary, on the grounds they are really British and have allegedly been serving Britain's interests.

Former allies of Mr Mugabe - such as Moses Mvenge, a founder member of the ruling party and its chief whip in parliament until the election - have no doubt what the man they once supported has become.

"I have never seen a country where one arm of government, the executive, goes all out to discredit another arm, the judiciary. It really is becoming a dictatorship because one man thinks he can make every decision and ignore every other arm of government," he said.

webTitle: Sportal signs contract with MSN.co.uk

fields.headline: Sportal signs contract with UK Microsoft portal
fields.trailText: 11am: Sports website Sportal has secured its future after striking a deal with Microsoft portal MSN, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Sports website Sportal.co.uk may well have secured its future with its latest content distribution arrangement - a year-long deal with Microsoft portal MSN.co.uk.

By distributing its content across MSN.co.uk - consistently number one or two in the top UK websites' chart - Sportal's news can potentially tap into more than 9.5m visitors each month.

Additionally, Sportal branding will feature heavily across all MSN's sports categories. At the end of the contract, both parties have the option of ending the tenure.

Alicia Phelps, Sportal head of distribution, stressed the importance of the deal.

She said: "Through this agreement Sportal will expose millions of MSN users to Sportal's top quality content, bringing them back to Sportal.co.uk for a wealth of Sport information."

MSN operator Microsoft recently announced that it would spend £1bn on developing and promoting MSN sites around the world.

The profile of the site has also been boosted by MSN securing the exclusive rights to webcast the Madonna concert.

Sportal has been active on the deal front of late, signing a wide-ranging arrangement with Fox Kids Europe last month to jointly create sports websites for children.

Last week, Sportal chief executive Rob Hersov was appointed chairman of The British Internet Publishers Alliance.

webTitle: Britain faces more floods

fields.headline: Britain faces more floods
fields.standfirst: Special report: weather
fields.trailText: Parts of the UK today faced more floods, powers cuts and transport chaos after storms lashed southern England, East Anglia and the Midlands.
fields.body:
Parts of the UK today faced more floods, powers cuts and transport chaos after storms lashed southern England, East Anglia and the Midlands.

Winds up to 80mph felled trees and power lines and closed rail lines, roads and even the M1. Felixstowe port in Suffolk was shut and three cross-channel ferries sought shelter as stormy seas made it too dangerous to dock at Dover.

Seventeen severe flood warnings were in place this morning - nine in the Midlands, five in Wales and three in southern England, the environment agency said. A total of 134 flood warnings were in place on rivers.

The environment agency said parts of Worcestershire and Somerset were likely to be the worst hit. In Shrewsbury, some homes and businesses which had only just recovered from previous floods were again under water last night. In Somerset and Avon, seven rivers and two streams were under flood watches with the north Somerset coastline between Porlock and Avonmouth braced itself for the highest tides this year. The whole of the river Severn from Worcester to Gloucester was under a severe flood warning today.

Thirty homes and businesses downstream in Ironbridge and Bridgnorth, Shropshire, were at risk from rising river levels while at Bewdley, Worcestershire, an estimated 80 properties were under threat.

In Worcester, where Worcestershire County Cricket Club's New Road ground was submerged and up to 30 properties affected, levels are expected to peak tomorrow.

The M1 southbound carriageway was closed at junction 18 after three lorries went over in high winds. No one was injured. Police forces across southern England reported dangerous driving conditions.

Cambridgeshire police said the situation in the county was "very desperate" with "trees coming down all over the place".

Efforts were under way to try to rescue the crew of a fishing boat being battered by high winds off the coast of Cumbria.

Hundreds of ferry passengers were delayed by up to five-and-a-half hours as storm force winds swept through the Channel. P&O Stena Line said three ferries arriving at Dover from Calais had been forced to seek shelter in calmer waters, but had been able to dock later.

At Heathrow airport hundreds of frustrated passengers were left kicking their heels after a busy runway was closed when a BA plane became stuck on a grass verge.

Rail passengers faced disruption as sections of track remained closed after strong winds brought overhead power lines down on the tracks north of London and in the Midlands.

In East Anglia, tens of thousands of homes were reported to be without electricity.

In Gloucestershire, the environment agency predicted that river levels would be even higher than they were after last month's storms. It warned that up to 40 homes could be affected in Gloucester and another five further upstream in Tewkesbury.

In Lancashire, part of Blackpool promenade was sealed off after scaffolding was torn from the front of the Royal Carlton Hotel and in Coppull, near Wigan, the gable end of a house was blown off.

A 19-year-old man was missing after falling into a swollen river in Salford, Greater Manchester, early today. The teenager was with two friends on the banks of the River Irwell. One of them also fell into the water but was able to scramble out. A large search was mounted with a police helicopter and rescue boat. In Cardiff 28 residents in a block of flats were evacuated after parts of the building's roof collapsed. Roads around the city centre were closed to traffic after scaffolding at a 14-storey building collapsed in strong winds.

Police in Gwent said the devastation caused overnight was the worse they had seen in decades.

Parts of the river Wye have been placed on severe flood alert, including the Monmouth area and a large stretch between Hereford and Ross-on-Wye. Flood warnings were also placed on rivers including the Lower and Upper Dee, Usk, Bran, Monnow, Teifi and Towy.

Electricity operator 24 seven said that 70,000 homes and businesses were without electricity across East Anglia. A spokeswoman said the worst hit areas were King's Lynn, Norwich and Bury St Edmunds.

Residents of Yalding in Kent were today again bracing themselves for further flooding after heavy overnight rain. The River Teise, one of three rivers that run into the village, which has already been hit three times by severe flooding, was on a severe flood warning.

The River Lavant in West Sussex has reached its highest levels so far this year. The environment agency warned that Lewes, East Sussex, also faced flood danger.

Two lorries toppled over on the A14 near Cambridge in high winds. Sections of the road were closed at Alconbury and Lolworth as a result. One driver suffered serious head injuries.

webTitle: The Pope, the tree and Mr Haider

fields.headline: The Pope, the tree and Mr Haider
fields.standfirst: The Vatican has got itself into a nasty political quagmire, reports Rory Carroll, and all because of a Christmas present
fields.trailText: The Vatican has got itself into a nasty political quagmire, reports Rory Carroll, and all because of a Christmas present
fields.body:
It was escorted into Rome by a convoy of police vehicles, hoisted into position under cover of darkness and placed under 24-hour armed guard. It is 115-ft tall, points at the sky and has an explosive impact, but this is no missile. It is a Christmas tree.

A handsome Carinthian fir, it is a green giant towering over the marble columns of St Peter's square. Every year a different region gives a tree but never before has it trailed a fuse.

It leads to Jörg Haider, the far-Right Austrian politician, for he is the donor and as such is due to meet Pope John Paul II on Saturday.

Accompanied by a 65-strong choir and a 52-piece band, Mr Haider, the governor of Carinthia, will have a private audience and then join public celebrations to unveil the tree.

Whatever greetings he has to offer are likely to be drowned out by a swelling cacophony of protest. Italian government politicians have joined Jewish and left-wing groups in demanding a cancellation.

Street battles cannot be ruled out since 400 Italian ultra-rightists are planning a counter-demonstration in support of Mr Haider.

The Vatican needs this like a hole in the head. The climax of its jubilee, or holy year, is approaching. Of all the jubilee's successes, the improved relationship with Israel was perhaps the sweetest.

The Pope's historic apology for the Catholic church's persecution of Jews was followed in March by an emotional pilgrimage to the holy land which melted suspicion. That breakthrough risks being undermined, though not destroyed, by Saturday's visit.

Mr Haider, a dominant force in Austria's Freedom party, is a hate figure for many because of remarks and policies which suggested a hankering for the Nazi period.

His party's entry into a coalition government last February triggered sanctions against Austria by European Union countries. The sanctions were dropped in September.

Calling the visit a disappointment, Israel's foreign ministry said: "Haider is a politician who is ostracized by the enlightened world. Granting honour to a man of this kind is liable to send a wrong and inappropriate message, unintentionally."

That last word captures the Vatican's dilemma, for it chose Carinthia three years ago, before Mr Haider became governor.

It could withdraw the invitation but that would break a tradition of not taking sides, or at least appearing not to, in political disputes.

Cardinal Agnelo Sodano, Vatican secretary of state, said: "The Holy See is open to everyone. During the war the Holy See had no relations with countries like the US, Britain or Japan, yet still (their) representatives regularly came and were received."

That cuts little ice with Mr Haider's opponents who have revived accusations that the Vatican has always been more than partial to the right.

Oliviero Diliberto - a cabinet minister as well as secretary of the Party of Italian Communists - anti-Nazi resistance fighters and the president of Rome's Jewish community have all signed a protest letter.

Leaflets depicting the tree as a gallows have been thrown at the Pope's car.

A torchlit procession will snake through Rome tomorrow under banners saying "Haider, Rome doesn't forget".

There is talk of a light aircraft trailing other slogans buzzing the Vatican on Saturday.

Those still hoping for a cancellation should not hold their breaths. The one true church has survived for 2,000 years paying little heed to public relations and damage limitation.

webTitle: ISBA casts verdict on white paper

fields.headline: ISBA brands white paper 'missed opportunity'
fields.standfirst: Special report: white paper
fields.trailText:
11am:The ISBA has said yesterday's communications white paper has failed to recognise the importance of advertising. By Claire Cozens.

Special report: white paper
fields.body:
The body that represents the UK's advertisers has described yesterday's communications white paper as a "missed opportunity", saying it had failed to recognise the importance of advertising.

The Incorporated Society of British Advertisers said that while it welcomed the general thrust of the white paper, it was concerned at the lack of attention given to UK's advertisers.

Malcolm Earnshaw, ISBA director general, said: "Not only does advertising play a crucial role in the wider consumer interest by driving competition in the economy, but it also provides the vast majority of funding on which UK commercial media is based.

"The viewers would be significantly more ill-informed, and certainly less well entertained without the massive contribution which advertisers make to UK media.

"This paper could in many ways prove to be an 'opportunity missed' by the government to take a fuller account place advertisers and consumer needs at the centre of the future media environment."

The ISBA also expressed concern that the white paper fails to bring the BBC under the control of the same single regulatory body as the commercial sector.

"The existence and activities of the BBC have a significant and increasing impact on the commercial sector, and should therefore not be allowed the competitive advantage that self-regulation through an unanswerable board of governors offers," it said.

The industry body calls for a firm commitment to self-regulation of the advertising industry.

It said: "In an environment of ever increasing media choice, controlling and monitoring content of both programming and advertising is likely to prove to be an impossibility in the future."

And it called on the government to look at ways in which it could allay advertisers' concerns over the creation of a single ITV.

One possibility, according to the ISBA, would be to look at the possibility of separating the advertising sales structures from a single broadcasting company.

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer talk notes that inflation is now 3.2% and rising
fields.trailText: West Ham will today sign Christian Dailly from Blackburn for £2.2m. According to the Sun, Harry Redknapp will attempt to pair his new central defender with Manchester United's Henning Berg, who could be available on a free transfer.
fields.body:
West Ham will today sign Christian Dailly from Blackburn for £2.2m. According to the Sun, Harry Redknapp will attempt to pair his new central defender with Manchester United's Henning Berg, who could be available on a free transfer.

Tottenham could make a bid for Leeds captain Lucas Radebe. The big South African is concerned that he may be edged out of the first-team picture by £18m arrival Rio Ferdinand; he was left on the bench at Southampton. "I'm aware George Graham would like to take me to Spurs," the 31-year-old is quoted as saying in the Daily Mail. "I've been settled at Leeds but I'm a professional. webTitle: Clare Short speaks on globalisation

fields.headline: Clare Short speaks on globalisation
fields.standfirst: Read the questions and answers from a recent Guardian Unlimited talk board session
fields.trailText:
fmk
Clare Short - how do you define "globalisation"? Is it possible for 'third world' countries to benefit from a system that simply uses them as a source of cheap labour and a location in which few environmental / human rights restrictions are imposed and most can be circumvented? Do you believe that Globalisation benefits 'first world' countries or do you believe that it makes them poorer by denying their citizens many rights?
fields.body:
fmk
Clare Short - how do you define "globalisation"? Is it possible for 'third world' countries to benefit from a system that simply uses them as a source of cheap labour and a location in which few environmental / human rights restrictions are imposed and most can be circumvented? Do you believe that Globalisation benefits 'first world' countries or do you believe that it makes them poorer by denying their citizens many rights?

ClareShort
Globalisation is defined in the White Paper. It has been going on since the end of the Second World War. It has accelerated recently with the end of the Cold War creating one global economy and information technology speeding the transfer of knowledge and information across the world. People talk as though it is uncontrollable. This is false. Countries that have increased their openness trade and inward investment have grown faster and reduced poverty for larger numbers of people than those that remain closed. But they vary in their degree in inequality - this is a matter of politics and choice not an inevitable consequence of globalisation. We need a positive agenda to manage globalisation so that the poor of the world will benefit and this is the whole point of the White Paper.

Meatloaf
It's not globalisation itself, but globalisation without restraint and regulation that's the problem.

ClareShort
Yes, I do agree and the White Paper makes clear that trade properly conducted will benefit everyone, particularly the poor of the world.

rjpineger
Is economic development killing the planet? Without protectionism, individuals are able to buy the cheapest goods and services. These often come from the place with the lowest overheads (both in terms of labour costs and environmental protection costs.) This prevents anywhere from rising above anywhere else in terms of environmental protection. If we lift the South out of poverty by converting them to the western model then global CO2 levels will rise. The paradox then is that "the South" is most affected by violent weather conditions caused by the rising CO2.

So, viewed in this light, your proposals suggest that whatever improvement the South attains through trade and economic development may be rapidly be taken away by adverse and extreme climatic events. Do you accept that you need to return to the drawing board and draft proposals which are more holistic and at least take into account some effects from climate change?

ClareShort
The position you put infuriates developing countries. They think that we have benefited from industrialisation and used the resources of the planet to get here and the green movement now wants to pull up the ladder behind us and leave a quarter of humanity living in squalor and poverty. The mindset of the environmental movement needs to move from conservation to sustainable development. International environment agreements are reached by consensus. Developing countries will not agree to strengthened controls unless we guarantee that we will support development and poverty reduction in their countries. Great poverty goes with overgrazing, spreading deserts, destruction of forests, and mounting environmental degradation. Economic growth is essential to improving the management of environmental resources in the poorest countries.

Saracen21
Before the 1997 election you spoke of "men in the dark" who undermine politics. Having spent three and a half successful years in government and worked closely with many of "the men in the dark" who you criticised, and indeed been helped by them personally on more than one occasion, I wondered if you had learnt to love the spin doctors.

ClareShort
No. I think too much spin is bad for politics and Labour Spin doctors now agree with me.

qcea
Two questions for Clare Short from the Quaker Council for European Affairs (QCEA) , Brussels. 1) For European Union development assistance, it is very difficult to get projects approval, so that payments are less than commitments and commitments are less than budgets. Commission officials claim that member states interfere in the approval process and that some at least of them welcome the underspends because the money goes back into national treasures. Have you any comments?

2) How do you see the relationship between conflict prevention and development?

ClareShort
European Union development assistance programmes are a disgraceful mess. The new Commission agrees with this and is putting in place a major reform programme. It is not true that delays in payments are a result of member state interventions. Many of their transactions currently require 40 signatures before a payment is made. KAFKA design their bureaucratic systems! We have published our agenda for reform. You might want to look at it. A lot of it is being implemented.

2) Half the countries in sub-Saharan Africa are affected by conflict. This is holding back development and causing growing impoverishment for a quarter of the population of the continent. Much of the conflict is caused by failed states with no effective government in place. There are more refugees and displaced people in Africa than ever before. Conflict also is a barrier to investment even in the reforming stakes because the continent is seen as so high risk. We have to succeed in Sierra Leone and then go on to put much more international effort into resolving the other conflicts in Africa.

lokithegoat
While I'm sure the Bretton Woods institutions (IMF, INBRD, GATT) haven't reduced poverty, and in many ways contribute to human suffering, the causes of poverty are pretty complex. Claiming the World Bank cause poverty is no less simplistic than blaming it on corrupt government, both of which seem valid arguments.

ClareShort
You are wrong. More people have climbed out of poverty in the last 50 years than in the previous 500. The misinformation that is so widespread on the role of the World Bank and the reality of development I find very worrying. Some people seem to want to believe that everything is doom and disaster. What we need to do is look at what works and take it to scale so that more people benefit. I hope you will read the White Paper.

shazam2
I think there are some benefits to globalisation that will help (in the long run) the world's poor. For the less developed countries, globalisation offers access to foreign capital, global export markets, and advanced technology while breaking the monopoly of inefficient and protected domestic producers. Faster growth, in turn, promotes poverty reduction, democratisation, and higher labour and environmental standards. While globalisation may confront government officials with more difficult choices, the result for their citizens is greater individual freedom. In this sense, globalisation acts as a check on governmental power that makes it more difficult for governments to abuse the freedom and property of their citizens.

ClareShort
I agree with you. But countries must shape the way globalisation effects them. Governments must provide education and health care for all their people - not just the elites in the city. And deal with corruption and put in place proper regulation of privatised utilities. With these and other reforms outlined in the White Paper, developing countries can move forward rapidly and bring real benefits to the poor.

cdesouza
The education of the third world population is obviously an important "long-term" route to successful globalisation. In the meantime, how do you focus an economy on "globalisation" when the major part of the population simply do not understand this western concept?

ClareShort
Education is key to poor countries getting access to IT and modern knowledge and technology. It is the commanding height of a modern economy. World Bank research shows clearly that the most powerful intervention that can be made in any country to promote development is getting a generation of children through primary education including the girls. As such children grow up, they transform their countries - girls marry later, have less children, their children are much more likely to live and be educated and girls that have been to school are better at getting health care for their families and increasing their family income.

People all over the world understand that the world economy is changing, whether they call it globalisation or not. The strange contradiction is that demonstrators from the rich countries demand that multinational companies should not invest in developing countries and suggest that poor countries should not be open to trade. People in developing countries want more investment and understand this is the only way they will get access to modern technology and they want more trading opportunities so they can afford to import the things they need.

webTitle: Ludovic Kennedy hits out at BBC's Bowen

fields.headline: Bowen branded 'ageing hamster'
fields.trailText: 10am: Veteran broadcaster Sir Ludovic Kennedy has called BBC1 Breakfast show presenter Jeremy Bowen an "ageing hamster" who should return to foreign reporting. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Veteran broadcaster Sir Ludovic Kennedy has launched a withering attack on BBC1 Breakfast show presenter Jeremy Bowen, dismissing him as an "ageing hamster" who should go back to foreign reporting.

"In 50 years of viewing I have never seen a presenter more twitchy and ill-at-ease," he said.

In an interview with Daily Express columnist John McEntee, Mr Kennedy added: "He has absolutely no sense of occasion. He's so laid back he might be in his coffin. He stutters and stumbles and is totally hopeless."

The author and former TV presenter also makes clear his feelings about Mr Bowen's Breakfast show performances in a letter published in the latest edition of The Oldie magazine.

Mr Kennedy describes the former BBC foreign correspondent as an "ageing hamster who had just woken up from a long winter's hibernation and was still trying to find his bearings".

He added that he "enjoyed" Mr Bowen's recent reports from Jerusalem, "and the best thing for him and us is if he goes back there".

A BBC spokesman said: "Since Jeremy started, audience figures are up and he's very popular with viewers according to the emails we get."

webTitle: The Texan way of death

fields.headline: The Texan way of death
fields.standfirst: With George W Bush as governor, Texas's execution tally has soared. But, asks Julian Borger, will he change his tune if he enters the White House?
fields.trailText: With George W Bush as governor, Texas's execution tally has soared. But, asks Julian Borger, will he change his tune if he enters the White House?
fields.body:
Almost every arithmetic total has been a matter of debate in this year's extraordinary election, but there is one count which Governor George W Bush won with an indisputable margin.

Under Governor Bush's leadership this year, Texas has carried out more executions than any other state since US records began. Forty prisoners were put to death - representing nearly half the total number of executions across the country.

According to the Death Penalty Information Centre in Washington, the last time a state came anywhere close in its use of capital punishment was in 1862, when the US army executed 39 native Americans after an uprising in Minnesota.

The ever-upwards trend in the Lone Star state runs against the tide in the rest of the country, where increasing doubts about the infallibility of the judicial system, in the wake of a string of well-publicised exonerations, have led to greater caution.

Eighty-four prisoners have been executed in the US this year compared to 98 last year, and no more executions are scheduled until January. The number of defendants sentenced to death has also declined.

The moratorium on the death penalty declared early in the year in Illinois, after new evidence revealed a host of miscarriages of justices, probably contributed to the slowdown. So did a justice department inquiry into the imposition of capital punishment by the federal government, which found that minorities were grossly over-represented on death row.

There has been no such introspection in Texas, despite the state's relative lack of safeguards. Unlike most other states, Texas has no public defender's office to assign legal representation to poor defendants. Instead defence lawyers are assigned by local courts, which have severely limited budgets and where the elected judges are under popular pressure not to spend money on suspected murderers and rapists.

As a result, lawyers are often appointed with little or no experience of capital cases. Many have been simply incompetent. Also unlike most other states, Texas elects its appeal court judges, which means they are also highly sensitive to the public mood of the moment.

The Texas court of criminal appeals seldom spends much more than a day considering death penalty cases and usually does not publish the reasoning behind its decisions. The Texas governor does not have the power to grant clemency directly, but he does appoint the state parole board, which does decide each case, and previous experience demonstrates that the board tends to follow hints and cues from the governor's mansion.

Yet Mr Bush has never exuded anything less than total confidence that the system works smoothly and sends the right people to be lethally injected in the state death chamber.

Mr Bush's nonchalance fits the overwhelmingly pro-death penalty mood in his state, so it will be interesting to see how he acts in the national arena. If elected, he will be called on to decide what to do about Juan Garza, a confessed murderer on the federal government's death row.

Last week, President Clinton postponed Mr Garza's execution for six months, pending further study of apparent racial and geographic disparities in the imposition of the federal death penalty, which is reserved for a restricted list of aggravated crimes, such as murders committed in the course of drug-trafficking - Mr Garza's crime.

A justice department survey found that since 1995, four fifths of defendants who have faced federal capital charges have been black or Hispanic. It also found that 14 out of the 20 inmates on federal death row had been sent there by only three states, Texas, Virginia and Missouri.

Mr Bush's treatment of the issue will set the tone for the country. He can either allow the present reappraisal to continue or bring it to an abrupt close. It will also be an important test of whether, once you have taken the governor out of Texas, you can take the Texan out of Mr Bush.

webTitle: McDonald's launches Italian campaign

fields.headline: McDonald's launches Italian campaign
fields.trailText: 8/15am: McDonald's has launched an ad campaign in Italy to allay consumer fears over "mad cow disease", writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
McDonald's has launched a major advertising campaign in Italy to allay consumer fears that eating its burgers can give you "mad cow disease".

The multi-national decided to run the campaign despite the fact that not a single case of BSE has been reported in Italy.

The campaign kicks off as panic over the safety of beef is spreading across Europe. A growing number of BSE cases in France and Spain has persuaded McDonald's to run similar campaigns in these regions, but this is the first time the company has acted in a country apparently free of the disease.

The campaign, created by Leo Burnett, is running in Italy's national and regional newspapers.

McDonald's proves it is willing to stake its whole reputation on the safety of its burgers. Ads showing photo of a hamburger with a small Italian flag hanging off one side read, "Relax. It's Guaranteed by McDonald's".

Beef sales in Italy have plunged by 35% due to the realisation over the past month that BSE has taken hold on the European continent.

Mad cow-infected meat products are believed to cause a new form of the deadly Creutzfeldt-Jakob brain disease in humans.

webTitle: Blair grilled on failing public services

fields.headline: Blair grilled on failing public services
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair faced waves of voter indignation over the failing state of key public services - notably the NHS, crime, schools and transport - during his live TV grilling last night.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair faced waves of voter indignation over the failing state of key public services - notably the NHS, crime, schools and transport - during his live TV grilling last night.

Quizzed by a studio audience and telephone callers on the subject of extra pay for nurses, police and teachers, he said: "It may not be enough or as much as people want, but it is a big start."

The NHS is the biggest single issue concerning the public, judging from the number of callers and audience members wanting to test the prime minister on health issues.

He confessed repeatedly that shortages of doctors and nurses, not cash, are the NHS's biggest problem.

At one point presenter Jonathan Dimbleby had to steer callers and audience members off the subject of health and onto other issues such as the euro and education during the hour-long ITV show.

Programme producer Alexander Gardiner told SocietyGuardian.co.uk: "We had more calls on health than anything else, although there was also lots of interest in crime and social disintegration."

Mr Gardiner said the key health topics raised by callers were "bad personal experiences" of NHS care, cancelled operations and waiting times.

On the programme Mr Blair confessed his inability to improve the NHS quickly enough to ease the suffering of a woman whose 87-year-old mother has been told she must wait 68 weeks to see an orthopaedic surgeon.

In an emotional exchange he told the distressed woman: "I accept it is my responsibility to turn this situation around. I am trying to do it, I am trying my very level best to do it."

Challenged to say why he and chancellor Gordon Brown had not spent more on public services like the NHS earlier in Labour's three year term, Mr Blair insisted they had been determined to ease crippling debt repayments to avoid Tory boom and bust in the economy.

In a rare breach of the night's good tempered but highly assertive cross-examination by an audience at Yorkshire TV's Leeds studio - and telephone callers around the country - Mr Blair, stung by one hurled taunt on tight public spending limits, said: "I don't intend to become a leftwing Margaret Thatcher. That is not what I am about."

At one point presenter Jonathan Dimbleby had to steer callers and audience members off the subject of health and onto other issues such as the euro and education during the hour-long ITV show. Programme producer Alexander Gardiner told SocietyGuardian.co.uk: "We had more calls on health than anything else, although there was also lots of interest in crime and social disintegration." Mr Gardiner said the key health topics raised by callers were "bad personal experiences" of NHS care, cancelled operations and waiting times. On the programme Mr Blair confessed his inability to improve the NHS quickly enough to ease the suffering of a woman whose 87-year-old mother has been told she must wait 68 weeks to see an orthopaedic surgeon. In an emotional exchange he told the distressed woman: "I accept it is my responsibility to turn this situation around. I am trying to do it, I am trying my very level best to do it." Challenged to say why he and chancellor Gordon Brown had not spent more on public services like the NHS earlier in Labour's three year term, Mr Blair insisted they had been determined to ease crippling debt repayments to avoid Tory boom and bust in the economy. In a rare breach of the night's good tempered but highly assertive cross-examination by an audience at Yorkshire TV's Leeds studio - and telephone callers around the country - Mr Blair, stung by one hurled taunt on tight public spending limits, said: "I don't intend to become a leftwing Margaret Thatcher. That is not what I am about."

webTitle: Who wants to be a prime minister?

fields.headline: Who wants to be a prime minister?
fields.trailText: Tony Blair promised that he would not be a "leftwing Margaret Thatcher" during his hour long TV grilling last night. Sketch by Simon Hoggart
fields.body:
Tony Blair walked down an illuminated catwalk. "Tonight, live from Leeds, Ask The Prime Minister!" a voice declaimed, and tingly music played. The lights cast shadows from below, so he looked like your uncle pretending to be a ghost on Christmas Eve. It was like the opening of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, and the prime minister had won the fastest finger round. In such ways does art imitate tripe.

"Well," he said at one point, "it's the only time I get the chance to talk to people direct and not through newspapers," though on occasion the experience seemed to have brought him close to panic. You can always tell, because his eyes glaze over, like Bambi hearing the bad news about his mother.

It's so much easier tackling William Hague. You felt he wanted Jonathan Dimbleby (surely the winner of the Leeds heat in the George W Bush lookalike contest) to tell him he still had one lifeline: shoot the audience.

The programme was on ITV, and the overall effect was curiously disjointed. The questioners depicted a country in which the infrastructure had collapsed, where health care is rationed, and our teachers and police are quitting in thousands, leaving packs of uneducated, feral youngsters to terrorise the land.

Yet the frequent ads which interrupted told the opposite story: the workers of Britain are buying computers, luxury Belgian chocolates, gourmet frozen food, scented unguents, and brand new BMW cars.

Which picture of Britain is right? Why, both are, of course. This is a nation where most people have stacks of money to buy things, yet nobody seems to be able to provide services.

The audience began with train services. "Ah want to be open with you," Mr Blair vouchsafed, "it's absolute hell travelling on the railways at the present time" - as if we didn't know. But, he added, some of the speed restrictions were "over the top".

Mr Dimbleby inquired if this meant Railtrack was "taking us all for a ride", which of course is the one thing they cannot manage. The prime minister was opposed to the "risk-aversion" which had "crept into the system", yet said that "the safety" (he has been absorbing Prescott-speak) had to come first. "You're saying two different things," Mr Bush - sorry, Mr Dimbleby - pointed out. A cynic might say that this was because he's a politician; I suspect he was merely tired. Four days in Nice; sleep deprivation always catches up with you.

"Police numbers are down, crime is up. That's not a very good record, is it?" he was asked. "It's not a matter of statistics," he said wearily, but of course that's exactly what all recent British governments have tried to reduce every problem to.

On the NHS, he declared again: "I genuinely believe the glass is half full, not half empty," a phrase which is half meaningful and half gibberish. We saw one flash of real passion when a woman complained that her mother had to wait 68 weeks for surgery. "I accept it's my responsibility to turn the system round. I'm doing my very level best," he said, and looked as though he meant it. The famous glassy smile was absent; he seems to realise it doesn't work any more.

A woman shouted from the back that the Tories had always looked after their own. "You haven't looked after ours!" she added, and was cheered by the audience. But then he was cheered for his reply: "I don't intend to be a leftwing Margaret Thatcher. That's not what I'm about."

And the man who attacked the euro was jeered by the audience. Mr Blair finished strongly, but he may find today's question time rather easier.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week seventeen, the expert's view

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week seventeen, the expert's view
fields.standfirst: Online bookmakers Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Patrick Murray dissects their latest wagers
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £189.58, Sean Ingle = £84.90, Football Unlimited punters collective = £54.86, Paul MacInnes = £51.20
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £189.58, Sean Ingle = £84.90, Football Unlimited punters collective = £54.86, Paul MacInnes = £51.20

Week seventeen's selections

Scott Murray: Manchester City v Everton: Everton to win at half-time £10 @ 12/5
Bet lost

My head hurts. A lot. I knew the eighth glass of champagne was a mistake. As was the fifth pint of lager. And the third bottle of wine. Last night was the Blue Square Christmas party and I've never been one to turn down free drink. Unfortunately.

But I'll soldier on, Bryan Robson like, in the vain hope my words of wisdom can make winners out of these losers.

Mr Scott Murray, of course, needs no such transformation, the man is a winner through and through. Okay, so he may have lost this week, but gambling is all about the long term and long term Mr M is in very good shape.

I see nothing wrong with this week's bet, however woefully inaccurate it may have proved. City have looked ripe for opposing for a while now, having got into the habit of losing despite some good performances.

The choice of the half-time market also had a certain logic to it with City such slow starters this season. Bookies tend to devote far less time to esoteric markets such as the half-time result, so its always a good idea to investigate the lesser markets where better value can often lurk. But anyway, Mr Murray may have lost this week, but as long as he continues backing value selections you can be sure he'll win in the long run.

Sean Ingle: Two £4 singles and a £2 double: Bari v Bologna: Bologna to win at 7/5; Lyon v Bastia: Bastia to win at 3/1
Bet lost

Perhaps I am a little harsh on the boy, maybe my world view is a little too black and white, but I feel it's a bit much for Mr Ingle to compare me to Mao Zedong. For the second time this season.

Granted I am known for my little red book, but in my case it's a Ladbrokes Diary, repository of all my betting wisdom, profits and losses, and a statistical analysis of said profit and loss. Unlikely to sell as many copies as Mao's version, I fear, but I'd be lost without it.

Mr Ingle, I'm sure, has no interest in the aphorisms of Patrick Murray though; he is his own man and no one is going to tell him what to do. His profit and loss figures may not be the most healthy, particularly when compared to those of Scott 'value singles' Murray, but nothing will shake him from his belief that multiples are the way forward.

I've no qualm with Sean's selections: quite rightly he continues to trawl the European leagues for value and comes up with logical (albeit losing) selections. But he just can't stop himself going for the big payout. It's still a marathon - though perhaps a Long March would be more appropriate - not a sprint, and we're only just approaching the ten-mile marker. Pace yourself better Mr I and victory could still be yours.

Lee Calvert of the Football Unlimited Punters Collective: Newcastle to win at Arsenal £5 @ 6/1
Bet lost

Hurrah, a sensible punter representing the FUPC again! And I thought those days were gone. But no, Mr Calvert, this week's guest punter, has seen the light. This has all the hallmarks of the classic value single, as used to such devastating effect by Scott week after week. Pick any out-of-form big-name side and the chances are the bookies will have overrated them (usually deliberately in the knowledge that they will be backed at any price) and hence there is often value to be had in opposing them. Chelsea have been crying out to be opposed for sometime now, particularly away, and of late Arsenal have also looked poor. Okay, so it didn't come off this week but in the long run this is where the money is to be made.

I have one quibble with Mr Calvert's comments however - what he was forgetting, or ignoring, when he wrote "sixes on any two-horse race seems frivolous" is the extremely important point that a football match as a betting medium is not a two-horse race (unless like me you play on the Asian handicaps), because the dastardly draw so often comes along and pips your runner on the line. Sixes on a three-horse race is not so attractive but I think Mr C has the right idea and you don't need many 6/1 shots to come in to make a profit on the year.

Paul MacInnes: A Sean Ingle trademark treble: Rangers to beat Motherwell @ 2/9, Chelsea to beat Derby @ 1/2, Dundee United to beat Aberdeen @ 7/2 - £5.10
Bet won £5

Ah the delicious irony of it. Mr MacInnes finally gets another winner but it's a winner almost entirely by accident. Still, a winner is a winner.

As Mr M explained last week, he actually wanted to do a single on Dundee United but because of the trebles-only rule he was forced find two other selections. And then, rather wonderfully, Aberdeen v Dundee United gets called off and his other two selections both cruise to victory leaving him a winner by default. Outrageous, but it's about time Mr M got a bit of luck.

This time of year, with postponements so common, there is more value to be had because it's often quite easy to get round the trebles-only rule by including selections from matches you know have already been called off. Or else you can do it Paul's way and get lucky; it's better to be lucky than good as the old gambler's saying goes.

But enough of such ribaldry, the aspirins are wearing off I can feel the throbbing starting up again. I still haven't worked out how my underwear ended up back to front, but doubtless I'll find out all about it at work tomorrow. Enough, dear punter, too much indeed. More words of wisdom next week, I hope, in the unlikely event I'm still a Blue Square employee. Until then, happy punting.

webTitle: Jennings' double lands Oxford repeat victory

fields.headline: Jennings' double lands Oxford repeat victory
fields.trailText: Rugby Union
fields.body:
Rugby Union

Oxford retained the Bowring Bowl with a tense 19-16 victory over Cambridge in the University match at Twickenham yesterday, the wing Ross Jennings scoring a try in each half to frustrate a gallant Light Blue effort in dismal wet conditions.

The Cambridge fly-half Simon Amor, who kicked three penalties and converted his side's only try by Mark Chapman-Smith, had a late chance to salvage the first draw in the fixture since 1965 but pushed his penalty attempt wide to concede Oxford's 50th victory over their rivals since the contest began in 1871.

The struggling European champions Northampton strengthened their back line by winning the battle to sign the Scotland centre John Leslie from Newcastle yesterday.

The New Zealand-born midfielder, who has won 13 caps for Scotland and was voted man of the series in the 1999 Five Nations, will join his Scotland team-mates Budge Pountney and Steve Brotherstone at Franklins Gardens.

The Gloucester prop Adey Powles, 33, may not play rugby again after the car crash in mid-November which left him unconscious for nearly a week. His wife is still in hospital with leg and pelvis injuries.

webTitle: Doctors 'faking research work'

fields.headline: Doctors 'faking research work'
fields.standfirst: Journals call for GMC to crack down on fraud
fields.trailText: Journals call for GMC to crack down on fraud.
fields.body:
Research fraud among doctors who want the kudos and money that go with publication in a leading medical journal is a problem that is "surfacing like a decomposing corpse" and yet the guardians of medical integrity are not taking the necessary steps to stamp it out, according to editors.

Yesterday the editors of three of the most prestigious medical publications in the UK, Richard Horton of the Lancet, Richard Smith of the British Medical Journal, and Michael Farthing of Gut, denounced the General Medical Council and the Royal Colleges for failing to set up a national body to root out the fraudsters and deter others from faking research results.

A year ago, they say in a letter to be published in their journals this week, the GMC and the colleges promised to act, but they had not.

Dr Horton said that the medical institutions had been promising to take fraud seriously ever since the journal editors set up the Committee on Publication Ethics as a forum in which to discuss research misconduct.

"The GMC and the Royal Colleges have not shown the resolve they said they would show," he said at the launch of the COPE's third annual report yesterday.

Last week the GMC found a consultant surgeon, Anjan Banerjee, guilty of serious professional misconduct for publishing an article in Gut that contained information that had been deliberately falsified.

It took 10 years to bring him to book. While a junior doctor at King's College Hospital Mr Banerjee carried out a study investigating drug-induced damage to the small intestine. Not only was it published in Gut but it also went out as an abstract at a scientific meeting. Mr Banerjee based his results on the urine samples of "12 healthy patients". It was in fact his own urine.

"Dr Banerjee was suspended and not struck off, in spite of the finding of fact about fraud," said Dr Horton.

He attacked the Academy of Medical Sciences, which acts as an umbrella body for all the royal colleges. It ought to be taking the lead in fighting misconduct, he said. "They have been especially negligent with respect to promoting research integrity. They have issued two sets of guidelines, neither of which deal with research misconduct when they should have done."

The GMC is deep in a process of reform, revising its constitution and reviewing the way it disciplines doctors. Only last month, Dr Horton said, the academy gave its advice. "It was the best opportunity any independent body has had in recent years to strengthen the GMC's resolve in respect of misconduct."

But instead, they said they had grave misgivings about making the GMC more accountable to the public. "They are more concerned about protecting the profession," he said.

The COPE's annual report is only a snapshot of the sort of research misconduct that is taking place, its members believe. The cases it discusses are only those which are raised at meetings by a journal editor who has nagging doubts about a paper that has been submitted for publication. Although papers are always sent for peer review to other scientists in the field, fraud is hidden and malpractice - such as a failure to ask the ethics committee for approval or the patients for consent - will not be picked up.

The COPE has dealt with 110 cases by now, 30 of which came to light this year. There must be many more. "Many, many editors in Britain don't bring cases to COPE," said Dr Smith. "We have no idea still what fraction of the whole this represents," said Professor Farthing." Not all of them involve fraud - a common complaint is that research studies are submitted to more than one journal. In the case of a successful drug trial, this could make it appear as if there is more evidence for its safety and efficacy than really exists.

Not all doctors agree there is a problem and if there is, then some argue about the solution. Richard Peto, the professor of epidemiology at Oxford University, famous for his work on the link between smoking and cancer, opposes the establishment of any new body that may impede scientists. He argues that scientists are already subject to "harassment and hassle" from ethics committees and other bureaucracies.

Other cases include the British Medical Journal being sent a paper for publication from a surgeon who claimed to have a new treatment for migraine. His big idea was to put stitches in an artery that runs down the outside of the head. He claimed to have carried out the operation on 1,200 patients.

"There is no clear definition of how the diagnosis (of migraine) was made," says the COPE report. There was also no control group - no patients in the study who were not given the operation and whose condition could be compared with those who had the treatment.
