webTitle: GWR chief urges relaxation of radio ownership

fields.headline: GWR chief urges relaxation of radio ownership
fields.standfirst: Special report: white paper
fields.trailText:
10am: The government must "grasp the nettle" and relax UK radio ownership, according to GWR boss Ralph Bernard, reports Dan Milmo.
Click here for latest on white paper
fields.body:
The government must "grasp the nettle" and relax UK radio ownership, according to the head of the market-leading GWR Group.

Ralph Bernard, GWR chief executive, said: "The government has clearly spent time thinking about TV ownership and not enough on radio ownership. TV always gets the headlines."

Yesterday's communications white paper made it clear that the government would consider a "fairer regime" for radio ownership, which could completely replace the existing radio points system.

GWR's portfolio is currently restricted to owning 38 local licences and the Classic FM station.

The UK commercial radio industry has been clamouring for the chance to reduce the number of players in the sector from around 12 to three, which would spark a multimillion pound acquisition spree.

The first sign of intent has been Scottish media giant SMG's move for Scottish Radio Holdings, which owns the Radio Clyde and Radio Forth stations.

Shares in SRH yesterday soared 122.5p to 1620p after it appointed advisers for a sale.

webTitle: A load of old flannel?

fields.headline: A load of old flannel?
fields.standfirst: Achieving universal internet access by 2005 may be a laudable aim, but how will Ofcom tackle pressing internet issues such as libel, standards of e-commerce and illegal material.
fields.trailText: Comment: The communications white paper does occasionally mention the internet, but its proposals do not address the issues of real concern, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
"A load of old flannel that doesn't address the main issues," said one key internet publisher of the communications white paper.

"It was optimistic expecting it to have any teeth this side of an election. Still one regulator is a step up from self-regulation," said the publisher, who wished to remain anonymous.

As broadcasters cheered plans for a single regulatory body, internet publishers and consultants felt decidedly overlooked.

While the report does occasionally mention "the internet" and repeats the line, "We aim to achieve universal access to the internet by 2005," it shies away from going into detail.

Rob Hersov, the newly appointed chairman of the British Internet Publishers Alliance, called for more detail on behalf of the internet industry.

"We need urgent clarification as to whether regulation of the BBC's new internet activities remains with the Department of Culture, Media and Sport.

"We are as yet unclear as to how the new regulatory framework will impact upon the internet and our concerns will remain until we discover how scrutiny on new and existing BBC online services will be dealt with.

"This white paper might be the first step forward on creating a fair and transparent marketplace but we need to know the detail."

In the white paper, it is stated repeatedly that mobile, 3G (third-generation phones) and television will play a huge role in creating "universal access" and there is reassurance that this is not just puff by a government promise of monthly reports from the e-envoy and e-minister, although at present both roles remain unfilled.

The e-envoy, when appointed, will run UKOnline, the government's linchpin for its whole e-commerce and internet strategy. UKOnline, which is pushing ahead with getting the population of the UK online (hence the name), has not been without its critics.

Some pundits have scoffed at the government's flaky attempt to be American - one only has to take a quick look at its "citizen" portal [UKOnline.gov.uk] to see an example of this.

Others have said the new initiative needs strong leadership and the government will always have problems attracting and retaining high calibre staff for ventures of this kind.

All in all, it is still unclear how Ofcom will set about its targets of tackling internet issues - does it plan to appoint a team of internet sharp-shooters or will one of the superfluous broadcast regulators take on that new but crucial role?

On the surface, many of the issues would appear to be the same - tackling illegal material is of paramount importance, but nowhere in the report is any mention of piracy and the increasingly mammoth issue of libel and internet content.

Instead, the white paper states that Ofcom will work with the "industry" to establish standards, such as Trust UK - a new standard for commerce - but by and large, Ofcom will favour filtering software.

Tackling of illegal material is mentioned and children are to be protected by a "superhighway safety pack" which will give tips on surfing.

The industry awaits details on Ofcom's thoughts on web broadcasting, mobile broadcasting and internet libel.

webTitle: December 13 Media Briefing

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

The billionaire Hinduja brothers, who bid for the Express newspapers, could be extradited to India to face corruption charges. P4
Government backs away from confrontation with broadcasters and newspaper tycoons by sidestepping big issues in the communications white paper. P6
Pro-European campaigners mock the attitude of UK tabloids towards Europe in their Christmas cards. P10
Employers are worried about US dot.com workers forming trades unions. P18
German court says a controversial Benetton advert, featuring limbs stamped "HIV Positive", is not indecent. P18
Chief executive of youth portal Liv4now.com steps down. P28
Sharon Mitchell's return to EastEnders confirms that she is a great soap character. P17

THE INDEPENDENT

Communications white paper clears way for single ITV. P1
BBC is let off the hook by white paper. P4
Lord Archer pleads not guilty to charges of perjury relating to the Daily Star libel case. P4
Media giant Vivendi Universal has received two $7bn bids for its Seagram drinks subsidiary. P19
Shares in Carlton Communications and Granada Media rise on the back of white paper. P18

BUSINESS REVIEW
The owners of online gadget retailer Firebox say it is better to build a business with your own cash rather than go running to venture capitalists. P2
The owners of online games retailer Gameplay talk about taking on an industry bigger than Hollywood. P8

THE TIMES

The communications white paper is attacked for its stance on cross-media ownership. P6
Baroness Jay, leader of the Lords, and Liz Forgan, former managing director of BBC Radio, are in line for the chairman's role in Ofcom, the new media super-regulator. P6
The BBC edited out footage of Prince William using an ITV pen to write to his brother in a documentary about the royal star's holiday. P20
Star Trek star William Shatner has abandoned an advertising deal with online ticket retailer Priceline.com. P25
European internet retailers could lose £500m-worth of trade this Christmas through rival companies passing themselves off as official retail websites. P27
The Racecourse Association investigates Go Racing's winning of TV rights to UK racecourses. P27

DAILY TELEGRAPH

Will Smith to earn up to £28m from Men In Black sequel. P3
Communications white paper unveils vague vision of the future. P12
The BBC has told dozens of reporters that they lacked the allure to appear on the main television news bulletins between 6pm and 10pm. P12
Countdown genius Carol Vorderman receives her MBE. P14
Russian media tycoon Vladimir Gusinsky is arrested in Spain. P18
Channel 4 news presenter Sheena McDonald describes rebuilding her life following an horrific car accident. P21
Scottish Radio Holdings is effectively up for sale. P33

FINANCIAL TIMES

Communications white paper is broadly praised by media industry. P2
The former head of mobile phone operator Mannesmann says the UK's Vodafone should have paid more for the company. P21
Profits warnings from US tech firms spark unlikely share buying spree. P27

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

Internet portal Terra Lycos under pressure following negative notes from analysts. P14
The new chief executive of Reuters, Tom Glocer, must deliver on the company's internet strategy. P25
Online retail giant Amazon parts company with advertiser True North Communications. P28

DAILY MAIL

TV cartoon character Bob the Builder set to oust uber-homie Eminem from the number one spot. P5
Campaigners alarmed by plans to let satellite and cable TV channels set their own taste and decency rules. P7
The authorities may still hesitate over approving a single ITV. P69

DAILY EXPRESS

Protesters splash paint over controversial Opium perfume advert in west London. P9
Veteran broadcaster Sir Ludovic Kennedy says Jeremy Bowen should be kicked off the BBC1 Breakfast Show. P31

THE MIRROR

Pictures of the marriage between Cold Feet lovebirds Adam and Rachel. P1
Legendary BBC sports commentator David Coleman faces the axe. P48

THE SUN

Coronation Street tops weekly ratings during week of 40th anniversary. P3
Alcohol experts warn Jim Davidson to get back on the wagon. P10
Arnold Schwarzenegger goes for his third on-screen grope in a week, with Melanie Sykes. P17
Simpsons fans are to get a monopoly game based on the hit TV show. P19

DAILY STAR

Undercover TV reporter Donal MacIntyre has returned to filming villains, despite fears for his life. P2
Capital Radio DJ Dr "Foxy" Fox presents the Capital Christmas Live Show with his flies undone. P7
Coronation Street star Curly Watts is to be arrested on his stag night, to make sure he's ready for the next day. P15

AND FINALLY...

Jim Davidson of Big Break and William G Stewart of Fifteen to One win battle of the quizmasters after answering 15 Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?-style questions. Carol Vorderman would have walked it, but she was too busy meeting the Queen. P12-13, The Mirror.

webTitle: Asylum seekers stuck in no man's land

fields.headline: Asylum seekers stuck in no man's land
fields.standfirst: Asylum is one of Britain's hottest political issues, but we know precious little about the people behind the statistics. Oliver Burkeman  spends a night with the migrants bent on reaching Britain.
fields.trailText: Asylum is one of Britain's hottest political issues, but we know precious little about the people behind the statistics. Oliver Burkeman spends a night with the migrants bent on reaching Britain.
fields.body:
Amid all the political posturing and the volley of statistics surrounding the issue of illegal immigration into the United Kingdom, it is an image which suddenly humanises the cross-Channel trade in stowaways. The Iraqi baby seems dazed, oblivious to the flashbulbs popping around her; her outsized pink bobble-hat strikes an incongruous note on the rain-sodden Calais docks. She has spent the previous few hours hidden in the back of a lorry bound for Dover, and much of the past month in similar conditions on the arduous trek from Turkey across Europe. But for now her family's covert journey to England is on hold, interrupted by security guards hired to search every truck making the crossing for signs of stowaways, smuggled on board for £400 a time.

This much is common knowledge; P&O Stena's newly toughened stance against illegal immigration has been a public relations coup for the ferry operator. What happens next is not.

If she is lucky, the baby girl will be bundled into a taxi by waiting police. Otherwise, her family will have a 12-kilometre walk along windswept motorways to their temporary home, the Red Cross reception centre near the coastal suburb of Sangatte - a huge, mud-green factory shed on a hill overlooking the Channel. Providing basic shelter and food to a constantly changing population of mainly Iraqis, Kurds, Palestinians, North Africans and Kosovars, it is a place without equal in western Europe: a refugee camp that feels like the edge of the world, but is actually a matter of minutes by car from the hypermarkets flogging cut-price beer and wine to booze-cruising Brits.

No questions are asked of the clandestines who pass in straggling groups through the camp gates. The authorities prefer it that way. Without any system of registration, the asylum-seekers are free to launch multiple attempts at the illegal crossing without explicit French backing.

"The doors are open, but it is a kind of prison," says Maher, a 32-year-old Palestinian computer programmer idling near the town hall, where somebody has scrawled graffiti labelling the local population xenophobes and Nazis. A journey he had planned for years and which has taken him two months so far is an hour's ferry ride from completion. "People are losing their minds in there," he says, gesturing towards the camp.

Sangatte's open-door policy is not extended to journalists, who are stopped at the gate. Stung by local criticisms that the centre is wasting millions of francs on "bogus" asylum-seekers, the Red Cross, a spokesman says, has made it "a basic principle" not to admit the press. But Maher reckons I could pass as Albanian, and sure enough, it proves easy to slip past the Red Cross marshals in the guise of an asylum-seeker.

The first thing that hits you is the stench from the toilet sheds wafting into the air which, at 5pm, is already seriously cold. Nearby, immigrants with children live in 20 Portakabins, around 25 people to each; they are divided into individual rooms of about three square metres by scraps of fabric hung from the wall. Maher and I are not so lucky. Our accommodation is in the military-style tents towards the back of the warehouse, where young men sleep 14 to a tent on narrow plastic hammocks. There are about 700 people in residence at the moment, but with fewer ferry crossings over Christmas, the Red Cross fears their numbers will rise steeply.

Most, with the exception of the Kurds, are articulate English speakers, often with university degrees and a scattering of PhDs. Many are frighteningly well read. Maher's conversation is peppered with references to Heidegger and Foucault, while Latif, a young Afghan who says he is fleeing the Taliban in fear of violent reprisals for his political views, frames his argument in terms of phenomenological philosophy. It is hard to avoid the feeling that their intellectual backgrounds make the indignities of daily life at Sangatte all the greater.

"We are very grateful to the French, but some of them, even the Red Cross, they treat us like animals," says Jouan, a mild-mannered lecturer who has travelled from Syria in the backs of trucks with one change of clothes, a guitar and a dog-eared Arabic copy of Nietzsche's Beyond Good and Evil. He was imprisoned, he says, because he had links with Amnesty International. His brother and sister are still serving 12-year sentences for membership of the Communist party. But his wealthy father bought him a 24-hour visit home and he took a midnight lift to the border. "The way they look at us, they treat us like we are nothing," he says of the camp staff. "I suppose we are nothing. But we were something."

Like Jouan, many in the centre are escaping political imprisonment or violence, but others freely admit to motives usually considered suspect in the UK and France alike: the fulfilment of entrepreneurial or academic ambitions cut short, they say, by the UN embargo on Iraq, or the Israeli government, or the Taliban. There are plenty of economic migrants among the political ones, but listening to them, it soon becomes hard to see a dividing line between the two.

Dinner, served on long tables lined with benches, consists of some dubious chunks of pinkish meat - "crazy cow," Latif guesses - and rice with peas. But we're among the last to eat, and as we try to leave we are pushed back by Red Cross staff, shouting "Hey mistair!", and thrusting cloths and buckets of water at us, refusing to open the metal gates of the eating area until we've sponged down the tables and benches.

It is a perfectly reasonable request, of course, but something about the way it is made goes to the heart of the camp residents' troubled relationship with the Red Cross. Stories abound of staff displaying what the asylum seekers interpret as contempt, locking them out of the showers, denying them hot water to wash clothes, waking them loudly at night while carrying out routine patrols. "Washing all our family's clothes in one tiny bucket of cold water, it's no way to live," says one woman. It is an attitude that it would be easy to interpret as ingratitude if one was so inclined.

"They're doing what they can, I suppose, but they could knock this place down, and we would still find a way," says Maher, disappearing to begin the nightly process of "borrowing" extra blankets from neighbouring tents. Opinions towards the French police are much harder: two Middle Eastern asylum seekers show numerous scars on their shoulders and arms they insist come not from mistreatment in their homelands but from the truncheons of port police.

Time stretches and yawns at the camp; with only a single television and a couple of old five-a-side football goals, most people seem to while away the hours smoking and pacing the warehouse floor. Ali, a portly 40-year-old Iraqi who had an English girlfriend before diplomatic relations soured, spends most of his time standing at the door of the building, positioned by cruel chance to provide a constant frieze of ferries plying the Channel. "On a clear night people say you can see the lights on the other side," he says, but he's not sure he believes them: during the two winter weeks he has spent making nightly attempts at passage to England, he can't remember any clear nights.

The halogen lamps flooding the warehouse are shut off and we return to our tents. Around 3am, a gnawing cold sets in. Every noise is magnified by the echoing concrete, but soon the rain starts to hammer deafeningly on the corrugated iron roof, dripping through onto our tents. "Listen," shouts Ali, as if it were possible to do anything else. "There's a war outside." At some point in the night we are joined by four Ethiopians, pulled off lorries at the docks hours before. Exhausted, they sleep through the cacophany, but for everyone else, sleep is fitful, punctuated by hacking coughs and children crying.

The England that dominates their thoughts is a strange place - "a completely inaccurate vision of Eldorado" is how the camp's deputy director, Michel Meriaux, puts it. For all of them, it is the ne plus ultra of democracy and human rights, a place where work permits are easy to come by - certainly far easier than in mainland Europe - and accommodation not so hard to find; for some, it is a stepping-stone to the US and Canada.

For Ali, who studied at Teesside Polytechnic in the 1970s, it is: "cheese and onion crisps . . . a pint of beer for about a pound, I think"; summer weekends in Neath; a kebab shop on the Old Brompton Road. "England is a place where they really value the past, hold on to historic things," he says.

Curiously, it is a vision which recalls nothing so much as John Major's picture of foggy cricket grounds and bicycling spinsters.

What it is, is a place where they do expect to have to work: work, after all, is precisely the point of the voyage for most. I ask Jouan, the lecturer and Nietzsche reader, about his professional ambitions. "A job," he says. "Just any job, really." The glowing tip of Maher's roll-up pierces the darkness. "Baudelaire had something to say about all this," he sighs. "You've read Baudelaire?"

' It's tonight, I think," says a man who tells me I can call him Mohammed, though he won't reveal his real name or country of origin. After breakfast - bread and tea or coffee - he outlines his plan: he has made a deal with "a friend in Calais" whom he is to meet at the ferry terminal tonight. He reckons I might be getting a taxi back to the city soon, and charmingly informs me that he will be sharing it.

Back in Calais, he explains that he wants to cover the final distance to the terminal alone, and catches one of the free transfer buses provided by the ferry operators. By the time I reach the terminal later that evening, he could be any one of the hunched figures scrambling up motorway embankments, hiding under bridges, slipping in and out of the shadows in the lorry parks, hardened against the wind and the hammering rain by the dream of stumbling, a few hours later, into the grey half-light of a Dover dawn.

"We are very grateful to the French, but some of them, even the Red Cross, they treat us like animals," says Jouan, a mild-mannered lecturer who has travelled from Syria in the backs of trucks with one change of clothes, a guitar and a dog-eared Arabic copy of Nietzsche's Beyond Good and Evil. He was imprisoned, he says, because he had links with Amnesty International. His brother and sister are still serving 12-year sentences for membership of the Communist party. But his wealthy father bought him a 24-hour visit home and he took a midnight lift to the border. "The way they look at us, they treat us like we are nothing," he says of the camp staff. "I suppose we are nothing. But we were something." Like Jouan, many in the centre are escaping political imprisonment or violence, but others freely admit to motives usually considered suspect in the UK and France alike: the fulfilment of entrepreneurial or academic ambitions cut short, they say, by the UN embargo on Iraq, or the Israeli government, or the Taliban. There are plenty of economic migrants among the political ones, but listening to them, it soon becomes hard to see a dividing line between the two. Dinner, served on long tables lined with benches, consists of some dubious chunks of pinkish meat - "crazy cow," Latif guesses - and rice with peas. But we're among the last to eat, and as we try to leave we are pushed back by Red Cross staff, shouting "Hey mistair!", and thrusting cloths and buckets of water at us, refusing to open the metal gates of the eating area until we've sponged down the tables and benches. It is a perfectly reasonable request, of course, but something about the way it is made goes to the heart of the camp residents' troubled relationship with the Red Cross. Stories abound of staff displaying what the asylum seekers interpret as contempt, locking them out of the showers, denying them hot water to wash clothes, waking them loudly at night while carrying out routine patrols. "Washing all our family's clothes in one tiny bucket of cold water, it's no way to live," says one woman. It is an attitude that it would be easy to interpret as ingratitude if one was so inclined. "They're doing what they can, I suppose, but they could knock this place down, and we would still find a way," says Maher, disappearing to begin the nightly process of "borrowing" extra blankets from neighbouring tents. Opinions towards the French police are much harder: two Middle Eastern asylum seekers show numerous scars on their shoulders and arms they insist come not from mistreatment in their homelands but from the truncheons of port police. Time stretches and yawns at the camp; with only a single television and a couple of old five-a-side football goals, most people seem to while away the hours smoking and pacing the warehouse floor. Ali, a portly 40-year-old Iraqi who had an English girlfriend before diplomatic relations soured, spends most of his time standing at the door of the building, positioned by cruel chance to provide a constant frieze of ferries plying the Channel. "On a clear night people say you can see the lights on the other side," he says, but he's not sure he believes them: during the two winter weeks he has spent making nightly attempts at passage to England, he can't remember any clear nights. The halogen lamps flooding the warehouse are shut off and we return to our tents. Around 3am, a gnawing cold sets in. Every noise is magnified by the echoing concrete, but soon the rain starts to hammer deafeningly on the corrugated iron roof, dripping through onto our tents. "Listen," shouts Ali, as if it were possible to do anything else. "There's a war outside." At some point in the night we are joined by four Ethiopians, pulled off lorries at the docks hours before. Exhausted, they sleep through the cacophany, but for everyone else, sleep is fitful, punctuated by hacking coughs and children crying. The England that dominates their thoughts is a strange place - "a completely inaccurate vision of Eldorado" is how the camp's deputy director, Michel Meriaux, puts it. For all of them, it is the ne plus ultra of democracy and human rights, a place where work permits are easy to come by - certainly far easier than in mainland Europe - and accommodation not so hard to find; for some, it is a stepping-stone to the US and Canada. For Ali, who studied at Teesside Polytechnic in the 1970s, it is: "cheese and onion crisps . . . a pint of beer for about a pound, I think"; summer weekends in Neath; a kebab shop on the Old Brompton Road. "England is a place where they really value the past, hold on to historic things," he says. Curiously, it is a vision which recalls nothing so much as John Major's picture of foggy cricket grounds and bicycling spinsters. What it is, is a place where they do expect to have to work: work, after all, is precisely the point of the voyage for most. I ask Jouan, the lecturer and Nietzsche reader, about his professional ambitions. "A job," he says. "Just any job, really." The glowing tip of Maher's roll-up pierces the darkness. "Baudelaire had something to say about all this," he sighs. "You've read Baudelaire?" ' It's tonight, I think," says a man who tells me I can call him Mohammed, though he won't reveal his real name or country of origin. After breakfast - bread and tea or coffee - he outlines his plan: he has made a deal with "a friend in Calais" whom he is to meet at the ferry terminal tonight. He reckons I might be getting a taxi back to the city soon, and charmingly informs me that he will be sharing it. Back in Calais, he explains that he wants to cover the final distance to the terminal alone, and catches one of the free transfer buses provided by the ferry operators. By the time I reach the terminal later that evening, he could be any one of the hunched figures scrambling up motorway embankments, hiding under bridges, slipping in and out of the shadows in the lorry parks, hardened against the wind and the hammering rain by the dream of stumbling, a few hours later, into the grey half-light of a Dover dawn.

webTitle: Regions take centre stage

fields.headline: Regions take centre stage
fields.standfirst: Labour is developing new policies for its old heartlands
fields.trailText: Labour is developing new policies for its old heartlands
fields.body:
Big job losses announced yesterday, in the car industry in Luton and in shipbuilding on Merseyside, came as Labour prepared to give a clear sign that it plans to bring regional policy in from the cold if it wins a second term.

The government's strategy to spread prosperity out from the thriving south-east is outlined today in a paper for the think tank, the Smith Institute, edited by two aides to Gordon Brown, Ed Balls, the chief economist at the Treasury, and John Healey, the chancellor's parliamentary private secretary.

An indication of the high priority given to the issue is that the paper will be launched at 11 Downing Street this morning, with many chairs of regional development agencies (RDAs) in attendnance before a meeting with treasury officials.

To show the policy is intended to cut across departments, the introduction is penned by Dick Caborn, the trade minister, and is peppered with references to work being carried out by John Prescott's department for the environment, transport and the regions.

At the root is the realisation that grumbling in Labour heartlands about being forgotten has a point. Under the Conservatives, regional policy was downgraded to trying to attract inward investment. Meanwhile, the economy's centre of gravity shifted towards London and the south-east, a trend that has not been arrested under Labour, though unemployment has come down in all regions.

As such, regional policy - albeit with a New Labour twist - is being rehabilitated, with the new regional development agencies given power and resources to act.

Mr Balls, says that although six of the eight English regions have incomes per head below the European average "there is nothing inevitable about regional inequalities - in incomes, employment or opportunity. Those regions and cities which led Britain in the 19th century can lead again in the 21st century."

But the old approaches - either emergency assistance to declining industries or the capital injections and tax incentives tried in the 1960s and 1970s - are out. Instead, the emphasis is on a regional policy that is bottom-up not top-down, flexible and driven by the need to deliver greater accountability and scrutiny.

The paper rejects the idea that salvation for the regions would come from macro-economic policies aimed at reducing the value of sterling. "We have tried that approach before and it was the manufacturing industry, the long-term unemployed and the regions of Britain that paid the price."

Instead, the government would like to build clusters of success, in which companies integrate their operations, take advantage of economies of scale and draw on a pool of specialised labour. Labour believes high rents, congestion and the costs of scale are making London an expensive place to locate. With improved communications technology there are attractions for firms to move outside the south-east.

There have already been initiatives such as 12 institutes for enterprise across the regions and the University Challenge scheme to support innovation. There is a recognition from Mr Balls that the government did not get everything right. Many RDA chairs felt hampered by restrictions on their budgets, their ability to direct resources to meet economic priorities and the fact they have been reporting to three departments. Mr Balls says these problems have been addressed, with extra money, better focus for RDAs on economic development and regeneration, and greater flexibility for RDAs to shift resources to local priorities. "In return, the RDAs will have to demonstrate top class leadership, coordinate with other regional and local partners and be more accountable for their actions - locally, regionally and nationally."

The pamphlet reveals how Yorkshire Forward, which covers Yorkshire and Humberside has signed up to measurable targets, including the creation of 150,000 jobs by 2010 and doubling the rate of small business start-ups.

Mr Healey concludes that a report on Labour's first term might read: "Slow start. shows promise". He suggests a long term strategy that aims for a wider spread of economic assets such as airports, universities, research labs and government offices will be essential.

webTitle: Health drive targets beer and fast food lifestyle

fields.headline: Health drive targets beer and fast food lifestyle
fields.trailText: British males who live on beer and fast food - around a third of all men between 16 and 64 - are prime targets for a new government health promotion.
fields.body:
British males who live on beer and fast food - around a third of all men between 16 and 64 - are prime targets for a new government health promotion.

Analysis, funded by the Department of Health, of the diets of more than 2,000 men and women confirm that few young men breakfast on cereals, eat fish or shellfish, consume low-fat dairy products or drink fruit juice or wines. It is time such groups were helped to make healthier choices, suggests the team headed by Jane Pryer, of University College London.

"Factors such as convenience, cost, peer group pressure and occupation may be relevant to food choices and lifestyle," she said.

Most men in what the researchers called the "beer and convenience" category were under 30 and single. "They eat a lot of fat and lack vitamins and minerals. Once you settle on a diet like this it can be a lifelong habit. Our recommended strategy would be to target health promotion at particular diet groups, rather than the whole population."

The latest findings, published in the Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, will come as a disappointment to nutritionists, even if they help explain why Britain has such high heart disease rates.

Most people studied by the researchers fell into one of four distinct diet "clusters" which differed between the sexes. Less healthy diets were found mainly in the north of England and Scotland whereas those with healthier diets tended to live in southern, central and south-west England.

The beer and convenience category accounted for 34% of men's diets. A further 18% ate the "traditional British diet" with high intakes of white bread, butter, tea, sugar and confectionery. A similar percentage (17.5%) ate plenty of fish, shellfish, fruit and nuts, and drank wine or spirits as part of a "mixed, sweet diet", which also involved a lot of cakes and pastries. A further 17% had a healthier diet involving pasta, rice and coffee.

Among women, 32% ate plenty of white bread, butter and high fat dairy products, but had low alcohol intakes. Neatly 25% ate a "healthier cosmopolitan diet" with high consumption of whole grain cereals, low fat dairy products, fish and wine, low intakes of chips and no beer or cider.

webTitle: English see smacking as a moral duty

fields.headline: English see smacking as a moral duty
fields.standfirst: Punishing children isn't wallop, it's codswallop, says Francis Wheen
fields.trailText: Punishing children isn't wallop, it's codswallop, says Francis Wheen
fields.body:
The English, on the whole, do not like children. As the size of the prison population demonstrates, we are also a nation of punishment freaks. Put the two together and you have a society where hitting tiny tots is not only acceptable but a moral duty.

When John and Elizabeth Newson of Nottingham University interviewed a random sample of 700 parents, they found that 62% had hit their child before its second birthday. By the age of seven, more than 8% of children were being beaten every day, and another 33% at least once a week. "The majority of parents we have interviewed," the Newsons noted, "seem to believe that physical punishment is an inevitable and probably necessary aspect of ordinary child upbringing."

New Labour thinks so too. I don't know if the prime minister has chastised his new baby yet, but he has admitted to beating Euan, Nicholas and Kathryn "when they were little". Not to be outdone, David Blunkett boasted to the Sunday Telegraph last weekend that "I smacked my children and it worked". Meanwhile, one of his junior ministers, Margaret Hodge, confirmed to the Independent on Sunday that she and Mr Blunkett want childminders to have the right to hit children "with parents' consent".

Britain was the last country in Europe to ban corporal punishment in schools - and then only because the European court of human rights gave us no choice. The present government now seems determined to be the last in Europe to outlaw the beating of children by parents and nannies. Mr Blunkett says that physical violence was "the only way of getting the message across" to his three sons. The message being, presumably, that it's OK to hit people who can't fight back.

Why should parents and childminders enjoy the unique privilege of being able to lash out with impunity? Here's the answer given by George Carey, the Archbishop of Canterbury, a few years ago: "You say 'Don't do this', 'You mustn't do that', and you gently slap them if they transgress, and there is nothing wrong with that as long as it is done with love and firm discipline within the family set-up." Mr Blunkett, who endorsed Mr Carey's "perfectly reasonable" remarks, has said that it is "important to distinguish between smacking and physical violence". Mr Blair, too, insists that "there is a clear dividing line between administering discipline on the one hand and violence on the other".

This isn't wallop, it's codswallop. Smacking is indeed physical and violent: its purpose is to inflict pain. No doubt many an 18th century squire believed that he was demonstrating love and firm discipline within the family set-up when he whacked his wife or housemaid. If he tried it today, he'd be up on a charge. It is amazing but true that the only British citizens who still have no legal redress against domestic violence are those who are most vulnerable.

Perhaps someone should slap Mr Blunkett about a bit, firmly but lovingly, until he sees sense. After all, as he is so eager to assure us, it works.

webTitle: Child carers jeer minister over smacking decision

fields.headline: Child carers jeer minister over smacking decision
fields.trailText: A minister was jeered yesterday as she defended the government's decision to allow childminders to smack children in their care with parental consent.
fields.body:
A minister was jeered yesterday as she defended the government's decision to allow childminders to smack children in their care with parental consent.

Margaret Hodge, minister for employment and equal opportunities, told a conference of childcare professionals in London that parents agreed by more than eight to one that they and not the government should decide whether childminders could slap their children.

The government is also allowing childminders to smoke in front of children - providing parents agree. Smacking and smoking are banned in nurseries and after-school clubs.

Stephen Burke, director of the Daycare Trust charity, said in his keynote speech to more than 600 delegates that the decision, confirmed last week, was an attack on children's rights, their health and their safety. "Why is it acceptable for childminders to smoke and smack children when the government has banned smoking and smacking in all other childcare decisions?" he said. The move was "bad and fundamentally flawed".

Delegates told Mrs Hodge the government should take a lead rather than follow opinion polls. Trisha David from Kent said it was helping "create a culture where it is all right to smack children".

Mrs Hodge said ministers were trying to get away from the culture of "nanny state government". She asked: "Do we as politicians have the right to make decisions for other parents?" Delegates shouted back "yes".

Both Mrs Hodge and David Blunkett, the education secretary, who spoke later, stressed that children could be smacked by the childminder only if the parents and the childminder agreed in advance. They were not advocating smacking of children. "I expect in most instances that the arrangements that parents reach with childminders will involve a ban on smacking and a ban on smoking," Mrs Hodge said.

Mr Blunkett, who received a polite but cool reception, said: "At some point, somewhere, we had to draw a line between parental and family decision and responsibility, and that of the state - we have to say that the state is not responsible for everything."

Mr Blunkett announced an extra 80,000 free nursery education places for three-year-olds next year. At the same time the office for standards in education said on the basis of 900 nursery inspections the standard of pre-school provision had improved markedly over the past three years.

In a poll commissioned by the government, 84% of parents said they should have the power to decide in agreement with the childminder whether the minder could smack their children. Only 10% said the government should decide.

Mr Burke said he believed very few people wanted children smacked. Mrs Hodge admitted later that officials had processed only 1,000 of more than 6,500 responses sent in during the consultation period, but said that was a representative sample. The opinion poll, by an independent company, RSGB, had confirmed the government's instincts.

Tory spokesman John Hayes said the government had presided over a drop in the number of childminder and nursery places.

webTitle: Summary of changes proposed

fields.headline: Summary of changes proposed
fields.trailText: Television
fields.body:
Television

The BBC is to be brought under a single regulator, Ofcom, which will regulate standards for all broadcasters. BBC governors retain role of overseeing its public service remit

Moves towards a single ITV: rule preventing one company owning the two London franchises is ended, as is limit preventing one company controlling more than 15% of advertising share. Regional interests will be protected

BBC will keep strong public service remit, although Channel 4's obligations will be updated. Channel 5 likely to lose most of its public service role, and ITV's prescriptive rules will be eased. Welsh-language S4C is preserved

Ofcom will ensure public service channels such as BBC and ITV are available on digital cable and satellite services

Radio

The points system which places limits on ownership of local radio licences may end

There will still be one independent national speech station, and one non-pop music station

Newspapers

Relaxation of rules governing newspaper mergers and takeovers will be considered

Further comment being sought on complex cross-media ownership rules that restrict newspaper groups' ownership of TV or national radio stations, for instance

Telecoms and the internet

Regulation given to Ofcom, replacing Oftel

Strategy to encourage adoption of broadband services and examine if the public sector has further role

More effort to tackle illegal material on the internet

webTitle: One regulator in broadcasting

fields.headline: One regulator in broadcasting
fields.standfirst: White paper allows single ITV and keeps BBC governors
fields.trailText: The communications white paper allows a single ITV and keeps BBC governors, write Matt Wells and David Teather.
fields.body:
The government backed away from a confrontation with broadcasters and newspaper tycoons yesterday when it published its long-awaited blueprint for the digital age.

In a white paper billed as a radical reform of media regulation, ministers appeared to have sidestepped the most controversial issues ahead of a general election.

BBC governors retain their powers to police the corporation; the strict rules that barred the way to a single ITV network are swept away; and Channel 4 won its battle against privatisation. Ministers delayed potentially sensitive reforms of the rules on newspaper takeovers and cross-media ownership.

The communications white paper proposes that a single, powerful regulator will cover broadcasting, telecommunications and new media. The body will have wide-ranging controls to maintain standards, ensure that no single company dominates the market, and will even attempt to police the internet.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, said "light-touch" regulation would allow Britain's media industry to compete on a world stage, but the interests of consumers would remain paramount.

Stephen Byers, the trade secretary, appeared to concede the proposals had not gone as far as expected: "The white paper does take a balanced approach and some may criticise us for that." But he said the plans provide for "intelligent and modern regulation".

Media lobbyists were celebrating victory in their key battles. The BBC was privately surprised at the extent to which it had escaped any dilution of the governors' role: many commentators had argued they were too close to the BBC's managers, and Mr Smith had expressed fury over their decision to allow the BBC to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm. But he lost to No 10, which wanted to avoid a clash with the corporation ahead of an election.

Sir Christopher Bland, chairman of the BBC's board of governors, was jubilant. "The BBC's independence remains intact," he declared. But rival broadcasters pointed out that the corporation would be placed under the same regulation as everyone else for the first time. Channel 4's chief executive, Michael Jackson, said the white paper was a "big vote of confidence" in his channel.

The government hopes to enact by 2003 legislation that sweeps away the plethora of regulators. The broadcasting standards commission, independent television commission, radio authority, and Oftel are swallowed up by a super-regulator, Ofcom. The body will have the power to pass judgment on taste and decency, privacy and fairness issues, and take responsibility for economic regulation.

But the BBC governors retain their role overseeing the corporation's public service remit and editorial independence. They also retain the power to investigate complaints; viewers or listeners unhappy with the outcome could then go to Ofcom.

The main ITV companies were pleased with the reform of ownership rules: the competition commission will now be the final arbiter. The ITV network welcomed a less stringent regulation of its public service remit.

In another area that would have proved controversial, the government put off any decision on relaxing the cross-media ownership rules.

Ministers "invited comments" on reforming the guidelines, which include a ban on major newspaper owners such as Rupert Murdoch holding a terrestrial TV or national radio franchise.

The white paper angered disability campaigners. The RNIB said the market could not be relied on to provide services such as subtitling and audio description, and stronger regulation was required.

Television

The BBC is to be brought under a single regulator, Ofcom, which will regulate standards for all broadcasters. BBC governors retain role of overseeing its public service remit

Moves towards a single ITV: rule preventing one company owning the two London franchises is ended, as is limit preventing one company controlling more than 15% of advertising share. Regional interests will be protected

BBC will keep strong public service remit, although Channel 4's obligations will be updated. Channel 5 likely to lose most of its public service role, and ITV's prescriptive rules will be eased. Welsh-language S4C is preserved

Ofcom will ensure public service channels such as BBC and ITV are available on digital cable and satellite services

Radio

The points system which places limits on ownership of local radio licences may end

There will still be one independent national speech station, and one non-pop music station

Newspapers

Relaxation of rules governing newspaper mergers and takeovers will be considered

Further comment being sought on complex cross-media ownership rules that restrict newspaper groups' ownership of TV or national radio stations, for instance

Telecoms and the internet

Regulation given to Ofcom, replacing Oftel

Strategy to encourage adoption of broadband services and examine if the public sector has further role

More effort to tackle illegal material on the internet

webTitle: How we can stop teenage suicides

fields.headline: How we can stop teenage suicides
fields.standfirst: After the death of two girls in a suicide pact,  Dorothy Rowe  asks: why would teenagers kill themselves and what can we do to stop them?
fields.trailText: After the death of two girls in a suicide pact, Dorothy Rowe asks: why would teenagers kill themselves and what can we do to stop them?
fields.body:
The recently reported death of two teenage girls in a gas-filled car is deeply shocking. Why would two young women, we wonder, choose to die in a suicide pact? Sadly, though, teenage suicide is not rare. After 1945, the rate of teenage suicide around the world began to rise significantly. In more recent years, the rate for young women has levelled out. The rate for young men, however, has continued to rise, possibly because many, faced with a dearth of traditional jobs and roles for men, have felt that society had no place for them.

The legal tradition has been to regard suicide as an act committed when the balance of the mind is disturbed - that is, as a permanent or temporary madness. This formulation does not, of course, explain why a person commits suicide. Suicidal thoughts are considered to be a symptom of depression, but while all depressed people contemplate suicide as a way of escaping their misery, not all depressed people even attempt suicide; and it is by no means certain that everyone who commits suicide is depressed. What is possible is to explain suicide in terms of what it is to be a person.

Each of us is keenly aware of being a person, that which we each call I, myself. This sense of being a person is made up of a structure of all our ideas, attitudes, opinions, memories and feelings. Within this structure are some central ideas about who we are and what our moral stance must be. Our sense of being a person is what we hold most dear, and our every decision and action is aimed in part at preserving our being that person.

But we also strive to survive as a physical body. For most of our lives, surviving as a person and as a body go together. A situation can arise, though, where we have to sacrifice one or the other. Suppose, as a loving parent, you find yourself and your child in some dangerous situation where only one of you can survive. Do you sacrifice yourself or your child? Your choice is simple. You die in order that your child will live. You sacrifice your body in order to continue being what you value most, a loving parent. You know that if you chose otherwise and lived while your child died, you would have failed yourself. This may seem an extreme example, and yet the mechanism is common: many of the people who suffer depression or post-traumatic stress disorder after a disaster believe that the only way they could have continued to be the person they once valued would have been to have died in the disaster.

Some people abandon their bodies when they realise that the world no longer offers them the supports they know are essential to the maintenance of themselves as a person. Some of them simply lose the will to live. Others contract a survivable illness and yet die. Research shows that a significant number of widowers (though, curiously, not widows) die within a year of their wives' deaths.

The will to live can be very strong, and so some people who feel that their situation will not allow them to be themselves choose to kill their body in order to be the person they know themselves to be. If they cannot live as themselves, they will die as themselves. In killing themselves, they leave a message to the world at large and to some, if not all, of their nearest and dearest. Their written message might be: "You will be better off without me." But the subtext is: "You have failed to be what I wanted you to be." Many of the parents of teenage suicides understand that this is the message and torture themselves with guilt.

Guilt is very familiar to parents, aware that none of us is perfect. Teenagers, suicidal or not, make life difficult for parents precisely because children are reluctant to accept that they have less than perfect parents. Part of the process of growing up is learning to accept the fallibility of our parents and the impossibility of the world ever being what we want it to be. When we are teenagers everything matters enormously. Yet in life things rarely turn out the way we expect. We come to accept compromise as wisdom, rather than as a betrayal of ideals. Adults can help teenagers arrive at such wisdom by listening and discussing, while refraining from criticism and instruction.

One common feature of teenage suicide is that the young person felt that there was no one who would listen. The Samaritans offer a special service to teenagers who find they have no one to talk to. Listening to your children is not easy, because you will hear a great deal that you may wish you had not heard, chiefly accounts of your shortcomings. But if you find you can, then you will have given your children the greatest gift: the gift of being listened to and accepted.

 Dorothy Rowe is the author of Breaking the Bonds: Understanding Depression and Finding Freedom (HarperCollins, £9.99).

webTitle: Prince William documentaries boost profile of charity

fields.headline: Prince William documentaries raise charity profile
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Charity Raleigh International has received an eight-fold increase in enquiries following coverage of Prince William's adventures in Chile. By Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Charity Raleigh International has received an 800% increase in enquiries following the media frenzy surrounding Prince William's adventures on the scheme in Chile.

Marketing manager Colin Dutfield said its website received 178,000 page requests immediately following Monday night's special broadcasts on the prince on BBC1 and ITV. Telephone enquiries were up by around a third.

"It's done a fantastic amount of good and helped change the dull old perception that we used to have," said Mr Dutfield.

However, the charity complains that people now believe it is a wealthy charity, which belies the truth.

"We are as poor as we've ever been and we can't invest to broaden the programme," said a spokeswoman.

Raleigh International receives half its £4m annual funding from volunteers, with the rest coming from a mixture of trusts, corporate funding and the National Lottery.

International conglomerate Inchcape recently terminated a five-year deal to support the charity, leaving it desperately seeking a new corporate sponsor.

The charity changed its name from Operation Raleigh to Raleigh International eight years ago in a bid to refresh its image.

webTitle: Leader: Ducking the issue of broadcasting content

fields.headline: A hole in the heart
fields.standfirst:
Ducking the issue of broadcasting content

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Ducking the issue of broadcasting content.
fields.body:
Billed as a joint effort by Stephen Byers and Chris Smith, yesterday's big bang on the telecommunications and broadcasting front echoed with trade and industry concerns. The white paper, in other words, had a lot of dynamic business opportunities and precious little culture.

What is to be shown, heard or distributed gets short shrift. There is nothing here about television or radio programmes to nourish, uplift, extend or challenge. There are, to be fair, glances in the right direction. The BBC may be compelled to restore television news to peak hours - Chris Smith's revenge for being snubbed by the its chairman over the booting upstairs of the Nine O'Clock News.

It is not, either, as if Labour, in its enthusiasm for profit-making in the media, has abandoned "public service". As long as free broadcasting lasts - which, in the shape of the BBC, we must hope it will for a very long time - that invocation of Reithian principle will remain part of the regulatory framework. But this paper gives no clues about what kind of scheduling, programmes or news bulletins the ordinance entails, nor the role of the regulator in securing quality.

Unified regulation of communications has been coming for a while. There cannot be separate regulators for the streamed programming we might soon receive on a telephone handset and the programming - its content perhaps the same - we get over the air on a radio set. But the white paper stops well short of standardisation. The proposed Ofcom will have oversight of films shown on television and the internet while the British Board of Film Classification continues to review the same material for cinema exhibition. An anomaly. Yet the paper does seek general principles to apply to damming, diverting and monitoring the flood of communications, old and new. Sadly, it focuses on the promotion of competition between media companies, as if content were secondary.

But content is about collective identity, the life of mind, politics. As predicted, the weakest part of the paper has to do with media ownership, including newspapers. The government was going to discuss "voice share" as a criterion in judging mergers. But now, on the eve of an election, the Blairites have no desire to provoke the moguls, despite their vituperative treatment of Labour over Europe and other issues. Indeed, the white paper toys with the fashionable theory that market share in the media does not matter: internet pluralism will wash away the sins of concentration. This is nonsense. Media products are not like retail groceries or financial services.

A government as concerned about education as this one should be passionately aware of the educative potential of the media. Over the past eight decades much of that has been carried by the BBC, but there is nothing to be gleaned here about its role or funding, after the current settlement ends. If a single company takes over independent television, we are left in the dark about what its obligations to the public might be, beyond some pabulum about regions and religion.

The paper has green gills. Plenty of time then to seek to strengthen media regulation that does not have Rupert Murdoch firmly in its sights. Joining up the regulation of the internet, mobile phones and so on is important; ditto the transfer from analogue to digital broadcasting. But Samuel Goldwyn's aphorism - if you want to send a message, use Western Union - needs revisiting. Broadcasting is about messages, so a regulatory regime suited to common carriers for whom content is secondary is bound to be deficient.

webTitle: Media message is that it's election time

fields.headline: Media message is that it's election time
fields.standfirst:
Labour plays safe in white paper

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Labour plays safe in white paper
fields.body:
With a general election looming, the communications white paper was always going to be a crowd pleaser. And so it was. Everyone received at least some sop to keep them on side.

For Granada Media and Carlton Communications it was the removal of barriers to the formation of a single company owning the ITV network. The rule limiting audience share to 15% is going, as is the ban on one company owning the weekday and weekend London licence.

Responsibility has been passed to the competition authorities who, by the way, are unlikely to approve a merger of the two in the foreseeable future.

For the radio sector - hope was held out that further consolidation can now take place with the possibility of revoking the current points system. Expect more deals along the lines of SMG's acquisition of 15% of Scottish Radio as the larger groups place their markers down.

The BBC was allowed to keep its governors with their powers intact to claim its continued independence. The commercial sector meanwhile claimed victory as the corporation will come under the broad over-arching remit of the new regulator Ofcom. There's even room for both Oftel boss David Edmonds and Patricia Hodgson of the Independent Television Commission within Ofcom. Instead of an all-powerful director general we are getting a board with a chief executive and a chairman.

Privatisation of Channel 4, which would have been fiercely controversial, was assiduously avoided. For ITN, the government appeared to give the nod for a stock market float by saying it may remove the 20% shareholding restriction.

The uncynical view is, of course, why should the government be criticised for producing a white paper which makes everyone happy?

Yet to suggest that consultation now begins on some of the more sensitive topics, such as cross-media ownership or rules on newspaper mergers is disingenuous. A lengthy consultation process has already taken place, with fulsome contributions from media owners. But then perhaps the government didn't fancy the backlash of allowing Rupert Murdoch a greater share of the media cake.

In many parts the white paper appeared carefully balanced to maintain the status quo while holding out hope for change among the titans, and hope for no change among the minnows keen not to be swallowed up, or those advocating plurality among the press. So, in the end, this was at heart a means of winning votes as much as an attempt to grapple with the changes being wrought on the media and telecoms sectors.

Flight of fancy

The government was also busy avoiding tackling the future of aviation yesterday. With Britons flocking to airports at the rate of an extra 5% a year, transport minister Lord Macdonald might have taken the opportunity to say something sensible on the government's plans as he outlined his strategy yesterday.

Not a bit of it. There are no votes to be won in saying where the next runway is going to be built in the south east or if the government wants to develop regional airports. Instead, he hid behind the excuse that the government cannot plan for the future until deciding what to do over Heathrow's terminal 5. Almost two years after Britain's longest public inquiry, we still have no result. In other words, there will be no decision until after the election.

In the meantime, all Lord Macdonald can do is to exhort the airlines to improve their service to customers, cut down on air rage and make passengers walk about the aircraft to prevent thrombosis.

By 2002, if we are lucky we may get an indication of what the government wants in a white paper, but it is likely to be broad brush stuff. It was left, as usual, to Sir Richard Branson to provide the only talking point when he suggested that the Treasury could recoup £10bn through an auction of landing slots at Heathrow and Gatwick over a 10-year franchise. And the money raised would go towards funding vital airport improvements. How fanciful.

Bourse poker

It is clear that a serious game of poker is being played out between the world's major bourses. If Don Cruickshank, chairman of the London Stock Exchange, thinks Nasdaq is bluffing in its implicit threat to link with Deutsche Börse if it cannot cut a deal with London, then he is playing an extremely dangerous game. What is more, London's army of small stockbrokers, who hold the votes in deciding the LSE future, better sit up and take notice.

If the Americans are allowed to sulk away to Frankfurt and, if they manage to cut a deal and if they get to the market nirvana of seamless highly automated cross-border trading first, then a lot of small brokers over here are going to be out of work (or learning German).

There are lots of "ifs" here, but the risks are real and immediate.

In the meantime, all Lord Macdonald can do is to exhort the airlines to improve their service to customers, cut down on air rage and make passengers walk about the aircraft to prevent thrombosis. By 2002, if we are lucky we may get an indication of what the government wants in a white paper, but it is likely to be broad brush stuff. It was left, as usual, to Sir Richard Branson to provide the only talking point when he suggested that the Treasury could recoup £10bn through an auction of landing slots at Heathrow and Gatwick over a 10-year franchise. And the money raised would go towards funding vital airport improvements. How fanciful. Bourse poker It is clear that a serious game of poker is being played out between the world's major bourses. If Don Cruickshank, chairman of the London Stock Exchange, thinks Nasdaq is bluffing in its implicit threat to link with Deutsche Börse if it cannot cut a deal with London, then he is playing an extremely dangerous game. What is more, London's army of small stockbrokers, who hold the votes in deciding the LSE future, better sit up and take notice. If the Americans are allowed to sulk away to Frankfurt and, if they manage to cut a deal and if they get to the market nirvana of seamless highly automated cross-border trading first, then a lot of small brokers over here are going to be out of work (or learning German). There are lots of "ifs" here, but the risks are real and immediate.

webTitle: Channel 4 chief welcomes 'lighter touch' regulation

fields.headline: Channel 4 chief welcomes 'lighter touch' regulation
fields.standfirst: Click here for latest on white paper
fields.trailText:
8.15am: Channel 4 boss Michael Jackson has welcomed plans for a more "positive" regulatory structure under yesterday's white paper, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Click here for latest on white paper
fields.body:
Channel 4 chief executive Michael Jackson has welcomed plans to move towards a more "positive" regulatory structure under yesterday's communications white paper.

He told MediaGuardian.co.uk: "We welcome the idea of responsible freedom, a lighter touch and an end to box ticking".

But he added that Channel 4 would not be shirking the responsibilities given to it under its original charter, of "encouraging innovation and experiment".

Under the plans set out in the white paper, the broadcaster's remit is to be reviewed by the DCMS before the bill becomes law.

After that point Channel 4 will be required to update its regulatory requirements, consulting with the DCMS on its regulatory strategy.

Under the new structure, Channel 4 will have more control over programming decisions concerning taste and decency, privacy, news and current affairs and regional content.

Mr Jackson denied that that the use of the word "positive" would allow Channel 4 a softer regulatory ride.

"It means we have to be clear about that which we are providing and can come forward and say it, rather than having to be assessed after the event."

He said that the forthcoming digital Channel E4 would be subject to the same regulatory requirements as Channel 4.

The new white paper recommends a three-tier regulatory structure, taking into account the need for different levels of regulation for different broadcasters and media companies.

webTitle: Livingstone launches London transport ad push

fields.headline: Livingstone launches London transport ad push
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Ken Livingstone has hired Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper to launch an ad campaign to encourage Londoners to have their say over transport. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone has hired Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper to launch a major advertising campaign to encourage Londoners to have their say over transport.

The campaign, which kicks off next year, will ask Londoners to submit their views on the mayor's plans for the capital's transport system.

People will be encouraged to reply to a consultation document on transport entitled "Hearing London's Views". The Greater London Authority is legally required to consult Londoners on its strategy for the transport system.

A series of poster and radio ads will spell out what the GLA has planned for the capital's transport, covering everything from London's buses to the proposed congestion charges.

The six-week campaign launches in February and will use humour to get the message across.

Among the proposals are a £43m investment in London's buses and a £68m programme of improvements for London's roads.

webTitle: Big employers lead flight from Equitable Life

fields.headline: Big employers lead flight from Equitable Life
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest employers were leading the exit from Equitable Life yesterday as it emerged that up to 1m people, mainly in company pension schemes, are affected by the crisis facing the insurer.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest employers were leading the exit from Equitable Life yesterday as it emerged that up to 1m people, mainly in company pension schemes, are affected by the crisis facing the insurer.

BT, the BBC, BP, Sainsbury's, Unilever, the Post Office and many local authorities and police forces are among the employers that set up pension schemes with Equitable Life. Many are close to cancelling further contributions and switching to other insurers.

A BT spokeswoman said: "We are in urgent discussions with Equitable Life about the BT additional voluntary contributions scheme." West Yorkshire Pension Fund, which covers local authority workers in the region, said: "Equitable Life of their own admission say that investment returns will be falling. Obviously we are now reviewing whether they should be our AVC provider and hope to make an announcement to staff in the new year."

Staff pension departments have been inundated with calls from worried employees. "We have had hundreds of people calling. We are currently in the process of selecting a new provider," said Hampshire county council pensions department.

Around 700,000 people are members of the 7,000 employer schemes provided by Equitable Life, although not all are with-profits schemes. Almost two-thirds of the FTSE 100 companies have a group pension arrangement with the insurer. This is in addition to the 650,000 people who hold individual policies.

William M Mercer, one of the largest employee benefits consultancies, said about three-quarters of its client companies, including many household names, have AVC schemes affected by the crisis.

Gordon Pollock of Mercer said it was recommending employees suspend contributions to with-profits AVC schemes run by Equitable Life. Company pension schemes should hold contributions on deposit "until the position is a bit clearer and they have had the opportunity to talk to individual members".

But others said companies would struggle to deal with inquiries. "It's almost impossible to give general guidance to employees who are in very different individual positions," said Grant Thornton financial planning manager Ian Johnson.

webTitle: New hearing for slap case head

fields.headline: New hearing for slap case head
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared on appeal of slapping a 10-year-old pupil, is to face a disciplinary hearing before school governors.
fields.body:
Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared on appeal of slapping a 10-year-old pupil, is to face a disciplinary hearing before school governors.

The National Union of Teachers said Mrs Evans was the victim of "double jeopardy" after governors at her school, St Mary's junior in Caldicot, Monmouthshire, announced the move yesterday. She has not returned to the school since being suspended in September 1999 and could still face the sack.

Following a three-hour meeting on Monday night, a statement released by Monmouthshire county council said the governors had considered "issues relating to allegations of inappropriate behaviour at the school".

The disciplinary hearing would "consider all issues arising from the investigatory files".

Further allegations have been made against her by staff and pupils.

But Gethin Lewis, secretary of NUT Wales, said: "Even now Marjorie Evans has no idea what the allegations are against her.

"Can you imagine a situation like this happening anywhere else? When a person is told they are to face a disciplinary procedure they should be told why. We are surmising that the allegations are the same ones that she was interviewed over by the police earlier this autumn - but we are just guessing."

He added: "The main issue here is that Marjorie is innocent. All teachers are under this double jeopardy situation. They are cleared in a court but are then open to be forced to relive the whole ordeal as part of an internal disciplinary procedure."

In July Mrs Evans was found guilty of assaulting the boy, but she was cleared in September. Police continued to investigate claims against her but in October the crown prosecution service said it would not be taking any further action.

Mrs Evans said yesterday she planned to write a book about her experiences once the case was over.

"There will be a time and a place, I am sure, when my side of the tale will be able to be told. I certainly have enough notes and information to be able to write a book and it's something I am seriously looking at doing.

"It all depends on whether I have the energy to do it but the support that I know is out there keeps me going."

The Prince of Wales has arranged to meet Mrs Evans at his Highgrove estate after expressing "heartfelt sympathy" for her plight.

Graham Powell, a former chairman of governors who supports Mrs Evans, said: "How many times must one person stand trial for the same offence? The phrase witch-hunt springs to mind - but it is not strong enough."

webTitle: George W Bush: key policies

fields.headline: George W Bush: key policies
fields.standfirst:
Special report: US election race

Now America finally has a president elect in the form of George W Bush, we look at his key policies.
fields.trailText: Now America finally has a president elect in the form of George W Bush, we look at his key policies.
fields.body:
Abortion
The president elect opposes abortions except in cases of rape, incest or to save the life of the pregnant woman. He would sign legislation outlawing "partial birth" abortion, cut federal funds for family planning services and ban overseas aid for abortion services.

The issue of abortion became very important before the election because of similarities between the candidates on other areas. Al Gore supported abortion and a woman's right to choose.
18 October: Barbara Bush sent in to win swing on abortion

Defence
Mr Bush has pledged to increase defence spending and give military personnel better pay and conditions. On missile defence, he would pursue ambitious programmes to protect US and allies from rogue nations. He would retain the "don't ask, don't tell" approach to the issue of gays in the armed forces.

The US should, he says, make big reductions in its nuclear arsenal, unilaterally if necessary - regardless of what Russia does. Mr Bush believes that the US must build its infamous "son of star wars" national missile defence system, NMD, hotly opposed by Russia, China and all of Europe.

As a sweetener for the programme, however, he says that Europe and Israel would benefit from NMD's protection. It would be an allied matter and even Japan could be covered.

But some scientists believe NMD - based on missiles knocking out incoming missiles - may never work well enough to justify its $60bn (£40bn) costs. Mr Bush argues it will leave the US better protected against "rogue states" host of potentially missile-wielding new enemies (North Korea, Iran, Iraq).
25 May: Comment - Bush 's missile project is insane
8 November: Stay at home Bush no friend of foreign affairs

Environment
Mr Bush's election victory is a disaster for the planet, according to green activists. He opposes the Kyoto treaty, would give tax breaks for controversial ethanol use and supports state efforts to reduce pollution from coal-fired power stations.

He also supports opening the Alaska reserve to oil and gas exploration. Mr Gore supported Kyoto and would have protected Alaska and introduced tax breaks for environmentally friendly homes, cars and businesses.

Critics of Mr Bush say he seems to know little, and care less, about non-military global threats such as climate change, desertification, Aids, population growth, poverty in the developing world and third world debt.
20 November: Analysis: Unless the winner wakes up to global warming, we'll all be the losers

Taxes
Mr Bush's tax plans formed the centrepiece of his election platform. He proposes to cut $483bn of taxes over five years, which he says would simplify the income tax system eliminating one bracket. He would cut tax rates for all Americans, increase child credits and phase out the estate tax.

But Mr Bush's detractors say his tax plans are reckless and inflationary and could stop the American economic "miracle" in its tracks and ultimately trigger a worldwide recession.

Mr Bush's policies appear to be geared without discrimination in favour of the rich. Mr Gore promised less than half the amount of tax cuts as Mr Bush, with the Democrats being mainly subsidies to middle and working class families.

Mr Bush will start privatising social security, while Mr Gore would have spent $400bn on health care - insurance for the low-paid and free drugs for the elderly. Mr Bush says he will spend a quarter of that.
22 January: Bush stakes all on promise to half taxes

Healthcare
Mr Bush wants to reduce the number of people without insurance by subsidising their ability to buy private coverage. He would expand medical savings accounts and make the cost of long-term care tax deductible. Mr Gore had promised to move closer to universal coverage.

Mr Bush supports US military disengagement in the Balkans and still regards China and Russia as potential enemies.

He is seen by critics as allied to rightwing unilateralists or neo-isolationists, who undermine the UN, ridicule concepts of nation-building, cut the foreign aid budget, wage trade wars and block or emasculate international treaties.

Democrats say Mr Bush would besiege and bully out-of-favour countries with sanctions and threats, and that he believes European allies are not pulling their weight.
1 November: Would he do what he did in Texas?

Education
While Mr Gore favoured spending $115bn on educatio over the next 10 years - a 50% rise in an area traditionally left to states and localities - Mr Bush wants to rearrange school structures rather than spend anything like that kind of money.

He has, however, declared a passion for education investment. Congress, Mr Bush has said, should not balance the budget "on the backs of the poor".
24 July: Education, education, education

Guns
It is unlikely that Mr Bush will alter gun policies one jot. The vice president elect, Dick Cheney, is also against any ban on handguns. Mr Gore had promised a crackdown on handgun ownership, arguing too many were falling into the hands of children and criminals.
4 November: Gun lobby to spend $10m fighting Gore
