webTitle: Bush's transitional cabinet

fields.headline: Bush's transitional cabinet
fields.standfirst:
Mark Oliver looks at the likely key figures in the Bush government

Special report: US election
fields.trailText: Mark Oliver looks at the likely key figures in the Bush government.
fields.body:
George W Bush has held back on naming his cabinet, but the following are people who have been tipped to be key figures in his administration and the transition to power.

Dick Cheney: Mr Bush's running mate is the only figure who is guaranteed to be in the cabinet. Despite suffering a minor heart attack last month - his fourth - he has been in charge of the transition to power. Mr Cheney was defence secretary in the earlier Bush administration.
Dick Cheney profile

General Colin Powell: Widely expected to be Mr Bush's secretary of state. Gen Powell was chairman of the joint chiefs of staff under his father.
Colin Powell biography

Condoleezza Rice: Mr Bush's defence and foreign policy adviser during the campaign, who is tipped to be national security adviser. She was Mr Bush senior's chief Russian specialist.
Condoleeza Rice's home page

Andrew Card: He has been designated White House chief of staff. Mr Card was deputy chief of staff to John Sununu in former president George Bush's administration, and then transportation secretary. He has been Mr Cheney's right hand man in dealing with transition issues.

Larry Lindsey: Expected to be given top economic job. He was the special presidential assistant for policy development in the previous Bush administration.

Katherine Harris: The woman at the fulcrum of the election dispute in Florida has reportedly been sounded out for a role in a putative Bush transition team. The Florida secretary of state has become an icon of Democrat demonology for refusing to accept recounted votes received after a deadline. But she is said to have been asked to consider taking on the task of adviser on Latin American affairs if Mr Bush becomes president-elect, working with the team that would prepare for his administration.
Official Florida biography

webTitle: Bush in quotes

fields.headline: Bush in quotes
fields.standfirst:
Plenty of people have an opinion on Dubya. We present a small selection

Special report: US election
fields.trailText: Plenty of people have an opinion on Dubya. We present a small selection.
fields.body:
Hunter S Thompson, writer and journalist, said: "The whole Bush family, from Texas, should be boiled in poison oil."

Jay Mcinerney, US novelist, said: "Bush wants to cut taxes across the board, meaning that the bulk of tax relief would go to the wealthiest taxpayers."

An anonymous, senior White House aide said that a Bush administration would be "the restoration of the aristocracy, motivated by revenge and greed."

Maureen Dowd, a New York Times columnist, has dubbed Mr Bush "president-elect mini-me", after the cloned villain of the Austin Powers movies.

George Bush Senior, the former US president, said before one of the string of key court decision's: "Whatever happens this time, my pride and Barbara's pride knows no bounds."

John Ellis, Mr Bush's cousin, says that there exists an "old man's network" that is hoping to benefit from Mr Bush coming to power. He said: "It is probably 50,000 people, and they were looking for some kind of vindication. I don't think you can possibly overrate the hatred of Bill Clinton in the Republican party."

An anonymous Texan Democrat consultant described Mr Bush as "the boy in the bubble of infotainment."

Andrew Gumbel, of the Independent, said: "Just how wild was the young George W Bush, exactly? Did he sniff cocaine? Did he sleep around and get young women pregnant? Did he use his wealth, his privileged background and the connections of his politician father to cover up for his more excessive behaviour? And, if he did, how bad does it need to have been before people worry about his suitability for high public office?"

Johnny Paul Penry, who is on death row in Texas for rape and murder and whose case has been used by opponents of Mr Bush, said: "I think it's a cruel thing to do, to put me to sleep."

webTitle: Comment: A nation divided

fields.headline: A nation divided
fields.standfirst: The bile of the battle for the presidency has exposed the disunity of the United States
fields.trailText: The bile of the battle for the presidency has exposed the disunity of the United States.
fields.body:
The Clinton farewell tour, now on the road in Ireland, is proof of what all the craziness of the past few months has been about - and why it was worth it. The moment Air Force One touched down on the Dublin tarmac, the waves of Clinton charisma rippling outward, you could see why the White House is still the biggest prize on the planet, why it's been worth haggling over, even for 36 legalistic and rancorous days.

For an American president can still make an enormous difference. Bill Clinton may have sipped Guinness in Dublin and tapped his toe to Danny Boy in Dundalk for his own reasons - as he joked earlier in the day, there are 45m Irish-Americans back home and the president likes keeping them happy - but that takes nothing away from the impact he makes wherever he goes. Whether it's filling Ireland's once-hostile communities with pre-Christmas cheer, or watching as Ethiopia and Eritrea sign a conflict-ending accord - as Mr Clinton's chief diplomat, Madeleine Albright did in Algiers yesterday - the mere presence of the United States can make the difference between war and peace.

Late yesterday both Al Gore and George W Bush waited to hear which one of them would inherit that responsibility. Perhaps they flicked through the cable channels, pausing to see the live pictures from Ireland which briefly interrupted the news vigil outside the US supreme court, wondering if they would ever have the chance to work the same magic. Will I, they might have asked themselves, be able to lead like that?

The plain answer is no. The campaign made clear that neither man has the political gifts of the president they sought to replace. Bush doesn't have his brains, Gore lacks his warmth - and neither has as much of either quality as Clinton has of both. As Peter Mandelson said of the outgoing president yesterday, "I think he is a one-off. He is a cross between a thoroughly charming, charismatic human being and a political computer." Coming from the political calculator himself, that was praise indeed.

But personality is not the whole story: Clinton, too, was once seen as callow and unfit for the job. What makes a mere politician look presidential? Becoming president. If Bush had secured a clear win on November 7, people might now be praising his subtle, creative intellect. If Gore had been the instant victor, it would have been a matter of days before observers praised his ability to connect with people.

No, the prime problem confronting the next president is not his own limita tions, so much as the terrain he inherits. For all the opportunities a US president has to play globe-trotting peacemaker, his prime task is to lead the American people. And it is that job which looks much more daunting now than it did when Clinton took over eight years ago.

For the United States is fast looking like an oxymoron. It is currently disunited, split in every institution through which the nation expresses itself.

Start with the presidency. By now the healing alchemy of the transition period should have done its work, magically turning the partisan victor of November into the national head of state by January. Instead the president of 2001 will raise his right hand while half the nation shakes its fist - angered at what they regard as a stolen election.

Or stroll down Pennsylvania Avenue to Congress where you will find Republicans and Democrats separated in the House of Representatives by just five votes. Walk along the corridor, where the senate is split exactly 50-50. Out in the country, state legislatures are equally divided: of the 50 states, Republicans control both chambers in 17, with 16 in the hands of Democrats. All the rest are deadlocked.

Even the judges are split. Florida's highest court ruled for Gore last week by four votes to three, only to be rapidly overturned by the US supreme court which divided 5-4. Add them up and you get 16 senior judges, split exactly 8-8.

This has left many Americans with a sense of despair, as if every institution they have is divided against itself, usually on tribal, partisan lines. That pessimism may be a tad excessive. All seven members of Florida's supreme court were appointed by Democratic governors - yet three of them sided last week against Gore. Equally, two of the four Washington supremes who went against Bush last Saturday were appointed by Republican presidents - one of them by Bush's father.

Still, even if partisanship is not yet an all-consuming disease, the division is real enough. November's was the closest election in US history, not just in Florida but everywhere. Gore's final victory margin in New Mexico was less than 400 votes; his edge in the entire country just 300,000 out of 100m votes, three-tenths of 1%. The country was genuinely torn - reflected by a Washington that is more split than at any time since the 1870s.

But here lies the riddle. America's previous periods of great political division were matched by vast cultural rifts. The nation was split not just by electoral arithmetic but in hard, bloody fact. So the photo-finish election of 1876 was an after-shock of the civil war of a decade earlier. The same is true of the impeachment crisis of that same period, which saw Abraham Lincoln's successor, Andrew Johnson, survive an attempt to remove him from office by a single senate vote.

In our own time, the symptoms are identical - impeachment rapidly fol lowed by a bitterly contested election - but what is the disease? What cultural divide will future historians blame for the institutional rupture of today?

It's a puzzle, if only because Washington's institutions were much less split during periods of far greater civil unease - say the McCarthyite wars of the 1950s or the generational, sexual and racial upheavals of the 1960s - than they are today. What great gash is it that tears America apart in these peaceful, prosperous days of the early 21st century?

The answer may be in what the failed, rightwing candidate Pat Buchanan calls the culture wars. For today's America is indeed a land of two nations. One favours gun ownership, opposes abortion rights, seeks the pre-eminence of Christianity, thinks America should do less in the world and lives mainly in the South and the countryside. It wears a stetson hat and looks like George W Bush.

The other seeks gun control, wants women to have the right to choose, celebrates ethnic diversity, looks beyond America's shores and lives mainly in the cities and on the continent's east and west coasts. It has gay friends, watches Seinfeld and voted for Al Gore.

The interminable election campaign that began in July 1999 and ended last month revealed almost none of this: both candidates lavished all their attention instead on the handful of "swing voters" who live in the middle, sandwiched between the two Americas. But the 36-day post-election campaign, with all its partisan bile and distrust, has revealed it all too clearly. America is a land divided; and not even the supreme court, in all its wisdom, can hide that now.

webTitle: Comment: Worse off, 2,000 years on

fields.headline: Worse off, 2,000 years on
fields.standfirst:
I have no figures about Egyptian asylum policy at the dawning of the first millennium, but nowhere can I find evidence of Joseph being held in detention.

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: I have no figures about Egyptian asylum policy at the dawning of the first millennium, but nowhere can I find evidence of Joseph being held in detention.
fields.body:
And when they [the Wise Men] were departed, behold the angel of the Lord appeareth to Joseph in a dream, saying, "Arise, and take the young child and his mother, and flee to Egypt, and be thou there until I bring thee word: for Herod will seek the young child to destroy him." (Matthew 2:13).

I have no figures about Egyptian asylum policy at the dawning of the first millennium, but nowhere can I find evidence of Joseph being held in detention. Nobody appears to have interrogated him, with or without an interpreter, about the family's reasons for flight. No one questioned him as to whether they had a well-founded fear of persecution or whether the carpentry trade was just slack in Judaea. No one wrote in the Cairo Advertiser that the slaughter of the innocents had been greatly exaggerated or that it was a civil war in which the babies were as much to blame as the Romans.

It seems that the Egyptians of 2,000 years ago had a more humane approach to refugees than does New Labour. What Jack Straw thinks of Herod's crackdown on potential young offenders is harder to assess. One might hope that, as a Christian of Jewish descent, Straw would be wary. But Herod was reacting to the possible emergence of a national liberation leader, so it seems likely that Straw would view the targeting of all boys under two as an imaginative piece of anti- terrorist legislation.

One thing we do know about the birth of Jesus was that he was given extremely boring presents by the so-called wise men. Joseph's tax affairs (his whole reason for schlepping his emergent family to Bethlehem) must have been thrown into disarray by the sudden acquisition of gold that would be very hard to account for. But Mary must have been a bit new age to favour a straw birth, so probably believed in aromatherapy and enjoyed the frankincense. Whether myrrh guards against nappy rash I don't know. The shepherds appear only in Luke and don't appear to have brought anything, but they were sore afraid by the angel of the Lord and probably a bit freaked out by the whole thing.

Two millennia on, we know that children need to be stimulated, to play. I say, "we" but apparently there are some who doubt this. The national asylum support service, a shadowy Home Office agency charged with making refugees' lives as miserable as possible, defines toys as "non-essential items". It is commendable, therefore, that the TUC is collecting and distributing toys to refugee children this Christmas. It is regrettable that union leaders were persuaded not to humiliate the government over the voucher scheme at the Labour party conference.

Many of us will be sending vouchers to nieces, nephews and godchildren at the moment, expressly because we want them to be able to buy a toy. It might be unimaginative in our time-poor culture merely to weigh up whether Smiths or Woolworths is the more festive place to spend a gift token, but at least we are hoping that the kids end up with something fun. Barbara Roche appears to consider toys to be frivolous trifles. Perhaps she distributes small boxes of fish fingers to the younger members of her family.

Roche is currently engaged in a "review", not of the principle of forcing refugees to live on vouchers with a value substantially lower than the level of income support, but of the way the scheme operates. This is less than was hoped for when the union revolt was headed off, and perhaps means that, after the deadline for submissions on the 22nd, an announcement will be slipped out over Christmas to the effect that supermarkets will no longer be able to pocket the change. The supermarkets are being canvassed for their views and I'm sure are heartily in favour of pocketing the change, but will still be glad of the captive market the vouchers assure them. Perhaps the review is actually a look at extending the scheme to other benefit claimants.

Meanwhile in this season of goodwill, the government is busily jailing as many refugees as it can. It has quietly ordered 500 new prison places to be set aside for them in the run-up to Christmas. There are now 75 places in HMP Belmarsh, with its 23-hour lock-up regime, and 60 in the notorious Wandsworth.

And 38% of asylum decisions are now refusals for "non-compliance" - meaning that refugees failed to fill in the 20-page standard evidence form on time, complete in every detail and in English. This figure has increased fourfold since January, and means people can be banged-up pending deportation without their cases even being considered.

No toys, then, but perhaps a visit to Daddy in jail will be a Christmas treat for the children of those who flee to Britain.

webTitle: Fears over radioactive particle

fields.headline: Fears over radioactive particle
fields.standfirst: Special report: Britain's nuclear industry
fields.trailText: The government's Scottish environment watchdog has demanded an urgent investigation after a highly radioactive particle was found near the Dounreay nuclear plant.
fields.body:
The government's Scottish environment watchdog has demanded an urgent investigation after a highly radioactive particle was found near the Dounreay nuclear plant.

Twelve radioactive particles have been found around the Caithness facility in the past year, but the latest had a higher level of radioactivity and was discovered in an area thought clear of contamination.

The material was found on December 4 near Dounreay Castle, an area accessible to the public with company permission, during part of a six-monthly monitoring programme carried out by the UK Atomic Energy Authority. The Scottish Environment Protection Agency said the find was a "significant development" because it appeared to rule out the theory that particles discovered over recent years had been washed up by the sea.

The theory of sea to land transfers of radioactive material stems from an incident in the 1960s which led to huge numbers of particles being washed down on to the seabed.

The Scottish environment agency said the UKAEA should now launch an urgent, detailed investigation into how the particle came to be deposited.

Lorraine Mann of the campaigning group Scotland Against Nuclear Dumping said the discovery was "possibly the worst and most understated leak from a nuclear plant in the developed world".

She added: "This is a devastating discovery and UKAEA must now be prosecuted for their ongoing negligence. Dounreay management's blind insistence on the seabed as the source of particles is nothing more than a transparent ruse to shield UKAEA from prosecution for their crass incompetence in allowing these deadly particles to continue to escape."

The campaigners believe that the latest particle was not present when the area around the castle was "stripped" and decontaminated a few years ago, and that therefore it must have turned up since then.

In a statement the UKAEA said it had acted properly over the discovery of the particle and kept the public informed. It said the position of the particle did not invalidate its extensive research over recent years, but that the company would look again at other possible pollution routes.

The statement read: "All the evidence so far suggests particles are washed on to the beaches from the offshore cache, although we continue to keep alternative options under review. UKAEA is undertaking a comprehensive programme of investigation into the occurrence of particles, and has engaged leading national experts to add to our understanding. We are making all the information...available to the expert group which advises [the Scottish Environment Protection Agency] on the particles issue. We are working hard to establish the route by which particles reach the environment, with the aim of protecting the public."

In October the authority unveiled details of the 60-year, £4bn plan to decommission Dounreay. All the main radiological hazards of the plant are supposed to be removed within 25 years, but the UKAEA has admitted that parts of the site will have to remain off limits for up to 300 years.

webTitle: Security fears greater than usual

fields.headline: Security fears greater than usual
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: President Clinton's visit to Northern Ireland will be over in a day, but has taken security advisers and police months of planning.
fields.body:
President Clinton's visit to Northern Ireland will be over in a day, but has taken security advisers and police months of planning.

Officials will not say so, but the uncertainty over Mr Clinton's successor is making them particularly edgy about security in a country struggling to save its peace process. No doubt they will heave a sigh of relief when Air Force One takes off from Belfast this afternoon.

The first tentative arrangements would have been made months ago by the RUC in tandem with Secret Service staff from the US and their permanent office in London. But even as they waited for the presidential helicopter to land at Belfast City Airport last night, they were aware that the plans could be altered at any minute.

Mr Clinton was due to land in a private area of the airport before being whisked along closed routes to his hotel.

"All venues are thoroughly searched prior to his visit, with police maintaining a presence," said an RUC source. "The routes taken by his entourage are closed while it is travelling along them, although we try to keep disruption to a minimum."

He added: "It's very much a case of working together. Don't forget, it's his third visit so we've built up close contacts with his officers."

The president's cavalcade is brought over from the States and includes motorcycle outriders and "road-runners" - secure communications vans - as well as his armoured Lincoln. Bomb-sniffing dogs, snipers and commandos will accompany him (he even took his bulletproof lectern on a visit to China). Security service agents preceded him over a week ago.

Inevitably, the task of guarding Mr Clinton is made harder by his penchant for pressing the flesh. He will address 8,000 people in a major speech at the city's new Odyssey Arena this afternoon.

Around 1,000 uniformed and plain-clothed police were involved in his visit to Dublin yesterday and a similar number will be on duty in Belfast. Clinton's last visit in 1998 landed the country with a £2.5m security bill, with 700 officers deployed in Omagh alone.

A spokesman for the US Secret Service yesterday played down the difficulties his agency faced. "We are certainly aware of issues wherever we go," he said. "But the challenges we face are very similar to those when he visits a city in the States. We have to plan for any scenario you could imagine."

webTitle: The long goodbye of Bill Clinton, an Irish hero

fields.headline: The long goodbye of Bill Clinton, an Irish hero
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: US President Bill Clinton yesterday began an emotional farewell to Ireland, the country he hopes will bear lasting testimony to his efforts as peacemaker.
fields.body:
US President Bill Clinton yesterday began an emotional farewell to Ireland, the country he hopes will bear lasting testimony to his efforts as peacemaker.

The outgoing president, his wife Hillary and daughter Chelsea received a rapturous welcome in Dublin and in the border town of Dundalk, on the first day of a two-day tour.

But while breakthrough is not expected during talks with key politicians in Belfast today, the president urged all sides not to give up trying to overcome the deadlock between Unionists and Republicans over decommissioning and demilitarisation.

"We've got to keep going, reversal is not an option," said Mr Clinton. "The people want this to go on and I think the leaders have to find a way through the last three or four difficult issues and I think it can be done."

London, Dublin and Washington have played down hopes of major progress during this visit but they are optimistic Mr Clinton could provide the catalyst to create a better climate for agreement in the next few weeks.

Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson said: "President Clinton will help give people the confidence to move forward together.

"He is a cross between a thoroughly charming, charismatic man and a political computer. I don't think we would have the peace process we do if we didn't have Bill Clinton."

Mr Clinton has not ruled out the idea of coming back to Northern Ireland as some sort of peace envoy after he leaves office and said: "If I can be a resource I will."

The Clinton charm and humour was evident when he joked: "When I started my involvement with the Irish peace process, to put it charitably, half the political experts in my country thought I'd lost my mind.

"After some of the all-night talk sessions I had I thought I'd lost my mind."

After being welcomed to Dublin by the Irish president, Mary McAleese, and the prime minister, Bertie Ahern, he met politicians before giving a speech to around 2,000 people at the Guinness brewery.

He sipped some of the black stuff at Mr Ahern's local pub, Fagan's, before greeting wellwishers and buying some Christmas gifts with Hillary and Chelsea in the city's fashionable shopping streets.

But underneath all the joviality, there is a serious and passionate message about the process he has been closely involved with during the eight years of his presidency.

This is his third visit to Ireland, he is the only serving US president to go to Northern Ireland, and he has kept in regular contact with all the key players in the peace process, phoning them with encouragement in the vital hours leading up to the signing of the Good Friday agreement two years ago.

The fact that he chose the dissident Republican stronghold of Dundalk to deliver a keynote speech is also being read as a powerful signal of his call for everyone to leave violence behind and move forward together.

Sinn Fein is urging the government to scale down security in nearby South Armagh but sources said this was unlikely while the threat from dissidents remained.

Republicans are also furious at Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble's ban on its ministers attending cross-border institutions set up under the Good Friday agreement and they will challenge the veto in court in Belfast this Friday.

But Mr Trimble insists his ban is justified because of the IRA's failure to re-engage with General John de Chastelaine's decommissioning body and make serious progress towards getting rid of its weapons.

Mr Clinton and the British prime minister Tony Blair are discussing these stumbling blocks with Mr Trimble, Mr Adams and other political leaders at Stormont today.

webTitle: Business: Rain helps to produce a dismal crop of inflation figures

fields.headline: Rain helps to produce a dismal crop of inflation figures
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Britain's dismal autumn weather is starting to have an impact on inflation, with supply problems caused by flooding pushing up the price of food, according to official figures yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's dismal autumn weather is starting to have an impact on inflation, with supply problems caused by flooding pushing up the price of food, according to official figures yesterday.

Seasonal food prices rose by 4% last month and government statisticians believe further increases may be in prospect as a result of crops being left in the ground. Potato prices have been particularly affected by the rain, and are 8% up on a year ago.

Yesterday's data showed the higher cost of seasonal food offset by the supermarket price war, but dearer petrol meant the annual inflation rate pushed higher last month.

The all-items retail prices index rose by 3.2% in the year to November, compared with a 3.1% increase the previous month. The government's preferred measure of inflation, the RPI excluding mortgage interest payments, edged up from 2% to 2.2%, but remained below Gordon Brown's 2.5% target for the 20th month in a row. On an internationally comparable basis, Britain's inflation rate is 1%, the lowest in the European Union.

Analysts believe the drop in petrol prices over the past few weeks and alcohol price-cutting in the run-up to Christmas will lead to inflation falling back in December. The fact that last year's mortgage rate increase has not been repeated will also have a downward effect on the all-items rate.

Jonathan Loynes, chief UK economist at Capital Economics, said there was nothing in the figures to frighten the Bank of England into raising interest rates. He added that if petrol prices on garage forecourts continued to fall in response to the falling price of crude oil, it was possible that underlying inflation would drop to 1.5%, the level at which the Bank's governor, Sir Edward George, would have to write a letter of explanation to the chancellor.

The detailed breakdown of the RPI showed a stark difference between the inflation rate for goods and services. Core goods (excluding food, petrol and alcohol & tobacco) are 2.4% cheaper than a year ago, while shop services (including catering, repairs, domestic and personal services) are rising by 3.9%. Non-shop services such as insurance and foreign holidays rose 6.4% on the year.

webTitle: Real powers behind bid for the dome

fields.headline: Real powers behind bid for the dome
fields.standfirst:
Controversial Irish property tycoons are driving force of firm hoping to buy site

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Controversial Irish property tycoons are driving force of firm hoping to buy site
fields.body:
The £125m bid for the Millennium Dome by businessman Robert Bourne has been presented to the public as the story of a Labour donor turning one of the government's greatest embarrassments into a useful and successful site.

But, in fact, it is the vehicle for two very ambitious Irish property tycoons to get a chunk of London's real estate using Mr Bourne as the front door.

Despite being cleared by the Cabinet Office's official scrutineers to become the government's "preferred bidder" for the site, their reputation in Dublin is highly contentious.

Richard Barrett and John Ronan - the two developers behind the Irish company Treasury Holdings - are the real owners of Legacy and will be putting up 80% of the cash to transform the dome site into "Knowledge City".

Mr Barrett, 46, a lawyer, and Mr Ronan, 47, an accountant, have been accused of being "deliberate liars" in the Irish parliament and have been involved in 38 legal actions in the past six years.

John Ronan is a stocky, bearded figure with a taste for erotic sculpture. Richard Barrett is a tall, suave charmer. Both are very sharp businessmen who have seen their property business move from handling small-scale office developments to schemes totalling £800m. They hold directorships in 89 companies and have been involved in a spate of controversial developments in Dublin. They also have a reputation for being highly litigious.

Last year they were denounced as "deliberate liars" in the Irish parliament over they way they lobbied for an amendment to a government bill which would have provided substantial financial benefits for their business interests.

Like Mr Bourne they are donors to political parties. Armani-suited Mr Bourne has given more than £60,000 to Labour, including about £6,000 to culture secretary Chris Smith's Islington South party.

Treasury's joint venture company, Castlemarket Holdings, gave £1,000 last year to the re-election campaign of Fianna Fail senator and Dun Laoghaire Rathdown councillor Don Lydon when he had a consultative role in an important Dublin shopping centre planning decision.

They have also given cash to the Progressive Democrats, Fianna Fail itself, a £10,000 to Labour leader Ruairi Quinn in 1997, and £1,000 to the Irish minister for foreign affairs, David Andrews.

In Dublin they became involved in a £1bn re-development of the city's docks on land owned by Ireland's nationalised transport company.

The aim was to build a prestige convention centre with subsidised offices surrounding the attraction. However the scheme is now back on the drawing board.

Furious

It has generated a huge row in parliament after Treasury lobbied for a change in the law to open up the Irish electricity market to private companies running combined heat and power stations. Parliamentarians were furious when they discovered that claims by Treasury that they had to build a £17m power station to supply the centre were not true. Treasury accused the electricity board of being "corporatist thugs" and were in turn accused by an Irish MP of being "deliberate liars". The law was not changed.

The company's spokesman denied that Treasury was always litigious. "They would not have got as far as they had without treading on people's toes. But their actions are defensive. These are not a pair of harum-scarum lads from Tipperary."

In Britain, knowledge of their activities seems limited. Lord Falconer, the dome minister who has responsibility for approving this scheme, insists that "due diligence" tests have been applied to the bid. But, questioned by the Guardian, his office seemed unaware that the developers had been involved in rows in the Irish parliament.

MPs also seem to be in the dark. David Faber, a Conservative member of the Commons culture committee, which examined the project, said: "Nothing would astonish me about the dome. A lot is being kept secret from us."

Examination

The disclosure looks certain to provoke a detailed examination by the national audit office, parliament's financial watchdog, with David Davis, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, saying last night: "This would certainly be looked at when we examine the sale of the dome."

The government is due to decide on the sale in February and rejected warnings from Lazards, the merchant bank advising the government, which estimated that the Treasury could make £300m if the dome was flattened and sold off.

A Legacy adviser claimed the government had already scrutinised the business dealings and financial standing of Mr Barrett, Mr Ronan and Treasury Holdings as part of the sale process.

Three teams of advisers, law firm Berwin Leighton, accountants Deloitte Touche and property consultants Jones Lang LaSalle, went through the books. "It came back with a tick in the box," said the Legacy adviser.

New Millennium Experience Company officials have admitted that the cost of the dome has hit £854m, nearly £100m more than the original budget. NMEC will have to spend £14.5m more than it initially put aside to clear out the contents under an agreement with Legacy.

Nothing in his career at the bar can have prepared Lord Falconer for the deciding whether or not to hand over the dome to the Irish tycoons. He has already been accused of being too slow in stemming its losses - now he could be attacked for being too quick in disposing of the site.

The future, according to Legacy

 Millennium Dome is to be reborn as "Knowledge City" under ambitious plans proposed by Legacy's front man, Robert Bourne

 Site to become one of world's leading centres of "innovation and excellence in hi-tech industry, e-commerce and bio-science, so that the Dome can become a real symbol of enterprise Britain", says Mr Bourne. Or another business park, according to others

 Legacy's post-bid publicity painted new site as trendy "incubator" space for fledgling hi-tech companies to establish themselves, and envisaged a "cluster" of offices supporting the industry - such as venture capital, academic, legal and financial advisers

 Under Legacy's plans, themed areas such as Body Zone would be gutted, and distinctive pin cushion-style skyline would shelter offices of hi-tech firms, with flats and shops interspersed with wooded areas, restaurants and cafes

 Legacy claimed support of Sun Microsystems, BT, London Business School and Open University. But Sun and BT later denied partnership

 IT companies expressed scepticism that firms would be interested in relocating to north Greenwich. Dome's image problem, and steep fall in confidence among City investors, means few internet companies could afford to move to the Dome without substantial incentives

 New owners boasted the entire operation would create 14,000 new jobs

 Firm support has come from 3COM, the company that currently provides the Dome's computer network, and Imperial College, London

Richard Adams

webTitle: Autonomy takes Japan

fields.headline: Autonomy takes Japan
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Autonomy shares were up again yesterday after the intelligent software firm widened its exposure to wireless internet devices by saying its technology would now support the Japanese i-mode phone platform. The shares closed up 140p at £30.40.
fields.body:
Autonomy shares were up again yesterday after the intelligent software firm widened its exposure to wireless internet devices by saying its technology would now support the Japanese i-mode phone platform. The shares closed up 140p at £30.40.

Unlike Wap, the European alternative to accessing the internet through your mobile phone, i-mode - the technology developed by NTT DoCoMo - has been a huge success in the Far East, particularly in Japan and South Korea.

The firm's software is well suited to small mobile phone screens because it filters out unnecessary information. Aside from exposing itself to growth in Asian markets, Autonomy has now hedged its bets on what will happen in the US, which lags behind in the mobile internet stakes. WAP and i-mode are competing standards and regardless of which wins, Autonomy should benefit.

webTitle: Serious message behind Clinton's visit

fields.headline: Serious message behind the smiles
fields.standfirst:
Dundalk in carnival mood shows off its prosperity but town is also a symbol of the Troubles.

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: It is a rare day when red, white and blue bunting goes up in the republican stronghold of Dundalk. But yesterday was that day. The colours, representing not the British but the American flag, hung side by side with the bold green and orange of the Irish tricolour.
fields.body:
It is a rare day when red, white and blue bunting goes up in the republican stronghold of Dundalk. But yesterday was that day. The colours, representing not the British but the American flag, hung side by side with the bold green and orange of the Irish tricolour.

An American president was in town and the town was out to celebrate.

To those who know little of the Troubles the choice of Dundalk for the visit of the world's most powerful man would seem as reasonable as any other town nestled in the Irish countryside.

Indeed the official reason given for this choice of venue for a speech on President Clinton's trip was that the County Louth town was a symbol of the new Ireland, having turned itself into an economic powerhouse, with no little help from US investment.

But the Clinton cavalcade entering this town, just across the border from South Armagh, had a resonance far beyond its new prosperity.

Its image has been tainted by the belief that the town harbours members of the Real IRA responsible for the Omagh bomb, which killed 29 people.

Now a bustling industrial base, neat and practical rather than pretty, it is proud of developments such as the £180m Xerox plant, which will employ 2,000.

Yesterday carnival costumes were everywhere, Irish dancers mixed with the local samba band, and strains of Danny Boy, apparently the president's favourite song, sung by Belfast man Brian Kennedy, could be heard all day long.

Even the driving rain failed to dampen the spirits of those who have come to see the man credited as a major inspiration to the peace process.

It is clear that the president is here to deliver a message - isolate the terrorists who belong in the past and move forward to a better future.

"We were surprised he was coming here but this visit is symbolic," said 20-year-old Jonathan Gorham. "He's making a point. A minority of people want to continue violence but the majority just want to get on with their lives.

"There's a certain hardline element wherever you go, you can't blame one town," said Patrick Connaughton, 80. "Clinton's showing he knows not all the bad eggs are in one bucket. It's not a bad place to live. There are nice pubs and clubs and any amount of jobs."

In Market Square, regenerated with money from the international fund for Ireland, where the president made his speech to tens of thousands, a similar number gathered two years ago to show solidarity with the people of Omagh and disgust for those who carried out the atrocity. "Omagh was terrible," said Evelyn McMahon, out with her friend Maeve Kinblon. "We came here then and we're back now to see Bill. We were surprised he was coming here but this town doesn't deserve its reputation. It's a great wee town now, compared to what it used to be - good jobs and a great social scene. There's a buzz that wasn't here before.

"Clinton had done so much for the peace process, I hope he stays on in some role for Northern Ireland." Just a few hundred yards away in the Long Walk shopping centre, local people ran out of their business Michael and Bernadette McKevitt. The pair were key figures in the 32 County Sovereignty movement, the political wing of the Real IRA.

Now their shop is dark and empty, post piling up in the doorway, as Christmas shoppers hurry in and out of the well-lit units all around.

While locals are keen to point out the town's friendliness, they are more reticent about sharing their opinions of those hardliners.

"A few gangsters spoil it for a lot of decent people," said one police officer.

Antrim man Ambrose O'Neill made the trip south because he thinks he will get closer to the president. "He's done a lot for peace," he said, "and he could teach our politicians a thing or two."

Security was never tighter in Dundalk, every drain and alleyway searched and sealed by the American secret service. Local police had done their utmost to ensure no leading dissidents got close enough to be photographed with the president.

But Mr Clinton, who brought Sinn Fein in from the political cold when he first granted Gerry Adams a US visa in 1994, would have known that somewhere, lurking in the back of the crowd or watching television in the pub, might be those still sympathetic to the dissident cause.

They are the ones he is courageously facing down when he tells people to leave violence behind.

Unlike the good cowboy, who rides into town and manages to sort out the situation in just two hours, Clinton is not naive enough to imagine he will change minds overnight.

Just as when he talks to key Northern Ireland politicians in Belfast today, he knows he might not produce a magic formula to solve the current deadlock, but hopes his visit can be a catalyst toward creating the right atmosphere for change.

But by opening his arms to Dundalk, he is showing people he does not demonise them because of a minority in their midst and that he hopes the impact of his visit will help them exorcise some of the past which haunts their town.

In Market Square, regenerated with money from the international fund for Ireland, where the president made his speech to tens of thousands, a similar number gathered two years ago to show solidarity with the people of Omagh and disgust for those who carried out the atrocity. "Omagh was terrible," said Evelyn McMahon, out with her friend Maeve Kinblon. "We came here then and we're back now to see Bill. We were surprised he was coming here but this town doesn't deserve its reputation. It's a great wee town now, compared to what it used to be - good jobs and a great social scene. There's a buzz that wasn't here before. "Clinton had done so much for the peace process, I hope he stays on in some role for Northern Ireland." Just a few hundred yards away in the Long Walk shopping centre, local people ran out of their business Michael and Bernadette McKevitt. The pair were key figures in the 32 County Sovereignty movement, the political wing of the Real IRA. Now their shop is dark and empty, post piling up in the doorway, as Christmas shoppers hurry in and out of the well-lit units all around. While locals are keen to point out the town's friendliness, they are more reticent about sharing their opinions of those hardliners. "A few gangsters spoil it for a lot of decent people," said one police officer. Antrim man Ambrose O'Neill made the trip south because he thinks he will get closer to the president. "He's done a lot for peace," he said, "and he could teach our politicians a thing or two." Security was never tighter in Dundalk, every drain and alleyway searched and sealed by the American secret service. Local police had done their utmost to ensure no leading dissidents got close enough to be photographed with the president. But Mr Clinton, who brought Sinn Fein in from the political cold when he first granted Gerry Adams a US visa in 1994, would have known that somewhere, lurking in the back of the crowd or watching television in the pub, might be those still sympathetic to the dissident cause. They are the ones he is courageously facing down when he tells people to leave violence behind. Unlike the good cowboy, who rides into town and manages to sort out the situation in just two hours, Clinton is not naive enough to imagine he will change minds overnight. Just as when he talks to key Northern Ireland politicians in Belfast today, he knows he might not produce a magic formula to solve the current deadlock, but hopes his visit can be a catalyst toward creating the right atmosphere for change. But by opening his arms to Dundalk, he is showing people he does not demonise them because of a minority in their midst and that he hopes the impact of his visit will help them exorcise some of the past which haunts their town.

webTitle: My conscience is clear, Milosevic tells TV audience

fields.headline: My conscience is clear, Milosevic tells TV audience
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, last night gave his first television interview since being forced from power in October, and declared that he had a clear conscience about his 13-year rule.
fields.body:
The former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, last night gave his first television interview since being forced from power in October, and declared that he had a clear conscience about his 13-year rule.

Looking calm and determined, Mr Milosevic said he had no qualms about what he had done during his period in power - which included four wars and the bloody break-up of Yugoslavia. "I am able to sleep tight, as my conscience is completely clear," he said.

His appearance was an attempt to ease himself back on to the political stage before crucial elections for the Serbian parliament, which are due on December 23.

Asked about the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague, Mr Milosevic said, looking into the camera: "I do not recognise that institution. It is a political institution and one of the means for committing genocide against the Serbs. This has become very apparent. The institution is completely illegal."

The interview, conducted in the headquarters of Mr Milosevic's Socialist party of Serbia, was broadcast by the private television station Palma, whose owner, Miodrag Vujovic, is reputed to be sympathetic to the former president.

Mr Milosevic, spruce in dark suit and red tie, sat in a large black leather chair intently answering the interviewer's sim ple questions like a benevolent uncle. Asked to talk about the man who unseated him, Vojislav Kostunica, Mr Milosevic said: "I would not comment on that. It is too early."

He said, however, that life for ordinary Serbs had already deteriorated. "The people already know that their purchasing power is miserable. The question is: Doesn't everyone see how much worse it is now than it was at the end of September?"

During the interview, Mr Milosevic said his years as Serbian and Yugoslav president had been a "struggle to preserve peace" and he referred to the reformers' victory in October as a "coup". He suggested that the January assassination of the warlord Zeljko Raznatovic, known as Arkan, had been part of a plot against Serbia. "Arkan was assassinated in the context of this operation that was under way ... because they knew that ... he was a patriot," Mr Milosevic said.

Mr Milosevic defended his family against criticisms, saying his son Marko, widely viewed in Serbia as a playboy and believed to have fled the country, had done nothing wrong and his accusers were "below every human dignity ... If they really believe in God, as they say they do, they should fear God".

The interview echoed the style adopted by Mr Milosevic when he conceded power on October 6. Then, he aped the kind of resignation speech that any western politician might make, even though 24 hours before he had sent in the tanks.

His Socialist party has splintered and suffered a rash of resignations since his regime was defeated in September elections, when the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS) had a landslide victory at presidential, federal and local level.

Latest opinion polls show that support for Mr Milosevic's party has dropped dramatically since then, from 24% in September to 16% now, while support for DOS has almost doubled from 32% to 61%.

A leading pollster, Srdjan Bogosavljevic, has estimated that since the September elections DOS has won the support of one in eight Milosevic supporters. "I can't imagine that there are any clever election strategies left for him," he said. Anti-Milosevic activists believe the December 23 poll will put the final seal on Mr Milosevic's defeat.

In the meantime Mr Milosevic and his wife, Mira Markovic, are still living in the White House, the palace used by Tito in Belgrade's leafy Dedinje suburb.

According to Aleksandar Tijanic, a Belgrade columnist and a minister of information for Mr Milosevic some years ago: "They are guarded by a unit of police bodyguards and by a section of the elite guard." The bodyguards are not under government jurisdiction, he said.

There is a strong desire in Serbia to see Mr Milosevic brought to justice, but most people want him to be tried in Serb courts and for corruption rather than for war crimes at the Hague.

Mrs Markovic had been due yesterday to hold a rare press conference at the headquarters of her party, the Yugoslav Left, which formed part of Mr Milosevic ruling coalition. This was cancelled, however, at short notice.

webTitle: Florida moves to hand Bush victory

fields.headline: Florida moves to hand Bush victory
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Florida's legislature last night began the process of trying to force the presidential selection in favour of the Republicans by approving a list of 25 electors pledged to select George W Bush.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington and  Julian Borger in Tallahassee
fields.body:
Florida's legislature last night began the process of trying to force the presidential selection in favour of the Republicans by approving a list of 25 electors pledged to select George W Bush.

The resolution was designed to hand all the state's votes in the electoral college to the Texas governor and assure him of victory whether or not a recount was approved by the US Supreme Court. It was fiercely opposed by Democrats who accused the Bush camp of trying to hijack the election and creating a dangerous constitutional precedent.

The vote took place in the lower house and the resolution will pass to the state senate - with an inbuilt Republican majority of 25-15 - today. It is not clear whether the senate will wait for a US supreme court verdict on whether Florida recounts can continue before it ratifies the pro-Bush list.

If the court finds in favour of Mr Gore but the legislature goes for Mr Bush, then the US could find itself in the midst of a constitutional crisis.

Yesterday it was revealed that the wife of one of the nine US supreme court justices whose decision could hand the White House to Mr Bush is helping to recruit political staff to a Bush administration.

Ginni Thomas, whose husband Clarence Thomas is one of the conservative group of judges that has supported Mr Bush in two actions in the past month, is working at a prominent conservative think-tank in Washington where she is coordinating rightwing recruitment for the Republican leader.

Mrs Thomas works for the Heritage Foundation and is actively approaching Republicans to come and work for Mr Bush if he becomes president. Earlier this month, she sent an email to Republican political staff members on Capitol Hill inviting them to submit their CVs "for transition purposes".

Justice Thomas has played a low-key role in the Bush v Gore case in which the supreme court heard oral arguments in Washington on Monday.

Alone among the nine justices, Justice Thomas did not ask a single question on Monday. But Judge Gilbert Merritt, a federal judge in Tennessee with personal ties to the Gore family, said in an interview yesterday that Justice Thomas faced a conflict of interest due to his wife's involvement and should stand down from the case.

If he were to step down, the court could be split 4-4 on the Bush v Gore case. In the event of a tie, the original ruling by the Florida supreme court allowing counts of Florida's "undervotes" would stand.

"The spouse has obviously got a substantial interest that could be affected by the outcome," Judge Merritt said. "You should disqualify yourself. I think he'd be subject to some kind of investigation in the Senate."

Judge Merritt cited section 455 of Title 28 of the United States Code in support of his call. The provision requires court officers to excuse themselves from a case if their spouse has "an interest that could be substantially affected by the outcome of the proceeding".

"There is no conflict here," Mrs Thomas told the New York Times yesterday. She said she rarely discusses court matters with her husband.

Kathy Arberg, a spokeswoman for the supreme court, said she had no comment on the claims. She also refused to comment on a separate revelation that Eugene Scalia, the son of a second conservative member of the court, Justice Antonin Scalia, is a law partner of Ted Olson, who acted for Mr Bush in the two cases he brought to the court in the past two weeks.

As the Thomas row flared yesterday, America had no option but to submit itself to a nerve-wracking national ordeal by tension.

But the country could be waiting for some time for a ruling. Lawyers pointed out that the supreme court's record fastest time for handing down a judgment following oral argument is three days after the hearing.

The two men at the centre of the storm continued to watch and wait along with everyone else. Mr Gore, whose mood was described by his aides as "determined and resolute", spent another day at his official residence in Washington.

Meanwhile, Mr Bush planned another business-as-usual day in Austin, saying that after talking to his lawyers he was "cautiously optimistic" about the outcome of the court's decision.

webTitle: Prodi attacks 'self-serving' Blair

fields.headline: Prodi attacks 'self-serving' Blair
fields.standfirst:
Commission president fears summit failures will harm EU

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Romano Prodi yesterday launched a scathing attack on Tony Blair's refusal to drop Britain's veto on tax and social security at the Nice summit
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and Michael White
fields.body:
Romano Prodi, president of the European commission, yesterday launched a scathing attack on Tony Blair's refusal to drop Britain's veto on tax and social security at the Nice summit, blaming the prime minister for a self-serving "lack of openness and understanding".

The fall-out from the European Union's summit exposed Mr Blair to fresh assaults from both sides as EU integrationists warned they would be back for more - and British Eurosceptics warned that such talk vindicated their fears.

As the European parliament threatened to block the new EU treaty, the president of the European commission said in Strasbourg that anyone who used Europe to get the best for themselves was making "an error of historical analysis" and "cheating future generations."

Diplomats described Mr Prodi as "forlorn, subdued and marginalised," after being repeatedly humiliated by the French president, Jacques Chirac, and seeing the removal of too few of the "manacles" of national vetoes.

Twenty-nine items moved to majority voting, but no country surrendered on sensitive matters. Mr Blair held his "red lines", but so did Germany's Gerhard Schröder over asylum, Mr Chirac on trade policy and Spain's Jose-Maria Aznar on regional funds.

There was no mistaking the commission president's target when he addressed MEPs angry with the way Nice dealt with reforms deemed crucial to streamline decision-making when the EU becomes a 27-strong club.

"I am deeply disappointed," he said. "In the sensitive issues ... progress has been insignificant or non-existent." Mr Prodi, former premier of Italy, was a Blair candidate for his current job, but has proved erratic and been hurt by the emphasis on inter-governmental co-operation in Nice.

Later, Pierre Moscovici, the French minister for Europe, said the summit results could not be set in stone. "It will be necessary one day to vote with qualified majority on fiscal and social issues," he warned in a BBC interview. I know the difficulties Mr Blair has with British opinion, but British opinion needs to move."

Francis Maude, shadow foreign secretary, said the Prodi-Moscovici remarks show that "these people are saying what Tony Blair does not want Britain to hear - that the EU superstate agenda is alive and well. The ink is not dry on this treaty and already EU politicians are talking about the next stage of integration."

Mr Chirac, also speaking in Strasbourg, defended the outcome of the EU's longest ever summit. "I know that the Nice treaty does not reflect all the ambitions," he said. "This treaty is the best possible agreement given existing constraints. There are no winners or losers here."

But the agreement has been widely condemned as securing the permanent dominance of the EU's three biggest member states over the smaller ones, by reforming the voting system in the decision-making council of ministers. From 2005, when the new system begins and enlargement gets under way, Germany, France and Britain will be able to block a decision backed by any majority of smaller states.

webTitle: Police in Damilola case make appeal to youths

fields.headline: Police in Damilola case make appeal to youths
fields.standfirst: More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: Police investigating the murder of Damilola Taylor, the 10-year-old boy stabbed to death in Peckham, south-east London last month, have   appealed for two groups of youths seen near the site where Damilola's body was found to come forward.
fields.body:
Police investigating the murder of Damilola Taylor, the 10-year-old boy stabbed to death in Peckham, south-east London last month, have appealed for two groups of youths seen near the site where Damilola's body was found to come forward.

The first group, consisting of four or five black males, was seen near telephone boxes on Blakes Road, Peckham, at around 4.30pm, some 20 minutes before Damilola's body was discovered.

The smallest member of the group was said to be wearing a dark jacket, possibly a Puffa, similar to the one that was worn by Damilola.

The second group of three black youths, all wearing dark-coloured anoraks and trainers, was seen further down Blakes Road at 4.45pm.

webTitle: Liberals put forward plan to bury Lenin

fields.headline: Liberals put forward plan to bury Lenin
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A proposal to remove Lenin's embalmed corpse from Red Square and replace his mausoleum with a memorial to victims of Soviet repression will be considered today by a committee in the lower house of Russia's parliament.
fields.body:
A proposal to remove Lenin's embalmed corpse from Red Square and replace his mausoleum with a memorial to victims of Soviet repression will be considered today by a committee in the lower house of Russia's parliament.

One of the most potent remaining emblems of the Soviet Union, Lenin's body has attracted renewed attention as debate continues to rage over the new iconography selected to represent modern Russia.

A liberal political faction has demanded the prompt removal of the Bolshevik leader from his shrine - arguing that this would be appropriate compensation for the official resurrection by the president of the Soviet national anthem last week.

The Union of Right Forces has recommended that Lenin should be buried and a new memorial to those who perished in the century's political purges constructed in place of the mausoleum.

Once a revered pilgrimage spot, the site is now just one of Moscow's weirder tourist attractions. Waxy, shrunken and yellowing, the corpse lies in a saint-like pose in a darkened chamber.

The Duma's agenda setting council will decide today whether to schedule a debate on the issue but, even if time is found, the motion has little chance of success. Neither President Vladimir Putin nor his Unity party have shown any desire to move Lenin.

webTitle: Thief of the future revealed

fields.headline: Thief of the future revealed
fields.standfirst: New strategies will be needed to tackle crime in internet age, says thinktank
fields.trailText: New strategies will be needed to tackle crime in internet age, says thinktank.
fields.body:
By 2020 the skilled British thief will be more interested in stealing somebody's identity to gain access to various cyber-services than in breaking into homes to lift their compact disc player, says a Whitehall thinktank report.

The Department of Trade and Industry "Foresight" crime prevention panel has told ministers that a national strategy to combat e-crime, or electronic crime, needs to be established within the next two years if law enforcement agencies are to keep pace with the speed with which sophisticated criminals are learning to use the new technologies.

The report said that in future thieves will not be targeting hardware such as videos, televisions and mobile phones, but the spoils of e-crime - internet services, intellectual property, knowledge and data.

The writers of the report, Just Around the Corner, predict that science and technology advances will lead to a sharp drop in property crime as the use of electronic "chips", coatings and tags, make it possible to brand an owner's identity on to all sorts of goods, including antiques and jewellery.

In future, the authors suggest, new technology will allow thieves to take advantage of their relative anonymity to strike through the internet quickly and without trace. Their favourite targets will be not "hot property" but "hot services", particularly those which cannot be terminated by the legitimate supplier once stolen and which can be sold on to others. Electronic services, such as pre-paid no contract mobile phones, are already fitting this description.

But the Whitehall panel engaged in this "blue sky" research exercise believes that by 2020 there will be more violent crime as the kind of services that criminals are interested in become harder to use for those without legitimate access.

Individual victims will find themselves targeted for their pin numbers, passwords or credit card details so that thieves can get access to their electronic services.

The panel, which included police officers, criminologists, scientists, and academics, says that new laws are already needed to tackle some emerging crimes. The report points out that defacing an individual's website is not a criminal offence despite the amount of damage it can cause. They also warn that it is not against the law to obtain a service by deceiving a "machine" - so there are difficulties in prosecuting those thieves who use other people's credit cards to order goods and services over the internet.

The panel came up with a number of innovative ways by which science and technology could help law enforcement agencies. Among the suggestions were:

webTitle: Who Wants To Be A Prime Minister

fields.headline: Who Wants To Be A Prime Minister
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair walked down an illuminated catwalk. "Tonight, live from Leeds, Ask The Prime Minister!" a voice declaimed, and tingly music played. The lights cast shadows from below, so he looked like your uncle pretending to be a ghost on Christmas Eve. It was like the opening of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, and the prime minister had won the fastest finger round. In such ways does art imitate tripe.
fields.body:
Tony Blair walked down an illuminated catwalk. "Tonight, live from Leeds, Ask The Prime Minister!" a voice declaimed, and tingly music played. The lights cast shadows from below, so he looked like your uncle pretending to be a ghost on Christmas Eve. It was like the opening of Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, and the prime minister had won the fastest finger round. In such ways does art imitate tripe.

"Well," he said at one point, "it's the only time I get the chance to talk to people direct and not through newspapers," though on occasion the experience seemed to have brought him close to panic. You can always tell, because his eyes glaze over, like Bambi hearing the bad news about his mother.

It's so much easier tackling William Hague. You felt he wanted Jonathan Dimbleby (surely the winner of the Leeds heat in the George W Bush lookalike contest) to tell him he still had one lifeline: shoot the audience.

The programme was on ITV, and the overall effect was curiously disjointed. The questioners depicted a country in which the infrastructure had collapsed, where health care is rationed, and our teachers and police are quitting in thousands, leaving packs of uneducated, feral youngsters to terrorise the land.

Yet the frequent ads which interrupted told the opposite story: the workers of Britain are buying computers, luxury Belgian chocolates, gourmet frozen food, scented unguents, and brand new BMW cars.

Which picture of Britain is right? Why, both are, of course. This is a nation where most people have stacks of money to buy things, yet nobody seems to be able to provide services.

The audience began with train services. "Ah want to be open with you," Mr Blair vouchsafed, "it's absolute hell travelling on the railways at the present time" - as if we didn't know. But, he added, some of the speed restrictions were "over the top".

Mr Dimbleby inquired if this meant Railtrack was "taking us all for a ride", which of course is the one thing they cannot manage. The prime minister was opposed to the "risk-aversion" which had "crept into the system", yet said that "the safety" (he has been absorbing Prescott-speak) had to come first. "You're saying two different things," Mr Bush - sorry, Mr Dimbleby - pointed out. A cynic might say that this was because he's a politician; I suspect he was merely tired. Four days in Nice; sleep deprivation always catches up with you.

"Police numbers are down, crime is up. That's not a very good record, is it?" he was asked. "It's not a matter of statistics," he said wearily, but of course that's exactly what all recent British governments have tried to reduce every problem to.

On the NHS, he declared again: "I genuinely believe the glass is half full, not half empty," a phrase which is half meaningful and half gibberish. We saw one flash of real passion when a woman complained that her mother had to wait 68 weeks for surgery. "I accept it's my responsibility to turn the system round. I'm doing my very level best," he said, and looked as though he meant it. The famous glassy smile was absent; he seems to realise it doesn't work any more.

A woman shouted from the back that the Tories had always looked after their own. "You haven't looked after ours!" she added, and was cheered by the audience. But then he was cheered for his reply: "I don't intend to be a leftwing Margaret Thatcher. That's not what I'm about."

And the man who attacked the euro was jeered by the audience. Mr Blair finished strongly, but he may find today's question time rather easier.

webTitle: Train travel is hell, admits Blair

fields.headline: Train travel is hell, admits Blair
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night admitted that rail travel in Britain has become an "absolute hell" and warned Railtrack that if the situation is not drastically improved by late January ministers will impose their own less severe speed restrictions.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night admitted that rail travel in Britain has become an "absolute hell" and warned Railtrack that if the situation is not drastically improved by late January ministers will impose their own less severe speed restrictions.

While he stressed the importance of rail safety he also betrayed evident frustration at the long delays caused by emergency track repairs - not justified by the real risk involved, the prime minister hinted during his hour long ITV grilling. During a live programme, Ask the Prime Minister, he also confessed his helplessness to improve the NHS quickly enough to ease the suffering of a woman whose 87-year-old mother has been told she must wait 68 weeks to see an orthopaedic surgeon.

In an emotional exchange Mr Blair told the distressed woman: "I accept it is my responsibilty to turn this situation around. I am trying to do it, I am trying my very level best to do it."

Immediately challenged to say why he and Gordon Brown had not spent more on public services like the NHS earlier in Labour's three year term the prime minister insisted they had been determined to ease crippling debt repayments - larger "than the whole of the school system" - and to avoid Tory boom and bust in the economy.

In a rare breach of the night's good-tempered but highlyassertive cross-examination by an audience at Yorkshire TV's Leeds studio - and telephone callers around the country - Mr Blair was stung by one hurled taunt on tight public spending limits to say: "I don't intend to become a leftwing Margaret Thatcher. That is not what I am about."

He confessed repeatedly that shortages of doctors and nurses, not cash, are the NHS's biggest problem. But in a flurry of agonised complaints from struggling doctors, teachers and a London policeman's wife the post-Hatfield rail crisis raised most anger.

"Just because they (Railtrack) say there is a minimal amount of risk you've got to test what they say... but there is a certain amount of risk paralysis creeping in," said Mr Blair who faced waves of voter indignation over the failing state of key public services, notably the NHS, crime, schools and transport.

Asked if he experienced directly what he had earlier called the "absolute hell to travel on the railways at the present time"," Mr Blair said he had - and during the journey "had ample opportunity to hear the views of commuters which are very strong".

If the system is not largely back to normal by the end of January, ministers will intervene to impose their own guidelines, he said, though he also pointed out that even ultra-moden rail systems like Germany's still have crashes.

To all his questioners Mr Blair was forced to admit "there is a limit to what we can do" or - on extra pay for nurses, police and teachers - "it may not be enough or as much as people want, but it is a big start".

On the single currency issue he reminded viewers that Labour has promised a referendum so that voters will decide.

Asked if he would copy Denmark and repeat the referendum if he got a No he replied: "No, I don't think that would be very wise."

webTitle: Tory treasurer denounces drugs 'cancer' in Lords speech

fields.headline: Tory treasurer denounces drugs 'cancer' in Lords speech
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Lord Ashcroft, the embattled treasurer of the Conservative party, yesterday used his maiden speech in the House of Lords to deliver an implied rebuke to critics who had accused him of having links with the Caribbean drugs trade.
fields.body:
Lord Ashcroft, the embattled treasurer of the Conservative party, yesterday used his maiden speech in the House of Lords to deliver an implied rebuke to critics who had accused him of having links with the Caribbean drugs trade.

The billionaire entrepeneur, whose fortune was consolidated in Florida and the tiny ex-colony of Belize, intervened in the Queen's speech debate on foreign policy to denounce "the cancer" of drugs in the Caribbean - and to plead with the government not to abandon its four remaining overseas territories.

It is almost exactly a year after a legal deal with the Times newspaper ended his libel suit against the newspaper which - as part of the settlement hammered out between the peer and Rupert Murdoch - denied his claim that it had implied he had commercial links with drug dealing.

Reading from a prepared text and in an an apparent reference to the US-Colombian routes of supply he said: "The Caribbean overseas territories are not drug producing countries. But they do sit astride some of the most prolific drug trafficking routes in the world.

"The threat of powerful, organised crime is ever present. Those who deal in drugs are a cancer on the societies in which they operate. Through my business interests in the Caribbean, I am mindful of the constant vigilance that is necessary to interrupt the supply line," Lord Ashcroft said.

His purpose was to urge ministers to fulfil their 1998 pledge to give full British citizenship to the remaining overseas territories in the region; Anguilla, volcano damaged Monserrat, the British Virgin Islands and the Turks and Caicos. Six other territories were also given the pledge.

Lord Ashcroft stressed the islands' vulnerability to changing fashions in tourism, the impact of IT, the spread of global business, the threats from drug traffickers and other international criminals, and the dangers of natural disasters.

Evidently on his best behaviour, Lord Ashcroft whose peerage was informally made conditional upon his return to Britain for taxpaying purposes, declared "certain business interests in the Carribean".

webTitle: Hunt ban 'breach of rights'

fields.headline: Hunt ban 'breach of rights'
fields.standfirst:
Countryside group ready to launch legal challenge

Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Countryside group ready to launch legal challenge
fields.body:
The Countryside Alliance is poised to launch a challenge under the Human Rights Act to the government's bill banning hunting if, as expected, MPs vote for an outright ban.

A leading human rights barrister, Edward Fitzgerald QC, said there was a "strong case" for arguing that a ban on hunting would breach rights to enjoyment of property and respect for private life guaranteed by the European convention on human rights.

The alliance, the main pro-hunting lobby group, plans to challenge the statement by the home secretary, Jack Straw, that the bill complies with the convention.

Since October, when the Human Rights Act came into force, making the convention part of UK law, new bills must include either a "statement of compatibility" with the convention, or a statement that the government wants parliament to proceed without one.

The Home Office said: "The home secretary made his statement on the basis of the best legal advice available. If the Alliance wants to challenge it, that's a matter for them."

The bill, which will have its second reading in the Commons next Monday, will allow MPs a free vote on three options: a ban on hunting with hounds, a "middle way" under which hunting would be regulated by statute, or a system of self-regulation put forward by the Countryside Alliance.

Labour MPs are expected to vote for a ban. The Commons voted for a ban three years ago when a Labour member put forward a private member's bill which ran out of time.

An alliance spokesman said: "If MPs are unwise enough to try to vote through an outright ban on hunting with dogs it is highly likely that we will be challenging the government's awarding of that certificate to that bill."

An inquiry under the former senior treasury official Lord Burns, set up by the government to look into a possible ban on hunting, warned that any ban could face challenges under the Human Rights Act.

Mr Fitzgerald said: "There is a strong case that a ban on hunting, backed by criminal sanctions, interferes with the right to the peaceful enjoyment of property, protected by article 1 of protocol 1 [of the convention] and the right to respect for private life guaranteed by article 8."

Interference can be justified, but in the case of enjoyment of property the state would have to show that it struck a balance between the interests of the community and the protection of the right to peaceful enjoyment of property.

In the case of the right to private life, the state can only interfere to protect morals, prevent crime or disorder, or prevent offence to religious or other sensibilities. It would also have to show the ban was proportionate and necessary.

Mr Fitzgerald said protecting animals from unnecessary suffering could come under the protection of morals. But the onus would be on the state to show hunting caused more suffering than other means of killing and the court, Mr Fitzgerald said, would expect to see some legitimate scientific findings before criminalising conduct that was otherwise lawful.

Deadline 2000, a coalition of animal rights groups which supports a ban, has obtained an opinion from three human rights lawyers arguing that hunting is a public activity and therefore not covered by the right to respect for private life.

Even if it is covered, they say, the courts will accord a "discretionary area of judgment" to parliament, particularly if the matter has been decided by a free vote.
