webTitle: Railtrack repairs are key worry, MPs told

fields.headline: Railtrack repairs are key worry, MPs told
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, yesterday backed moves to end Railtrack's heavily criticised policy of sub-contracting out all track maintenance work, saying it was one of his areas of greatest concern.
fields.body:
The transport minister, Lord Macdonald, yesterday backed moves to end Railtrack's heavily criticised policy of sub-contracting out all track maintenance work, saying it was one of his areas of greatest concern.

The sub-contracting is seen as one of the causes of the Hatfield rail crash and the subsequent panic response of checking over 3,000 separate sites of guage cracking.

Lord Macdonald said yesterday the relationship between sub-contractors and Railtrack would be the central issue in the second part of the Cullen inquiry into the Hatfield rail crash.

He also told members of the Commons transport committee yesterday he was deeply concerned by the skill shortages in rail maintenance. He had called in senior Railtrack managers in the wake of a Daily Mirror story showing an undercover reporter had been appointed a site access manager in charge of 18 men on one of Britain's busiest train lines.

The reporter had been given just 48 hours training by Jarvis Rail, one of the six sub-contarctors working for Railtrack.

The transport commitee, in a report to be published later today, is expected to slam the poor monitoring of sub-contracted work.

The RMT union told the committee permanently employed maintenance workers had fallen from 31,000 in 1994 to 19,000 today. At the same time the number of casual staff had risen to 84,000. The former Railtrack chief executive, Gerald Corbett, told the committee that the number of contractors will be reduced from six to four, but said "the whole issue of culture on the front line is going to have be addressed".

Lord Macdonald yesterday went further, agreeing Railtrack may have panicked in the wake of Hatfield because it had not been running a sensible long term track renewal programme. He said: "Railtrack has said its relationship with management sub-contractors is not satisfactory.

"They concede they have a management responsibility and practices in the past have been inadequate. It's important for people on the ground to be under quite clear command from above and that does not always seem to have been the case."

The committee chairwoman, Gwyneth Dunwoody, asked why the government was giving Railtrack £4bn of extra cash when "they patently cannot do the job".

Lord Macdonald produced new figures showing only 64% of Intercity trains were arriving within times set out in the revised timetables.

He also revealed that even at the end of January when the bulk of the repairs are supposed to have been completed only half of all journeys will be completed within the time set before the Hatfield rail disaster.

Intercity trains would be running 30 minutes late, and Anglo-Scottish trains 45 minutes late. The minister said even these improved timetables might not be met if there is bad weather or snow.

The number of 20mph speed restrictions had fallen from 401 to 379, the number of 40mph restrictions had fallen from 69 to 45 and the number of 60mph restrictions had risen from 83 to 104.

He adamantly refused to take a minority stake or golden share in Railtrack, saying it would not increase any policy influence over the railways. He also insisted any discussion of fundamental reorganisation of the railways now would be destabilising and demoralising. He accepted however the government was in effect giving Railtrack £5bn over the next five years for rail investment.

Lord Macdonald promised the new regulatory structure and new management on the Railtrack board will reduce the fragmentation.

He adamantly refused to take a minority stake or golden share in Railtrack, saying it would not increase any policy influence over the railways. He also insisted any discussion of fundamental reorganisation of the railways now would be destabilising and demoralising. He accepted however the government was in effect giving Railtrack £5bn over the next five years for rail investment. Lord Macdonald promised the new regulatory structure and new management on the Railtrack board will reduce the fragmentation.

webTitle: Comment: You're sexy Wills, but so is a republic

fields.headline: You're sexy Wills, but so is a republic
fields.standfirst:
Other newspaper writers are now backing the Guardian campaign

Special report: The future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Alison Roberts: Call me an old cynic, but those photographs from Chile are perfectly timed, an antidote to the stuffier December traditions of the Queen's speech and that stiff royal procession to church on Christmas morning.
fields.body:
Prince William looks like a nice enough kid, doesn't he? Like a normal 18-year-old lad mucking in on his gap-year trip to Chile.

The endless pictures in nearly every national newspaper and the lengthy special reports on television news programmes gave us ample opportunity to assess his loo-cleaning skills, his Ali G impersonation and his instinctive rapport with children of nursery-school age. We look at these photographs and see a handsome, surprisingly well-adjusted young man doing what thousands of middle-class British teenagers do every year, travelling the world and trying to help less privileged people in poorer countries - or, rather, this is what we're supposed to see.

The average teenager, of course, enjoys his gap year without a camera crew and a Press Association photographer trailing his every step for a week. The average teenager doesn't have his gap year used, really quite shamelessly, as part of a publicity offensive for the dubious benefit of his family and the ancient institutions upheld by his dad and his grandma.

William is undoubtedly the royal family's best asset, its most effective promotional tool and, of course, its future. You can hardly blame royal spin doctors for wanting to build a sympathetic relationship between the prince and his public, nor for encouraging his youthful attractiveness to reflect seasonal goodwill upon the royal family as a whole.

Call me an old cynic, but those photographs from Chile - taken by PA at the invitation of the palace - are perfectly timed, an antidote to the stuffier December traditions of the Queen's speech and that stiff royal procession to church on Christmas morning. They come just after the Guardian launched its republican campaign for major constitutional change.

So who, exactly, are these pictures aimed at? Who do they seek to impress and why? Teenage girls will certainly love them. William has attained the status of popstar among the fifth-form sorority - without ever asking for it - because of his good looks and his inherited glamour.

But schoolgirls are notoriously fickle; they grow out of pin-ups as quickly as they grow out of boob tubes and acne. By the time these girls reach their own 18th birthday, they're statistically far more likely to entertain republican thoughts than want William for a boyfriend. Opinion polls show that 18- to 24-year-olds are the most vigorous supporters of constitutional change.

Prince William might be cute, he might do a passable impression of a member of the Staines Massive, and he might win hearts. But the battle for the minds of his young fans, for their ideological support, is very probably unwinnable.

What about their parents? A straw poll reveals a number of attitudes towards those photographs from Chile, all of them vaguely supportive of William - a proportion of older women still feel a sentimental attachment to his mother and feel justifiably sorry for him - but few of them decidedly pro-monarchist. It's happening incrementally and with each generation, but it's definitely happening: London, at any rate, is turning republican.

Why not publish the pictures in Hello!, asked one friend of mine - then they won't get mixed up with proper news. And she has a point. How many of us really want to wade through pages and pages of royal sycophancy over breakfast?

Presumably, part of the decision to release photographs of the young - and undeniably likable - prince was based on a desire to demonstrate yet more movement towards royal modernisation. Had William decided to spend his gap year working in a posh Cork Street gallery (he is studying the history of art, after all), mixing only with well-heeled Sloanes, we'd quickly condemn it as typical "them and us" behaviour.

But royal modernisation doesn't just mean issuing pictures which show the heir to the throne but one looking like an average bloke, or behaving like an averagely idealistic teenager. That is, of course, entirely cosmetic - and manipulative into the bargain. Royal modernisation means giving up some of the archaic power which adheres to the throne; it doesn't just mean scrapping the gilded carriages and silly costumes - though that's a start - it means proper constitutional debate and then reform.

It means removing some of the ancient prejudices - particularly of religion - which the monarchy upholds and accepting that the British people, especially its young, are no longer willing participants in a culture which encourages unthinking deference to those who happened to be born into a family (and I don't just mean the royal family) prefaced by a title and possessed of a manor.

The palace could begin, indeed, by rethinking the immensely patronising assumption that the entire country wants to look at glossy pictures of its teenage offspring.

 Reprinted from yesterday's London Evening Standard

webTitle: Analysis: The price of air travel

fields.headline: Turbulence ahead
fields.standfirst:
Demand for cheap air travel has taken off, but the price of plane tickets ought to rise for the sake of the environment

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The government yesterday cleared its throat on the question of how far and how fast air travel can be permitted to grow.
fields.body:
The government yesterday cleared its throat on the question of how far and how fast air travel can be permitted to grow. A consultation paper discussed - governments have been reluctant even to do as much as this - new airport capacity. The crux question is where any expansion in airports should be, given that demand from travellers is focused on London and in the south-east.

The debate has to go wider - to the economic, social and environmental costs and benefits of aviation to society. Last year, a report by Oxford Economic Forecasting (OEF) made great claims. Aviation was said to increase UK productivity and in consequence even modest restraint on growth would have a negative impact. If air travel were constrained at 1998's levels - the starting point for the chart on the right - the economy would be £30bn or 2.5% smaller in 2015 than if growth in passenger numbers could let rip. This analysis underpins the business view that, as a London Chamber of Commerce report blandly puts it, "capacity must be provided to meet all reasonable demand".

But where? Between now and Christmas, the barrister Roy Vandermeer QC will hand over his report on the proposed fifth terminal at Heathrow airport (T5), marking the end of the longest planning inquiry in British history and the start of a big headache for the government. The inquiry has taken five and a half years, cost millions and divided local communities. Few doubt that Mr Vandermeer will give the go-ahead for T5. The question is what conditions will he seek to impose on noise, night flights and access to the airport by public transport.

T5 would allow an increase in the number of passengers using Heathrow from about 60m a year to 80m, assuming existing runway capacity. But this represents only about two years of growth, at the present rate, in the number of passengers using UK airports. Air freight is growing at an even faster rate, most of it carried in passenger planes.

Forecasts for growth over the next 30 years suggest that if it were unconstrained the number of air passengers would treble from about 180m this year to more than 500m in 2030. Even if full use were made of the existing runway capacity at all major airports, physical limits would begin to bite with a vengeance within about 10 years.

But the OEF report that projected such increases is flawed - according to a study this week from Berkeley Hanover Consulting (BHC), which was commissioned by the strategic aviation special interest group of the Local Government Association. It argues that there is no link between growth in aviation and higher productivity. This is not necessarily surprising. A report by the standing advisory committee on trunk road assessment (Sactra) last year found no simple link between transport and economic activity, especially in a mature economy with a well-developed transport system such as the UK.

The Oxford forecasters assumed that physical constraints would have the same effect on business and leisure air travel, when it is known that business travel is much less price sensitive and more important to the economy. More than three-quarters of air travel to and from UK air ports is for leisure, which is more price sensitive. The UK has a huge trade deficit in international tourism, about £9bn in 1999.

As the Sactra report pointed out, improving transport can just as easily suck economic activity out of a region as it can bring in new investment. Account has to be taken, too, of the economic costs of additional visitors to the UK in congesting the transport system and tourist attractions. Unconstrained growth in aviation could also unbalance regional economic development and contribute to over-heating in areas where there is already full employment. There is a good case for expanding airports outside the south-east.

So the Oxford forecast is fatally flawed even on its own narrow terms. It still tells only part of the story, for it takes no account of aviation's wider social and environmental costs and benefits. These include, on the positive side, wider travel horizons for most of the population.

On the negative side, they include the impact of aircraft noise on people who live near airports, under flight paths or next to busy airport road and rail links. Also to be factored in are local and global air pollution, the use of land for airport infrastructure, road and rail links. These costs are not reflected in the price of air travel and consequently the growth in air transport is environmentally unsustainable and socially inequitable.

The economists' answer to the above would be to ensure these costs are reflected in the price of air travel on the principle that the "polluter pays". That would require the use of economic instruments such as taxation and emissions trading, often requiring agreement at international level so that one country's aviation industry is not disadvantaged relative to another. As events at Nice have shown, achieving agreement on fiscal matters at international level is not easy.

The bottom line - politically difficult - is that the price of air travel will have to rise if aviation is to develop in a way that is environmentally sustainable. Such policy instruments as regulation, planning and compensation for people who are adversely affected by airport developments must also come into play. For new airport capacity as for road building, the government must move beyond the passive approach of just accepting growth in demand.

Tony Grayling is a transport specialist at the Institute for Public Policy Research t.grayling@ippr.org.uk

webTitle: Leader: Judges must change

fields.headline: Judges must change
fields.standfirst:
The Human Rights Act will blow away aloof and archaic judges. They should have to explain themselves

Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: Conor Gearty:  The Human Rights Act will blow away aloof and archaic judges. They should have to explain themselves.
fields.body:
It is obviously wrong that any judges should be in the Lords at all. What business do those who must later apply the law in particular disputes have in participating in the formulation of the very rules which they are later required dispassionately to apply?

Are there things that the judges can say in the Lords that are so valuable that they must be said as part of the legislative process itself rather than as an attempt to influence it from the outside - which is where every other profession and group in our society finds itself?

I doubt it: the judges are not a weak group of marginalised persons in need of this special treatment. Their participation in the Lords is a Victorian anachronism which surely need not survive the further reform of the chamber.

(This is not to say that they should be given some new "dome"-like structure or some grand new title such as Supreme Court by way of consolation; the judicial committee of the privy council could be developed into a review court or the appellate committee of the Lords be reconstituted as a final court of appeal.)

Post Human Rights Act the presence not just of the lord chancellor but of all the law lords in the legislative chamber will no doubt be raised sooner rather than later.

For no one could have expected that the legislative branch itself would invite the judiciary to exercise legislative power of a far more general and pervasive nature than has ever hitherto been countenanced. This is the effect of the new Human Rights Act. The act positively mandates the judiciary to transform its function.

One challenge will be to guide the measure away from the kind of constipated legalism with which the adversarial system invariably seeks to both swamp and destroy all novel laws. Here the signs are not good. There have been some decisions in Scotland which have adopted a highly legalistic and very narrow approach to the act.

We also need now to work out the best way of getting the full facts before a court so that when it makes a ruling under the Human Rights Act, it does so explicitly acknowledging its legislative character and with a clear understanding of its widespread implications. This goes further than the occasional amicus brief or the importation, without more, of American ideas drawn from a different constitutional culture.

The higher courts should have appointed to them a "public interest officer" with a small team of officials, to prepare reports on the effects of possible rulings not just on the law but on the wider public and on society as a whole.

Such an officer is absolutely necessitated by parliament's insistence that the effectiveness and continuing operation of legislation not be irreparably damaged by judicial interpretation.

How can judges know about such operational matters? How can the lawyers for the litigants know? How can the court be sure that an amicus brief that has been filed is authoritative? The advantage of a "public interest statement" filed by a court officer would be that it would take such huge issues out of the narrow and artificial confines of the adversarial process, and it would also open up the process to persons other than lawyers.

In the new era the judges are going to have to gird themselves to be treated far more politically than in the past. The main opposition party in Ireland has recently published proposals under which the judges would be overseen by a judicial board and individual judges subjected to penalties where the board thought they had got things wrong.

The UK pressure for appointment only after a process of selection involving parliament should not be resisted. There will soon be in the select committee on human rights an ideal forum for such (let us call them) "confirmation hearings".

Now everybody recoils from this because of the US experience. But there are not nearly so many controversial candidacies in the US as is widely believed, and the main ones we know about - those involving Robert Bork and Clarence Thomas - were rightly controversial in my view. US federal judges have, in the main, drawn a degree of comfort from their confirmation hearings, feeling that it has given them at least a degree of democratic legitimacy in relation to their subsequent judicial work.

I also think senior UK judges will have to be prepared to meet parliament to explain in general terms what is happening in the courts under the Human Rights Act and to defend - not specific decisions but general policy developments.

The committee might quite legitimately want to investigate, for example, what has happened to parliament's criminal statutes under the Human Rights Act. Or it might want to assess the cost of particular decisions, or the rationale behind some particularly controversial declaration of incompatibility.

All this will be very new for the judges. But far from being antagonistic about such developments, they should welcome them.

Extracted from a lecture on Monday by the professor of human rights law at King's College London

webTitle: Centenarian dies after opening Queen's birthday message

fields.headline: Centenarian dies after opening Queen's birthday message
fields.trailText: Centenarian Robert Talley died happy, collapsing moments after he opened his 100th birthday message from the Queen and gasped: "Yes, I made it."
fields.body:
Centenarian Robert Talley died happy, collapsing moments after he opened his 100th birthday message from the Queen and gasped: "Yes, I made it."

The pensioner was apparently overcome with joy at receiving the message two weeks ago. He was suffering from a serious chest infection but had told his carers he was determined to live long enough to open the royal envelope.

He had already fought against the odds, surviving a brutal mugging in 1985 in which he was stabbed 22 times. A source at the Braganza nursing home in Kennington, south London, where Mr Talley spent his last years, said: "He died on his 100th birthday and was overjoyed to get the card. He was a lovely man, a real character and everyone loved him."

A Buckingham Palace spokesman said: "It is good to know that Robert Talley received his congratulatory card from the Queen, particularly as he was looking forward to it so much. Of course it is very sad to learn that he died so shortly afterwards."

Mr Talley's friends and family were due to join him for a special party. One friend had flown from Australia to join the celebrations.

A friend, Fred Ricketts, said Mr Talley was known by everyone around his former East Dulwich home. He enjoyed whisky, gambling and his catchphrase was "God bless you". He died two weeks ago and will be cremated at Honor Oak crematorium, south London, tomorrow.

The 100th birthday telegram is a tradition that began in 1917, with even the Queen Mother receiving one from her daughter. The number of cards sent each year is rising, a trend which is thought to reflect more applications as well as increased longevity.

webTitle: Despair of workers who heard of job cuts on local news bulletin

fields.headline: Despair of workers who heard of job cuts on local news bulletin
fields.trailText: Vauxhall workers spoke yesterday of their betrayal at the "Christmas present" of thousands of job losses.
fields.body:
Vauxhall workers spoke yesterday of their betrayal at the "Christmas present" of thousands of job losses.

Workers spilled out of the giant Luton plant into the rain-swept car park and mourned the end of a tradition in which jobs had been handed down from father to son. Most heard of it on the local lunchtime radio news.

Lineworker Bob Bhungal, 25, who had followed in his father's footsteps to work at the factory, said: "We feel we've been betrayed. I've worked here for five years and every year we had improved productivity and quality.

"We accepted terrible pay rises to keep our jobs in exchange for promises that they were safe, but they didn't turn out to be worth anything.

"They did not even tell us themselves - we had to hear it first on the news. All we have got to look forward to now is our redundancy cheques."

The news has spread trepidation among small businesses in the shadow of the Vauxhall plant on which they depend.

webTitle: Nowhere to hide in global car market

fields.headline: Nowhere to hide in global car market
fields.standfirst: UK may have outdone rest of Europe in attracting automobile giants, but drive for rationalisation knows no boundaries in face of overcapacity
fields.trailText: UK may have outdone rest of Europe in attracting automobile giants, but drive for rationalisation knows no boundaries in face of overcapacity
fields.body:
Both Tory and Labour governments have prided themselves on making Britain one of the easiest countries in Europe in which to invest, and the effort has paid off with a flurry of foreign car plants.

But the blunt message to Tony Blair from the decision to close Luton for car production is that it is easy to come, easy to go (even if Vauxhall has been at the Bedfordshire town since 1905, and the US company General Motors has owned the firm since 1925).

Easy come, easy go is not just the view of angry trade unions, which were forced recently to watch impotently as Ford announced plans to cease car output at Dagenham, in Essex.

It is the view of respected academics such as Garel Rhys, a professor at the University of Cardiff, who recently upset the unions when he dismissed apocalyptic estimates by them of ancillary job losses should Dagenham shut.

Prof Rhys says there is no doubt it is easier to shut down capacity in Britain than it is in, say, Germany - for tax, labour and general business reasons.

Is it any surprise then that both Ford and General Motors have opted to axe their British plants in favour of building new models in Germany?

But with or without the laissez-faire business environment in the UK, the forces of globalisation can wreak havoc, says Prof Rhys. "The lessons for government in this are that in modern manufacturing there is nowhere to hide. With no tariffs or quotas to be eroded, business can go wherever it wants. You cannot take it for granted any more that anything stays in the UK."

This warning seems dire but easily credible in what is described by John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, as "rapidly becoming UK manufacturing's blackest week". In seven days thousands of textile workers in Derbyshire, shipyard workers on Merseyside, and steel workers in Wales have been dismissed or face redundancy.

That is on top of the 1,300 to lose their jobs at Dagenham and 1,500 gone already; and on top of the 1,000 who left Longbridge when MG Rover took over from BMW. Attention will switch to Sunderland, where Nissan has the most productive plant in Europe but still makes a thumping loss. The Japanese firm could opt to build its new Micra in France. If so, the 1,700 employed on the current model will eventually lose their jobs. Losing a new design will also damage morale and put a question mark over those working on the Primera.

After that the spotlight could return to MG Rover, with 5,500 workers still at Longbridge. There has been speculation the firm will find it dif ficult to survive in the volume car business while making only 200,000 a year. There have also been boardroom rifts and on-off talks with potential partners, but so far management and unions are united that Rover can thrive.

More worrying for the car industry have been statements from Honda, hitherto considered a beacon of success at its purpose-built site in Swindon. The firm disclosed last month it did not expect its European operations, including Swindon, to return to profit until 2003 - a year later than planned. Minoru Harada, president of Honda Europe, has said the firm would definitely not build a car plant in Britain today, because of the strength of sterling, and repeatedly urged the government to join the euro.

Currency is a problem, but also a convenient smokescreen. It is global overcapacity and the need for rationalisation that threatens to drive away the multinationals from an island that once looked so attractive.

Fears over weakness of euro against pound

Workers fear for 1,700 jobs at Nissan's Sunderland plant if the Japanese firm builds its new Micra model in France. Most of the Micra and Primera models built by the 5,000 employed at the UK plant are sold on the continent. Sunderland is Europe's most efficient car plant but is running at a loss because of the high value of sterling; its position is worsened by Peugeot buying a 36.8% stake in Nissan. Peugeot is pushing Nissan to build the Micra in France alongside a Peugeot model.

Ford has announced plans to close car production at Dagenham, Essex, in 2002, with the loss of at least 1,300 jobs. Ford says it is committed to expanding the diesel engine assembly plant but unions fear other Ford car assembly plants in Britain could close too. Union officials called for a strike of all 7,000 workers there but a majority voted against industrial action. Ford had considered building a new Fiesta model in Essex but decided instead on its Cologne plant in Germany. The firm has scaled back many operations worldwide. It dropped a £5bn move to buy the ailing South Korean car company, Daewoo Motor, in September.

MG Rover's commitment to the Longbridge car plant in the Midlands, has been debated since Rover was bought from BMW in the summer. The unions and 5,500 workers have defended the management team. But there have been boardroom rifts. Critics say MG Rover will be lucky to survive making just 200,000 cars a year.

Honda worried its 3,000 workers in Swindon after it binned plans to construct a "super mini" in Britain. The Japanese group blamed the weakness of the euro and pricing uncertainty in the UK car market for its decision to build the new car in Japan. It also says it will not build a greenfield plant in the UK and questions the future of UK car manufacturing with a strong pound. The firm makes 90,000 vehicles. With a second plant near Swindon it could build 250,000 cars.

webTitle: Spoof mocks scare stories

fields.headline: Spoof mocks scare stories
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Brussels bureaucrats are stepping up their campaign to destroy the British of way of life by banning Christmas.
fields.body:
Brussels bureaucrats are stepping up their campaign to destroy the British of way of life by banning Christmas.

Heartbroken children will be relieved to know that the plan is, of course, a joke. Pro-European campaigners have decided to poke fun at British tabloids, who run endless scare stories over Europe, by producing a spoof front page with the headline: "Brussels Plot To Ban Christmas."

The Christmas card from the Britain in Europe group reveals under a "world exclusive" banner that Santa is to be made redundant by Brussels.

Aping the language of anti-European tabloids, the Myth newspaper reports: "Santa could be jobless under a new Brussels plot to ban Christmas, the Myth can exclusively reveal. A storm of protest is expected from children looking forward to Santa's annual visit." Thousands of the cards were sent out last night to friends and foes of the Britain in Europe campaign, including the prime minister and senior executives of the Sun.

Britain in Europe described the card as a light-hearted attempt to poke fun at "anti-European myth makers". Danny Alexander, a spokesman, said: "We are confident that we will not scare children who are sensible enough not to believe the sort of euro myths peddled by the tabloids."

webTitle: Comment: Corruption in the third world is our problem

fields.headline: Corruption in the third world is our problem
fields.standfirst:
Britain is slow to punish businessmen who offer bribes abroad

Special report: Globalisation
fields.trailText: Britain is slow to punish businessmen who offer bribes abroad
fields.body:
You bribe a foreign official to give your company a contract. It works and you get the business. You escape prosecution in Britain because corruption performed abroad is not illegal here. Better still, the British government gives you a tax break because "commissions" paid abroad are accepted as a deductible expense.

Not bad going, and in the fourth year of New Labour's tenure there is still no action to change things. The tireless Clare Short made a big issue of corruption in the Department of International Development's white paper on globalisation this week, but much of her fire was directed at kickbacks taken by foreign officials from their compatriots rather than from foreigners.

It is certainly true that poor people suffer most from corruption. In developing countries and most of the so-called transition economies in the former Soviet Union and eastern Europe, people often have to bribe teachers and doctors to get services which are supposed to be free. Local police and judges frequently want their palms greased. Foreign-donated medicines and other items of aid disappear into private hands.

Most non-governmental organisations working in the third world have not made enough of these scandals for fear of discrediting aid in general or making reform look too difficult. So the Department for International Development's focus on this prevalent but "petty" corruption is welcome.

The government is also promising to help countries tackle the "grand" corruption involving politicians, senior officials, and businessmen. In last week's Queen's speech, the government pledged to bring in a bill to strengthen the law on money laundering and make it easier for countries to recover funds which their leaders or officials acquired corruptly and deposited in British banks. Yet for every Marcos, Milosevic, or Mobutu there is a British salesman or senior executive who has offered cash illegally abroad. When is action going to be taken in this country against them?

Britain's record is poor. Last summer the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development reviewed the action rich countries had taken to implement its 1997 anti-bribery convention. It found Britain was falling behind almost everyone else. Although it had ratified the convention, it had no law which explicitly criminalised bribery of foreign officials. When New Labour came to power, it initially followed in its predecessor's footsteps in arguing that a 1906 statute on bribery at home implicitly covered bribery abroad. Yet in more than 90 years there had not been a single prosecution under this law.

British companies are among the worst offenders. Some 37 of the 55 companies which the World Bank publicly blacklists and has disbarred from participating in its contracts because of evidence of corruption are domiciled in Britain. Transparency International, which publishes a "bribe-payers' survey", based on perceptions by business executives and professionals in the third world of how foreign companies behave, confirms that bribes are most common in the arms trade, public works and big infrastructure projects. British companies are among the strongest players in all these sectors.

This summer the government accepted that a new law is needed to bring bribery by Britons abroad under the jurisdiction of British courts and remove the problem of "extra-territoriality". Ministers made all the right noises in a discussion paper.

"Corruption is like a deadly virus. It has no boundaries. We need to fight it wherever it is found," thundered Jack Straw, the home secretary. "For too long dishonest individuals have profited at the expense of undermining the integrity of professional and public life in this country. The international business community increasingly realises that a culture of corruption is a disincentive to investment and trade."

Richard Caborn, the trade minister, added his own controlled wrath: "The government believes that bribery has no place in a modern economy. These proposals demonstrate our determination to be at the forefront of international efforts to stamp out bribery."

Yet the government continues to delay. It says the money-laundering bill which it will publish this session will not be given time until the next parliament. The same holds for its promised bill to tighten controls on the arms trade. The anti-bribery bill is in even worse shape. There is no commitment even to publish it this session, nor is drafting firmly on track within Whitehall to have it ready for the next one.

The OECD's inter-governmental working group, which provides peer-group review on compliance, came close to censuring Britain this autumn for this failure to honour its convention obligations. "British companies could be considered unsafe until new legislation is in force," said Professor Mark Pieth, the Swiss lawyer who chairs it. At the time the OECD was fobbed off with the promise that legislation was on the way. Now it has been delayed again, to the anger of the US, France, and other countries which feel Britain is trying to steal business through laxer standards.

The Department of Trade and Industry made one important advance this month when it joined other OECD member states in agreeing on an action programme to deter bribery in government-supported export credit transactions. From now on the export credit and insurance agencies of OECD countries will demand signed statements from companies applying for coverage, stating they will not engage in bribery. If bribery is established, the agency will reject claims for indemnification and refer the case to the judicial authorities. This could act as a powerful deterrent, provided it is enforced.

Bribery is notoriously difficult to establish. The OECD guidelines recognise that small "facilitation" payments to obtain licences in a foreign country cannot realistically be pursued, although it declines to set a size limit. When a sales commission amounts to a quarter or half of a contract's value, the bells of suspicion must ring. Payments of this size cannot easily be explained, if auditing procedures require them to be clarified.

When she introduced her white paper this week, Clare Short renewed the government's pledge "to put our own house in order" by passing anti-bribery legislation. Yet it remains blocked. If the problem is only that parliamentary time is limited, there is no reason why clauses outlawing foreign bribery could not be added to the bill the government is proposing on money laundering.

The home secretary, the trade minister, and Clare Short all favour action. So where are the forces of conservatism stopping progress? Is the problem the prime minister and his wish to appear business-friendly at all costs?

webTitle: Leader: Clinton will still be needed after the presidency

fields.headline: Clinton's cheer
fields.standfirst:
He will still be needed after the presidency

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: He will still be needed after the presidency.
fields.body:
Guinness must be grinning. As if it's not enough that the brewing company can claim the greatest television advertisement of all time - the surfers and white horses, currently airing again on British TV - they were handed yesterday the ideal moment of free publicity. It was every advertising exec's dream: the most powerful man in the world, sipping a Guinness.

The image was the photo opportunity heart of the Irish leg of Bill Clinton's visit to these islands, which will see a further stint in Belfast today and Britain tomorrow. The picture caught the spirit of this, which is perhaps Mr Clinton's last foreign trip as US president, perfectly: for, like the drink, Mr Clinton's mission is designed to be warming, full of heart and a little bit frothy.

He played just that role yesterday, addressing Irish leaders in a Guinness brewery in Dublin. He spoke only briefly, light on the detail, happy to stick with generalities.

That was right: at this late stage of his presidency, Mr Clinton can no longer be the nitty-gritty broker. Instead, he is seeking to spread a feelgood, festive mood - by urging all the people of Ireland to raise their sights and concentrate on the big picture."Nobody wants to go back to the troubles," he said yesterday, a statement of the obvious which can nevertheless often be forgotten amid all the bitterness over issues like police reform and decommissioning. And then he appealed to Irish pride, suggesting that American involvement in the peace process would only ever be a "tiny" repayment of "all the massive gifts" the Irish nation had endowed, via its migrants, on the United States.

There is no doubt that this kind of talk, delivered as winningly as Mr Clinton does it, can only help. Ever since he became involved in Northern Ireland, the president's pleas for both traditions to find "the courage to compromise" have helped the province's politicians rise above their immediate disputes and think - if only for a while - like statesmen. We hope they work their healing magic once again now, breaking the current logjam.

So if the persistent hints that the president might carry on pushing for peace, even after he leaves office, turn out to have been right, Northern Ireland should, for once in a while, consider itself very fortunate. For, as Guinness already knows, there can be few more potent allies to have on your side.

webTitle: 'Vacuum' in Hamilton claim

fields.headline: 'Vacuum' in Hamilton claim
fields.trailText: A claim that documents were stolen to help Mohamed Al Fayed's battle with Neil Hamilton was supported by evidence that had only emerged in bizarre circumstances worthy of a Jeffrey Archer play, the appeal court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A claim that documents were stolen to help Mohamed Al Fayed's battle with Neil Hamilton was supported by evidence that had only emerged in bizarre circumstances worthy of a Jeffrey Archer play, the appeal court heard yesterday.

The disgraced former Conservative minister is claiming that the outcome of his failed libel action against Mr Fayed is invalid, because papers taken from his lawyer's bins were passed on to the Harrods owner.

On the second day of Mr Hamilton's attempt to set aside the jury's verdict against him, Michael Beloff QC, for Mr Fayed, said the claim was "so flimsy" as not to even require a factual rebuttal.

Lawyers for Mr Hamilton say that the papers were taken from rubbish outside the chambers of his counsel, Desmond Browne QC, by one Benjamin Pell, who makes a living from rifling the bins of the rich, famous and powerful.

The papers were handed, Mr Hamilton claims, to a freelance journalist, Mark Hollingsworth, who has worked for Mr Fayed for some years and was employed to help him with the libel case. Mr Hamilton claims that Mr Hollingsworth was paid £10,000 for the papers by Mr Fayed.

Mr Beloff said that Mr Fayed disputed the allegation, and was available to be cross-examined if the court required. He said there was no proof that the papers had reached Mr Fayed, and he attacked Mr Pell and Mr Hollingsworth. The alleged transaction between them had been a "seedy money making exercise".

Mr Beloff said that tapes of conversations involving the pair that are being used by Mr Hamilton's side to support his case had surfaced in "bizarre circumstances" that would "do credit to a play by Jeffrey Archer".

He did not spell out what the circumstances were - though on Monday the court heard that two tapes were found in a burned-out van - but went on to dismiss their content because they had clearly been edited and were out of sequence. "They are utterly corrupt in every conceivable way."

Mr Beloff said there was, in any case, a "vacuum" in Mr Hamilton's claim, in that there was no proof that any information that could have been culled from the documents had in fact been used to help Mr Fayed's case.

Counsel for Mr Hamilton has argued that the papers included clear and detailed notes of how witnesses supporting Mr Fayed were to be cross-examined.

Mr Beloff countered: "They were in truth dustbin-type documents."

Mr Hamilton has been fighting to clear his name since 1994 when the Guardian reported the "cash-for-questions" controversy.

Mr Hamilton subsequently sued Mr Fayed over claims he made in a Channel 4 documentary that the former MP demanded and received thousands of pounds in cash, Harrods gift vouchers, and hospitality at the Ritz Hotel in Paris in return for parliamentary services.

Mr Fayed pleaded justification - that the allegations were true - and the jury found in his favour.

Mr Hamilton is now asking permission for a full appeal to be brought, claiming the verdict should be set aside.

Yesterday his counsel, Anthony Boswood QC, compared Mr Fayed to an Olympic champion who had been found to have cheated and should pay the penalty. Mr Boswood told the court: "He should be deprived of his medal and banned for life."

He said judgment should be made in favour of Mr Hamilton, who would then have to consider whether to pursue damages, given that such a ruling would not clear his name.

The costs orders imposed on Mr Hamilton after the libel trial should also be set aside. A £2m legal bill meant he faced "imminent bankruptcy".

Mr Beloff countered that, even if the appeal judges found in Mr Hamilton's favour, the most he would be entitled to was a re-trial.

"It would certainly not be in the public interest for him to obtain a verdict in his favour at this juncture," he said.

Mr Fayed has been put on standby to appear in the witness box today if required.

The case continues.

webTitle: Vauxhall axes 2,000

fields.headline: Vauxhall axes 2,000
fields.standfirst: Luton car plant to close despite improved productivity
fields.trailText: Luton car plant to close despite improved productivity
fields.body:
Vauxhall yesterday unveiled plans to axe 2,000 jobs and cease car production at Luton, one of the country's more efficient plants, sending shock waves through British manufacturing.

The move comes weeks after Ford announced the end of car production at Dagenham, while there are continuing fears about the future of jobs at Nissan and MG Rover.

The unions reacted with fury to what they called a "bolt out of the blue" and believe there will be a further 5,500 redundancies among Vauxhall suppliers. They vowed to fight the closure in Bedfordshire where 146,000 cars a year are produced and where a new Vectra model was expected to be built. Vauxhall has been building cars in Luton since 1905.

The General Motors subsidiary had announced plans to invest £189m in Britain with £32m earmarked for the Luton plant and more for its Ellesmere Port facility on Merseyside.

But a company spokesman insisted: "Since those decisions were made, circumstances have changed, with a substantial reduction in expected demand for cars in the Vectra segment and this has been matched by an increasingly competitive environment."

Overcapacity in Europe was the main reason for the restructuring but it admitted the strength of the pound played a part. Government policies designed to help consumers by hammering down the price of cars also played their part. In total, 5,000 staff are to be axed in Europe while 10,000 GM workers in North America are to be sacked as part of a global shake-up by the Detroit-based company.

The company, like Ford, has also found itself failing to keep up with the more innovative designs that have been pouring out of French and Italian manufacturers. While huge productivity gains have been made at Luton, they have failed to match the relative gains of those same continental companies such as Peugeot.

Car production will cease at Luton from the first quarter of 2002 but Vauxhall will retain production of vans and off-road vehicles.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, described the move as "a bitter blow" but made clear the government would not try to get Vauxhall to change its mind.

He explained: "Our key aim will be to find new job opportunities to replace those being lost over the next year and the government is determined to play its part."

Mr Byers said the government would help companies in the supply chain to diversify and find new business as well as working with Vauxhall, local authorities and other relevant bodies to provide a package of advice and assistance to those affected by the decision.

Manufacturing is being badly battered at a politically sensitive time with a general election expected next year. Around 1,200 textile jobs are to be cut by the former Coats Viyella company while Cammell Laird has announced 250 shipyard lay-offs. Last week the former British Steel group, Corus, unveiled plans to restructure which some fear could cost a further 6,000 jobs, while Nissan could decide to build its new Micra car model in France rather than Britain.

David Heathcoat-Amory, shadow trade and industry secretary, said his party had been warning that higher tax and regulatory burdens would affect jobs. "These job losses are a massive blow to the UK's manufacturing base and and a personal tragedy for the workers. Again the government has been caught unawares."

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said he was particularly angry because the work force at Luton had met all its productivity targets and had been promised a new car model. "This has come as a massive bolt out of the blue. It is unacceptable to announce something like this two weeks before Christmas."

Garel Rhys, a car industry expert from Cardiff University business school, said he was "very surprised" at the news from Vauxhall.

"This just shows it does not matter how productive you have become; if you cannot sell your cars, then no plant is safe. There is overcapacity in Europe which has badly hit Ford. General Motors has shown it was determined not to be caught out in the same way and has acted to stop this."

Professor Rhys said the high pound was only a marginal factor. More telling was perhaps that Luton was a relatively old plant that struggled to compete as effectively as a greenfield site.

GM has seen its European operations swing from a $32m (£22.8m) profit to a $181m loss in the third quarter of the year and predicts worse to come.

In total, the job cuts affect 5% of GM's 224,600-strong US workforce. The world's largest car company employs about 388,000 people worldwide.

webTitle: Regions take centre stage

fields.headline: Regions take centre stage
fields.standfirst:
Labour is developing new policies for its old heartlands

Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: Labour is developing new policies for its old heartlands
fields.body:
Big job losses announced yesterday, in the car industry in Luton and in shipbuilding on Merseyside, came as Labour prepared to give a clear sign that it plans to bring regional policy in from the cold if it wins a second term.

The government's strategy to spread prosperity out from the thriving south-east is outlined today in a paper for the think tank, the Smith Institute, edited by two aides to Gordon Brown, Ed Balls, the chief economist at the Treasury, and John Healey, the chancellor's parliamentary private secretary.

An indication of the high priority given to the issue is that the paper will be launched at 11 Downing Street this morning, with many chairs of regional development agencies (RDAs) in attendnance before a meeting with treasury officials.

To show the policy is intended to cut across departments, the introduction is penned by Dick Caborn, the trade minister, and is peppered with references to work being carried out by John Prescott's department for the environment, transport and the regions.

At the root is the realisation that grumbling in Labour heartlands about being forgotten has a point. Under the Conservatives, regional policy was downgraded to trying to attract inward investment. Meanwhile, the economy's centre of gravity shifted towards London and the south-east, a trend that has not been arrested under Labour, though unemployment has come down in all regions.

As such, regional policy - albeit with a New Labour twist - is being rehabilitated, with the new regional development agencies given power and resources to act.

Mr Balls, says that although six of the eight English regions have incomes per head below the European average "there is nothing inevitable about regional inequalities - in incomes, employment or opportunity. Those regions and cities which led Britain in the 19th century can lead again in the 21st century."

But the old approaches - either emergency assistance to declining industries or the capital injections and tax incentives tried in the 1960s and 1970s - are out. Instead, the emphasis is on a regional policy that is bottom-up not top-down, flexible and driven by the need to deliver greater accountability and scrutiny.

The paper rejects the idea that salvation for the regions would come from macro-economic policies aimed at reducing the value of sterling. "We have tried that approach before and it was the manufacturing industry, the long-term unemployed and the regions of Britain that paid the price."

Instead, the government would like to build clusters of success, in which companies integrate their operations, take advantage of economies of scale and draw on a pool of specialised labour. Labour believes high rents, congestion and the costs of scale are making London an expensive place to locate. With improved communications technology there are attractions for firms to move outside the south-east.

There have already been initiatives such as 12 institutes for enterprise across the regions and the University Challenge scheme to support innovation. There is a recognition from Mr Balls that the government did not get everything right. Many RDA chairs felt hampered by restrictions on their budgets, their ability to direct resources to meet economic priorities and the fact they have been reporting to three departments. Mr Balls says these problems have been addressed, with extra money, better focus for RDAs on economic development and regeneration, and greater flexibility for RDAs to shift resources to local priorities. "In return, the RDAs will have to demonstrate top class leadership, coordinate with other regional and local partners and be more accountable for their actions - locally, regionally and nationally."

The pamphlet reveals how Yorkshire Forward, which covers Yorkshire and Humberside has signed up to measurable targets, including the creation of 150,000 jobs by 2010 and doubling the rate of small business start-ups.

Mr Healey concludes that a report on Labour's first term might read: "Slow start. shows promise". He suggests a long term strategy that aims for a wider spread of economic assets such as airports, universities, research labs and government offices will be essential.

webTitle: Mugabe turns thugs on critics within his party

fields.headline: Mugabe turns thugs on critics within his party
fields.standfirst:
Dissidents risk expulsion or worse at special congress of Zimbabwe's ruling party

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's ruling party opens an extraordinary congress today with the one issue on everyone's lips officially off the agenda - Robert Mugabe's future.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's ruling party opens an extraordinary congress today with the one issue on everyone's lips officially off the agenda - Robert Mugabe's future.

The Zanu-PF party has purged and sidelined critics of Zimbabwe's beleaguered president ahead of the meeting - and used the thuggish "war veterans" against dissidents in the way they were earlier used against white farmers - in an attempt to stifle accusations that Mr Mugabe is driving the party towards its doom.

Issues that are on the agenda, however - including land reform - potentially open the way for more daring critics to press for the president to stand down before the 2002 election.

Mr Mugabe goes into the meeting amid open hostility from former allies in the party and the tepid backing of some of his own cabinet, including the finance minister who has cast doubt on the president's leadership.

But Mugabe loyalists, such as the former cabinet minister and key politburo member Nathan Shamuyarira, say there is no question of the president being challenged.

"We are quite happy with President Mugabe's leadership. He's dynamic, he's forceful, he's given good leadership on the land issue. He was elected leader of the party in December last year. Mugabe is our president and will be our candidate," he said.

The country's financial and polling numbers should spell Mr Mugabe's doom as president. Inflation, unemployment and poverty surged this year as the land conflict helped contract the economy by 5%. Nearly half the government's expenditure is on debt interest, much of it short-term loans taken out to deal with the crisis.

Spending on health is now below the level it held at independence 20 years ago, and Zimbabwe can afford only half its fuel needs. With the occupation of white-owned farms continuing, and crop production declining as a result, critical food shortages look increasingly likely.

In September, a senior World Bank official in Zimbabwe, Rogier van den Brink, warned that the only way out of the crisis was for the present government to go.

"A wide cross-section of economists tend to agree that a successful political transition, as illustrated by restoration of law and order and a more pluralistic political dispensation, is the key to a suc cessful economic stabilisation and recovery," he said.

The best hope for that transition is the 2002 presidential election. If Mr Mugabe stands again as Zanu-PF's candidate, he faces almost certain defeat in a free and fair poll.

According to a comprehensive survey by South Africa's Helen Suzman Foundation in October, support for the president and the ruling party had fallen sharply since its narrow victory over the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) in parliamentary elections six months ago.

Zanu-PF has the backing of just one in five voters, the survey found; three-quarters want Mr Mugabe to step down immediately, and half the voters think he should be put on trial for the Matabeleland massacres in the early 1980s and the election violence earlier this year.

In contrast, just 5% of Zimbabweans blame their country's problems on the white population and more than half of voters, including a substantial number of Zanu-PF supporters, believe that whites who emigrate are an important loss to the country.

With public dissatisfaction growing, it is little surprise that the party is struggling to keep a lid on internal dissent. Among the more open critics of Mr Mugabe's policies is the politburo member and former cabinet minister, Eddison Zvobgo. In September, by now out of office, he offered the most forthright denunciation of the government ever heard in parliament.

"We have tainted what was a glorious revolution, reducing it to some agrarian racist enterprise," he said. "We have behaved as if the world owes us a living. It does not. We have blamed other people for each and every ill that befell us. As every peasant, worker, businessman or woman now stares at the precipice of doom, let us wake up and draw back. We must clear the slate, bury everything that has divided us, and begin again."

Mr Zvobgo has already lost his cabinet post and the war veterans have been used to take over the party leadership in his own province, Masvingo. His days in the politburo are probably numbered but on Monday, in a sign that he speaks for more than himself, the Zanu-PF politburo said it would permit a "Zvobgo faction" to attend the congress.

Others have been more subtle but their message is no less clear.

Zimbabwe's finance minister, Simba Makoni, gives a less than wholehearted endorsement of Mr Mugabe when asked if the president can win another election.

"The majority of Zimbabweans need political leadership that leads the country out of the present social and economic problems. If President Mugabe delivers that leadership, I'm sure Zimbabweans will vote for him. If he doesn't deliver the leadership, they will not vote for him," he said.

Is he delivering the leadership?

"Time will tell," he said.

Some have left or been thrown out of the party for challenging Mr Mugabe's policies.

Moses Mvenge, parliamentary chief whip until this year's election and a founder of Zanu-PF, won no friends for questioning excessive government spending and exposing large-scale corruption in the building of Harare's new airport.

"Zanu has one major weakness. It is not able to reform itself. What the party was when it was formed in 1963 it is now," he said. "It all comes back to one man. The politburo is appointed by the president. The cabinet is appointed by the president. They are paying allegiance to one man. Our party never used to be like this. We never wanted this hero-worshipping of an individual. It started at independence."

"We are quite happy with President Mugabe's leadership. He's dynamic, he's forceful, he's given good leadership on the land issue. He was elected leader of the party in December last year. Mugabe is our president and will be our candidate," he said. The country's financial and polling numbers should spell Mr Mugabe's doom as president. Inflation, unemployment and poverty surged this year as the land conflict helped contract the economy by 5%. Nearly half the government's expenditure is on debt interest, much of it short-term loans taken out to deal with the crisis. webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Drink coffee, smokers told

Coffee drinking may protect smokers against bladder cancer, scientists reported yesterday in the Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health. Researchers in Spain found that smokers who drank fewer than two cups of coffee a week were seven times more likely to contract the disease than non-smokers. The figure dropped to three times the risk for smokers who did drink coffee.
fields.body:
Drink coffee, smokers told
Coffee drinking may protect smokers against bladder cancer, scientists reported yesterday in the Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health. Researchers in Spain found that smokers who drank fewer than two cups of coffee a week were seven times more likely to contract the disease than non-smokers. The figure dropped to three times the risk for smokers who did drink coffee.

Royal PC in gun blunder retires
A royal bodyguard who twice fired his gun accidentally on the royal train last June as the Queen slept nearby is retiring. PC Michael Slade, 60, of Scotland Yard's royalty protection group, met the Queen in a farewell audience at Buckingham Palace yesterday.

Councils face food inquiry
Food and hygiene inspections by 18 local authorities are to be investigated by the Food Standards Agency, after they failed to persuade the food watchdog they are doing the job properly.

Mystery of dead birds
Hundreds of dead and dying sea birds have been found on remote beaches in Scapa Flow, Orkney. The RSPB admits it is puzzled as to the cause and is to conduct post mortem examinations on some of the birds, which include guillemots, puffins and razorbills.

Robbery victim barmaid dies
A 38-year-old barmaid died yesterday, two days after being attacked by two masked robbers outside Harleys pub in Ipswich, Suffolk.

Rover to race at Le Mans
MG Rover is to return to international motor racing and in June will compete in the Le Mans 24-hour race for the first time in 36 years. The ex-BMW subsidiary is developing a range of sports cars with the motorsport specialist Lola Cars.

False alarm at Heathrow
A BA 747 about to take off for Miami was held up for seven hours at Heathrow on Monday when a crew member found cards with Arabic writing in a toilet. The 329 passengers had to wait while the plane was searched by security staff. Nothing was found, and it turned out the cards were advertising a calendar.

Soldiers killed on railway line
Two young soldiers were found dead on electrified track near Poole station in Dorset late on Monday night, after a member of the public saw smoke and reported the smell of burning. The unnamed men were based in nearby Hamworthy, and transport police said it appeared they had attempted a short cut back.

£2,000 hello for social workers
To remedy a shortage of staff Oxfordshire social services is offering £2,000 to diploma students in the city if they agree to work for the county for at least two years. It is also raising the pay for social workers by £1,065 to £23,259 pa.

Mothers get the night shift
A third of first-time mothers report being deprived of sleep in the four months after their baby's birth, according to a survey by Johnson & Johnson. In most cases it was not the father who leapt out of bed in the night - 85% of women said they got up to answer cries, 11% shared, and only 4% said their partner took the role.

webTitle: Billionaire brothers could face extradition over Indian arms deal

fields.headline: Billionaire brothers could face extradition over Indian arms deal
fields.trailText: The billionaire Hinduja brothers last night faced the embarrassing prospect of returning to India in connection with a long-running corruption scandal after a judge ordered their appearance at court within the next month.
fields.body:
The billionaire Hinduja brothers last night faced the embarrassing prospect of returning to India in connection with a long-running corruption scandal after a judge ordered their appearance at court within the next month.

Srichand, Gopichand and Prakesh Hinduja, who rescued the Millennium Dome's faith zone and entertained Tony Blair to a Diwali dinner last year, could be extradited from Britain if they fail to appear before the judge, Arjit Bharihoke, on January 19.

The Hindujas' lawyers have assured the court that the industrialists intend to co-operate. During a one-minute hearing, Judge Bharihoke rejected arguments that the Hindujas should get the chance to have the case thrown out now for lack of evidence. The brothers can appeal but last night Ujwal Rana, one of their lawyers in Delhi, said: "We have not yet received a copy of the order and until we consider that we will not be able to advise."

The Hindujas, who control a global business empire, are accused of receiving £6m in illegal payments from the Swedish arms manufacturer AB Bofors in 1986. The case concerns "kickbacks" allegedly paid by Bofors to secure an £800m deal to supply howitzer cannons to India. The brothers deny involvement in the scandal, which helped bring down Rajiv Gandhi's government three years later.

Indian prosecutors claim that between May and December 1986 Bofors made three illegal payments of Swedish kroner into three Swiss bank accounts codenamed Tulip, Lotus and Mont Blanc, and say the accounts were controlled by the Hindujas. In October India's central bureau of investigation filed a list of proposed charges against Srichand, 63, Gopichand, 59, and Prakash, accusing them of criminal conspiracy, cheating and offences under India's Prevention of Corruption Act.

Srichand and Gopichand, who live in London, recently obtained British citizenship. Prakash lives in Switzerland. The brothers accept that the money came from the Axonobel Group, which is part of Bofors, but insist it was part of their business dealings with the Swedish firm and nothing to do with the howitzers.

The case is a huge embarrassment to India's main opposition Congress Party, led by Rajiv Gandhi's widow, Sonia. Prosecutors have made it clear that Rajiv would have been indicted if he had not been assassinated in 1991.

webTitle: Storms bring flood alerts

fields.headline: Storms bring flood alerts
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Many parts of England and Wales were on flood alert last night as high tides, heavy rain and strong winds combined to create severe weather conditions.
fields.body:
Many parts of England and Wales were on flood alert last night as high tides, heavy rain and strong winds combined to create severe weather conditions.

Around 80 flood warnings are now in place on rivers mainly in Wales, the Midlands and southern England. There are 12 flood warnings on rivers in north Wales and three in the north-east of England.

Ten severe flood warnings were in place last night: seven on the river Severn and its tributaries; on the river Teme in Worcestershire; on the river Wye in Herefordshire; and on the river Ems near Chichester in West Sussex.

Areas between Gloucester and Avonmouth were expected to be dealt a double blow with a force nine gale combining with a high tide overnight.

The Environment Agency said that in areas where there were flood warnings residents were being told to be prepared to evacuate their homes as there was a high probability of flooding. People living in areas where there were severe flood warningsshould expect the emergency services to call at any moment asking them to evacuate their home.

Heavy rainfall which fell last weekend is now working its way down the Severn. As more rain is forecast the flood risks will remain for the next few days.

A man dived into the river Leadon at Dymock in Gloucestershire to rescue a woman and her eight-month-old child who fell into the water when a wooden footbridge they were crossing gave way.

Helen Dodd, a mother of two children, was walking with a friend when the accident happened on Monday afternoon. She said yesterday that she feared for her life when she plunged into the swollen river with her daughter Emma. Mrs Dodd was forced to stand in waist-high freezing water for 15 minutes before they were rescued.

"I was more worried about the baby than myself," she said.

"I fell face-down in the water and went under, but because Emma was on my back, I don't think she did. It was very frightening."

Much of the land around Shrewsbury, Tewkesbury, Worcester, Hereford and Ross-on-Wye is saturated with water.

Eighteen homes along the river Thames were flooded in the Oxford, Shiplake, Wargrave and Henley areas.

The Thames Barrier was closed twice yesterday in an ticipation of high tides.

Richard Symonds, of the Environment Agency, said that 75 homes were under threat from flooding on the Somerset Levels. At the village of Northmoor flood levels are currently 4.6 metres and rising.

Mr Symonds said that up to 40mm of rain was forecast for the rest of the week. "This is a very serious situation," he said. "Everyone concerned must be ready to move out as soon as they are requested to by the police."

The Meteorological Office said that the strongest winds would be in the counties surrounding the Bristol Channel and the English Channel. Severe gales and even storm-force winds are forecast.

The worst affected areas today will be exposed coastal uplands.

webTitle: Nothing like a dame

fields.headline: Nothing like a dame
fields.standfirst: Frenzied bidding for Fonteyn's effects
fields.trailText: Frenzied bidding for Fonteyn's effects.
fields.body:
The last great collection of the art and life of Dame Margot Fonteyn, the supreme ballerina of her time, fetched £654,000 at auction in London yesterday.

Collectors, many private and mostly thought to be from abroad, paid six times the forecast total for 150 costumes, accessories, dresses, letters and mementoes of her career. But bidders from the Royal Opera House, Royal Ballet and Theatre Museum - helped by a last-minute campaign by admirers - saved more than 50 items for display to dance lovers and students in Britain. These included the auction's treasures - the tutu she wore in Sleeping Beauty and correspondence with her teacher, Dame Ninette de Valois.

The biggest frenzy at Christie's was for her high fashion clothes. A buyer paid £91,750 for an Yves St Laurent ensemble dating from 1967. Christie's expected it to fetch at most £1,200.

The Christian Dior wedding dress she wore for her marriage to the Panamian diplomat Roberto Arias went for £14,100 to a dance museum in Chile.

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
A strong contender for Most Amusing Press Release 2000 arrives by fax. "Why Jesus would have gone to Anthea and Grant's wedding," says the headline, "by the Baptist minister who married them." Yes, who else? In Christianity magazine, Diary vicar the Rev Steve Chalke argues that Jesus might even have elbowed him out and taken the service himself. "Would he have gone to the wedding?" muses Steve. "I think so. The gospels give us no reason to think otherwise." Really? Have you honestly forgotten the Apocrypha 7:11: "And lo, He did say unto God, 'O Father, though I would die upon the cross to redeem Man, if thou thinks that I will pose with new Cadbury's Sno-flake, or share a dance floor with John Stapleton, then verily art thou pulling my bell end." Steve admits that whether Jesus would have officiated is a "harder question. But in the end, I think yes. You see, I didn't marry Grant and Anthea because I thought they were perfectly sorted people in a perfect relationship." So why did you? "I married them to extend and demonstrate to them the principle of God's outrageous love." How simply marvellous.

 I am disappointed that boss-eyed Sun showbiz hack Dominic Mohan has missed another pop scoop. David Shayler has been asked to be a guest presenter at next year's Brit awards, and has said yes. In my day renegade intelligence operatives, however portly, were slammed inside and left to rot, but now they become celebrities. Still, if the 2001 awards are anything like the ones presented by Mick Fleetwood and Sam Fox, Mr Shayler would probably prefer a decent stretch inside instead.

 Also facing porridge (of a sort) are several Railtrack employees who are up before the central London county court beak today. What may earn them Christmas with Her Majesty is not deaths on the railways but their continued refusal to fix a leaking roof. Having chased Railtrack, her landlord, for five years over a problem which eventually forced her to leave her office - a Grade II gate lodge near Euston - architect Sophie Owuze has injuncted chief executive Steve Marshall and others to explain why they shouldn't feel the full force of the law over the matter. Whatever the outcome, it is another Railtrack triumph in that replacing the roof would have cost £12,000, a fraction of the cost of hiring smart lawyers and barristers to defend the case. Hats off.

 The conclusion to the letter in the Magazine of the Month, Richard Desmond's Best of Forum, from DB (Address Withheld) is postponed. When we left DB, you will recall, he was recalling how, when a soldier in Germany, he was surprised in flagrante by his girlfriend's mother. Apologies for the delay, but we will get to it tomorrow.

 For the penultimate time, to my mother's recipe for chicken soup. So far we have: 1) bought, cleaned and quartered a boiler; 2) bought to boil in saucepan full of water, then simmered, skimmed thrice and left on low flame for two hours; 3) added giblets and vegetables; 4) added salt and pepper; 5) brought back to boil, skimmed again and simmered with lid on for two more hours. Now then, 6) remove pan to cool and when cold put in fridge overnight; 8) cut off layer of fat; 9) remove chicken and vegetables, strain soup repeatedly in very fine strainer until clear. Tomorrow, we come to the endgame, which involves vermicelli and egg.

 A nomination arrives for one of the three remaining spots in our Turncoat of Turncoats vote. In the Telegraph, Sion Simon writes of his rapprochement with the concept of fox hunting - something of which, until very recently, he was a ferocious enemy. And this just as No 10 is more eager than ever to be rid of the vexatious issue ... another example of the happy Jungian synchronicity that marks Sion's journalistic career. Well done.
