Having chased Railtrack, her landlord, for five years over a problem which eventually forced her to leave her office - a Grade II gate lodge near Euston - architect Sophie Owuze has injuncted chief executive Steve Marshall and others to explain why they shouldn't feel the full force of the law over the matter. Whatever the outcome, it is another Railtrack triumph in that replacing the roof would have cost £12,000, a fraction of the cost of hiring smart lawyers and barristers to defend the case. Hats off.  The conclusion to the letter in the Magazine of the Month, Richard Desmond's Best of Forum, from DB (Address Withheld) is postponed. When we left DB, you will recall, he was recalling how, when a soldier in Germany, he was surprised in flagrante by his girlfriend's mother. Apologies for the delay, but we will get to it tomorrow.  For the penultimate time, to my mother's recipe for chicken soup. So far we have: 1) bought, cleaned and quartered a boiler; 2) bought to boil in saucepan full of water, then simmered, skimmed thrice and left on low flame for two hours; 3) added giblets and vegetables; 4) added salt and pepper; 5) brought back to boil, skimmed again and simmered with lid on for two more hours. Now then, 6) remove pan to cool and when cold put in fridge overnight; 8) cut off layer of fat; 9) remove chicken and vegetables, strain soup repeatedly in very fine strainer until clear. Tomorrow, we come to the endgame, which involves vermicelli and egg.  A nomination arrives for one of the three remaining spots in our Turncoat of Turncoats vote. In the Telegraph, Sion Simon writes of his rapprochement with the concept of fox hunting - something of which, until very recently, he was a ferocious enemy. And this just as No 10 is more eager than ever to be rid of the vexatious issue ... another example of the happy Jungian synchronicity that marks Sion's journalistic career. Well done. diary@theguardian.com

webTitle: Recycling minister given pizza problem

fields.headline: Recycling minister given pizza problem
fields.trailText: A government minister had to spend an embarrassing half-hour rummaging through a bin bag full of half eaten pizzas, nappies and empty drinks cartons at a Commons hearing yesterday.
fields.body:
A government minister had to spend an embarrassing half-hour rummaging through a bin bag full of half eaten pizzas, nappies and empty drinks cartons at a Commons hearing yesterday.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, was ambushed when he gave to evidence to the environment committee on the government's waste strategy.

He was presented by Andrew Bennett, the committee chairman, with a large black bin liner of rubbish donated by Parliament's works directorate, and asked to give reasons why most of it should not be recycled. The nappies - luckily unused - were donated by a woman MP.

Mr Meacher immediately promised action by his department to dispose of many of the items and conceded that not enough had been done by suppliers or local councils to prevent them getting in there in the first place.

He said the government should introduce a scheme to ensure pizza boxes were collected and recycled. The half-eaten pizza itself should have gone on a compost heap, although "I would be worried if it encouraged rats", he said.

Mr Meacher had more fun with a copy of the Financial Times which had also been dumped in the bag. "Of course newspapers should be recycled but you do have a problem with its colour - pink is not the best colour", he said.

He went on to say that the UK did not have the best facilities to recycle newsprint but said his department was looking at a new mill to recycle newprint in Aylesbury, Buckinghamshire.

The most embarrasing item in the rubbish bag turned out to be a large fluorescent tube - something that should no longer be placed in rubbish bags at all.

Mr Meacher had been told that all government departments were planning to send their used tubes to a new recycling centre in the north-east of England, so to find the item in a parliamentary rubbish bag was not good news. In fact he was advised by his officials that nothing had come of the scheme.

Later under questioning from MPs Mr Meacher indicated that he planned a bigger increase in recycling after 2004. He has already set local councils a 25% target in three years. "Once the momentum has started I see no reason why it should not be increased to the best levels in the rest of Europe - equivalent to 35% or 40% of all materials," he said.

webTitle: Crackdown on prostitute cards is shelved

fields.headline: Crackdown on prostitute cards is shelved
fields.trailText: The government admitted yesterday that it has abandoned plans to crackdown on the posting of prostitutes' cards in public telephone boxes until after the general election.
fields.body:
The government admitted yesterday that it has abandoned plans to crackdown on the posting of prostitutes' cards in public telephone boxes until after the general election.

Ministers had indicated that they were keen to introduce legislation to impose fines of up to £1,000 on men and women caught posting the increasingly explicit cards in call boxes. But the home office minister, Charles Clarke, confirmed yesterday that the legislation has been shelved for at least another year.

"We are keen to make progress in this area and will bring forward proposals when parliamentary time allows," Mr Clarke said in a parliamentary written reply. His statement was a carefully phrased way of saying that the crackdown will not be included in the raft of anti-crime legislation introduced in last week's Queen's speech.

In his parliamentary reply, Mr Clarke said that the government would ensure that fines could be imposed across the country when the new law is eventually introduced. Under the government's earlier plans, unveiled last year, local authorities would have decided whether to impose fines.

The government will also give the police the power to arrest anyone suspected of posting a prostitute's card.

The government's decision to delay the introduction of the prostitutes' card law will prompt Tory criticisms that ministerial spin is not matched by action. Jack Straw first made clear his determination to crack down on the cards in 1998 when the Home Office announced that prostitutes who place cards in public telephone boxes would be guilty of a criminal offence.

About 13m cards advertising male and female sexual services are removed from 1,000 BT telephone boxes in central London every year. A further 1mcards are removed from 240 telephone boxes in Brighton and Hove. Other areas, where cards are posted, include Norwich, Felixstowe, Bath and Birmingham.

The announcement on prostitutes' cards came as Mr Straw defended himself against Tory claims that he has failed victims of crime.

In a Commons debate on the crime bills introduced in the Queen's speech, the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, dubbed the government's legislative programme a "missed opportunity" that would fail to reverse rising crime or increase police officer numbers.

Facing the home secretary, she asked: "Doesn't this just show where your priorities lie? Not in effective action, but in headline grabbing announcements, in an attempt to salvage your long-gone reputation of being tough on crime."

Mr Straw said that the five anti-crime bills unveiled in the Queen's speech would help to cut crime. The populist bills include fixed penalties for disorderly behaviour in public places and extended child curfew schemes. He added: "Crime is still high, but thanks to the measures we have introduced crime is now under control."

webTitle: Crash forces US marines to ground new planes

fields.headline: Crash forces US marines to ground new planes
fields.trailText: Fresh doubts were raised last night about the future of a revolutionary military aircraft after an MV-22 Osprey from the United States Marine Corps' fleet crashed, killing all four men on board.
fields.body:
Fresh doubts were raised last night about the future of a revolutionary military aircraft after an MV-22 Osprey from the United States Marine Corps' fleet crashed, killing all four men on board.

The accident in North Carolina was only the latest disaster to befall the Osprey, known as a 'convertiplane' because it can take off like a helicopter but flies like a conventional plane.

All Ospreys were grounded last night and General James Jones, the Marine Corps commandant, has asked William Cohen, the defence secretary, to draw up a panel of experts to look into the aircraft's future.

Earlier this year 19 marines were killed during a training exercise when an Osprey crashed while attempting to land in Arizona. That accident was blamed on human error; the cause of the latest one is not yet known.

Quite apart from safety considerations, its critics - who include the Republican vice-presidential candidate Dick Cheney - say that it is too expensive. The Pentagon had been expected to decide this month on whether to go ahead on full production of 360 of the aircraft at a cost of almost $40bn (£27.5bn).

"This programme is very, very important to the Marine Corps, to me and I think to the nation and we're going to work very hard to find out what happened," said Lieutenant General Fred McCorkle, the head of marine aviation. "I don't think this will be a show-stopper."

The latest crash happened in a forest near Jacksonville after the pilot, said to be the most experienced flyer of Ospreys, steered away from houses.

"They did a pretty valiant effort to try to avoid the civilian population area," said Colonel Mark Goodman, chief safety officer at Camp Lejeune, where the men were based. "The pilot gave no specifics on the nature of the situation, just that it was a mayday."

Mark Calnan, who lives near the forest where the four, who were aged between 24 and 42, died, said: "The rotors got real loud and it disappeared behind a tree. There was an orange flash, a great big one. Then I heard a pop. It cracked like thunder."

The Osprey, a joint project by Bell Helicopter Textron and Boeing Helicopters, has had a troubled past. A prototype crashed nine years ago just three minutes into its first flight . A year later seven people died when another crashed after its engine caught fire during a demonstration.

Gen Jones said only a fortnight ago that he expected the marines, who had nine before the North Carolina crash, to regain their full complement of Ospreys. "I'm confident it should be approved," he said then. "I've seen nothing to lead me to believe that it won't."

Later the same day an Osprey made a "precautionary landing" at a civilian airport.

The marines want the Osprey to replace their fleet of transport helicopters, which dates back to the Vietnam War. It is capable of converting from a helicopter to an aeroplane in just 12 seconds and is considered by the corps to be "leap-ahead technology" that would give it unprecedented ability to move forces.

The vertical takeoff and landing vehicle is considered crucial for pulling men in and out of military flashpoints and for rescuing civilians.

The Osprey moves at twice the speed, has twice the range and carries twice the load of the elderly CH-46 craft that it would put out of business. Its two propjet turbines drive two oversize propellers and it can fly at more than 300mph.

Its maximum load is 24 troopers or 20,000lb and it can reach an altitude of 25,000ft. The Osprey's design allows it to fly long distances at low levels in bad weather and then hover in search and rescue missions. It can also be modified for use as an aerial refuelling tanker. Up to 12 patients can be shifted in medical evacuations, moving victims of war or accidents faster than any other aircraft.

fields.trailText: Tipple of the day
fields.body:
Tipple of the day

Former Northern Ireland secretary Mo Mowlam has told how she developed a fondness for whiskey during her time in the province. Ms Mowlam made her comments in an article for an internet magazine. She said whiskey helped her to relax after tough negotiations - "whiskey for me became an essential part of the peace process in Northern Ireland" - but stressed she did not fear developing a drink problem.

Quote of the day

"The only time the shadow foreign secretary Francis Maude is up at 4.30 in the morning is when he comes swaggering out of the Carlton Club" - Europe Minister Keith Vaz paying tribute to the early morning negotiating skills of the prime minister and the foreign secretary

webTitle: Spain arrests Russian media tycoon

fields.headline: Spain arrests Russian media tycoon
fields.trailText: Spanish police acting on an Interpol warrant arrested the Russian media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky on fraud charges yesterday as he arrived back at his beach resort on the southern coast after a trip to Gibraltar.
fields.body:
Spanish police acting on an Interpol warrant arrested the Russian media magnate Vladimir Gusinsky on fraud charges yesterday as he arrived back at his beach resort on the southern coast after a trip to Gibraltar.

This latest development in the dramatic ongoing Media Most saga was bitterly condemned by Mr Gusinsky's supporters, who said they were confident that attempts to extradite him to Russia would fail on the grounds that the charges were politically motivated.

Mr Gusinsky was taken from a house in Sotogrande, near Cadiz, and held for several hours in a police station in the nearby town of La Linea. He was later taken to Madrid, where he was he to face an extradition hearing in the Spanish high court. The court has 40 days to consider Russia's request. The Spanish government, however, has the authority to take a final decision.

Lawyers for Mr Gusinsky said they were confident they could block extradition proceedings. "Under international conventions, there is protection for suspects in political cases," Media Most lawyer Pavel Astakhov said.

A spokesman for Mr Gusinsky argued that the Russian authorities had made inaccurate accusations in the material they handed to Interpol, which formed the basis for the arrest. Dmitri Ostalsky said he hoped that the "Spanish justice system would make a detailed study of the situation and will not become a tool in the hands of the Russian prosecution service, which has persecuted Vladimir Gusinsky for purely political motives".

An international arrest warrant was issued for Mr Gusinsky when he failed to appear for questioning in Moscow last month. He was charged in his absence with 13 counts of fraud, and accused of misrepresenting Media Most's assets when he accepted bank loans of more than £200m.

Media Most officials deny the accusation.

webTitle: Business: market forces

fields.headline: SAB loses merger fizz
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: South African Breweries saw its shares drop 5.89% to 456.5p as expectations of a merger or takeover fizzled out and fears of sales problems in South Africa increased.
fields.body:
South African Breweries saw its shares drop 5.89% to 456.5p as expectations of a merger or takeover fizzled out and fears of sales problems in South Africa increased.

Profit takers moved in, according to analysts, and heavy rain in its main South African regional markets led to fears that beer sales could fall even further. The company, the fifth-largest brewer in the world, released interim results a couple of weeks ago which showed a 6% drop in beer volumes in South Africa.

The FTSE 100 closed up 20.1 points at 6390.4 yesterday although technology, media and telecom stocks looked weak after their rebound on Monday.

Profit warnings from Microchip Technology and Honeywell in the US dampened the sector and led to computer-related shares falling.

BAE Systems saw its shares slump 23p to 367p in reaction to Honeywell's profit warning.

Bookham Technology fell 103p to £13.55 and Logica 124p to £18.46 as, according to analysts, investors got in the mood to take short-term profits from technology stocks and the effects of last weeks Nasdaq rally on the technology sector seemed to wear off.

Marconi , however, bucked the trend and finished the day up 5p at 861p.

Baltimore Technologies fell 14.5p to 443.5p, but not all was bleak for the company because it was given a "buy" rating from Robertson Stephens, the investment bank that focuses on growth companies.

Telecom stocks showed some gains, with Vodafone up 2.5p to 276.5p, and the media sector was up slightly as the government announced plans for a new communications regulator. Accompanying proposals to make television consolidation easier left Carlton Communications up 20p at 635p and Granada Media 18p higher at 453p.

Television Group VFG rose 8p to 43.5p after announcing on Monday it was building a new national group of local television stations. The company yesterday said it had set up the Local Broadcasting Group to take charge of the new TV network after it acquired 36 regional licences.

The pharmaceuticals sector also did a U-turn, showing strength after Monday's weakness. SmithKline Beecham rose 30.5p to 871.5p and Glaxo Wellcome was up 86p to £19.21 after the latter announced a SmithKline merger date of December 27. The company has won approval from the US federal trade commission officials for the merger. Formal clearance is expected soon.

AstraZeneca fell, however, 49p to £32.11 on a statement that a new oral anti-thrombin medicine had not been proved to be superior to other drugs in a clinical trial. Shire Pharmaceuticals also took a dive, down 61p to 974p.

Oil stocks were on the up after crude prices rose in re sponse to blizzards and cold Arctic winds. BP Amoco was up 7p to 558p and Shell rose 11p to 531p.

British Polythene Industries, which will find out on Saturday whether Macfarlane will take it over, saw its shares fall 2.5p to 303p after the company announced the continuation of its restructuring plan. It is closing a small manufacturing site in Workington and three depots in its merchanting business to save about £1.5m a year.

Macfarlane shares were up 1p to 60.5p.

Hopes of the latest bid from Lloyds TSB being accepted gave fresh encouragement to Abbey National, which rose 35.5p to £11.80. Lloyds rose 12p to 688p.

On AIM, computer games company Pure Entertainment Games saw its share price rise 3.5p to 33.5p as chief operating officer Bob Dewar was promoted to chief executive officer and the company announced it would become cash flow positive "significantly ahead of its formerly announced date of March 2002". The group said that there would be redundancies from the in-house games development studio.

webTitle: Torex pays £40m for German prescription

fields.headline: Torex pays £40m for German prescription
fields.trailText: Oxfordshire software company Torex is set to take charge of the medical records of millions of Germans by paying £40m for the Laufenberg Group, a supplier of computer systems to German hospitals.
fields.body:
Oxfordshire software company Torex is set to take charge of the medical records of millions of Germans by paying £40m for the Laufenberg Group, a supplier of computer systems to German hospitals.

The deal will be funded by a one-for-six rights issue at 480p a share, raising £27.2m.

Torex is already a leading designer of IT for doctors in Britain - its provides NHS-approved systems which link GPs, provide electronic appointment registers and hold up-to-date records.

Torex's finance director Mark Pearman said: "We've set ourselves pretty aggressive growth targets. Inevitably, the UK healthcare market is finite and we've made no secret of our ambition to expand into Europe."

The purchase of Laufenberg will increase the size of Torex by more than half. The German business made profits of £2m on sales of £26.8m last year.

Laufenberg provides information management software for laboratories, hospitals and the medical departments of large corporations. It has helped German surgeries upgrade their systems from old-fashioned "green screens" to Windows-based platforms.

webTitle: Letters: Opium advert reeks of exploitation

fields.headline: Opium advert reeks of exploitation
fields.trailText: Libby Brooks' article on the Sophie Dahl advert for Opium completely misses the point (Anatomy of desire, December 12). My complaint to the Advertising Standards Authority about the advert was twofold: if there is a place for pornography or "erotica", it is certainly not on advertising hoardings around the country; and secondly, the advertisement exploits and degrades women in order to sell the product.
fields.body:
Libby Brooks' article on the Sophie Dahl advert for Opium completely misses the point (Anatomy of desire, December 12). My complaint to the Advertising Standards Authority about the advert was twofold: if there is a place for pornography or "erotica", it is certainly not on advertising hoardings around the country; and secondly, the advertisement exploits and degrades women in order to sell the product.

Debating people's response to "sexual appetite" or "sexual passivity" is off the point.
Claire Bradley
c.bradley@cableinet.co.uk
Wolverhampton

 Not everyone wants to have sex pushed in their faces. We can choose to buy magazines or turn on televisions if we want to see porn. It is offensive to have it forced on us the way the Opium ad does.
Lisa Lamb
llamb@interbrand.co.uk
London

 How the new lads will swoon to hear that a woman's best moments are to be found wearing nothing but perfume and six inch gold stilettos, spreadeagled in classic porn star pose, squeezing her breasts in invitation.

The Opium advert is simply another example of a multinational industry using a male fantasy of women's sexuality to sell its product. And, in this instance, seeing how far towards pornography it can veer before someone tells them to shut up. This type of billboard fills our head with sexual imagery which bears little resemblance to life, fantasy or otherwise, and can only further aggravate the already tormented relationship between humans and their sexuality. The fact that this genre degrades women was an argument I thought already won and locked away.
Rene F Rice
rene@kervaig.demon.co.uk
Bristol

 Nothing offensive about an image explicitly celebrating solitary female pleasure. What is outrageous is the hijacking of this erotic image to take money out of the pockets of women in the mistaken belief we can be transformed from how we are into a gorgeous bejewelled model with a splash of scent. No different from suggesting that a nice car puts inches on your cock.
Consuelo Morales
London

webTitle: Letters: Monarchs and martyrs

fields.headline: Monarchs and martyrs
fields.trailText: The Stuarts, Hanoverians and Windsors were full of defects that any minor historian can take pot shots at (Piers Brendon, December 9). But willy-nilly our English monarchs' defects have led to the emergence of the world's most effective liberal democracy - starting of course with "John, John, bad king John" and continuing with Charles I and the Bloodless Revolution.
fields.body:
The Stuarts, Hanoverians and Windsors were full of defects that any minor historian can take pot shots at (Piers Brendon, December 9). But willy-nilly our English monarchs' defects have led to the emergence of the world's most effective liberal democracy - starting of course with "John, John, bad king John" and continuing with Charles I and the Bloodless Revolution. Remember please, that the killing of kings leads to an extreme rightwing reaction and the creation of "royal martyrs".

I suggest that monarchy - like Christianity or any other religion - is a useful, life-giving, partly historical myth. Of course kings exist - some would say gods exist too! Man cannot live without myths - in the case of monarchy, a need to identify with the tribe, or a leader, the need for a father or a mother figure.

Remember the fate of Cromwell's corpse. Remember that arguably the present anti-monarchist rot set in with the arrival of two neurotic, non-royal young ladies in the royal family.
Dilys Frascolla
Perugia, Italy

 Cardinal Winning is offended by words written over 300 years ago that, I admit, have no place in the 21st century (Cardinal renews call for Act of Settlement repeal, December 11). Oh the irony, then, that he places such importance on words written over 3,000 years ago, that "man shall not lie with man", when seeking to justify his own bigotry and discrimination.
Matthew Phillips
London

webTitle: Business: At this price?

fields.headline: At this price?  International Greetings
fields.trailText: Cards, wrapping paper and cracker maker International Greetings is looking forward to Christmas - Christmas 2001 that is. Analysts are forecasting that its profits for 2001 will reach £11m, up from £9.7m
fields.body:
Cards, wrapping paper and cracker maker International Greetings is looking forward to Christmas - Christmas 2001 that is.

The orders for its seasonal products from retailers like Sainsbury, Tesco, Boots and Woolworth are usually in place by the previous March - not, incidentally, the company's year end. This helps to give a pretty clear indication of how revenues and profits are going to turn out well in advance of the festive season.

So far the company is optimistic, and analysts are forecasting that its profits for 2001 will reach £11m, up from £9.7m.

About 70% of International Greetings' turnover comes from Christmas sales, and it is keen to lessen its dependence on the festive season. It has made a start by buying up companies which have gone into receivership to broaden its range. These include Copywrite Designs in July 1998, a children's stationery business whose licensed characters include Barbie, Action Man and Disney favourites. It has closed the company's Manchester plant and moved the production to the Far East.

It has also boosted its US presence by paying £1.7m for the Stephen Lawrence Company, its main competitor across the Atlantic. And in a move which may dismay parents badgered to distraction by their children, International Greetings is attempting to promote Hallowe'en with attendant masks, witches' capes and other ghoulish items. This October it sold £1m worth of Hallowe'en goods, up from £150,000, and it has just signed a distribution deal with CSS Industries, the largest supplier of Hallowe'en products in America.

The company continues to be on the acquisition trail with the main objective to buy a birthday card manufacturer and is talking to a British card company.

The shares slipped 5p to 355p yesterday. In recent days they have fallen after a strong run. Worth a look on any further weakness.

webTitle: Letters: Appetiser

fields.headline: Appetiser
fields.trailText: I am pleased Roy Hattersley has joined those of us already in the vegetarian party (Endpiece, December 11). He should not believe, however, that life will all be plain sailing. In the US I spotted "vegetarian pizza with pepperoni"; once I was asked by a restaurateur whether or not, as a vegetarian, I "included chicken".
fields.body:
I am pleased Roy Hattersley has joined those of us already in the vegetarian party (Endpiece, December 11). He should not believe, however, that life will all be plain sailing. In the US I spotted "vegetarian pizza with pepperoni"; once I was asked by a restaurateur whether or not, as a vegetarian, I "included chicken".

In the European parliament restaurant, the vegetarian option has been known to include les lardons (pieces of bacon - but only for flavour!) and one specialité végetariènne would have been okay were it not for the lobster's head stuck on the top. The waiter assured me that this was perfect for vegetarians as it was neither meat nor fish.
Robert Evans MEP
Strasbourg
rjeeevans@globalnet.co.uk

webTitle: Dot.com workers tempted by unions

fields.headline: Dot.com workers tempted by unions
fields.standfirst:
Long hours, job insecurity and low wages are driving employees in the new industry to seek an old-fashioned way of protecting their rights

Net news
fields.trailText: Workers in the dot.com world who feel they have nothing to lose but their stock options are rising up, according to union organisers in the field. But the surge of union activity has provoked an angry response from the employers.
fields.body:
Workers in the dot.com world who feel they have nothing to lose but their stock options are rising up, according to union organisers in the field. But the surge of union activity has provoked an angry response from the employers.

This week sees the latest attempt to unionise one of the world's best-known dot.com companies, Amazon.com, and at another leading firm, Etown. Employers and industry workers are watching to see what happens in moves that could change the way the industry operates as the long honeymoon of the new commerce comes to an end.

"It is a new trend," said Barbara Judd of the Washington Alliance of Technology Workers, which is trying to unionise Amazon.com. "We're getting inquiries every day. There was this myth of a pot of gold at the end of the rainbow so a lot of people are watching this to see what will happen."

WashTech was formed two years ago as part of the 750,000-strong Communications Workers of America. It says workers have complained about mandatory overtime and poor wages at Amazon, which employs 8,500 people worldwide, around 5,500 of them in the US, and has an annual turnover of $2bn (£1.25bn).

Ms Judd said that since the recruiting drive started there has been interest from workers in other dot.com companies.

"Belonging to a union has declined over the last few decades and a lot of people have not grown up in union households," she said. "But once people see how we can help they say 'this is what I want.' "

To have a union recognised, 30% of the workforce have to sign a petition to the national labour relations board so that a vote can take place; a union is recognised if 50% plus one of the workforce vote for it.

Erin Tyson-Poh of the Northern California Media Guild which has been recruiting dot.com workers in San Francisco and Silicon Valley, said: "People are joining unions for the exact same reasons they always have: for dignity, a voice in the workforce, job security."

Today there is a hearing on the guild's attempt to unionise Etown, the San Francisco-based dot.com. The company sacked a number of workers last month while the union was trying to recruit them. Ms Tyson-Poh said that interest in unions had increased greatly after the downturn in the dot.com economy this year and the loss of many jobs.

She said they had been approached both by people who had been in media unions before and by people who were new to the union movement. "We're seeing the younger workers, the group of people they said could never be organised," she said. "It's very encouraging."

The dot.com companies respond that there is no need for their employees to have unions.

Patty Smith of Amazon.com said the company's workforce was well treated. "We take great pride in having people who are passionate about delivering excellent service to the customer and are intelligent ...We pride ourselves on being progessive."

She said that the company operated an "open door" policy and four times a year had an "all hands" meetings when any grievances could be aired.

Amazon's internal website gives supervisors advice on how to spot union activity and on how to combat it.

The website suggests that "hushed conversations when you approach which have not occurred before" and "small group huddles breaking up in silence on the approach of the supervisor" are possible clues.

Steve Ramirez of Etown, which has 99 employees and was formed in 1995, said the company had devoted a lot of time and energy to ensuring that employees' complaints could be aired.

"We have open door access," said Mr Ramirez. He added that the firm's director of human resources acts as an ombudsperson in disputes.

"The genesis of this goes back to a couple of disgruntled former employees looking to incite current employees.

He added: "In my opinion, we work side by side and a more efficient process would be a one on one discussion. Introducing a third party contributes very little and could be more of a hindrance than a help."

Mr Ramirez said the recent decision to get rid of workers as the union started organising was a cost-cutting measure and coincidental.

Pat Dillon, a senior editor at Forbes ASAP magazine, which covers the dot.com industry, and a former dot.com worker himself, said the realisation that people were not going to get rich with their stock options had been a major factor in prompting interest in unions.

"It's a case of the chickens not coming home to roost," Mr Dillon said. "People were living in their own special bubbles and at the end of the 17-hour days, when the vision did not bear fruit, the natural evolutionary behaviour patterns took place."

He said that the new economy had taken advantage of a redefinition of the rules of work and what was happening now was inevitable.

"There is a sense of betrayal," he said.

webTitle: Letters: Tube creaks to crisis point

fields.headline: Tube creaks to crisis point
fields.trailText: Keith Harper's report (Passengers kept in the dark about Tube perils, December 12) parallels the difficulties we experienced in obtaining figures for delays for which London Underground is responsible. Known as attributable delays, passengers can claim compensation under LU's Customer Charter.
fields.body:
Keith Harper's report (Passengers kept in the dark about Tube perils, December 12) parallels the difficulties we experienced in obtaining figures for delays for which London Underground is responsible. Known as attributable delays, passengers can claim compensation under LU's Customer Charter.

The figures we obtained from LU in 1999 for the previous year were for a total of 2,071 attributable delays of 15 minutes or more; the figures we were advised to use this year for 1998 gave a total of 1,711 delays. Keith Hill, the minister responsible, has said in parliament that the methodology used to measure attributable delays is reliable (July 4, written answer).

We have yet to receive a satisfactory answer as to how and why the number of these delays in 1998 can decrease by 17% retroactively. Since passengers are at the receiving end, the correct number can hardly be a matter of commercial confidentiality.
Cynthia Hay
Capital Transport Campaign

 So, on the privatisation plans for London Underground, Her Majesty's Railway Inspectorate (HMRI) may "produce a report on the government's plan to part privatise the system, which could sound the death knell for the project". As one of the RMT union health & safety reps on the Safety Case consultation group, I wish I had Keith Harper's faith in the HMRI to act as independent watchdog. The HMRI will, in effect, be writing the very Safety Case it is supposed to be independently approving. Between December 22 and March next year, the HMRI will be informing LU of any faults they find with the Safety Case and recommending improvements. They are also directly employed by John Prescott, the man responsible for the proposed PPP which splits up the Underground. Finally, they also accepted Railtrack's Safety Case, the one that was in operation during the Paddington and Hatfield rail crashes.
Brian Munro
RMT

 On the Hammersmith and District line 18 months ago I noticed that the aperture which previously held fire extinguishers was empty. I wrote to John Prescott and was quickly contacted by the director of customer services. They had all apparently been removed because of vandalism. But I was told that the driver kept one so that little fires could be prevented from becoming bigger ones.

I contacted Bob Crow at the RMT, who told me that drivers, in the event of a problem, were told not to get out of their cab. So the only fire extinguisher was held by someone who, under company rules, was prevented from leaving their cab.
Phil Katz
philkatz@netcomuk.co.uk>
London

 I was horrified to read that London Underground does not regard its breakdown records to be "for public debate". I pay £83.40 a month for the pleasure of being herded into a hot, cramped metal box twice a day, which regularly breaks down and seldom gets me to and from work without a hitch.

Surely, LU should not only be offering its customers a vocal public debate on its services, but should also be prostrating itself in front of us, asking us for forgiveness for its catalogue of sins?
Sophie Green
ldn-sg@jbic.go.jp
London

fields.bodyText: Keith Harper's report (Passengers kept in the dark about Tube perils, December 12) parallels the difficulties we experienced in obtaining figures for delays for which London Underground is responsible. Known as attributable delays, passengers can claim compensation under LU's Customer Charter. The figures we obtained from LU in 1999 for the previous year were for a total of 2,071 attributable delays of 15 minutes or more; the figures we were advised to use this year for 1998 gave a total of 1,711 delays. Keith Hill, the minister responsible, has said in parliament that the methodology used to measure attributable delays is reliable (July 4, written answer). We have yet to receive a satisfactory answer as to how and why the number of these delays in 1998 can decrease by 17% retroactively. Since passengers are at the receiving end, the correct number can hardly be a matter of commercial confidentiality. Cynthia Hay Capital Transport Campaign  So, on the privatisation plans for London Underground, Her Majesty's Railway Inspectorate (HMRI) may "produce a report on the government's plan to part privatise the system, which could sound the death knell for the project". As one of the RMT union health & safety reps on the Safety Case consultation group, I wish I had Keith Harper's faith in the HMRI to act as independent watchdog. The HMRI will, in effect, be writing the very Safety Case it is supposed to be independently approving. Between December 22 and March next year, the HMRI will be informing LU of any faults they find with the Safety Case and recommending improvements. They are also directly employed by John Prescott, the man responsible for the proposed PPP which splits up the Underground. Finally, they also accepted Railtrack's Safety Case, the one that was in operation during the Paddington and Hatfield rail crashes. I wrote to John Prescott and was quickly contacted by the director of customer services. They had all apparently been removed because of vandalism. But I was told that the driver kept one so that little fires could be prevented from becoming bigger ones. I contacted Bob Crow at the RMT, who told me that drivers, in the event of a problem, were told not to get out of their cab. So the only fire extinguisher was held by someone who, under company rules, was prevented from leaving their cab. webTitle: Letters: Winners and losers at Nice

fields.headline: Winners and losers at Nice
fields.trailText: Big business was the only outright winner at Nice, but you'd never guess it from the oceans of coverage concentrating on the governmental antics there (Tories left floundering by EU deal, December 12). Tony Blair's triumph of red lining tax means that the UK can continue to be a low tax country. This allows firms based here to grab the market shares of European neighbours who choose the higher taxes needed for their superior health, education and pension systems.
fields.body:
Big business was the only outright winner at Nice, but you'd never guess it from the oceans of coverage concentrating on the governmental antics there (Tories left floundering by EU deal, December 12). Tony Blair's triumph of red lining tax means that the UK can continue to be a low tax country. This allows firms based here to grab the market shares of European neighbours who choose the higher taxes needed for their superior health, education and pension systems.

Unanimity on tax will also mean that the Europe-wide energy tax increases, so crucial to effectively deal with climate change, will be easily overruled by any country rented by the oil industry. Finally the "WTO mouthpiece in Europe" - European trade commissioner Pascal Lamy - has been given increased power to push his agenda for a new trade round, as more trade decisions pass out of national control.

Nice was supposed to make enlargement easier in order to benefit all Europe's citizens. Instead we have an enlargement of TNC control over our trade agenda, and continued carte blanche for their pressure to curb Europe's tax base - and its social provision. The far right across the continent must be licking its lips.
Colin Hines
chines@dial.pipex.com>
Twickenham, Middlesex

 In 1861, the United States began a civil war over the issue of states' rights. The arguments over the presidential election show that the tensions are still there. Those who support greater European integration should not despair (nor the sceptics gloat) if the road towards it is just as tough and painful.

The reason the Tories are "left floundering by EU deal" is that Tony Blair is wearing Tory trousers with more panache than the Tories themselves have achieved. All the celebrations about "success" at Nice have reflected the aim of protecting Britain's position within Europe. Nobody - not the government, nor even Hugo Young or your own third leader (December 12) - has the courage to stand up and say that we would be better off (measured in wealth, political power or moral influence) by taking a smaller share of a larger pot.
Robin Harrison
Robin_Harrison@btinternet.com>
Southampton

 I was amused to see the banner of the South Gloucestershire NUT branch pictured alongside placards proclaiming "Fuck capitalism" at Nice. Still, why bother agitating, never mind educating, in Nailsworth at this time of year when the weather is so much nicer on the Cote d'Azur?
Andrew Furlong
Leicester

webTitle: Leader: Penitentiaries join the property market

fields.headline: Jails for sale
fields.standfirst: Penitentiaries join the property market
fields.trailText: Penitentiaries join the property market.
fields.body:
It is a challenge to which the most notorious writers of purple prose are sure to rise. Want a Victorian home? A new vendor has a choice selection of homes, all on historic sites; offering central town positions convenient for shops, offices and entertainment; and with previous residents meticulously recorded. All offer high ceilings, acclaimed Victorian architecture, and special security features with a proven record. Some modernisation may be needed. Estate agents may, however, be a bit shy about disclosing the former use of the properties.

Home owners will be familiar with the many and varied conversions of 19th century Victorian buildings - warehouses, water mills, public baths, fire stations, churches, chapels and schools. Now a new category is joining the list. Martin Narey, the director general of the prison service, is considering selling off the country's Victorian prisons to help finance more modern penal institutions. Some of the most famous names in penal history - Pentonville, Brixton, Wandsworth, Armley and Exeter - could come under the hammer.

In general, the proposal has been well received. Mr Narey was responding to a report from the chief inspector of prisons condemning conditions in 37 prisons. Penal reformers note that today's prisoners are provided with just 10 minutes more of purposeful activity daily than was the case 10 years ago. But three caveats: not all new buildings are better than the old. Ask the inmates.

Albany's low ceilings and inhumane electronic cell gates created a far more oppressive atmosphere than Victorian Parkhurst next door. Second, let the old be replaced with much smaller community prisons, proposed by the Woolf report 10 years ago to keep prisoners nearer their families. Third, let the rebuilding programme be linked with a drive to reduce the unnecessary numbers being put inside. Of the 24 new prisons built in the last decade, half are already overcrowded.

webTitle: Moving on Liv4now founder steps down

fields.headline: Moving on Liv4now founder steps down
fields.trailText: Serena Doshi, above, is stepping down as chief executive of youth portal Liv4now.com.
fields.body:
Serena Doshi, above, is stepping down as chief executive of youth portal Liv4now.com.

Ms Doshi, 28, will be succeeded by 22-year-old co-founder Ewan MacLeod but remain on the board as a non-executive director. After the change at the end of January Ms Doshi will be free to pursue other interests, though she will retain her large shareholding.

"I always said our focus was on turning a profit and we have now done that," she said. "The focus for the business now is to 'stick to the knitting' of operating the business through what we expect to be a tight market over the coming months, and that is Ewan's strength."

Ms Doshi, a former corporate financier, met Mr MacLeod, a computer consultant who was hosting an internet chat room for AOL, two years ago when he arrived at her house to fix a printer.

They discussed how the internet failed to cater for people like them who like clubbing, bars and going out, and decided to set up Liv4now. Ms Doshi provided the financial expertise and Mr MacLeod the technical knowhow.

The site carries articles and forums on topics such as "why we love Beckham" and "how to have sex with a friend".

Several other youth portals have struggled to generate revenues. BT-backed venture Uprush folded and a popular Swedish site, Dobedoo, has made staff redundant.

Liv4now has gained additional revenue by running "communities" for corporate clients such as weddings site Confetti.co.uk, and has agreed a distribution deal with Yahoo!

Ms Doshi said Liv4now remained well funded and had a large amount of its initial funding "sitting in the bank, gaining interest".

webTitle: Business: Rivals force retailer into the red

fields.headline: Rivals force retailer into the red
fields.trailText: The scale of the problems facing mid-market fashion retailers was underlined yesterday as the Littlewoods group slumped into the red, announced nearly 300 job losses and warned of more redundancies on the way.
fields.body:
The scale of the problems facing mid-market fashion retailers was underlined yesterday as the Littlewoods group slumped into the red, announced nearly 300 job losses and warned of more redundancies on the way.

Like Marks & Spencer and the Arcadia group, the privately owned Littlewoods is struggling against discounters like Matalan and TJ Hughes on the high street. Its catalogue shopping business is in terminal decline.

Yesterday the group revealed that in the past six months it had slumped to a £15.6m trading loss, compared with a £27m profit a year earlier. A spokesman described the results as "very disappointing".

The company has been fighting back with a programme called Better Value Retailing - which means slashing prices to match those offered by the discounters - which has cut its margins 2%. But sales still tumbled 3% to £862m.

"We were budgeting for a significant decrease in profitability, but not this severe," said finance director Alan White. "We didn't get the increase in sales that we'd hoped."

The retailer has 113 high street shops, around 160 Index catalogue store sites - some of which are within stores - and the second largest catalogue-shopping business in the UK.

Yesterday, chief executive Barry Gibson said the strategy of tackling the cheaper competition would continue. He said: "The objective is to make Littlewoods as price competitive as any other retailer on basic lines and key entry level prices."

Catalogue prices, which have already been slashed by about 10%, will be cut by a further 15% in the spring-summer catalogue. Home shopping sales were down from £440m to £404m in the last half and the division's profits slumped from £30.5m to just £3.2m.

A spokesman described the catalogue business as "certainly ex-growth".

"Customers want key value ranges even though the product isn't as good," said Mr White. "It's part of our disposable society ... they don't want something to last forever."

On the high street Littlewoods is taking over six C&A stores - being vacated as a result of the Dutch-based retailer's decision to quit the UK market. Refurbished Littlewoods stores are producing a 40% sales uplift and 70 of the high street outlets are now to be revamped.

Around 35 of the group's catalogue shops will be relocated inside Littlewoods stores and five outlets will be closed, with the loss of 87 jobs. This is expected to save £10m.

A further 200 of the 800 staff employed at the group's Liverpool head office will also be made redundant, saving £12m a year. A spokesman said: "There are more to come, no question about that." He declined to say how many more jobs might be affected.

The group's Dial home shopping joint venture with Arcadia has also backfired. Its order level climbed 29%, but stock and delivery problems meant sales were up only 2%. Mike Wynne, the director who headed the operation, has resigned, along with trading director Paul Sprague.

Littlewoods TV shopping channel and Index Extra internet shopping website were the best performers.

Overall group profits before tax were £144.7m - a result of the £155m received after the sale of the group's pools operation to Sportech.

webTitle: Business: Blow for AstraZeneca

fields.headline: Blow for AstraZeneca
fields.trailText: A conference in Sweden intended to showcase AstraZeneca's drugs pipeline failed to impress analysts yesterday, as the company's shares dropped 49p to £32.14.
fields.body:
A conference in Sweden intended to showcase AstraZeneca's drugs pipeline failed to impress analysts yesterday, as the company's shares dropped 49p to £32.14.

The biggest disappointment surrounded a circulatory drug, H376, which has proven not to have done well in clinical trials when used to treat patients with blood clots.

The company insisted the product was still on track to treat stroke victims but chief executive Tom McKillop admitted: "We were ambitious with the design of the post-orthopaedic studies and we didn't quite make it."

AstraZeneca has been struggling to convince investors that it has enough products to replace ulcer drug Losec, which is the world's top selling prescription medicine but will soon be subject to generic competition.

webTitle: Business: SmithKline and Glaxo near merger go-ahead

fields.headline: SmithKline and Glaxo near merger go-ahead
fields.trailText: Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham have reached a draft agreement with US competition regulators over their long-delayed £119bn merger, putting them on track to complete the deal on December 27.
fields.body:
Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham have reached a draft agreement with US competition regulators over their long-delayed £119bn merger, putting them on track to complete the deal on December 27.

The news will be unwelcome for thousands of employees at risk of redundancy - some will be told they are out of a job in the run-up to Christmas.

Trade unions fear that up to 5,000 jobs could be lost from the combined workforce of 107,000, although the two companies have refused to put a number on redundancies.

The deal, which creates the world's largest drugs company, was due to be closed in the summer. Then the federal trade commission raised a series of objections, the most recent concerning a possible clash between the groups' smoking cessation products.

It appeared yesterday that the companies have convinced the commission that there is no clash between Glaxo's anti-addiction drug, Zyban, and SmithKline's anti-nicotine products, Nicorette and Nicoderm.

A Glaxo spokesman said: "We do not expect any divestitures to be required in the smoking cessation area."

The agreement still has to be approved by the FTC's five commissioners, who have the power to order further measures if they feel that concerns remain.

Job losses were frozen by Glaxo and SmithKline in September, when the deal was last delayed by regulators. Hiring and firing recently restarted, in a sign of the companies' confidence of an imminent conclusion.

Insiders yesterday suggested that there were other issues besides smoking cessation which had delayed the deal. The two groups have already had to sell two significant products - Glaxo's herpes drug, Famvir, and SmithKline's nausea treatment, Kytril - for nearly £2bn.

Glaxo has also had to pull out of a tie-up to develop a genital herpes vaccine with Cantab Pharmaceuticals.

A potential clash over irritable bowel syndrome was resolved when SmithKline sold its treatment for the condition to biotech firm Alizyme.

Yesterday Glaxo's shares leapt 86p to £19.21, while SmithKline's jumped 30.5p to 871p. This was despite announcement of the failure of a SmithKline heart drug, lotrafiban, in late-stage clinical trials.

webTitle: The migrants bent on reaching Britain

fields.headline: No man's land
fields.standfirst:
Asylum is one of Britain's hottest political issues, but we know precious little about the people behind the statistics. In the first of two special reports, Oliver Burkeman spends a night with the migrants bent on reaching Britain.

Related story: Spain's beaches of death
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Asylum is one of Britain's hottest political issues, but we know precious little about the people behind the statistics. In the first of two special reports,  Oliver Burkeman  spends a night with the migrants bent on reaching Britain.
fields.body:
Amid all the political posturing and the volley of statistics surrounding the issue of illegal immigration into the United Kingdom, it is an image which suddenly humanises the cross-Channel trade in stowaways. The Iraqi baby seems dazed, oblivious to the flashbulbs popping around her; her outsized pink bobble-hat strikes an incongruous note on the rain-sodden Calais docks. She has spent the previous few hours hidden in the back of a lorry bound for Dover, and much of the past month in similar conditions on the arduous trek from Turkey across Europe. But for now her family's covert journey to England is on hold, interrupted by security guards hired to search every truck making the crossing for signs of stowaways, smuggled on board for £400 a time.

This much is common knowledge; P&O Stena's newly toughened stance against illegal immigration has been a public relations coup for the ferry operator. What happens next is not.

If she is lucky, the baby girl will be bundled into a taxi by waiting police. Otherwise, her family will have a 12-kilometre walk along windswept motorways to their temporary home, the Red Cross reception centre near the coastal suburb of Sangatte - a huge, mud-green factory shed on a hill overlooking the Channel. Providing basic shelter and food to a constantly changing population of mainly Iraqis, Kurds, Palestinians, North Africans and Kosovars, it is a place without equal in western Europe: a refugee camp that feels like the edge of the world, but is actually a matter of minutes by car from the hypermarkets flogging cut-price beer and wine to booze-cruising Brits.

No questions are asked of the clandestines who pass in straggling groups through the camp gates. The authorities prefer it that way. Without any system of registration, the asylum-seekers are free to launch multiple attempts at the illegal crossing without explicit French backing.

"The doors are open, but it is a kind of prison," says Maher, a 32-year-old Palestinian computer programmer idling near the town hall, where somebody has scrawled graffiti labelling the local population xenophobes and Nazis. A journey he had planned for years and which has taken him two months so far is an hour's ferry ride from completion. "People are losing their minds in there," he says, gesturing towards the camp.

Sangatte's open-door policy is not extended to journalists, who are stopped at the gate. Stung by local criticisms that the centre is wasting millions of francs on "bogus" asylum-seekers, the Red Cross, a spokesman says, has made it "a basic principle" not to admit the press. But Maher reckons I could pass as Albanian, and sure enough, it proves easy to slip past the Red Cross marshals in the guise of an asylum-seeker.

The first thing that hits you is the stench from the toilet sheds wafting into the air which, at 5pm, is already seriously cold. Nearby, immigrants with children live in 20 Portakabins, around 25 people to each; they are divided into individual rooms of about three square metres by scraps of fabric hung from the wall. Maher and I are not so lucky. Our accommodation is in the military-style tents towards the back of the warehouse, where young men sleep 14 to a tent on narrow plastic hammocks. There are about 700 people in residence at the moment, but with fewer ferry crossings over Christmas, the Red Cross fears their numbers will rise steeply.

Most, with the exception of the Kurds, are articulate English speakers, often with university degrees and a scattering of PhDs. Many are frighteningly well read. Maher's conversation is peppered with references to Heidegger and Foucault, while Latif, a young Afghan who says he is fleeing the Taliban in fear of violent reprisals for his political views, frames his argument in terms of phenomenological philosophy. It is hard to avoid the feeling that their intellectual backgrounds make the indignities of daily life at Sangatte all the greater.

"We are very grateful to the French, but some of them, even the Red Cross, they treat us like animals," says Jouan, a mild-mannered lecturer who has travelled from Syria in the backs of trucks with one change of clothes, a guitar and a dog-eared Arabic copy of Nietzsche's Beyond Good and Evil. He was imprisoned, he says, because he had links with Amnesty International. His brother and sister are still serving 12-year sentences for membership of the Communist party. But his wealthy father bought him a 24-hour visit home and he took a midnight lift to the border. "The way they look at us, they treat us like we are nothing," he says of the camp staff. "I suppose we are nothing. But we were something."

Like Jouan, many in the centre are escaping political imprisonment or violence, but others freely admit to motives usually considered suspect in the UK and France alike: the fulfilment of entrepreneurial or academic ambitions cut short, they say, by the UN embargo on Iraq, or the Israeli government, or the Taliban. There are plenty of economic migrants among the political ones, but listening to them, it soon becomes hard to see a dividing line between the two.

Dinner, served on long tables lined with benches, consists of some dubious chunks of pinkish meat - "crazy cow," Latif guesses - and rice with peas. But we're among the last to eat, and as we try to leave we are pushed back by Red Cross staff, shouting "Hey mistair!", and thrusting cloths and buckets of water at us, refusing to open the metal gates of the eating area until we've sponged down the tables and benches.

It is a perfectly reasonable request, of course, but something about the way it is made goes to the heart of the camp residents' troubled relationship with the Red Cross. Stories abound of staff displaying what the asylum seekers interpret as contempt, locking them out of the showers, denying them hot water to wash clothes, waking them loudly at night while carrying out routine patrols. "Washing all our family's clothes in one tiny bucket of cold water, it's no way to live," says one woman. It is an attitude that it would be easy to interpret as ingratitude if one was so inclined.

"They're doing what they can, I suppose, but they could knock this place down, and we would still find a way," says Maher, disappearing to begin the nightly process of "borrowing" extra blankets from neighbouring tents. Opinions towards the French police are much harder: two Middle Eastern asylum seekers show numerous scars on their shoulders and arms they insist come not from mistreatment in their homelands but from the truncheons of port police.

Time stretches and yawns at the camp; with only a single television and a couple of old five-a-side football goals, most people seem to while away the hours smoking and pacing the warehouse floor. Ali, a portly 40-year-old Iraqi who had an English girlfriend before diplomatic relations soured, spends most of his time standing at the door of the building, positioned by cruel chance to provide a constant frieze of ferries plying the Channel. "On a clear night people say you can see the lights on the other side," he says, but he's not sure he believes them: during the two winter weeks he has spent making nightly attempts at passage to England, he can't remember any clear nights.

The halogen lamps flooding the warehouse are shut off and we return to our tents. Around 3am, a gnawing cold sets in. Every noise is magnified by the echoing concrete, but soon the rain starts to hammer deafeningly on the corrugated iron roof, dripping through onto our tents. "Listen," shouts Ali, as if it were possible to do anything else. "There's a war outside." At some point in the night we are joined by four Ethiopians, pulled off lorries at the docks hours before. Exhausted, they sleep through the cacophany, but for everyone else, sleep is fitful, punctuated by hacking coughs and children crying.

The England that dominates their thoughts is a strange place - "a completely inaccurate vision of Eldorado" is how the camp's deputy director, Michel Meriaux, puts it. For all of them, it is the ne plus ultra of democracy and human rights, a place where work permits are easy to come by - certainly far easier than in mainland Europe - and accommodation not so hard to find; for some, it is a stepping-stone to the US and Canada.

For Ali, who studied at Teesside Polytechnic in the 1970s, it is: "cheese and onion crisps . . . a pint of beer for about a pound, I think"; summer weekends in Neath; a kebab shop on the Old Brompton Road. "England is a place where they really value the past, hold on to historic things," he says.

Curiously, it is a vision which recalls nothing so much as John Major's picture of foggy cricket grounds and bicycling spinsters.

What it is, is a place where they do expect to have to work: work, after all, is precisely the point of the voyage for most. I ask Jouan, the lecturer and Nietzsche reader, about his professional ambitions. "A job," he says. "Just any job, really." The glowing tip of Maher's roll-up pierces the darkness. "Baudelaire had something to say about all this," he sighs. "You've read Baudelaire?"

' It's tonight, I think," says a man who tells me I can call him Mohammed, though he won't reveal his real name or country of origin. After breakfast - bread and tea or coffee - he outlines his plan: he has made a deal with "a friend in Calais" whom he is to meet at the ferry terminal tonight. He reckons I might be getting a taxi back to the city soon, and charmingly informs me that he will be sharing it.

Back in Calais, he explains that he wants to cover the final distance to the terminal alone, and catches one of the free transfer buses provided by the ferry operators. By the time I reach the terminal later that evening, he could be any one of the hunched figures scrambling up motorway embankments, hiding under bridges, slipping in and out of the shadows in the lorry parks, hardened against the wind and the hammering rain by the dream of stumbling, a few hours later, into the grey half-light of a Dover dawn.

webTitle: Carpets off the back of a lorry

fields.headline: Carpets off the back of a lorry
fields.trailText: Carpet warehouse group Carpetright is rolling out a nationwide home shopping service, selling carpets off the back of a lorry, which it expects to be profitable within 12 months.
fields.body:
Carpet warehouse group Carpetright is rolling out a nationwide home shopping service, selling carpets off the back of a lorry, which it expects to be profitable within 12 months.

The service, Harris Carpets at Home, began as a pilot project in London three months ago. Potential customers access the service via the web and the company then dispatches a van and sales rep to their home. So far 10 vans are on the road, making five to six calls a day each and taking orders worth a total £70,000 a week.

By the end of April the company plans to have 100 vans, each carrying thousands of broadloom carpet samples, operating across the country.

Lord Harris, the chairman, said: "This is going to be very, very profitable. We are going to expand this in a big way in the next 12 months."

The average van order, he said, was £800, compared to £150 in store, and orders are coming from professional people and those who for lack of mobility do not use the company's traditional outlets. He estimated the service would build to a £200m-a-year operation.

Rowan Morgan, an analyst at Teather & Greenwood, said the market for home carpet sales could reach £1bn a year, potentially "bigger than the out-of-town [stores] market".

Lord Harris, who with his family owns 26% of Carpetright, said the service accessed at www.carpetright.com or www harriscarpets.com was already winning repeat business and was successful because "it is the right place to buy a carpet - at home".

Nevertheless, he is pushing ahead with store expansion. The chain, which has 322 outlets, plans 12 new stores in the second half, six in the UK and six in Ireland, a new market. The chain expects to have 350 outlets within 18 months, Lord Harris said. He aims to win 30% of the carpet market and achieve net margin of 15%. Currently Carpetright has a 20% share and 14% net margin.

Last month - just in time for the worst floods on record - the group moved into the insurance replacement business, which is dominated by rival Allied Carpets. Carpetright estimates the insurance market is worth £60m a year and so far has signed a cooperation deal with one big insurer.

Carpetright was reporting profits up 17% to £19m in the six months to the end of October. Like-for-like sales in the past six weeks, the busiest time of year for carpet retailers, are 7.3% up on last year.

The shares, which have climbed 100p in recent weeks, last night closed down 19.5p at 522p.

Mr Morgan has a price target of 600p on the stock but yesterday Credit Suisse First Boston downgraded the shares to a "sell" because of worries about group costs.

webTitle: Birchin training spin-off wins £2.3m for growth

fields.headline: Birchin training spin-off wins £2.3m for growth
fields.trailText: Time2Learn, financial training arm of Birchin International, has been demerged and floated on the AIM exchange, valuing the company at £6.6m.
fields.body:
Time2Learn, financial training arm of Birchin International, has been demerged and floated on the AIM exchange, valuing the company at £6.6m.

The spin-off, which trains bank staff in credit analysis and mergers and acquisitions, will use the £2.3m raised to develop its embryonic online business, recruit specialist staff and open an office in New York.

Time2Learn's share price closed unchanged after making its debut at 1p. Birchin retains a 65% stake in the training company with the remaining stock being taken up by Birchin shareholders.

Colyn Gardner, chairman of Birchin, said Time2Learn had a turnover of £1m from its traditional classroom-based business but the prospects for online business were enormous.

"Electronic-based education and learning will be one of the great growth industries of coming years." The spin-off would help recast Birchin as a financial services investment company.

webTitle: Surgeons fail to save ailing Bengal tiger

fields.headline: Surgeons fail to save ailing Bengal tiger
fields.trailText: A five-month-old Bengal tiger believed to be the first to undergo heart bypass surgery has died from complications, it emerged yesterday.
fields.byline: Associated Press in College Station, Texas
fields.body:
A five-month-old Bengal tiger believed to be the first to undergo heart bypass surgery has died from complications, it emerged yesterday.

Karma died late on Saturday, hours after surgery to correct a congenital heart defect.

Officials at the Tiger Creek Wildlife Refuge in Tyler, Texas, became concerned about Karma after he failed to grow as quickly as his sister, Kali.

After finding a hole in Karma's heart, doctors at Texas A & M University performed a five-hour operation to fix the hole and to unblock the flow of blood to his lungs. But complications arose during the surgery.

"Karma's lungs filled with fluid and we were not able to save him," said Terry Fossum, chief of surgery. "We are not certain if this was a response to the procedure, the medicine, or other complications."

Tissue samples are being tested to determine the cause of death.

webTitle: International in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Dozens die in road crash
fields.body:
Dozens die in road crash

Sixty-two people, most of them bus passengers, were killed in a fire sparked by a three-vehicle pileup on a road in south-eastern Nigeria on Saturday, a newspaper reported yesterday.

The accident occurred after the bus, which was travelling to Lagos from Umuahia, 370 miles away, hit an oncoming truck. A third vehicle crashed into the cars, causing them to burst into flames.
AP, Abuja

Israel targets enemy activists

A wanted activist in the Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement was shot dead by Israeli soldiers near Bethlehem yesterday, Palestinian witnesses said. The killing came hours after Israel said it would find and kill those who attack Israelis.

Also yesterday, three Israelis were wounded in roadside shootings in the Gaza Strip.
AP, Jerusalem

Trial condemns Japan's Hirohito

Japan's late Emperor Hirohito was found guilty of crimes against humanity yesterday when activists, frustrated by the failure of lawsuits brought by women forced to work as wartime sex slaves reached a verdict in a mock trial.

Organisers said they hoped to put pressure on Japan to make restitution for forcing women to work in brothels.
Reuters, Tokyo

Appeal saves Benetton ad

Germany's highest court ruled yesterday that advertisements by the Italian clothes retailer Benetton displaying photos of human limbs stamped with the words "HIV Positive" were not indecent.

It upheld an appeal by the publisher of the magazine Stern against a 1995 lower court ruling, saying the ruling breached rules on free speech.
Reuters, Karlsruhe

Crocodile kills midnight bather

A crocodile killed a South African woman at Lake St Lucia, north of Durban, as she was taking a midnight swim with her boyfriend, police said yesterday.
Reuters, Johannesburg

webTitle: Bookings surge at First Choice

fields.headline: Bookings surge at First Choice
fields.standfirst: Holidaymakers flee rain and rail chaos
fields.trailText: The holiday industry is enjoying a stampede for the sun as Britons dash to escape from floods, rain and rail delays, according to tour operator First Choice.
fields.body:
The holiday industry is enjoying a stampede for the sun as Britons dash to escape from floods, rain and rail delays, according to tour operator First Choice.

The company, which is the country's fourth largest holiday firm, yesterday reported a 30% jump in bookings over the past four weeks.

Popular winter hot spots include Cyprus, the Canary Islands, while ski resorts are also enjoying a renaissance.

First Choice's chief executive Peter Long said: "I'm probably the only character who wakes up in the morning and smiles when it rains - because it means people want to go on holiday."

The recent surge in demand has offset a slow start to the season. First Choice's overall winter sales are up 5%.

Mr Long said: "The rail crisis has helped - customers are just getting fed up with disruption. That's causing increased demand."

He believes there has been a significant change in spending patterns. "A higher proportion of peoples' discretionary spending seems to be going on foreign holidays. The fashion industry, meanwhile, is not having a good time."

First Choice's pretax profits for the year to October were up 47% to £68.9m, helped by a quick succession of acquisitions. The company has bought the travel division of Barcelo, a Spanish firm, for £250m and has purchased Ten Tour, a Turkish business specialising in trips to the Mediterranean and north Africa.

Mr Long said he was keen to buy more companies serving holiday makers from southern Europe, as First Choice tries to reduce its reliance on the volatile, highly competitive British market.

Purchases are likely to be in companies offering tailor-made holidays such as cruising and sports.

Mr Long said he saw specialised companies such as Club Med and Kuoni as First Choice's peers, rather than mass-market leaders such as Thomson and Airtours.

"There are a whole lot of discussions going on," he said. "There are talks with a lot of companies about ways of fitting into our strategy of running specialist businesses."

The holiday market has gone through a tumultuous year - market leader Airtours has issued a succession of profits warnings. Thomson Travel has been taken over by Germany's Preussag, while Thomas Cook was snapped up by Frankfurt-based C&N for £550m this month.

The industry has been suffering from over-capacity and has struggled to recover from disappointing trading over the millennium break.

First Choice said it was soon to launch a £5m website for online ordering. Mr Long dismissed internet travel agencies such as Ebookers and Lastminute.com.

"Quite honestly, I'll be surprised if many of them are around in six months, let alone being a threat to our shops," he said.

First Choice shares edged up 3p to 126p in trading yesterday.

webTitle: France horrified by rise of the teenage killers

fields.headline: France horrified by rise of the teenage killers
fields.standfirst: Turf wars and macho culture fuel increase in violent crime by juveniles
fields.trailText: It was supposed to be a fundraising evening for genetic research and the Auguste-Delaune gym in Drancy, north of Paris, was packed with young people watching displays of dance, rap music and martial arts. The trouble started with taunts between rival gangs. It swiftly turned more deadly.
fields.body:
It was supposed to be a fundraising evening for genetic research and the Auguste-Delaune gym in Drancy, north of Paris, was packed with young people watching displays of dance, rap music and martial arts. The trouble started with taunts between rival gangs. It swiftly turned more deadly.

The teenage gangs, one from nearby Gaston-Rouleau, the other from the Nord housing estate, began waving knives and guns and the evening degenerated into a mass brawl which spilled onto the streets.

One boy, 17-year-old Sami, tried to find refuge on a bus but a gang of 30 followed him and in the ensuing fight he was stabbed twice in the chest.

Sami - the French police do not release the family names of juvenile perpetrators or victims of crime - died shortly later. A youth of his own age has admitted the crime.

The incident last Friday in Drancy is just one of a series of murders of teenagers by teenagers. Like Britain in the wake of the death of Damilola Taylor, France is agonising over the causes of the killings.

The violence is often associated with gang feuds in the tough, high-rise estates that ring French cities. There, unemployment is high and the young people, many from ethnic minorities, often reject authority.

After Sami's death, the Communist mayor of Drancy, Gilbert Conte, called for "national measures to calm the violence which has taken hold of our young people". So far no special measures have been taken.

Explanations for the rise in youth crime abound - ranging from an absence of parental control and the influence of drugs to the alienation of young Muslims from mainstream French society - but no single factor appears to account for the recent spate of killings.

On November 8, Romuald, 14, became the innocent victim of rivalry between two gangs. He and a friend were walking just yards from his mother's flat in Courcouronnes, south of Paris, when a driver in a parked car called out to him. He walked over, and was killed by two shotgun blasts.

On November 26, Salim, 17, was shot dead on the Cedres estate in Marseille. A youth the same age told police he shot at Salim's head "to scare him".

On December 2, Soufiane, 15, was found with his throat slashed in a cellar in La Villeneuve, near Grenoble. Police believed that the boy had been playing truant and initially his parents' fears for his life were not taken seriously.

Soufiane's body was found three days after he went missing - in the interim, a school was burned down by young people protesting at the police's failure to find him.

Police have since arrested two 17-year-old boys for the crime, and claim that an unpaid drug bill was their motive for the killing.

"The motive for this gang warfare? The young people involved forgot what that was a long time ago," said Sebastien Ramhoux of Le Parisien newspaper. "All this rivalry is just a pretext for stabbings or shootings; in the bus, in schools, in the street."

Between 1993 and 1999, the number of 13-18 year-olds in jail in France almost doubled to 4,326. The number jailed for violent crime almost tripled between 1994 and 1998 to 3,825. But it is the rate of murders of adolescents, which for the past 20 years has ranged between 20 and 40 per year in France, that has proved most disquieting.

"I've been in this job for 25 years but this phenomenon of young boys from housing estates killing each other is the most disturbing thing I've witnessed," Rene Guillemet, a director of the juvenile offenders' agency, Le Protection Judiciaire de la Jeunesse, said.

"Among delinquent minors we take in charge, we keep noting that their behaviour is increasingly violent, not just among themselves, but to their teachers too."

One of France's most popular films at the moment is La Squale (a squale is a girl tearaway), directed by Fabrice Genestal, a former teacher at a school in Sarcelles, near Paris. He was alarmed by the violent, macho culture he saw and has tried to portray it faithfully on the big screen.

Like La Haine (Hatred), Mathieu Kassovitz's acclaimed 1995 film about three alienated youths from suburban Paris, La Squale is set in a tough estate. It features disturbing scenes, including the gang rape of a girl in a cellar. "My film must serve as an alarm bell," Mr Genestal said.

French psychiatrists met at a conference in Paris last weekend to discuss the rise in juvenile crime. Dr Didier Lauru, one of the organisers, said: "Violence is most brutal, most fundamental among adolescents. During adolescence there is always great pressure for the child to transgress the law. And murder is the ultimate transgression."
