webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: No Spice is an island
fields.trailText: The Players Club | Brookside
fields.body:
Comparisons are odious, but they were hard to avoid while watching The Players Club (BBC2), a no-warts-at-all profile of Melanie Brown. Only a couple of nights ago, Channel 4 devoted several hours to Madonna, and still seemed only to have skimmed the surface; The Players Club took 50 minutes to plumb Mel B's depths, and there was still time left over for some video clips to promote the album. Mel B is a simple soul who inhabits her Scary Spice persona as long as there's a camera within focal range, and who wastes very little time pondering her art. By her own admission, she doesn't read the papers. "As long as they print a nice picture of me, I don't give a fuck", she said, which seems as good a coping strategy as any.

Bulletins from Spiceworld have become a staple of British TV in the last year or so, and from last night's evidence it seems that Mel B is the current Sad Spice. Mel C may have grabbed headlines with tales of depression and anorexia, but Mel B is going through the mill in her own hysterical way. Take away the laughter - this woman laughs a lot - and we were left with a single mother rattling around in an empty house, surrounded by reminders of a failed marriage, with neighbours sending hate mail of the "Go back to Brixton" variety. Mel's parents were quick to point out that they never liked her ex-husband Jimmy Gulzar, nor did any of the other Spice Girls.

An average day consisted of relentless promotional work, permanent cameras, a trip to the divorce lawyer and the usual duties of parenthood. Mel's daughter, Phoenix Chi, was the only one who wasn't queueing up to criticise her mother's personal conduct, but that could be because she can barely talk.

Everyone else, however, couldn't wait to get the boot in. An unidentified young woman, so consumed with jealousy that she looked as if she'd been chewing a wasp, offered authoritative opinions on the singer's sex life, vocal talents and breast enhancement. "I can sing better than her", she claimed, the permanent cry of the under-achiever. The landlady of the local pub in Marlow, Buckinghamshire, spoke with icy politeness of her new neighbour. Even the Brown family joined in this chorus of disapproval, dragging out the wedding albums to point out Jimmy Gulzar's freeloading gay friends.

Mel B, to her credit, rose above it all. Her strategy is to be as earthy as possible, assuming (quite rightly) that it's hard to dislike a woman who has two toilets in her bathroom "so I can have a widdle and a poo with my mates". She expressed no regrets about marrying Gulzar, and countered boob-job rumours with a general invitation to "have a feel". She saved the best line of all to reply to a question about her living quarters. Don't you get lonely in this huge house, asked presenter Trevor Nelson? "No," said Mel B. "It's huge, but it's homely."

So, when the cameras are no longer running, does Scary Spice cry herself to sleep? Almost certainly not. Hers is not the fairytale existence of bandmate Victoria Beckham, but things could be a lot worse. She has a beautiful daughter, vast amounts of money and Max Beesley on tap. With those advantages, we could all cope with a bit of public vilification.

Brookside (Channel 4) continues in macabre mode. Mad Max was getting on with life while his dead wife decayed in the living room. "Remove from box and place in boiling water", he said - referring, happily, to a boil-in-the-bag meal and not to a DIY embalming process. "Silly Daddy keeps losing everything", he told the children - yes, Daddy, including your marbles, they might have replied as they raced off to nursery. Elsewhere in the Close, late-flowering lesbian Jackie was indulging in a fantastically symbolical bit of decorating to assuage her guilt over sleeping with her own daughter's girlfriend. Could she paper over the cracks? All might have been well but for Bev, a Merseyside Nemesis in a burgundy leather jacket, determined to find out who had been doing what to whom. With a woman's intuition, and a mind so open that she could believe even a Brookside storyline, she jumped to the right conclusion. "Oh my God," she said to Shelley, "you have done it with Jackie Corkhill and Lindsey Corkhill. You dirty mare." Just, if not poetic.

webTitle: Random views

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What record company press officers watch on TV
fields.trailText: What record company press officers watch on TV
fields.body:
Polly Birkbeck, V2: (Stereophonics etc)

"Cold Feet (pictured) is my must-see programme of the moment - I hate it when people call it the British version of Friends because I detest Friends. The repeats of League Of Gentlemen are genius - even better the second time around. The vet's mishaps make me cry with laughter, which is a bit sick, I know. Most music programmes these days feature Westlife in some shape or form so they're unwatchable. Later with Jools Holland is all right, but you have to watch a load of arse while you wait for the stuff you like. "

Caffy St Luce, Hall Or Nothing: (Manic Street Preachers etc)

"Graham Norton is God. I hate the news, though, it's bad for you, I think. I'm glad that they have made it impossible to find! I think Trevor McDonut is the people's reporter, mind. They can stick their gardening and decorating programmes up their arse and all the other "experts" telly too. Why don't they get a channel where Charlie can bounce her Dimmocks and that decorator twit can waffle on... And if they've got room they can stick Chris Evans up their arse too. I think that he is a robot. Favourite personalities? Be-haaaave!"

Gordon Duncan, APB: (Martine McCutcheon etc)

"Being a self-confessed kidult, I'm loving the current quality of Pop TV. On Saturdays SM:TV rules, of course. In a double entendres celebrity death match, Ant, Dec and Cat would kick Norton, Clary and Savage's asses. On Sundays, TOTP Plus is much more promising, except for pretty-but-vacant Vernon."

Peter Berry, Jive Records: (Steps etc)

"There hasn't been much on telly recently which has been a 'must see'. The wife likes Cold Feet and I thought State Of The Planet was depressing but strangely addictive - despite the fact that it made you want to punch Americans. We're waiting with bated breath for the new series of Friends and ER and also Buffy and Angel if there are new series of them."

 Sin Pattenden spoke to press officers working in London.

 Asian first Internet portal Rasmallai has launched the first finance website for the UK's Asian community to meet business, personal investment, money management and other needs.

 Fat end Pekka Sivonen, chairman of Finland's Digia Oy, which groups Britain's Psion, said his firm has raised almost €35m (£21m) from investors to develop software for wireless products.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Three Colours: White | LA Confidential | Hell In The Pacific | The Last Broadcast
fields.body:
Three Colours: White

(Krysztof Kieslowski, 1993)

8pm, FilmFour

The second in Kieslowski's majestic Colours trilogy is an ironically black comedy on the theme of equality, with Zbigniew Zamochowski as a Polish hairdresser doing fine in Paris, except that he's impotent with his wife Julie Delpy. Soon he's ruined and busking on the Metro, and later, back in Warsaw, an act of revenge on his wife only makes him sadder.

LA Confidential

(Curtis Hanson, 1997)

10pm, FilmFour

Superb, dense and dark thriller featuring Russell Crowe as a hardnut cop teaming up with colleagues Guy Pearce and Kevin Spacey to root out corruption. Hanson and Brian Helgeland richly deserved their Oscars for adapting James Ellroy's long, intricate novel, and the murky underworld of 50s LA is brilliantly realised. Kim Basinger (pictured) is impressive as a nearly fatal femme, but the biggest surprise, after his kindly farmer in Babe, is James Cromwell's calculating police captain.

Hell In The Pacific

(John Boorman, 1968)

1.15am, Carlton Cinema

An American pilot and a Japanese naval officer are marooned on a tiny Pacific island during the war: at first they're inclined to continue hostilities, but gradually come to a boozy understanding. Boorman tends to inflate the allegorical importance, but it's well shot and solidly founded on the craggy head-to-head of Lee Marvin versus Toshiro Mifune.

The Last Broadcast

(Stefan Avalos, Lance Weiler, 1998)

2.10am, FilmFour

A $900 movie about people meeting gruesome ends in the woods - sounds familiar? Released months before The Blair Witch Project, there was much debate about whether any copycatting had occurred. A filmmaker (David Beard) is making a documentary about the murders of a pair of cable show hosts in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey, while searching for the mythic Jersey Devil. The only surviving member of the party was convicted - but a horrifying truth is revealed.

A filmmaker (David Beard) is making a documentary about the murders of a pair of cable show hosts in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey, while searching for the mythic Jersey Devil. The only surviving member of the party was convicted - but a horrifying truth is revealed.

webTitle: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
After last week's deluge there has been a brief let-up in the rain. Days begin with low, rushing stormy skies; sometimes with the peachy underglow which often signals snow, yet none comes. Last night the moon spun through flying wraiths of cloud. Today grey wave-spirals of the Atlantic oscillation return, pressing hard down on the landscape. I drive out early to a high point of the Severn Valley to see the floods. The view itself seems to belong to another century. From the medieval ruins of Buildwas Abbey, where the valley constricts the river at the mouth of the Ironbridge Gorge, to the buried Roman city of Viraconium and just beyond it to Atcham and the confluence with the River Tern, the Severn has completely flooded its plain.

All the sinuous meanders lie under a sheet of water a mile and a half wide. Old trees which have weathered many a flood in the past stand darkly, half submerged. This is the powerful, watery world of the Severn, an indomitable spirit thousands of years old which is destroying all our cherished notions of a landscape in which Nature is tamed. Back home I wander down the lane to the ford. Although it has subsided a bit, the brook which usually dribbles under the concrete road is now ripping out its surface and crashing, brown as beer, under a little footbridge. Is it perverse to enjoy this weather and the liberation of the rivers? It is surely possible to feel deep sympathy for the tragedy many have had to endure and at the same time find this natural phenomenon inspirational. It starts raining again. All is quiet, wet, strangely portentous and millennial.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio 2 Young Folk Awards | Connect
fields.body:
Assorted musical youngsters try to calm their nerves as they reach the closing stages of the Radio 2 Young Folk Awards (8.0pm, Radio 2). Mike Harding introduces six acts hoping to win a lot of international publicity and an appearance at next year's Cambridge Folk Festival. Among those in the finals are 13-year-old Sarah Hayes, a flautist and singer from Northumberland, and the Scottish multi-instrumentalists Frame, McKerrell, Napier.

The climatic changes predicted for Europe may not only result in such obvious side effects as floods and storms. Scientists think we could face renewed assaults from diseases we thought long gone from the continent. Where mosquitoes and other creatures serve as carriers the risks have already increased. There have been noticeable surges in such diseases as malaria, dengue fever and cholera. In Connect (9.0pm, Radio 4) Quentin Cooper talks to some of the specialists trying to offset the trend.

webTitle: Court circular

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Listen out for the ardent screams of a thousand hormone-addled teenage girls echoing through the legal chambers of New York in the near future, after a Manhattan appeals court ruled that Leonardo DiCaprio should face trial on alliterative charges of aiding and abetting assault and battery. The offences, which also constitute part of a $45m lawsuit, arose when one Roger Wilson (a 41-year-old screenwriter who readers with bad cinematic taste may remember as a star of Porky's) became embroiled in a scuffle with DiCaprio's entourage at the Asia de Cuba restaurant back in March 1998: a ruckus which the actor himself stayed out of but (allegedly) helped to incite.

And the reason for the fisticuffs? An irate Wilson confronting the pudgy Leonardo and company over various phone calls made by the star to the former's live-in girlfriend, Showgirls actress Elizabeth Berkley. "The claim... is utterly false," thundered DiCaprio's attorney Paul F Callan. "We look forward to presenting a vigorous defence and to a dismissal of all the remaining claims at trial. The end result will prove that the allegations against Mr DiCaprio are fabricated and without any merit." Or will it? The answer, one way or another, will come when the case comes to trial early next year.

Meanwhile, another much-loved screen icon - or perhaps not - has found themselves on the wrong side of the police, with the news that Michael Moriarty (aggressively right-wing star of long-running cop opera Law And Order) has been charged with assault after striking a female companion during a meal in a Vancouver restaurant. The libertarian charmer, who relocated to Canada in the mid-90s on the grounds that Hollywood was in the throes of a leftist conspiracy, appeared in court late last week without a lawyer, before being instructed to attend another hearing later this week. The eggs and rotten fruit are on us...

webTitle: Sharon Mitchell is returning to Albert Square

fields.headline: Homecoming queen
fields.standfirst: EastEnders' Sharon Mitchell is returning to Albert Square after five years. Does this mean the scriptwriters are running short of ideas? No, says Matthew Baylis , they just know a great soap character when they see one
fields.trailText: EastEnders' Sharon Mitchell is returning to Albert Square after five years. Does this mean the scriptwriters are running short of ideas? No, says Matthew Baylis , they just know a great soap character when they see one.
fields.body:
She was last glimpsed getting into the ubiquitous EastEnders getaway cab in July 1995. At the time we were told that Sharon Mitchell, daughter of Den and Angie, Watts had taken up residence with her dipsomaniac mum in Florida. But she's coming back - with, we're promised, an explosive entrance in the New Year. As yet, the reasons for Sharon's return are under wraps. Maybe Angie's taken up with some alligator-wrestling brute from the boondocks, or maybe Sharon can't face life without Clinton as president.

Pundits usually greet soap comebacks with a chorus of groans. It's assumed that the writers must be floundering. Either that, or the actors have grown weary of an anonymity broken only by provincial pantomimes. In reality, this theorising says more about the psychology of viewers than it does about the people who make soap operas. Soap writers use the ugly, but thoroughly apt term "investment" to describe the process whereby an audience comes to believe in a character, simply by following them over a number of years. Like parents who have shelled out for a costly education, we become mighty annoyed when our little investments turn round and say they want to become pop stars. When a popular soap actor or actress decides to quit the show, it is tantamount to a betrayal of our faith in them. We have been cheated of our investment. In revenge, we make unkind judgements about the traitor: they have become too greedy, we decide, too big for their boots. Any attempt to make it as a singer or a serious actor, we prophesy smugly, will end in tears.

Plenty of departing stars do retreat into obscurity. But recently, there have been notable exceptions. Like it or not, Ross Kemp made a credible defence barrister in ITV's In Defence. And the news that he's going to play upper-crust English swimming champ Captain Webb proves he's not afraid of a challenge. Meanwhile, Michelle Collins was on our screens only last weekend, and if Martine McCutcheon is not pulling Madonna-sized audiences, she is far from being obscure. Key roles in soap opera tend to go to versatile performers, people who can carry on earning a living once they've wiped the Walford grime off their faces.

Letitia Dean, who played Sharon for ten years, has not been in the news so much. Her stint as Chris Cross, feisty phone operator, in BBC1's retro piece Hello Girls might not have reaped any Baftas, but it proved a willingness to tackle new ground - even if Sunday night feel-good is not the most demanding genre. And unlike Collins, McCutcheon and Kemp, whose characters joined the EastEnders cast as adults, she faced the additional handicap of having played Sharon from a young age. More screen time, more investment, more viewer resistance to seeing her in new roles.

It should also not be forgotten what an engaging character Sharon was. The pantomime season is currently upon us, so it is small wonder that EastEnders and Coronation Street have both brought back their own moustache-twirling villains (Nick Cotton and Terry Duckworth, respectively) to whip us into a booing, hissing frenzy. But Sharon was far more complex, and her return to Walford deserves a more balanced reading.

She grew up loving two parents who hated one another. At an early age, she understood the power of sex - even making a memorably terrifying assault on bespectacled barman Lofty. After quitting school at 16 and shacking up with the apparently sexy Simon Wicks, she rapidly developed into a character who invites comparison with the Street's Elsie Tanner - simultaneously vamp and victim. After the body of her murdered father was dredged from the canal, Sharon fled to the arms of Grant Mitchell, who beat her up and nearly succeeded in burning her to death. Not deterred, she conducted an illicit affair with his brother Phil, and the episode where Grant revealed this to the Square - so-called "Sharongate" - chalked up record ratings. She survived the sort of shunning normally suffered by 13th-century Welsh witches in order to wreak the perfect revenge on Grant, tricking him into publicly proposing to her, just so she could turn him down.

Rarely has a character's exit been so satisfying to watch, and it was a homage to Sharon's strengths as a character that she left with so much unfinished business behind her. Business which will hopefully turn into gripping storylines when she comes back. Peggy Butcher hates her, and owns the pub that Sharon may view as her rightful inheritance. Phil hates her, but will doubtless find her a bewitching alternative to current squeeze Lisa. Those loyal to Phil's ex-wife Kathy, such as Ian and Pat, are equally likely to spit on the floor as Sharon enters the bar, but perhaps their own recent sufferings will teach them charity.

So if returning to old ground invites criticism, EastEnders should be commended for daring to face it. In the wake of storyline hits such as Ian's bankruptcy and Sonia's baby, the show is hardly in the doldrums. And with a vintage original such as Sharon as its latest weapon in the ratings war, it's hard to see what can go wrong.

webTitle: Allied Domecq withdraws from Seagram bidding

fields.headline: Allied Domecq withdraws from Seagram bidding
fields.trailText: Allied Domecq has thrown in the towel in the battle to buy Seagram's drinks business, leaving a joint bid from Diageo and France's Pernod Ricard as the front runner.
fields.body:
Allied Domecq has thrown in the towel in the battle to buy Seagram's drinks business, leaving a joint bid from Diageo and France's Pernod Ricard as the front runner.

The liquor and wine portfolio, which includes Chivas Regal and Crown Royal whiskies, has been put up for sale by French entertainment firm Vivendi, which bought Seagram this year.

Vivendi yesterday announced it had received only two offers by Monday night's deadline. Diageo and Pernod are understood to have have tabled between $7bn (£4.8bn) and $8bn, putting them ahead of a rival partnership between Bermuda-based Bacardi, US firm Brown-Forman and Sweden's Vin & Spirit.

With two bidders left, industry sources suggested the auction could be settled within a week: "It's going to be immediately clear who's won. There's already been an indicative round, now this is the real thing," said one.

Allied Domecq had been keen on buying the Canadian business as a way of closing the gap with Diageo, by far the world's biggest drinks firm. However, Allied has attempted to circumvent the auction by doing a £700m deal on the side to snatch Captain Morgan, the rum brand seen as Seagram's jewel in the crown.

This could lead to a lengthy courtroom tussle - other bidders are challenging Allied's agreement to buy Captain Morgan from Destileria Serralles, the Puerto Rican originator of the brand, which claims to have first refusal in the event of any change of Seagram's ownership

One industry source said: "Seagram are confident that they control Captain Morgan. I would say that lengthy litigation is likely."

Allied's shares fell 11.5p to 416p as it became clear it had withdrawn. Allied recently secured the rights to distribute Stolichnaya, the world's best selling vodka, and therefore feels there are no more gaps in its portfolio. One insider said: "Allied went into the game to get a vodka and a rum. They've got both of those, and the rest of Seagram's brands are pretty second division."

If successful, Diageo will get Seagram's Crown Royal whiskey, a big US seller. It would take the bulk of the wine portfolio, leaving Chivas Regal scotch for Pernod Ricard. Diageo shares jumped 11p to 678p.

webTitle: A quick one

fields.headline: A quick one
fields.trailText: Global warming, the ongoing destruction of the planet, third world debt, the uselessness of the railways, the takeover by the corporations, the scary George Bush person: all these things are important and should be animating me into outrage. Yet somehow they do not.
fields.body:
Global warming, the ongoing destruction of the planet, third world debt, the uselessness of the railways, the takeover by the corporations, the scary George Bush person: all these things are important and should be animating me into outrage. Yet somehow they do not. I feel ashamed in the presence of committed friends. Come on, Smith. Shape up. Get involved. Instead of becoming "engaged" I sit about wondering how many words like "uselessness" end in "-lessness". Try it. It's interesting*. Tony Blair and his alarming teeth beam out of the screen and I look away. I'm an armchair kind of guy, especially when it's raining, which it always is and always will be.

Not surprising, then, that I have drifted into the orbit of the Idler, which advertises itself as "the magazine for those who live to loaf". My own contribution is described as "advanced loafing from the master". I feel bad that I don't feel worse.

But then, looking through the magazine, which comes in the form of a book, I find myself chuckling and surprised. There is a description of "Travel Twister", to be played with the fingers, and an account of microwaving a Wall's Viennetta, which produces, apparently, "a delicious choco-cream syrup drink. Truly the Viennetta is a milkshake in suspended animation." In an extraordinary interview John Lloyd, producer of Not the Nine O'Clock News, Blackadder and Spitting Image, says, "I think Spitting Image kept Mrs Thatcher in power for years longer than she would naturally have been." Then he says, "I wouldn't bother to teach history; I think it's pointless. History is just the record of human crime." Blimey. In a hilarious account of a night spent drinking urine in Addis Ababa I learned that "apart from a brief fracas with Mussolini, "Ethopia is the only African country never to have been colonised." All this stimulates me to thought, but not too much. The rain, as ever, beats upon the winder.

*A few to get you started: joylessness, hopelessness, gormlessness, homelessness. Who can think of a happy one?

webTitle: Stephen Jeffreys defends his new play

fields.headline: Whites and the blues
fields.standfirst: Would the new play by Stephen Jeffreys be better if he were black? Our critic thought so. Here, the playwright bites back
fields.trailText: Would the new play by Stephen Jeffreys be better if he were black? Our critic thought so. Here, the playwright bites back.
fields.body:
Here are three cracking plays of recent years: The Sanity of George III by Alan Bennett, Three Tall Men by Edward Albee and Observe the Sons of Connaught Marching Towards the Somme by Frank McGuinness. If the titles are unfamiliar, it is because they have been revised to fit the new codes of critical correctness now in force following the review of my new Royal Court play, I Just Stopped By To See the Man, by this paper's theatre critic, Michael Billington. There are three characters in the play and two of them - a blues singer and his politically radical daughter - are black Americans. It is this that has vexed Billington and led him to committing two critical faux pas.

First he uses the fact that he knows me to be a white British writer to belittle the play as a piece of "artful impersonation". The colour of my skin and my passport are enough to invalidate the writing. However, when we auditioned for the part of Jesse in New York, each of the 17 actors we saw asked the casting director about my colour and nationality - they could not distinguish either from the text. But Billington implies that writers who dare to portray anything but immediate autobiographical experience will be flagged offside.

Second, Billington suggests that a black writer would have brought some "hectic, bluesy, volatile veracity" to the proceedings. Leaving aside the possibility that a black writer might have come up with a cooler, more scholarly work, would a black American writer have been successful in portraying the third character - a white rock singer from Surrey? Or suppose a black British writer had tackled the subject: would Winsome Pinnock have had difficulty in writing two male parts? Would Roy Williams have been unable to write Billington's imaginary play through being too young to remember the 1960s blues revival? Of course not, but Billington would rule them out.

One of the basic requirements for being a playwright is to be able to inhabit other people's skins. But why, when no one has ever questioned my right to create roles for women, old people and gays, am I supposed to baulk at the barrier of race? Billington applauded me for writing the role of the Earl of Rochester in The Libertine, but I have no direct experience of being an aristocrat, an alcoholic, or a citizen of 17th-century London. Rochester is more remote from me than the old blues singer Jesse but, because I share his race and nationality, the issue of authenticity is never raised. In fact, the process of writing these two roles is similar: every dramatist has to believe that people have more in common with each other than they have differences. By mixing parallel personal experience, research and instinct, figures from remote times and cultures can be conjured into life. Playwrights have always worked in this way and they always will.

Conferences on the future of black theatre always conclude, among other things, that there is a responsibility for playwrights to write black roles. As a white writer writing parts to be played by black actors, I am following an honourable tradition at the Royal Court, treading in the footsteps of Rebecca Pritchard's Yard Gal and Che Walker's Been Here So Long. Indeed, Che Walker informs me that he asked one of the black actors in his play if he felt it was OK for him, a white writer, to write for black people. The reply was simple: "If you don't, I don't work." None of the many black people who have seen, read, or worked on my play have questioned my right or ability to portray black characters on stage. Why is it a problem for critics?

A lesser critic than Billington would not be worth arguing with: but he, more than any other observer of drama, has argued for a theatre with a social and political agenda, for big plays on public themes. How is such a theatre possible if each playwright is condemned to plodding the limited circumferences of their own cell? "Unscrew the locks from the doors, unscrew the doors themselves from their jambs," wrote Walt Whitman. If we cannot break through the barriers to try to reach one another in the sphere of art, where can we?

 I Just Stopped By To See the Man is at the Royal Court, London SW1, until January 6. Box office: 020-7565 5000.
fields.bodyText: Here are three cracking plays of recent years: The Sanity of George III by Alan Bennett, Three Tall Men by Edward Albee and Observe the Sons of Connaught Marching Towards the Somme by Frank McGuinness. If the titles are unfamiliar, it is because they have been revised to fit the new codes of critical correctness now in force following the review of my new Royal Court play, I Just Stopped By To See the Man, by this paper's theatre critic, Michael Billington. There are three characters in the play and two of them - a blues singer and his politically radical daughter - are black Americans. It is this that has vexed Billington and led him to committing two critical faux pas. First he uses the fact that he knows me to be a white British writer to belittle the play as a piece of "artful impersonation". The colour of my skin and my passport are enough to invalidate the writing. However, when we auditioned for the part of Jesse in New York, each of the 17 actors we saw asked the casting director about my colour and nationality - they could not distinguish either from the text. But Billington implies that writers who dare to portray anything but immediate autobiographical experience will be flagged offside. Second, Billington suggests that a black writer would have brought some "hectic, bluesy, volatile veracity" to the proceedings. Leaving aside the possibility that a black writer might have come up with a cooler, more scholarly work, would a black American writer have been successful in portraying the third character - a white rock singer from Surrey? Or suppose a black British writer had tackled the subject: would Winsome Pinnock have had difficulty in writing two male parts? Would Roy Williams have been unable to write Billington's imaginary play through being too young to remember the 1960s blues revival? Of course not, but Billington would rule them out. One of the basic requirements for being a playwright is to be able to inhabit other people's skins. But why, when no one has ever questioned my right to create roles for women, old people and gays, am I supposed to baulk at the barrier of race? Billington applauded me for writing the role of the Earl of Rochester in The Libertine, but I have no direct experience of being an aristocrat, an alcoholic, or a citizen of 17th-century London. Rochester is more remote from me than the old blues singer Jesse but, because I share his race and nationality, the issue of authenticity is never raised. In fact, the process of writing these two roles is similar: every dramatist has to believe that people have more in common with each other than they have differences. By mixing parallel personal experience, research and instinct, figures from remote times and cultures can be conjured into life. Playwrights have always worked in this way and they always will. Conferences on the future of black theatre always conclude, among other things, that there is a responsibility for playwrights to write black roles. As a white writer writing parts to be played by black actors, I am following an honourable tradition at the Royal Court, treading in the footsteps of Rebecca Pritchard's Yard Gal and Che Walker's Been Here So Long. Indeed, Che Walker informs me that he asked one of the black actors in his play if he felt it was OK for him, a white writer, to write for black people. The reply was simple: "If you don't, I don't work." None of the many black people who have seen, read, or worked on my play have questioned my right or ability to portray black characters on stage. Why is it a problem for critics? A lesser critic than Billington would not be worth arguing with: but he, more than any other observer of drama, has argued for a theatre with a social and political agenda, for big plays on public themes. How is such a theatre possible if each playwright is condemned to plodding the limited circumferences of their own cell? "Unscrew the locks from the doors, unscrew the doors themselves from their jambs," wrote Walt Whitman. webTitle: The Secret Diaries of Desmond Olivier Dingle

fields.headline: Just call me God
fields.standfirst: Desmond Olivier Dingle is staging his epoch-making play, The Messiah, at the Bush Theatre. In an exclusive extract from his production diary, the artistic director of the National Theatre of Brent shares some of his traumas and triumphs
fields.trailText: In an exclusive extract from his production diary, the artistic director of the National Theatre of Brent shares some of his traumas and triumphs.
fields.body:
Saturday

Hard to believe that the National Theatre of Brent will be presenting my award-winning yuletide oeuvre The Messiah at the stylish and fashionable Bush Theatre in Shepherd's Bush this Christmas. Must get down to rehearsing. We open in less than a fortnight. Spend the morning working out my guest list for the first night. It will include numerous world-famous celebrities from all walks of life.

Sunday

Wake early after an extraordinary dream in which I find myself in Bethlehem with Trevor Nunn discussing my first night guest list. Then relax on my theatrical divan and read Sunday papers and various theatrical journals in my attractive and stylish Dollis Hill offices. As I do so, I recall all the numerous other first nights I done and find myself marvelling at the long and glamorous career I have had in the theatre.

My reminiscences are rudely broken by a call from my permanent acting company - Raymond Box - complaining that he's trying to learn his lines but can't read my hand- writing. Of course he can't. Famous playwrights write illegibly. This is because their writings burst from the seething hotbed of their own internal organs. Look at Shakespeare, to name but one, I tell him. His writing was totally indecipherable. Not to mention Chekhov, who not only wrote back to front but also in Russian!

Monday

Call from the Guardian arts desk, begging me to write a production diary of my award-winning oeuvre The Messiah, opening at the stylish and fashionable Bush Theatre in Shepherd's Bush in less than a fortnight. I am told it should be in the same vein as the Secret Diary of Sir Peter Hall. I tell him I would be honoured as Sir Peter's diaries are in my humble view probably one of the most inspirational diaries ever done and he lies constantly by my bedside.

An urgent call from Raymond in a state of panic claiming I never told him he was playing the Virgin Mary. I told him he was playing Mary at least a week ago! We had the same brouhaha last year when I cast him as Princess Diana in our award- winning oeuvre Love Upon the Throne. He aks why he has to play all the lady characters all the time. Eventually I mollify him by offering him the key role of Balthazar, the chief wise man, and agree that he can find himself an inexpensive headdress to wear in act one. An aspect that will appeal to a simple mind such as Raymond's. Sometimes one is forced to resort to such draconian ruses! Work into the early hours honing my first night guest list. I have now whittled it down to 750 people and it will include numerous media, showbiz, political, sports and church personalities.

Tuesday

Wake after a vivid and some would say prophetic dream in which I am in bed with Trevor Nunn and Sir Peter Hall in the middle of Shepherd's Bush Green in ornamental bejewelled turbans. Breakfast on All-Bran. Relax with periodicals. Reminisce about my fascinating childhood. Raymond arrives and presents me with receipts for two books - Having Babies the Natural Way and the Teach Yourself Home Midwifery. I tell him in no uncertain terms that for as long as I've been in the theatre, actors always pay for their own research, thank you very much! In the evening I treat him to a fascinating slide show of "stills" from many of my previous successes. Then he insists on watching Who Wants To Be a Millionaire. How can people watch this rubbish? All it does is give not very bright people an inflated idea of their own intelligence. The fact that Raymond managed to reach £500,000 is a perfect case in point.

Wednesday

We open The Messiah in a week at the popular and stylish Bush Theatre in London's fashionable Shepherd's Bush Green. Can hardly believe it! Just remembered we need an opera singer to sing highlights from The Messiah by Johann Sebastian Handel while Raymond and I re-enact the Christmas story. Arrange to meet a certain Mrs Flowers, who is the only person to have answered our advert in the Dollis Hill Advertiser. We lunch at the Dome in Shepherd's Bush Road over a bowl of French onion soup (not the same bowl, obviously) and I ask her a number of searing biblical and operatic questions. She tells me her life story then starts singing about sheep. I offer her the job to shut her up.

Thursday

Arrive at the Bush for first run-through. Shocked to discover Raymond, whose job it is to build and transport the set, stuck halfway up the stairs with two Greek temple pillars and a box of stuffed sheep. This lack of foresight is typical!

Regretfully have to decline to give help as I never think it's good for one's actors to see an artistic director lugging sets and props about. Would you ever see Trevor Nunn lugging sets about at the National Theatre? Or Adrian Mole at the Royal Shakespeare Company? I think not, Raymond!

Spend the rest of the afternoon on the couch in my dressing room adding more names to my first night guest list and marvelling at the extraordinary number of my own glittering first nights I have attended. Shocked to discover that the Bush seats only 101 people! The Bush press office is in a state because I have invited over 1,600 people on the first night. This was followed by - I have to say - an appalling dress rehearsal. I myself have never been better as Joseph, first shepherd and God, but Raymond's performance as Balthazar the chief wise man is frankly appalling. Not only that, but he has found himself an exquisitely bejewelled and rare ornamental headdress that totally unbalances his characterisation in my view. I fear I will be forced to recast Balthazar and wear the headdress myself.

Also - and more worrying - Mrs Flowers fainted during the birth scene. Raymond's depiction of all stages of labour and delivery are graphic, to say the least. I asked him to tone it down a bit but he just looked at me with a strange wild stare and muttered something about having the baby his way and no one was going to stop him! I told him in no uncertain terms that I have invited the Archbishop of Canterbury to the first night and we simply cannot have a trained opera singer keeling over during possibly the most pivotal moment in the entire Christian doctrine.

Friday

Hard to believe that the National Theatre of Brent will be presenting my award-winning yuletide oeuvre The Messiah at the stylish and fashionable Bush Theatre in Shepherd's Bush in just a few days' time.

My exhilaration is somewhat blighted by a very unfortunate argument with Mrs Flowers about the size of her and Raymond's dressing room. Try to explain that, as artistic director, I have to have the larger (actually the only) room with en-suite facilities and the panoramic vista over Shepherd's Bush Green. If I don't, I'll have to go in the cleaning cupboard with Raymond, which is clearly untenable.

Also, I need a larger room for all my important political showbiz friends who I will be entertaining on a nightly basis, including Chris Smith, the Spice Girls, Charlotte Church and Sophia Loren. Then I have Raymond whingeing on about the fact that Mrs Flowers has used his hairpiece to clean the toilet. I'm afraid to say I have no sympathy. Raymond's toupee has caused more problems than it's worth. It finished up in an old folks' home in Galashiels last year during the Edinburgh festival, but that's another story.

The Bush is still in a state about my guest list, which has now reached over 2,000 people. As artistic director of one of the most prestigious national theatres in the land, surely I have a right to ask who I want!

Finally, during a searing interview with the Hounslow Chronicle, I drift off in sheer exhaustion. I dream that I am standing in a Greek temple with Trevor Nunn, Sir Peter Hall, Charlotte Church and the Archbishop of Canterbury. The archbishop lays his hand on my weary head and Trevor Nunn gives me a holly wreath. Somehow I know that everything's going to be all right and we have a massive success on our hands.

 This is an edited extract from The Secret Diaries of Desmond Olivier Dingle (soon to be published by a major publishing house, eg HarperCollins or Penguin). The Messiah is at the Bush Theatre, London W12, from tonight until February 3. Box office: 020-7610 4224.

webTitle: TV critic Gareth McLean reviews Madame Butterfly

fields.headline: Confessions of an opera virgin
fields.standfirst:
Our job swap experiment continues with Guardian TV critic Gareth McLean dressing up for Madama Butterfly, while, our dance critic Judith Mackrell visits Spectacular Bodies at the Hayward Gallery

Related story: Too, too solid flesh
fields.trailText: Our job swap experiment continues with Guardian TV critic Gareth McLean dressing up for Madama Butterfly.
fields.body:
'You'd better get dressed up," my friend Gill said when I told her I was going to the opera. "A suit at the very least. If you want to do it properly, you should wear black tie. Definitely." I sighed. "That means no jeans and no trainers," she concluded pointedly. I sighed again. No jeans, no trainers. She made it sound as though I was going to a nightclub that also displayed signs such as "Over 25s only" and "No football colours". (In a way, I was. When I eventually arrived, there were indeed no trainers, jeans or football colours. And there were only a couple of people under 25, whom the rest of the more mature audience eyed with curiosity.)

So, suit, dinner jacket or smart trousers? Still unsure, I called Drew, Scottish Opera's press officer. He said black tie was really only a first night thing, and that donning a suit would rank me among the best dressed opera-goers. Something smart, he implied, but not too smart - unless you want people to know you're an opera virgin. But no jeans, no trainers. Given that I normally do my TV reviews in pants and a T-shirt - or, on a cold day, pyjamas - any outfit would be "dressed up" for me. I finally opted for a pair of smartish trousers and a short-sleeved, Chinese-red Joseph shirt. Smart but casual, as they say in Glasgow, with a hint of the Orient in homage to Madama Butterfly.

I was confident my outfit wouldn't betray me as a pleb whose last trip to the opera started off with him pronouncing Turandot incorrectly (I thought the final "t" was silent) and ended with him close to tears because the whole thing was so bloody long. Madama Butterfly was quite straightforward on the pronunciation front - if I remembered not to say Madame - and it was only two hours and 50 minutes long. I say "only" but, coming in at the length of two EastEnders omnibuses, that was probably as much as I could endure without a cup of tea.

My job dictates I don't really get out much, so to be in a crowded theatre with lots of old people is quite frightening. Surrounded by men in tartan trousers and bifocals and women whose last orgasm coincided with the Suez crisis, it was like being in the waiting room for heaven. I nervously found Drew, who was suited up. "I thought you were getting dressed up," he said. Unsure whether he was joking - in retrospect, I think he was - I replied: "This is as dressed up as I get. Unless it's a wedding or a funeral."

He gave me my tickets and bade me enjoy the show. Feeling incongruous, fraudulent and a teensy bit intimidated ("TV critic is beaten to death by opera lovers for suggesting John Thaw has a wooden leg"), I climbed the stairs into the auditorium. It was very posh and I was glad I wasn't in my pyjamas. As the safety curtain rose and a hush fell, I was quite excited. And then it started. The set was nice - minimal Japanese rather than the Shogun props room look. Sliding opaque screens were, I imagine, emblematic of the lies told by BF Pinkerton and the layers of truth revealed to Madama Butterfly. Due to the stylish lighting, silhouette was used to great effect and, visually, it was quite stunning, though not as epic as I expected.

As Pinkerton was telling the marriage broker of his plans for an American wife, I had great fun guessing what BF stood for, though none of my thoughts are printable in a family newspaper. And it was hard not to shout, "Don't do it!" at Butterfly, especially when I realised the poor love was only 15. Did it she did, however, and even when a Phil Mitchell-type uncle shouted the odds, Butterfly said she didn't care for her relatives as long as she had Pinkerton. Oh dear, I thought. This happens in Family Affairs all the time. It is bound to end in disaster. And when she brandished her dad's ceremonial dagger, it was a foregone conclusion that someone would be gutted before the night was out.

Of course, that's the frustrating thing about classics such as Madama Butterfly: the conclusion is foregone. We know she dies at the end and there's no chance she might knife the duplicitous Pinkerton. While getting to the end point is an interesting journey, what I really wanted was a different destination. (Woman is shafted by man and pays the ultimate price is not a story I want to hear again, especially after Charlie's Angels.) And I was sick during the interval. Not directly because of the opera but I did have sushi before I went - to get in the mood, you understand. So I missed a bit of the second half and wasn't really concentrating until Butterfly and her son Sorrow started attacking the mean marriage broker, Goro.

When the end came, it was a blessed relief. As I was unaccustomed to opera, the form estranged me from the content. Being used to TV drama, which strives to make its style unobtrusive - or at least "realistic" - at some points during the opera I wanted them to stop singing and just get on with the action. It wasn't even like a musical, where you can sing along. As accomplished and pleasant as the singing was, it didn't engage me.

In short, I did not have a moment like Julia Roberts does in Pretty Woman. The only tears in my eyes were because I was unwell. In the end, all I wanted was my pyjamas and a cup of hot, sweet tea.

webTitle: Lawyers help island nations keep afloat

fields.headline: Lawyers help island nations keep afloat
fields.standfirst:
This month we are highlighting the work of our four Christmas appeal charities. Today: Field, which gives legal aid to poor nations threatened by climate change

Special report: Christmas appeal 2000
fields.trailText: This month we are highlighting the work of our four Christmas appeal charities. Today: Field, which gives legal aid to poor nations threatened by climate change
fields.body:
As they battle for insurance payouts for all the floods of the past few months, the inhabitants of Uxbridge, Middlesex, might spare a thought for the people of Samoa. On small islands like this, and others including the Maldives and Marshall Islands, there is more than just insurance at stake. In this location global warming could mean islands being so swamped they disappear.

As temperatures rise, scientists are forecasting higher sea levels, freak weather, storms, floods and tidal waves. But it is not the biggest industrial nations, the source of most of the pollution, that will be hardest hit. The small, low-lying coastal nations - which, in particular, lack resources to protect fragile ecosystems - face being wiped out.

Various green groups are tackling the issue, publicising it, and working at international level and with the communities concerned.

But one group has been taking a different approach, aiming, since 1989, to empower the disadvantaged by giving free legal aid. They are a team of environmental lawyers known as Field - the Foundation for International Environmental Law and Development - whose focus is not just climate change but habitat loss, water pollution, and the ozone layer.

Farhana Yamin, who directs Field's climate change work, has seen first-hand how developing countries can be overlooked or even bullied as the international heavyweights haggle over environmental reforms. The biggest irony, she says, was that the nations most threatened by global warming and climate change were excluded from negotiations over the deals.

Ms Yamin believes the Hague summit was characterised by suspicion and brinkmanship. "Many Hague delegates felt a selected few countries, including Britain and America, were going to cook the books together and once they had agreed everyone else would be forced to rubber stamp it. That's the type of thing we have to worry about. We are there to provide support to Aosis states to ensure their interests are fully represented."

At the last climate change summit, in Kyoto, five Field lawyers served on Aosis delegations to ensure that the final protocol text, which had legally binding targets, was "as progressive and environmentally effective as could be negotiated". One of the many challenges small island developing nations face is how to strengthen their position as the UN proceeds with negotiations on climate change.

Small island states have a strong collective voice acting as the Aosis group, says Ms Yamin, but since they are dispersed across the globe they come under pressure not just from the superpowers but from their neighbours, such as Australia and Japan. Developing countries which depend heavily on overseas aid, says Ms Yamin, may find their wealthy benefactors suddenly calling in the favours to secure, for instance, support for contentious issues such as whaling agreements. The small nations often fear that if they do not play ball their aid packages may dry up.

Jürgen Lefevere, staff lawyer at Field, says: "Australia, for example, has taken a particularly bad position on carbon sinks, a practice where countries plant forests as a way of absorbing harmful carbon dioxide emissions - rather than actually cut emissions."

Australia, he adds, has "used all sorts of tactics" to undermine Aosis countries on the "sinks" issue. Up against such international bullying, the small nations have discovered their best tactic is to speak from the heart.

Neroni Slade, an ambassador from Samoa who is also chair of Aosis, says: "Climate change is real. We know this from what is happening to our islands, whether through excessive rainfall or drought, or through the destructive forces of increasingly frequent hurricanes and storms.

"We make no apology for [being] driven by our fears and concerns for the safety and survival of our islands and communities.

"We believe very deeply that there is a question of equity and justice at stake. We are the first and we are the most severely at risk."

The effects of these weather patterns are dramatic, none more so than in sea-level changes. "We need to save the coral reefs and resurrect or replant protective natural vegetation like mangroves. It is frustrating, says Ms Yamin, that messages like that from the Samoan ambassador have not led to more action by the main culprits of environmental pollution to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

The UN framework convention on climate change obliges industrialised nations to demonstrate that they are "taking the lead" in controlling emission. As the first test of commitment, the proposal is for the stabilisation of emissions down to 1990 levels by 2000. But most industrialised countries have seen increases in greenhouse gas emissions.

The 21 nations of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development report a rise in carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion of 10.8% over the decade. The US increased its emissions by 12.7%, Canada by 12.4%, Australia by 15.4%, and Japan by 13.6%. All these increases took place when representatives from these nations were negotiating with smaller countries about how to strengthen the commitment to stabilisation.

"They definitely boxed well above their weight by forcing the rich polluting nations to listen to their plight and also by fighting against Opec countries that have a different agenda. Many small nations found it frustrating that the emission rates of a lot of countries had gone up in the past 10 years. "But we will be back at the next round of negotiations," insists Ms Yamin. "We will be assisting Aosis members in trying to get the heavyweights to reduce their emissions. For our clients, it could literally mean the difference between life and death."

webTitle: Pass notes: Jim Davidson

fields.headline: No: 1781 Jim Davidson
fields.trailText: Jim, Jim, he's such a funny guy! Seven million viewers can't be wrong.
fields.body:
Jim, Jim, he's such a funny guy! Seven million viewers can't be wrong.

I tell you what, I particularly like that Big Break show, uniting my love of both snooker and Jim Davidson. You actually love Jim Davidson?

With a passion. Doesn't everyone? Well, er, not exactly. At least not Suzi Perry, his co-star in Homeward Bound for Christmas, a hil-ar-i-ous BBC variety-show romp set on board the Royal Navy carrier HMS Invincible.

Suzi Perry? What's she got that I haven't? Well, for starters she's a busty, flaxen-haired ex-model with a dazzling knowledge of superbike racing.

I see. And Jim goes for that kind of bird, does he? You could say that. Poor old Jim got himself shambolically drunk trying to woo his lady-love.

Well, it is a foolproof pulling technique. Sadly not in this case. Jim, who gave up the booze in 1994, leapt off the wagon in an effort to impress the lovely Suzi. But stunner Suzi claimed that she had absolutely no idea he had the hots for her.

Perhaps Jim's approach was too subtle? Or perhaps not. He even wrote her a love letter, but then admitted that he was so gone it looked as if it had been written by a six-year-old.

Smiling through the tears. And when he saw Suzi dancing with another member of the crew who was, inexplicably, clad as Elvis, he cried: "Oh no, she doeshn't love me, and she'sh left me for Elvis."

I notice Jim was slurring by this stage. Mmm, yes, in fact the funny man claims: "I had only ever been that drunk once before - and that was from 1971 until 1990."

Side-splitting. So why did he give up the bottle? Jim readily admits that his drinking hasn't helped his previous marriages.

Marriages? Plural? Oh yes, very plural. There have been four Mrs Davidsons. And not one of them could tolerate the birds and the booze.

Funny that. Bloody hysterical.

webTitle: 250 jobs go in Italian ship row

fields.headline: 250 jobs go in Italian ship row
fields.trailText: Doubts over a £51m contract to upgrade an Italian cruise liner have resulted in the loss of 250 shipyard jobs on Merseyside.
fields.body:
Doubts over a £51m contract to upgrade an Italian cruise liner have resulted in the loss of 250 shipyard jobs on Merseyside.

Cammell Laird said the jobs will go immediately because of continuing uncertainty over the contract to fit a new section to the Costa Classica, owned by Costa Crociere. The vessel was heading to the Birkenhead yard last month when it was ordered to turn back amid claims from the Italians of delays in the work.

Cammell Laird said it had won new contracts from P&O European Ferries for maintenance and refit work on three of its ships, but manning levels had been based on the Costa Classica contract. "Despite the new work, the continuing uncertainty surrounding this contract has resulted in a level of overmanning that cannot be sustained.

"Cammell Laird deeply regret the need for redundancies and will continue their efforts to resolve the dispute with the owners of Costa Classica and to attract further new work to the yard." The cut will leave 680 workers and 263 apprentices at the yard.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, said Cammell Laird had had the order stolen from under its nose. "We have been warning for months that European governments were breaching the rules on shipbuilding."

webTitle: Financier told clients he could fix share price, court hears

fields.headline: Financier told clients he could fix share price, court hears
fields.trailText: City financier Johnny Townsend told clients not to worry about their company's share price as he could make it "what he wanted it to be", a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
City financier Johnny Townsend told clients not to worry about their company's share price as he could make it "what he wanted it to be", a court heard yesterday.

On day two of his trial for insider dealing, colleagues said the former vice chairman of stockbroker Hoare Govett made the boast during secret talks with WT Foods over plans to buy the Noon group.

Ranald McGregor-Smith, a former Hoare Govett director who attended the meeting, said Townsend reassured WT its sinking share price would not affect the £50m deal.

"He said they shouldn't worry as he could make the share price whatever he wanted it to be," Mr McGregor-Smith told Blackfriars crown court.

Another colleague who attended the talks, Robert Finlay, said the comment "struck me as a foolish thing to say and showed bravado".

But WT's chief executive Keith Stott and finance director Roderick Garland, who called the secret meeting at a country hotel in Hertfordshire, both deny Townsend made any such comment.

Townsend, 58, is accused of encouraging his friend Salah Shohet to buy 1m shares in WT after this meeting. He denies the charge.

Mr Shohet, a property dealer and father-in-law of concert pianist Murray Perahia, said Townsend had previously "praised" WT shares and urged him to buy them on a Friday in late May 1998.

"He rang me three times in the morning to insist on the purchases," he told the court.

Roderick Ayres, responsible for executing trades at Hoare Govett, said Townsend had placed Mr Shohet's order in two phone calls after he missed a flight to Italy.

The trade was actually cancelled shortly afterwards by Govett's chairman Peter Meinertzhagen after suspicions were raised. Under cross-examination by Nicholas Purnell QC, defending, Mr Ayres admitted not telling Townsend it had been stopped in their second conversation, but denied he was under orders.

The case continues.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Virgin Express weighs offers
fields.body:
Virgin Express weighs offers

Discount airline Virgin Express said yesterday it was seeking a possible sale of its Virgin Express Ireland subsidiary after receiving a number of approaches from potential third-party investors.

"Following a number of approaches and a strategic review of our business, it is clear that we must re-focus our business around profitable routes out of our Brussels hub," chairman David Hoared said.

Virgin said existing routes would be flown until January 15. After that, Virgin Express said it would fly from Brussels to eight European cities.

Lapse rate alarms FSA

The financial services authority said yesterday it was concerned about the number of people who are stopping payments into life assurance, endowment and pension policies too early.

Almost a third of those who take out such regular premium policies exit them within four years. "Many of these consumers will have got back less than they have paid in and some will have got back nothing at all," an FSA spokeswoman said. This is because some policies levy sizeable upfront charges.

The FSA said a recent decline in "lapse rates" had halted. Of the 2.68m regular premium policies sold in 1995, only 1.89m (70.7%) were still in force after four years.

Boots buys study centre

Boots said it had acquired the Centre for the Study of Complementary Medicine, for more than £1m.

The acquisition came at a time of increasing regulation and research into complementary and alternative medicine following the recent House of Lords science and technology committee report, Boots said.

Monotub plans to raise £3.1m

Monotub Industries said it planned to raise £3.1m through a cash placing of 641,037 new ordinary shares at a placing price of £5 per share.

The company said the funds raised were for continued development and expansion as well as introduction of the Titan washing machine in certain European markets.

The group said in the six months to September 30 it showed a loss of £600,256 compared to £181,918 for the same period last year.

Lloyd's chief joins Aon

Max Taylor, chairman of the Lloyd's of London insurance market for the past three years, is to join Aon, the insurance company, in January.

webTitle: Obituary: Al Timothy

fields.headline: Al Timothy
fields.standfirst: Energetic jazz all-rounder whose song was a hit for Shirley Bassey
fields.trailText: Energetic jazz all-rounder whose song was a hit for Shirley Bassey.
fields.body:
Al Timothy, who has died aged 85, was a rumbustious saxophonist who left jazz to work as a cabaret entertainer. He was also a successful songwriter whose work was recorded by Shirley Bassey and the future Nation of Islam leader, Louis Farrakhan.

Born in Radix, Trinidad, Timothy started playing flute at the age of eight, taught by his father Edgar, a carpenter, musician and instrument maker. He taught him violin, too, and, accompanied by a friend playing cuatro, toured the streets during carnival. When he began to play double-bass and alto saxophone, he hid his prowess from his mother, who did not want him to follow a career in music. He became a tailor and, at 20, opened a haberdashery shop in Port-of-Spain.

With a 12-piece band, Timothy won local competitions, then secured a residency at an exclusive, virtually whites-only, country club in Maravel. He switched to tenor saxophone, playing what he called "unconstituted jazz and Glenn Miller", and slipped in the occasional calypso, popular with many whites but frowned on by the club's conservative management. There were rural jobs, too - weddings, dances, parties - before, in 1946, he inherited the remnants of the leading band, when most of them left for Britain.

Timothy was not far behind. He arrived in 1948, a few weeks after the Empire Windrush. He settled in Hoxton, east London, found a tailoring job and renewed a friendship with trumpeter "Rannie" Hart; together, they accompanied calypsonian Lord Kitchener in a Brixton pub. From there, he gravitated to the bottle parties where the new wave of settlers began to change London nightlife.

The popular, Louis Jordan style suited his personality as featured artist with Cab Kaye, but he continued to play bebop with the young bloods of Soho. Melody Maker called him a "booting tenor player, who is making a name for himself around town".

In 1953, Timothy backed Lord Kitchener's calypsos for Melodisc Records and recorded as "King Timothy" and "Timothy Otis", his amusingly hip Gerrard Street being one of several period calypsos to acknowledge the impact of bebop. His best known compositions are Kiss Me, Honey Honey, Kiss Me, which Shirley Bassey took to number three in the British charts early in 1959, and the teasing calypso Don't Touch Me Nylon, a risqué number recorded by an artist known as "The Charmer", who subsequently emerged as Louis Farrakhan.

Friendship with the Rothschild heiress, Baronness Nica de Koenigswarter, changed Timothy's horizons. Famous for her patronage, she was in London to hear pianist Teddy Wilson, and was impressed by Timothy, who shared the bill. When she opened the refurbished Studio 51, London's leading modern jazz venue, he became resident bandleader of Al Timothy and his All-Stars!

With Singaporean pianist David Wu and Vincentian trumpeter Shake Keane, he formed the Timwu-Kee Sextet for a long residency at Mayfair's Celebrity restaurant. The band put the club on the map, with even Jean Metcalfe airing her end of an edition of Two-Way Family Favourites from there. Other Mayfair jobs followed, and Timothy appeared on the pioneer teen-music programme Oh Boy!

In 1956, he travelled to New York, where Nica introduced him to cutting-edge jazzmen; days and nights were spent carousing with Thelonious Monk and his saxophonist, Ernie Henry. It was during this visit that Timothy learnt of the Charmer's recording, although record company chicanery ensured that he never received composer royalties.

Back in England, he continued to write; successes include Football, Football and That's What Love Does For You, recorded by Edmundo Ros and David Essex respectively. As he languished on summer seasons in Jersey, memories faded of halycon New York days. He still thought of himself as a jazz saxophonist, did the splits on stage, and also played violin and bass. The circuit took him as far as Addis Ababa, but increasingly to nightclubs and working men's clubs in the provinces.

For a long residency at the Barn, Chingford, in the early 1970s, Timothy's 12-year-old son, Michael, played piano, and he continued working in cabaret until retirement. He suffered a stroke in 1999, following a visit to Trinidad, but retained a phenomenal memory. News of a CD release of the Charmer's hits stirred him to ferocious comment, although he admitted admiration for Farrakhan's artistry.

He met his wife, Joy, soon after his arrival. She was one of the adventurous Englishwomen who visited the Paramount dance hall on Tottenham Court Road to dance with the new migrant settlers. She survives him with their sons, Adrian, Nicky and Michael, whose keyboard credits include Boy George, Hugh Masekela, Womack and Womack, and Massive Attack.

 Albon Timothy, saxophonist, singer, bandleader, composer, born July 5 1915; died December 8 2000

In 1956, he travelled to New York, where Nica introduced him to cutting-edge jazzmen; days and nights were spent carousing with Thelonious Monk and his saxophonist, Ernie Henry. It was during this visit that Timothy learnt of the Charmer's recording, although record company chicanery ensured that he never received composer royalties. Back in England, he continued to write; successes include Football, Football and That's What Love Does For You, recorded by Edmundo Ros and David Essex respectively. As he languished on summer seasons in Jersey, memories faded of halycon New York days. He still thought of himself as a jazz saxophonist, did the splits on stage, and also played violin and bass. The circuit took him as far as Addis Ababa, but increasingly to nightclubs and working men's clubs in the provinces. For a long residency at the Barn, Chingford, in the early 1970s, Timothy's 12-year-old son, Michael, played piano, and he continued working in cabaret until retirement. He suffered a stroke in 1999, following a visit to Trinidad, but retained a phenomenal memory. News of a CD release of the Charmer's hits stirred him to ferocious comment, although he admitted admiration for Farrakhan's artistry. He met his wife, Joy, soon after his arrival. She was one of the adventurous Englishwomen who visited the Paramount dance hall on Tottenham Court Road to dance with the new migrant settlers. She survives him with their sons, Adrian, Nicky and Michael, whose keyboard credits include Boy George, Hugh Masekela, Womack and Womack, and Massive Attack.  Albon Timothy, saxophonist, singer, bandleader, composer, born July 5 1915; died December 8 2000

webTitle: RUC telephonist warned Derry man off march

fields.headline: RUC telephonist warned Derry man off march, says witness
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: A telephonist at the RUC's headquarters in Derry warned a man to stay away from the march which led to Bloody Sunday because paratroopers were "coming in and coming in shooting", the Saville inquiry heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A telephonist at the RUC's headquarters in Derry warned a man to stay away from the march which led to Bloody Sunday because paratroopers were "coming in and coming in shooting", the Saville inquiry heard yesterday.

Charles McDaid said the warning, passed to his wife, came from an anonymous phone caller, who was later identified as Jean Manning.

Mr McDaid told the inquiry that the message, which came on the morning of the march, said: "Tell junior [Mr McDaid] not to go to the march because the paras are coming in and coming in shooting, and others have been informed." Later, the caller made herself known to him. She has since died.

In a statement to the inquiry, which is investigating the killings of 13 unarmed civil rights marchers in Derry on January 30 1972, Mr McDaid said that some people he expected to see on the march were conspicuous by their absence. They included John Hume, now leader of the SDLP.

Christopher Clarke QC, counsel to the inquiry, also read out part of a statement to the inquiry by Mr Hume in which he said he had spoken out against the march, deciding well in advance not to attend it.

Lord Saville asked Mr McDaid to consider "very carefully indeed" a request to give names of possible IRA members to the inquiry, in confidence. "It would then be a matter for those people to decide whether or not, if they had anything to do with Bloody Sunday, they wanted to remain anonymous."

Earlier, a resident, Dermot Carlin, told the inquiry that he had been pointed out by one soldier to another. After Mr Carlin responded to cries to help Damien Donaghey, who had been wounded by gunfire, this second soldier directed his rifle at him.

Mr Donaghey, 15, was shot along with John Johnston, 59, on the fringe of Derry's Bogside area. Mr Johnston died five months later.

Another witness, Patrick O'Carolan, said he had always wondered why these two residents were shot. "I could not understand [the shooting of] Mr Johnston - his age and his appearance, why anybody would want to shoot him, because he would not be a danger to anybody."

webTitle: How they help

fields.headline: How they help
fields.standfirst: Special report: Christmas appeal 2000
fields.trailText: Action on Disability and Development helps disabled people in 12 of the world's poorest countries by assisting them to form self-help organisations and influencing decision makers to invest more in their needs.
fields.body:
Action on Disability and Development helps disabled people in 12 of the world's poorest countries by assisting them to form self-help organisations and influencing decision makers to invest more in their needs.

Refuge offers a national lifeline for women suffering domestic violence, providing accommodation and emotional support. Its aim is to help women and their children enjoy a future free from physical and emotional abuse.

Foundation for International Environmental Law and Development provides legal advice on environmental issues, often to smaller countries that cannot afford the fees of commercial lawyers, to ensure they are fairly represented at international negotiations and conferences.

The Place 2 Be sends specialist counsellors into primary schools to offer emotional and therapeutic support to children who are troubled, unhappy and confused.

webTitle: Obituary: William Scammell

fields.headline: William Scammell
fields.standfirst: Poet of wit, craft and restless observation
fields.trailText: Poet of wit, craft and restless observation
fields.body:
I first met the poet Bill Scammell, who has died aged 61, in the early 1960s. He and Frank Pike, then at the outset of a distinguished career with Faber's, were running a literary discussion group for the New Left Review. The format for its meetings, held above a cheap and cheerful restaurant in Soho, was simple: an invited person would give a paper, it would be followed by a discussion, and then everyone would tumble downstairs for drinks and a bite to eat.

I gave a paper on Henry James's The Spoils Of Poynton, about which I recall very little. I do, however, have a clear memory of the genial ferocity of Bill's questions. It was a quality he put to good use in later years, when he became a regular, always entertaining and often illuminating, reviewer of poetry for, among others, the Independent, the London Magazine, and Poetry Review.

By then, he had become a much-respected poet, whose first collection, published by Harry Chambers's Peterloo Poets in 1979, won a Cholmondley Award, and established his reputation for wit, craft, and eager, restless observation. But his career as a poet might never have happened.

Scammell was born into working-class circumstances in Southampton. Having failed the 11-plus, he was marked down as an educational failure and, once out of school, took a succession of menial jobs before becoming a ship's photographer on the Queens, Elizabeth and Mary. There, to quote from his 1987 collection, Eldorado, he found himself "in luxury's hard lap", able to watch and record the goings on of the passengers, of how:

On Fancy Dress Night the bloods went wild then dived back into their sober bickering.

His time abroad began an educational awakening which continued when he worked as a copywriter for the Potato Marketing Board in Covent Garden. Encouraged by his older brother, the Russian scholar and biographer, Michael Scammell, he enrolled as a mature student at Bristol University to read English and philosophy. Then it was into life as a Workers' Education Association tutor, first in the Cotswolds, later in the Lake District, where he moved with his artist wife, Jackie, and their two sons, in the mid-1970s.

Scammell at first wanted to write fiction, "but," he once said to me, "every time I sit down to write a story, the damned thing turns into a poem". After the justly admired and much-praised Yes And No, he decided that poetry was what he had to write, and in rapid succession came A Second Life (1982), Jouissance (1985) and Eldorado (1987), all published by Peterloo, and all marked by Scammell's characteristic sardonic wit, his gift for button-holing lines and vivid descriptions, and his fascination with testing forms - from rhyming couplets through sonnets to that most difficult of all stanzas, Pushkin's tetrasyllabic tightly-rhyming 14-liner, a form he handled with typical panache in Stare At The Moon, from Bleeding Heart Yard. That collection, published in 1992, the same year as The Game Tennis Poems, marked the end of his association with Chambers.

His next volume, Five Easy Pieces, was published in 1993 under the imprint of Sinclair-Stevenson. The emergence of this ambitiously conceived list, at a time when many commercial publishers were choosing to regard poetry as an expendable item, seemed good news. But all too soon it went belly up, and Scammell was left without a publisher. Then, in 1994, the Dublin based Dedalus Press brought out a small collection, Barnacle Bill, Scammell's last major collection. All Set To Fall Off The Edge Of The World was published by Flambard Press two years ago.

The loss of a publisher especially irked him because he had taken early retirement from the WEA to concentrate on literary work. This included editing anthologies and putting together Winter Pollen (1983), a collection of the critical writings of Ted Hughes, whom he much admired and with whom he became friendly, as he did with Derek Mahon, another poet whose work he hugely respected.

It may seem odd that Scammell held these widely different poets in equally high regard, but the uncompromising, northern darkness of the one, and Mahon's formal grace, spoke to an element deep within (as did the poetry of the American Louis Simpson), and helps to explain Scammell's abiding devotion to the poetry of Keith Douglas.

Knowing of this, I pressed him to write a critical monograph on Douglas for the series I was then editing for Faber. Bill was initially reluctant. "I'm not a critic," he said. But he was, and a fine one, too; Keith Douglas: A Study (1988) is worthy of its difficult subject.

In 1991, he had a six-month stint as creative writing tutor at Nottingham Trent University, and helped to initiate what is now a highly successful MA programme. Tennis was a passion, and he was sufficiently good at it to be for a time, captain of his county team. But it is as a poet and independent-minded critic that he deserves to be remembered. Roy Fuller once called him "a true poet", and that seems right.

His first marriage was dissolved in 1996. A year later, Bill married Jan, and they moved to Heathfield Cottage, at Aspatria, Cumbria, where he got stuck into vegetable gardening. Jan survives him, as do his first wife and their two sons.

William Neill Scammell, poet, born January 2 1939; died November 29 2000
