webTitle: Kaduketer - the patch of land where time stands still

fields.headline: The patch of land where time stands still
fields.standfirst: Sixty miles from Jakarta's skyscrapers, the Baduy are finding that the best way to survive is to cling on to tradition
fields.trailText: Sixty miles from Jakarta's skyscrapers, the Baduy are finding that the best way to survive is to cling on to tradition
fields.body:
There was barely a manmade fibre in sight as Mastina climbed 30ft up a sugar palm to collect the watery sap he would later boil up to make into sugar. His ladder was a single bamboo pole with clefts cut into it for his bare hands and feet; his buckets were bamboo tubes with straps made of bark strands.

Old holes in the tree were plugged with leaves to stop the sap running out and going to waste, and the filter to prevent muck getting into the buckets was a mesh of bark and thin strips of wood.

Mr Mastina - most of the Baduy use only one name - makes few concessions to the outside world: his 15-inch metal machete, his cotton shorts, jacket and the sarong wrapped around his head are the only things he carries which are not derived directly from nature.

Welcome to the world of the Baduy, a tribe of animist farmers living less than 60 miles south-west but several light years from central Jakarta's gleaming skyscrapers and political turmoil. The Dutch, Indonesia's former colonisers, named them after a nearby mountain and river.

The Baduy's list of taboos - or customary laws as they prefer to call them - is long enough to frighten off anyone used to modern living. Electricity, plastic, leather, oil, china, books, glass, writing implements, sport, four-legged animals (except for the odd dog and cat), ducks, fertiliser, irrigation, formal government, schools, hospitals, guns, wheels, watches, bricks and cement are just some of the items that are banned.

The foundations, doors and pillars of their homes are made of wood, the walls are a lattice of thin bamboo strips and the roof is layers of dried palm leaves. At least once a year "police" go round checking that people are not breaking the rules and bringing in forbidden objects.

"Our religion says that the rules should be like this," said Sai'idi, a tribal elder in Kaduketer, one of 68 villages in their 20 square mile area. "I learned them from my father, he learnt them from his father and so on going back thousands of years."

Sacred lands

Their religion, the neo-mystical Sunda Wiwitan faith, states that the Sunda people of West Java were the first people on earth and if they do not live as god originally intended disaster will strike. In the heart of the Baduy land there are sacred megaliths and the trees are never felled.

The tribe is divided into two - inner Baduy and outer Baduy. The inner Baduy are more devout, adhering strictly to the rules -although even they have swapped bark loincloths for shirts and shorts - and all but off-limits to foreigners. A little more latitude is shown in the outer villages; here a few people wear sandals and watches while bras, plates, cups, nails and carpentry tools are common. The occasional radio can also be heard.

Life consists of work, food, sleep, religious worship and music played on tuned bamboo instruments and wooden drums.

Work for most people is farming rice, palm sugar, vegetables and fruit. Others oversee sugar-making or weave clothes and bark-fibre bags. Produce is bartered with friends or sold in the outside world in order to buy matches, cooking pots, cotton clothes and coffee.

They have survived as long as they have thanks to a mixture of authoritarianism, pragmatism and playing on Javanese superstitions. "We have three leaders, called puun ," said Mr Sai'idi who is the most senior of the 12 deputy puuns . "One oversees the territory, another is in charge of religion and the third is for defence. No one questions what they say."

When one puun dies, the next is chosen after discussion between the two surviving leaders and their deputies. "God directs us by revealing in visions who should be the next puun ," Mr Sai'idi added.

"It helps that the culture is completely oral," said Rudi Badil, an anthropologist and journalist. "So when a puun says the long should not be shortened and the straight should not be bent, people do not question him."

Acknowledging they are Indonesian - although they never fly the flag - taking on some Islamic customs, such as circumcision, and allowing only Muslims into inner Baduy has helped, he believes.

"The majority of the surrounding people are Muslim so the Baduy have earned respect by respecting them and their ways," he said. "Things would probably be different if the West Javanese were predominantly Christian."

The Baduy were threatened with extinction in the early 80s, during General Suharto's 32-year rule. Government officials wanted to build schools, roads, offices and an electricity network in the area but the people refused.

A group of Baduy walked to Jakarta to appeal to Suharto. A deeply superstitious man, he told them to plant poles along the boundary of their land and everything inside would not be touched. "He said that if Indonesia was a tree then the Baduy were the roots of the tree," Mr Sai'idi said. "If the roots are destroyed then the whole tree would collapse."

Since then the government has never tried to modernise the Baduy, or even forced them to vote in elections. However that does not mean that the tribe is immune from development.

Rising population

A rising population and pressure on land pose the biggest threat to the Baduy's existence. Even though more and more younger Baduy are leaving the tribe, sufficient numbers are remaining to perpetuate growth. Most admit that if their traditional medicines do not work they sneak off to the nearest health centre.

"When the Baduy marked their territory in the 1980s there were about 4,000 of them," Mr Badil said. "Now the tribe is almost double that. The chances are high that something will have to give."

He has no idea when this could happen, though, and is optimistic that the culture will survive for several more decades at least.

"Not only are most of the Baduy committed to their religion, they are opportunists," he said. "They realise that people are willing to pay a lot more for their goods than those of their West Javanese neighbours so many are in no hurry to change.

"It might not be the purest motivation for remaining as they are but it does mean they will not die out that easily."

webTitle: Obituary: Owen Hickey

fields.headline: Owen Hickey
fields.trailText: Owen Hickey, who has died aged 76, was one of the last of the great leader-writers.
fields.body:
Owen Hickey, who has died aged 76, was one of the last of the great leader-writers. The art of elegantly conveying a newspaper's informed stance on a range of issues, from the important to the obscure, is itself dying. Leaders today, even in the most committed broadsheets, rarely alter public opinion or influence government policy. But when Hickey started writing them for the Times in the 1950s, under Sir William Haley's editorship, that newspaper's opinion mattered in the corridors of power.

For 30 years, more than half of them as chief leader-writer, Hickey - his name unknown to the public, which was as he liked it - honed and shaped the Times's policy. Of course, it was the editor who had the final decision, and Hickey was not infrequently out of sympathy with the views of William Rees-Mogg during his spell at the helm. For the most part, however, he subtly managed to accommodate the editor's wishes, while continuing to exert his influence over content.

I spent seven years as a Times leader-writer under Hickey's stimulating regime. He was, though he would never have had the immodesty to think of himself in that way, a mentor and an inspiration to me and other fledgling leader-writers.

It was in the daily leader conference, which determined the paper's agenda, that his intellectual mastery was at its most impressive. He would sit silently while others held court, animatedly promoting this or that viewpoint.

Then, quietly and politely, he would make a comment which cut to the heart of the issue, or hit on a pertinent point we had all missed, or posed the vital question we had failed to see. He had a lucidity of thought that enabled him to spot flaws in arguments, even on subjects he knew relatively little about.

On the surface, he was an austere, shy, self-effacing and slightly remote figure, not - until his latish, happy marriage to Caroline in 1977 - known for his sartorial precision. Any closer acquaintance revealed a man of great humour, charm, wide interests and, surprisingly, sporting prowess; despite the loss of an eye in a bomb blast during wartime service with the Irish Guards (he was born in Kildare), he remained a formidable cricketer into his 40s.

Hickey was educated at Clifton, captained the college at cricket and rugby, and took a first in greats at Magdalen College, Oxford. He joined the Times Educational Supplement in 1949, and moved to the Times as a special writer, and then leader-writer, in 1954.

Much opinion-forming is these days left to columnists, and a newspaper's own views are pushed with more aggression and undisguised one-sidedness than in the past. Hickey's style, and his rigorous intellectual approach, are no longer fashionable; but, in his time, he was supreme.

He is survived by Caroline and two stepsons.

fields.bodyText: Owen Hickey, who has died aged 76, was one of the last of the great leader-writers. The art of elegantly conveying a newspaper's informed stance on a range of issues, from the important to the obscure, is itself dying. Leaders today, even in the most committed broadsheets, rarely alter public opinion or influence government policy. But when Hickey started writing them for the Times in the 1950s, under Sir William Haley's editorship, that newspaper's opinion mattered in the corridors of power. For 30 years, more than half of them as chief leader-writer, Hickey - his name unknown to the public, which was as he liked it - honed and shaped the Times's policy. Of course, it was the editor who had the final decision, and Hickey was not infrequently out of sympathy with the views of William Rees-Mogg during his spell at the helm. For the most part, however, he subtly managed to accommodate the editor's wishes, while continuing to exert his influence over content. I spent seven years as a Times leader-writer under Hickey's stimulating regime. He was, though he would never have had the immodesty to think of himself in that way, a mentor and an inspiration to me and other fledgling leader-writers. It was in the daily leader conference, which determined the paper's agenda, that his intellectual mastery was at its most impressive. He would sit silently while others held court, animatedly promoting this or that viewpoint. Then, quietly and politely, he would make a comment which cut to the heart of the issue, or hit on a pertinent point we had all missed, or posed the vital question we had failed to see. He had a lucidity of thought that enabled him to spot flaws in arguments, even on subjects he knew relatively little about. On the surface, he was an austere, shy, self-effacing and slightly remote figure, not - until his latish, happy marriage to Caroline in 1977 - known for his sartorial precision. Any closer acquaintance revealed a man of great humour, charm, wide interests and, surprisingly, sporting prowess; despite the loss of an eye in a bomb blast during wartime service with the Irish Guards (he was born in Kildare), he remained a formidable cricketer into his 40s. Hickey was educated at Clifton, captained the college at cricket and rugby, and took a first in greats at Magdalen College, Oxford. webTitle: Obituary: Altaf Gauhar

fields.headline: Altaf Gauhar
fields.standfirst: He devoted his journalistic and business skills to helping the world's poor and founded the Guardian's Third World Review
fields.trailText: He devoted his journalistic and business skills to helping the world's poor and founded the Guardian's Third World Review.
fields.body:
Altaf Gauhar, who has died aged 77, was a man of extraordinary versatility, charm and intelligence. At various stages in a multi-faceted life, in his native Pakistan, Britain and elsewhere, he made each of these qualities work for him - in public life, in his journalistic and other writings, in his thinking about Islam, and in his endeavours to do what he could to improve the lot of the world's poorest.

He survived prison terms and clashes at the highest policymaking level in his own country, and he had warned, from first-hand knowledge, that "unless power is treated as a trust, it will degenerate into force". But, in the end, the president of Pakistan, several ministers and other national figures were among those at his funeral in Islamabad.

In the mid-1970s, Gauhar came to London, and with financial and philanthropic support from the Bank of Credit and Commerce International (BCCI), which later went controversially into liquidation, he set about launching a number of initiatives to highlight, mainly through responsible journalism, the problems and challenges confronting developing countries. His aim was to achieve a working partnership with the Guardian, then edited by Peter Preston.

Having newly joined the paper as a foreign ideas person, with a willingness to obtain more coverage for so-called third-world issues, I was deputed to negotiate with Gauhar and his advisers. We met for several beguiling, but convivial, sessions in discreet Mayfair curry houses, eventually clinching a deal. Very soon, with Gauhar and myself as its first co-editors, there were meetings in New Zealand House, where Third World Media (with Altaf as chairman) had its offices, and in March 1978, the Third World Review, consisting of one or more Guardian pages, was on the road.

It ran, initially weekly, for 10 years, with Gauhar featuring prominently. The Brandt Com mission was in the news, so he interviewed Willy Brandt; the Arusha Declaration was in the news, so he interviewed Julius Nyerere, and others, including Nelson Mandela.

Throughout, he was a sort of intellectual impresario, finding time simultaneously to start, from London, an academic journal, Third World Quarterly, a monthly magazine called South, and to launch the Third World Foundation. He also wrote books on political matters, and occasional poetry.

Gauhar was born at Gujranwala, the eldest of five children of a minor official, and studied at Government College, Lahore. Before partition, he was a broadcaster on All India Radio; after it, he was one of Pakistan's first civil servants. He was soon appointed first secretary of the state bank, moving to become a magistrate in East Pakistan (now Bangladesh) and later its deputy home secretary.

At the age of 39, after a series of senior government commercial posts, Gauhar was appointed information secretary for the rightwing president, Ayub Khan, and given unprecedented powers to manage the press, a role comparable in many ways to that of Alastair Campbell to Tony Blair (and attracting much of the same sort of obloquy from the general public). During his tenure, draconian laws governing the press were passed, something for which Gauhar later publicly apologised.

On leaving the civil service in 1969, he became editor of the quality Pakistani news-paper, Dawn, where he was twice imprisoned, latterly when Zulfikar Ali Bhutto was chief martial law administrator. It was while in jail, with no other reading matter, that Gauhar became deeply absorbed by the Koran, from which he was later to make several distinguished translations, the last one shortly before he died, when he was in great pain and undergoing chemotherapy for cancer.

On release from prison, he left Dawn for London. After BCCI went into liquidation, he returned to Pakistan, and more journalism. He poured his energies, his thinking and his skills into the role of editor-in-chief of the Muslim.

Latterly, Gauhar restricted himself to an occasional column, but left the newspaper when its editor, ABS Jaffery, was sacked by the owner. In Pakistan, on his death, he was commemorated as "a very eminent Pakistani", a man who knew power and how it could be used or abused.

He leaves his wife, a son and two daughters.

webTitle: Letters: the late Eric Winter

fields.headline: Letter: Eric Winter
fields.trailText: Roger Protz writes: Folk music aside, in the 1970s and 1980s Eric Winter (Obituary, October 31) helped transform the National Union of Journalists from a craft organisation into a trade union no longer treated with derision by employers and print unions.
fields.body:
Roger Protz writes: Folk music aside, in the 1970s and 1980s Eric Winter (Obituary, October 31) helped transform the National Union of Journalists from a craft organisation into a trade union no longer treated with derision by employers and print unions.

When I first met him, he was father of IPC Magazines Group chapels. Unlike many of his generation, who drew their inspiration from the Communist party, Eric did not dismiss 1970s activists as "infantile leftists" but embraced their enthusiasm.

He was briefly a member of the NUJ national executive, but his major contribution was at branch level, where, as chairman or committee member, he expanded the size and influence of the magazine branch, later magazine & book. It became the force for change in the NUJ, arguing for closed shops to stop freeloaders enjoying the fruits of the union's achievements on pay and conditions.

He was a familar figure at NUJ annual meetings, both on the rostrum and at the ceilidhs he organised with Stan Crowther, later MP for Rotherham. Eric even sweet-talked the comedian Ken Dodd into appearing at a widows and orphans benefit.

Eric left IPC for the London College of Printing journalism course. He did not abandon his beliefs: in 1974, when I was purged as editor of Socialist Worker - and was unemployable in mainstream journalism - he got me regular work on his courses. When LCP students went on strike, Eric was one of the few lecturers to refuse to cross their picket lines.

webTitle: Injured rail user can sue

fields.headline: Injured rail user can sue
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A commuter yesterday described in court how he spent two years trying to get compensation for the back injury he suffered after a ticket inspector put him in a headlock as he rushed for his train.
fields.body:
A commuter yesterday described in court how he spent two years trying to get compensation for the back injury he suffered after a ticket inspector put him in a headlock as he rushed for his train.

Patrick Fennelly, 33, a legal executive from Bromley, south London, won an appeal court ruling allowing him to sue Connex South Eastern for the spinal injury.

The appeal judges heard that Mr Fennelly showed his rail ticket before trying to get on his train at Bromley South station, but that the ticket inspector, Keith Sparrow, demanded a second look at it. When Mr Fennelly refused because he was late for his train the ticket inspector threatened to "punch him in the face".

The ticket was again produced, but on handing it back, Mr Sparrow put Mr Fennelly in a headlock and dragged him down some stairs, saying "I have had enough of this nonsense", the court was told.

Connex South Eastern had won a ruling in Bromley county court in February which said that although Mr Sparrow had lost his temper and assaulted the passenger, the company was not responsible because the ticket inspector was not then involved in carrying out duties for Connex. But the court of appeal reversed the decision, allowing Mr Fennelly to launch a "substantial" damages action for his permanent injuries.

Mr Fennelly said after the hearing: "This has been a terrible time for me since the incident occurred. I am still having treatment for the back injury caused that day. I never believed that such a thing could happen."

Lord Justice Buxton, ruling that Connex was responsible for the actions of its ticket inspector, said Mr Fennelly had been assaulted.

At Bromley county court Judge Cryan had found that Mr Sparrow acted out of anger and that his behaviour had not been in the interests of his employers, who therefore were not responsible.

Lord Justice Buxton said the incident stemmed from the altercation when Mr Sparrow was working as a ticket inspector, although he was not acting as Connex would have wished. "It seems to me that the attack was a reaction to the insult Mr Sparrow thought was inflicted on him while he was carrying out his duty."

Mr Fennelly won the costs of the appeal court and county court actions.

David Ewart, media relations manager for Connex, said: "We are investigating the customer's claim with a view to reaching an amicable settlement."

webTitle: Diego Garcia exiles to seek £4bn from US

fields.headline: Diego Garcia exiles to seek £4bn from US
fields.trailText: Indian Ocean islanders illegally evicted from their homes 30 years ago to make way for an American base at Diego Garcia are to sue the US government for $6bn in compensation.
fields.body:
Indian Ocean islanders illegally evicted from their homes 30 years ago to make way for an American base at Diego Garcia are to sue the US government for $6bn in compensation.

The islanders are to mount the legal challenge after their case in the High Court in London last month, in which they won the right to return home.

Most of the islanders were moved from the Chagos archipelago, which includes Diego Garcia, to Mauritius, where they have failed to integrate and live in poverty.

An end to their exile appeared to be in sight following the case in London but complications have arisen. The US, which leases Diego Garcia from Britain and which strongly opposes the return of the islanders, is throwing up obstacles.

The US has conceded it cannot prevent them returning to neighbouring islands but it will not allow them on Diego Garcia itself. It has also refused to allow the islanders more than a handful of jobs on Diego Garcia and, most important of all, is denying them use of the landing strip.

The cost of building an airstrip on a neighbouring island is estimated at £50m to £100m. Without access to an airfield, life on the islands would be difficult.

Richard Gifford, a lawyer acting on behalf of the islanders, was in Washington last week preparing the legal case. "I think there are considerable problems if the US sits tight in Diego Garcia," he said.

He held initial discussions with Commander Ed Grogan, a lawyer representing the navy section of the US state department.

Mr Gifford said court hearings will expose the discriminatory employment practices: "We want to let it all hang out."

Since the base opened, the US has brought in workers from the Philippines and Mauritius but has never employed any of the exiled islanders.

The Foreign Office is also being sued for compensation. Mr Gifford declined to put a figure on it yesterday, asking what price could be put to taking homes from 6,000 people. "It will run into millions," he said.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, initially tried to block the islanders return but caved in after last month's court setback. His office has accepted that it will have to pay the costs of resettling the islanders, but it will fight any claims for compensation, arguing that it will have done enough if it meets the costs of making the islands habitable again.

Of the 6,000 islanders in line for the £4.1bn compensation being sought, between 400 and 4,000 want to return home. The initial compensation estimate put forward by US lawyers was £1m for each islander.

An initial assessment carried out by the Foreign Office into the feasibility of making some of the islands habitable found that it would be practicable but expensive. A further study into fresh water supplies, projected to take a year, is being carried out.

In a further twist, Mauritius, whose territory once included Diego Garcia, is demanding a restoration of sovereignty.

Madeleine Albright, the US secretary of state, met the island's prime minister, Anerood Jugnauth, on Sunday and said she was now well briefed on the Chagos Islands.

"But I think it's important to understand," she said, "that the legal aspects of this discussion are between the United Kingdom and Mauritius, and not between the United States and Mauritius."

webTitle: Bodies in barrels case grips Australia

fields.headline: Bodies in barrels case grips Australia
fields.standfirst: Four men are alleged to have claimed victims' welfare benefits
fields.trailText: A pathologist giving evidence at the first court hearing on the serial killing which has horrified Australia described yesterday how he examined putrefied body parts found sliced up and stuffed inside six barrels hidden in a disused bank vault.
fields.body:
A pathologist giving evidence at the first court hearing on the serial killing which has horrified Australia described yesterday how he examined putrefied body parts found sliced up and stuffed inside six barrels hidden in a disused bank vault.

Ten bodies were discovered in May 1999, eight in the bank vault in Snowtown, 90 miles north of Adelaide, and two buried in a north Adelaide backyard. All the victims, eight men and two women aged 18 to 47, were friends or relatives of the four men charged with their murders.

Robert Wagner, 29, John Bunting, 34 and Mark Haydon, 42, face 10 counts of murder, while James Vlassakis, 20, faces five murder charges. All four men pleaded not guilty at the commital hearing in Adelaide.

When police first searched the vault, Mr Haydon attributed the stench of the barrels to pickled kangaroos. Pathologist Dr John Gilbert told the court that the putrefied state of the four bodies he examined made identifying the cause of death difficult. The deaths are said to have occurred between December 1995 and May 1999.

Dr Gilbert described how one victim, Troy Youde, whose torso and head were found in one barrel and his legs in another, was killed by strangulation.

He added that the "crude" dismemberment of the victims was likely to have occurred after their death. "There was cutting, quite a bit of cutting. The number of pieces the legs were reduced to showed quite a deal of work in getting flesh off the bones," he said.

Another pathologist described on Monday how several victims were found with skin blackened from electric and fire burns. The court heard how handcuffs, knives, rubber gloves and a machine capable of giving electric shocks were unearthed in the vault alongside the bodies.

The prosecution said the alleged murderers pretended their victims were still alive so that they could claim their welfare benefits, sometimes forging the dead people's sig natures. The victims were forced to repeat phrases on tape before their deaths, so that their voices could be replayed on relatives' answer machines to make it appear as if they were still alive.

The South Australian gov ernment is spending A$6m (£2.5m) on the commital stage of what is likely to be Australia's longest and most expensive murder trial. The commital is likely to last three months, while a full trial could take another year. More than 1,000 witness statements have ben taken and 200 witnesses called to give evidence.

Much of the court's time so far has been spent debating temporary orders suppressing the publication of court evidence in South Australia.

Magistrate David Gurry, who will decide whether to send the accused to trial, called for media restraint in the coverage of the case. Defence lawyers argue that publication of the case's lurid details could prejudice potential jurors and prevent a fair trial.

For Snowtown, the case has brought unwelcome infamy for its population of 500, although some local entrepreneurs made a quick buck selling barrel-shaped fridge magnets with slogans such as "I've been to Snowtown and survived".

webTitle: Horn of Africa rivals sign deal pact

fields.headline: Horn of Africa rivals sign deal pact
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ethiopia
fields.trailText: Ethiopia and Eritrea signed a peace treaty in Algiers yesterday, ending their two-year border war which has claimed 100,000 lives and displaced more than a million people on the Horn of Africa.
fields.body:
Ethiopia and Eritrea signed a peace treaty in Algiers yesterday, ending their two-year border war which has claimed 100,000 lives and displaced more than a million people on the Horn of Africa.

The leaders of both countries agreed that the border, a 620-mile line across largely uninhabited semi-desert, is to be demarcated by an independent commission in accordance with colonial maps. Bar the odd minor adjustment in either direction, this means that the border's location will remain essentially the same as it was before the war.

The Ethiopian prime minister, Meles Zenawi, and the Eritrean president, Isaias Afwerki, former allies against Ethiopia's long-time strongman Mengistu Haile Mariam, shook hands after the signing ceremony.

Afterwards, Mr Zenawi pledged his country's commitment "to the full and scrupulous implementation of the agreement".

"We believe the signing of the peace agreement will lead us to our pre-eminent task which is the struggle against poverty," he said.

webTitle: Whale watchers fear for pod trapped in North Sea

fields.headline: Whale watchers fear for pod trapped in North Sea
fields.trailText: A pod of five sperm whales has been crossing the North Sea for 10 days in search of an escape route. Experts fear that they will be stranded and die.
fields.body:
A pod of five sperm whales has been crossing the North Sea for 10 days in search of an escape route. Experts fear that they will be stranded and die.

The sperm whales, weighing 40 to 50 tonnes, have missed their normal migration route via the west coast of Scotland and Ireland to the Canary Islands and become trapped. Marine biologists say that as a deep water species they would be too afraid of busy shipping lanes and shallow water to head through the Channel and their best hope is to head north to start again.

The whales, all juvenile males, were first seen in shallow water trapped among sandbanks off Zeeland in the Netherlands on December 3. The incoming tide swept them away before they came to harm and the whales were next seen two days later by coastguards off the Isle of Sheppey in the Thames Estuary. Again there was a fear they would be stranded but a combination of high tide and flood water swept them back out to sea.

They were seen again off Zeebrugge and reported at the entrance to the Thames this weekend. Chris Smeenk, the curator of mammals at the National Museum of Natural History in the Netherlands, said: "The last two sightings were not so definite but conform to a pattern we have seen in the past of these whales getting lost on their southern migration and getting in a panic. The sea gets shallower as they head south and they know they should be in deep water. They won't go any further south and presumably looked for a way out heading from coast to coast.

"The best hope is that they should turn north and basically start again at the Shetlands, heading down the west coast, but that is a long way. The sea is rough at the moment so they are difficult to spot but I expect they are out there somewhere in trouble."

The sperm whale is not normally seen in the North Sea because the sea is too shallow but the number of stranded mammals has been increasing. Since 1995 there have been 22 whales found on beaches around Britain.

Only males migrate to the far north of the Norwegian Sea to feed in the summer on deep water squid. They return south to the breeding grounds in semi-tropical waters in the winter. Females seldom go farther north than Ireland.

Dr Smeenk believes that the sperm whales, about 20 to 30 years old, were feeding in the southern Norwegian Sea and took a wrong turning.

"Since the end of whaling numbers of sperm whales have been increasing. As a result it may be that these juveniles just reflect larger numbers or they may have been driven off by other males and got off course."

Amanda Truett, from the Sea Watch Foundation in Oxford, said: "We have alerted everyone to look out for the whales. Anyone who sees them should contact us as soon as possible."

webTitle: £1.5m funding boost for families' disability support service

fields.headline: A problem shared ...
fields.standfirst: £1.5m funding boost for families' disability support service
fields.trailText: £1.5m funding boost for families' disability support service
fields.body:
Parents of disabled children will today be given a boost by an announcement that the government is to provide £1.5m for a national information centre and helpline. The service will be run by Contact A Family (CaF), the only charity who provide support and advice to parents whatever the medical condition of their child.

Families who are given devastating news of a child's disability often complain of feeling isolated at a time when they are most vulnerable. Every day, more than 60 children in the UK are born or diagnosed with a serious disability, and the vast majority are cared for at home. Parents may be told their child has Down's syndrome, is autistic, or suffers from one of the 1,000 rare syndromes and disorders. Yet it is rare that families are given the support they need. The feelings of isolation, both emotional and physical, can often be acute. Helen and Gary Cumberland were devastated on learning from a geneticist that their two-year-old daughter, Alex, was suffering from Coffin Siris syndrome - a genetic disorder so rare that there are only 79 known cases worldwide.

The family was in desperate need of support. Sufferers of the syndrome are distinguished by small stature, mental retardation, pronounced facial features and feeding difficulties. They also have a short life expectancy. But the only information the Cumberlands were given was the address of a website giving details of the condition, and an appointment to see the geneticist again - in two years' time.

Cases like this have prompted ministers to provide extra funding for services. For the first time, there will be a new national telephone advice and helpline, which will include an 0800 number for disabled children, their parents and carers. The national information centre will also be able to provide information on all medical conditions affecting children, as well as putting families in touch with support groups or other families who have experienced a particular disabling condition. It is hoped that the funding, to be phased in over the next three years, will enable the charity annually to provide support to 21,000 families of newly-diagnosed disabled children. Francine Bates, chief executive of CaF, believes the cash will make a huge difference to thousands of families. "All too often, parents are left to stumble on information about their child's condition without knowing what support groups are around or what benefits they are entitled to," she says.

"We have a fantastic database with all the information about the medical conditions and support groups that exist. But, up until now, our resources have been very limited. We know that parents feel very isolated and vulnerable. Many want to talk to someone, as well as get information about their child's condition. They can find it very useful talking to other families who are in a similar situation. Now we should be able to provide that kind of service to everyone."

For the Cumberlands, the pressures of coping alone with Alex, while looking after their two other children and a seriously ill relative, put their marriage under an enormous strain.

"It was only when our marriage started cracking up that we received help. I rang a social worker and she put us in touch with Contact A Family," says Helen.

That was in June last year. Over the next few months, the Cumberlands, who live in Blackburn, Lancashire, made contact with four other families with children suffering Coffin Siris syndrome. "Being able to talk to families in the same situation as yourself really does help," says Helen. "You need it otherwise you really would go to pieces."

Alex is now three-and-a-half. Helen is setting up the Coffin Siris Support Network in the hope that other families will not have to go through her and Gary's experience. Bates says: "Having a dedicated freephone helpline should make a terrific difference. But our work has only just begun".

 Contact A Family is on 020-7383 3555; the Coffin Siris Support Network is on 01254-727101

webTitle: Housing charities warned over competitive behaviour

fields.headline: Housing charities warned over competitive behaviour
fields.trailText: Housing charities must stop competing against each other and colluding in a funding merry-go-round if they are serious about improving the lives of the people they are supposed to be serving, a leading housing expert will tonight warn.
fields.body:
Housing charities must stop competing against each other and colluding in a funding merry-go-round if they are serious about improving the lives of the people they are supposed to be serving, a leading housing expert will tonight warn.

Richard Best, director of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, the social policy research body, will argue: "Too much time and energy has been spent in competitive pursuits when talents could be better used by acting in concert. Housing charities have competed with other charities for donations from the public, competed in winning bids for government funds - they even have had to compete for the ear of a minister."

Mr Best, former director of what is now the National Housing Federation, will be speaking to an invited audience of guests celebrating the 40th anniversary of the Housing Association's Charitable Trust (Hact). He welcomes the achievements of social housing over the past four decades, which have meant that only a tiny proportion of tenants now live in poor conditions and overcrowding, but he will also deliver a less palatable message: that the sector needs to take a hard look at itself.

"Whether it be drug and alcohol abuse, family difficulties that have driven young single people to leave home, racial attacks, bullying or neighbourhood nuisance - the answers lie in social housing landlords cooperating with each other, their residents and other agencies," Mr Best said. "We own the properties, we have the money. But we can't work alone and make decisions at a distance from the very people experiencing the problems."

While Mr Best welcomes much in the government's housing green paper, from fostering mixed communities to stimulating resident involvement, he is calling on housing charities to join with other agencies to challenge government where policies are clearly failing.

"Housing charities with older residents need to risk the wrath of government in pointing out that very substantial increases in public funding will be needed to meet the care needs of poorer elderly people in the next 40 years," Mr Best said. "There's a lot of sweeping under the carpet as elderly people don't count for very much in terms of votes and they don't make a fuss."

Hact, which distributes £1m a year to voluntary organisations working on housing-related projects, is using its 40th birthday to review and re-focus its role. But it is determined to retain its community remit. "Supporting partnerships and networks is the way forward," says Heather Petch, Hact's director. "But it is vital that small organisations are not swallowed up as they reflect diversity and encourage the active involvement of people in need of, and using, the services."

webTitle: Hospital assessments not all bad

fields.headline: Hospital assessments not all bad
fields.standfirst: Judging by the first three CHI reports, hospital care has undoubted room for improvement but is not at all the insensitive, broken down service of media caricature, writes David Brindle
fields.trailText: Judging by the first three CHI reports, hospital care has undoubted room for improvement but is not at all the insensitive, broken down service of media caricature, writes David Brindle.
fields.body:
Now that the NHS "winter crisis" seems a self-fulfilling prophecy, hospital workers must feel as if trapped in the headlights of a speeding train. But today at least they can set aside the apocalyptic predictions and the tabloid talk of "third world wards", and focus on the first of what will be the most comprehensive assessments of the quality of the nation's health care.

The findings are not at all bad. Judging by these first three reports, hospital care has undoubted room for improvement but it is not at all the outdated, insensitive and broken down service of media caricature.

The City Hospitals Sunderland trust is judged to have a "range of systems to support a high standard of patient care" and a "strong performance culture". The Chesterfield and North Derbyshire Royal trust is said to have "built a good foundation" and to have "a number of strengths". And the Southampton University Hospitals trust is found to be "making good progress", with an ambitious programme to reshape services across health and social care boundaries.

But the reviews have also highlighted clear failings. Although Sunderland emerges the best of the three, there are doubts about its "prevailing style"; Chesterfield is told to give priority to explaining and reducing its "significantly higher than average" death rates; and Southampton, which plainly has the most to do, is reprimanded for its inability to assure acceptable care standards on some wards.

"At the time of the review," said the Commission for Health Improvement (CHI) report on Southampton, "CHI had serious concerns about the quality of care given to trauma and orthopaedic patients. Management of clinical staff on the wards was deficient, junior doctors lacked direction and supervision from consultants and nurses were under constant pressure."

Over the next four years, the commission is to assess the "clinical governance" of every NHS body in England and Wales. This is the core of the role of the new health watchdog, which also has a lesser brief to be sent into trusts in difficulties to troubleshoot. Because its first published reports last month fell under the latter heading - on past abuse of patients at the North Lakeland Healthcare trust and the death of a patient after a blunder at the Carmarthenshire trust - the commission is likely to be saddled for some time with a "hit squad" image.

As Dame Deirdre Hine, who chairs the commission, recently said: "Very early on - far too early for our own comfort - we were asked to take on two investigations."

The trusts in today's reports were chosen at random, according to the commission, and were subject to a 24-week review process, including a visit by a team of NHS staff and others. The team which went to Southampton comprised a trust chief executive, a general manager, a nurse director, a manager of cancer services, a consultant radiologist, a consultant anaesthetist and, as lay member, a management consultant in health and social care. Lay members of the other two teams were a teacher and a social worker.

The teams observed the practices at close hand. The Chesterfield report says: "Our observations at night revealed a significant amount of controllable noise. For example, CHI heard telephones with loud rings, frequently used doors that bang shut and members of staff with noisy shoes."

Patients and carers were also asked about their experiences. Standards of food and cleanliness were common complaints, but the overriding grievance was waiting times.

One Southampton patient said: "I attended clinic, sat and waited one-and-a-half hours only to be told this clinic was now being cancelled, with no explanation why." At Chesterfield, a patient who had been waiting to see a nurse said: "One hour went by; still I hadn't seen her. Eventually I asked a member of staff I'd noticed chatting to other nurses - and it was her!"

Far more positively, another Chesterfield patient wrote: "I was very surprised at being admitted to hospital at 6pm. Immediate treatment as soon as I arrived. The doctors and nurses were sympathetic and reassuring. A meal was provided, even at 8pm at night."

Prior to publication of today's reports, the trusts have had an opportunity to address criticisms. At Southampton, "immediate action" is said to have been taken in the trauma and orthopaedic areas, including appointment of a senior clinical nurse to improve leadership. At Chesterfield, a decision has been taken to recruit a statistician to help discover the reasons for the trust's high mortality rates.

Chesterfield's action plan comprises 28 points; Southampton's runs to 32 pages. All the action plans, like the review reports themselves, will be available to the public. As Avril Johns, Chesterfield's chief executive, said: "The developments in the plan show we are committed to better clinical services and high standards of care."

All three trusts reported satisfaction with the review process. Ms Johns described it as "valuable and challenging"; Peter Campion, head of public relations at Southampton, said of its report: "It's fair, it's balanced, in terms of showing a busy organisation that has achieved a lot but obviously has more to do."

At Sunderland, Carol Harries, director of corporate affairs, echoed the other trusts in saying that CHI has come up with "no surprises". But she added: "While we have numerous outside bodies coming in, like the [medical] royal colleges and district audit, we have never before had any single body looking at a whole range of things across the trust. That's the value."

But the trusts are braced for some selective representations. "We are a £130m trust and had an audit report exemplary in terms of financial procedures, but it mentioned a £167 catering fiddle," Ms Harries recalled. "People outside picked it up as 'major fraud at local hospital'."

 The reports on the Sunderland, Chesterfield and Southampton trusts will today be posted on the CHI website at or are available free on 020-7448 9200

webTitle: How being an 'appropriate adult' opens up the world of youth crime

fields.headline: Lessons for life
fields.standfirst: Karen Liebreich on how being an 'appropriate adult' opened her  eyes to the causes of youth crime
fields.trailText: Karen Liebreich on how being an 'appropriate adult' opened her eyes to the causes of youth crime
fields.body:
When a young person is arrested, their parent or guardian is called. If they cannot or will not come to the police station, an "appropriate adult" must be called. For the past year, I have been acting as an appropriate adult in Hounslow, west London, where recent research showed that a huge proportion of crime is carried out by children on other children - a finding tragically underlined by the murder of Damilola Taylor.

Almost by definition, appropriate adults get called out to the "worst" cases - youngsters no longer living with their parents, or those whose parents cannot be bothered to come to the station (yet again).

It's been an eye-opener. Until I started this voluntary job, my only contact with the police had probably been similar to those of any other white, middle-class woman. I've been to report a stolen bike; I slow down when I see a police car on the school run. Now I see an outsider's view of inside. I am on nodding terms with local police officers; I walk into police stations in the middle of the night; I am offered rides home in squad cars.

Making a quick analysis of my statistically insignificant number of call-outs, they have been 50% female, and almost equally split between white and black with only one Asian. Only two of the many kids I have dealt with has had a father living at home. The most common crime was shoplifting, with more serious car theft a worrying second.

The most pathetic case was that of a recently-arrived Somali boy, whose gloves were taken at school and who stole a new pair from a department store because his hands were cold. He lived with his aunt, who had gone away for the day to a wedding. As he walked away after hours of being locked up and interrogated, returning in the dark to their undoubtedly depressing hostel, I wondered about our immigration laws. On the one hand, we had let him in, housed him and offered him free education. On the other hand, he had 5p in his pocket, was far from home, attending a tough school, with no hope of becoming a doctor as he dreamed.

At least with recent immigrants, we can appreciate that there are deep roots to the fault; the effects of war in the African sub-continent, for example, are too great to expect local solutions. But for most of the youngsters I came into contact with, I could only blame their parenting. A string of mothers told me they couldn't cope; it was the child's own problem; or just hung up the phone once they knew the police were trying to get hold of them and then refused to answer again. One stepfather said it was nothing to do with him.

One of the boys had so many siblings he could not even remember his half-sister's name without a struggle (though he thought he recognised her voice from the cell next door). Several were either "special needs", just about able to write their names (though not read the charges), or had simply been in school so rarely they had had little chance to learn anything. Some were violent - one had just been excluded from school, not for the first time, for hitting a girl on the head with a rolling pin. Another was out on bail for an alleged axe attack. One even punched his solicitor in the face just as I arrived.

One 15-year-old girl was in a children's home where she had been placed after her mother's drunkenness became too problematic. She had a record of violence, having attacked somebody on a bus, and was angry and disturbed. The social worker told me she had been absent for 130 nights since her admission to the home 10 months earlier. More than one in three! What kind of a "home" was that? Where was she the other nights?

Some had a redeeming interest - if only society could be bothered to get them interested in their one gleam of hope, be it running fast or car mechanics. Several others, though, seemed hopeless.

For a large proportion of these kids I have felt hugely depressed, both for them as people and for society. One 16-year-old, whose mother had chucked him out for trying to burn down the house, was arrested for failure to show for bail, stealing another car, driving without insurance and shoplifting. Social services had lodged him in a hotel in the local high street. The police clearly knew him well - every one of the officers greeted him by name. After being charged and bailed for a few days, he asked me for a lift back to his hotel. I refused, but I doubt he went straight back to his dull and solitary room.

I have sat for hours by the cells, waiting for solicitors to arrive, and seen the police deal with abuse, drunkenness and colossal amounts of paperwork. To my surprise I have seen only one tiny flicker of racism, though I have looked hard. I have seen a curious complicity, almost an understanding, between some of the regular offenders and the police. Perhaps it is just that they meet so often.

The youngsters I have dealt with were mostly aged 14 to 17. Soon, some of the girls will be pregnant and produce their own children, while many (or most) of the boys will carry on wending their way to prison. Early intervention and help seems essential. Cost is not the question - each trivial shoplifting case costs a fortune in police time, legal fees, social worker fees and court costs, let alone the costs to society and the victims of crime themselves.

What should be done? Scrap regular education: these children are never going to read Shakespeare or speak French. Try to find a vocational spark to build on and provide some hope of a better life, some chance of progress. If a girl is interested in nail varnish, apprentice her to a manicurist and let her acquire some useful skill and hope for a future.

Try also to break the vicious circle and ensure that these kids' own kids are not regulars at the police station in a few years' time. Maybe this means obligatory attendance at mother and baby sessions, where they can see what is meant by the real parenting they never experienced themselves. If receipt of benefits must be tied to attendance, then so be it. There seems to me to be no other way of breaking, or at least trying to stretch, the loop which will bring the next generation in turn into the police station.

If you would like information about serving as an appropriate adult, contact your local youth justice team through your local authority.

webTitle: Poverty continues to thrive

fields.headline: Poverty continues to thrive
fields.standfirst: Poverty continues to thrive as the New Policy Institute's excellent poverty audit, published on Monday, grimly reminded everybody
fields.trailText: Comment: Poverty continues to thrive as the New Policy Institute's excellent poverty audit, published on Monday, grimly reminded everybody, writes Malcolm Dean
fields.body:
Poverty continues to thrive as the New Policy Institute's excellent poverty audit, published on Monday, grimly reminded everybody. Two decades of brutal, regressive Tory policies, which tripled the numbers living below the poverty line, cannot be wiped out in one parliamentary term. Sensibly, ministers have set themselves a 20-year goal of eliminating child poverty - with an intermediary target of a 50% reduction within 10 years. Even this is a steep challenge.

Would a ministry of poverty help? Recently, the Guardian suggested that the prime minister was considering replacing the present social exclusion unit (SEU) with a new department for social inclusion to spearhead an anti-poverty drive in the most deprived areas. The expanded department would carve out responsibility for crucial poverty issues - from John Prescott's DETR, inner city regeneration and 1,370 run-down estates suffering multiple problems, plus possibly 18,000 excluded pupils.

Certainly large numbers of poor people live on run-down estates. Indeed, two-thirds of heads of households in all council and housing association homes do not have a job, and 75% have incomes of less than £200. But the proposal does not make sense. If you want a poverty ministry, you do not start with the DETR. You have to begin with social security, add in employment and the New Deal, and take in tax. Cynics might even call it the department of paid work. The naive might believe that Whitehall departments would welcome losing their most difficult clients - but history shows they fight for every last part of their empires.

The impetus for the change was said to be a review of the SEU, published a year ago, which concluded that the unit's work "has been, on the whole, less enthusiastically received inside government than outside". Far from being a criticism, this should have been seen as an accolade. It is the job of Cabinet Office units to be unpopular with insiders. In the words of Lord Rothschild, boss of the former think tank, their role is to produce the grit which creates the oyster.

Abolishing the SEU would be a huge setback for the poor. Moira Wallace, the director, was an ideal choice with her former posts at the Treasury and Downing Street. It has far more influence as a Cabinet Office unit with close ties to the PM, than it would have as a separate department - it would be quickly marginalised by Whitehall's big bruisers and turned into a minor irritant.

Tony Blair should read his history. Harold Wilson carved two new departments - land and economic affairs - out of existing departments. Both failed miserably.

webTitle: Ex-miner helps to breathe new life into a dying community

fields.headline: Ex-miner helps to breathe new life into a dying community
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot meets the ex-miner who's become a lynchpin in his community
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot meets the ex-miner who's become a lynchpin in his community
fields.body:
We're driving slowly down a pot-holed street in Grimethorpe, past terraced houses ready for demolition. Roofbeams are visible through great holes in the tiles. Bulldozers are hovering, ready to execute the final coup de grace on Old King Coal. Generations of miners lived in these terraces. Today, contractors are consulting plans and shouting orders. Private homes are to be built here and, nearby, new light industrial units offering new hope to new generations from the surrounding estates.

Suddenly our ears are assailed by the whine as three motorbikes flash past, careering across the adjoining wasteland. The youths astride them could be bunking off school or old enough to be at work. It's difficult to tell at the speed they're going.

Danny Gillespie shakes his head and mutters: "I know who they are." And they would almost certainly know him if they had paused long enough to glance through the car window. Everybody in Grimethorpe (population 4,200) seems to know Mr Gillespie. He is founder of the neighbourhood watch association, a big man who's made a big impression on criminal activity in a part of South Yorkshire that was rapidly being dubbed Crimethorpe.

The joy-riding incident is an indication that there is still some way to go. But then Mr Gillespie is not a miracle worker. He's a decent, former miner of 57 who stood up to be counted on behalf of a community he cares for, built around a coal mine that gave him a living for over 35 years. When it closed in 1993, the grime went out of Grimethorpe. But the name stuck.

Everybody had heard of the place because it had a world-famous brass band. And as for that name - well, it simply helped to keep alive southern prejudices about the landscape of northern England being all belching chimneys and slagheaps. It gave way to that predictable tale of despair and drug-taking among disillusioned local youth and a consequent sharp rise in vandalism and robbery. End of story.

Well, not quite. The latest figures show a very significant reduction in crime in Grimethorpe. Burglaries are down by 23% and car crime by 43%. Judges in the Norwich Union Neighbourhood Watch Awards were impressed enough to give Grimethorpe first prize in the urban section. Next Monday, Mr Gillespie and his association's secretary, Elsie Smith, will be in Brussels to represent the UK in the European crime prevention awards.

Whether they win or not, there will be no let-up in their drive to make their village a better and safer place. They can't turn back the clock to the days when Mrs Smith's husband, Bryan, was solo horn player in a Grimethorpe Colliery band full of colliers. They can never recapture the community spirit forged by men working together in harsh, dangerous conditions. But they can continue the steady crawl away from the mid-90s depths of low morale.

"The streets were looking mucky, yobs were strutting around being very verbal, and there were no end of break-ins," Mr Gillespie recalls. "I was talking to a mate of mine and we decided that we'd both had enough. So we went down to the Acorn Centre, home of the Grimethorpe Regeneration Executive, and asked about starting a neighbourhood watch scheme. While we were there, a lady tapped me on the shoulder and introduced herself as the local crime prevention officer. That was it. She put us on the right road."

But she was careful not to be seen leading the way. Police uniforms are not universally respected, even among law-abiding folk in South Yorkshire pit villages, where they have keen memories of what happened during the 1984-85 miners' strike."Anyway," says Mr Gillespie, "it was the Metropolitan police who gave us some hammer during the strike, not the local bobbies." Indeed, the local bobbies have since donated more than £25,000 for two youth workers.

All the same, Mr Gillespie knew he would be a target for the "wrong 'uns" who would see him as a "grass" when he went round knocking on doors to generate support for his scheme. He expected trouble and, sure enough, it found him. "That place on the corner used to be full of druggies," he says, pointing through the front window of the house which he and his wife, Kathleen, bought from the coal board for £2,800 in 1983. "But I only had problems with one of them. He spread nails all over my drive one Friday when I was out at a disco I run for the kiddies. I knew there was something wrong as soon as I pulled in."

The morning light revealed 38 shining heads embedded in his tyres. When he returned from the garage, there were 10 young men eyeballing him from the wall across the street. He stood and faced them down. Mr Gillespie has suffered back injuries and a heart attack in his hardworking life, but he's not a man to be intimidated.

Nor is he a man whose idea of neighbourhood watch is simply sitting behind a lace curtain and dialling the police at regular intervals. His association has become adept at raising funds and ploughing the proceeds back into the community.

Security lights have been provided for every elderly resident. A rat-infested piece of wasteland has been transformed into a safe, security-lit parking area and a Portakabin houses a mothers-and-toddlers group in the mornings and a youth club four evenings a week.

It's run, voluntarily, by another former miner, Roy Mills, who says that more than 50 youngsters have passed their Duke of Edinburgh Award.

Mr Mills and Mr Gillespie used to take their families on camping trips in the days when they earned a good living underground. Perhaps it's hardly surprising that they look back fondly. "I went to prize-giving day at my grand-daughter's school the other day and dropped on and old mate from the pit," Mr Gillespie reveals. "We started reminiscing and I don't mind admitting we cried over what we'd lost."

Still, he's realistic enough to understand that the future for his grandchildren depends on the new building, which continues apace on the site of the old colliery. Old King Coal is dead and buried, its waste products moulded into the grassed-over hills which flank the new Dearne Valley link road - a ribbon of black Tarmac beckoning the 21st century into Grimethorpe.

European threat to new jobs

The sites on and around former collieries at Grimethorpe and nearby Houghton Main now make up one-third of the potential development land set aside by Barnsley metropolitan borough council. Since the 1997 general election, the council has been working with a government-backed regional development agency called Yorkshire Forward. Money has also come from the European Union.

But the possibility of attracting big employers to the area is under threat from a ruling by the European Commission that direct grant subsidies breach state-aid rules on fair competition. The subsidies had been used as an insurance to reassure private sector investors that they won't lose money on buildings.

"The ruling could have a fundamental impact on areas like this where land values are low," says Ben Morley, of the Grimethorpe Regeneration Executive. "It may be that the public sector will have to take the lead by building units and renting them out."

webTitle: Single mother raises awareness of plight

fields.headline: Single mother raises awareness of plight
fields.standfirst: Single mother Karen Chazen's dual role, as a Sure Start programme coordinator and an executive member of the National Council for One Parent Families, means she is tackling child poverty and single parent issues head on, reports Deborah Mulhearn
fields.trailText: Single mother Karen Chazen's dual role, as a Sure Start programme coordinator and an executive member of the National Council for One Parent Families, means she is tackling child poverty and single parent issues head on, reports Deborah Mulhearn
fields.body:
Karen Chazen is on a high after attending the annual meeting of the National Council for One Parent Families. It takes a moment to sink in that the "Jo" she has been chatting to is Harry Potter author JK Rowling, who addressed the event. And Chancellor Gordon Brown mentioned her by name in his speech, thanking her for her work on Merseyside, where she is a Sure Start programme coordinator.

"He came over afterwards and asked me how I was, how my son was and how Sure Start was doing," said Ms Chazen. She was laughing, but obviously delighted. "It's nice to be acknowledged, but it doesn't really matter whether it's Gordon Brown or Anne Brown, as long as I can raise the profile of the project." And then she laughed again at the incongruity of it all and how everything has snowballed from the inauspicious start of an unplanned pregnancy seven years ago.

Her dual role, as a Sure Start programme coordinator in Liverpool and an executive member of the national council's board, means she is tackling child poverty and single parent issues head on. Ms Chazen, 31, realises she has become something of a figurehead, and feels slightly in awe of the responsibility that brings. Back in April, she spoke at 11 Downing Street at the launch of the lone parents' helpline - again attended by Mr Brown, who later spoke of how moved and inspired he had been by her story of struggle as a single parent to achieve her career ambitions.

But she is quick to point out that her experiences are no different from the isolation, anxiety and - more often than not - poverty of millions of other single parents. "I see myself as a representative, really, and it's great to have the opportunity to give lone parents a voice," she said. "We've had a tremendous year as a charity, with Jo Rowling coming on board and a chancellor who is committed to the eradication of child poverty, just as we are committed to eradicating lone parent poverty."

Ms Chazen was born in Liverpool and spent five years working for an insurance company after leaving school because she was, by her own admission, aimless. She then decided to study childcare and it was in the middle of the course that she got pregnant. She had her son, Zak, in October 1993 and qualified in January 1994, breastfeeding him in lectures because she was so determined to finish the course.

When her relationship foundered, she started on the relentless round of juggling work and childcare. "I just did it, as others do it," she recalled. "I look back and wonder if I should have done it differently, but I know it was right for me, and I look at Zak now and know it was right for him. I think I said this in Downing Street - that with ambition comes guilt, but at the back of my mind was always that Zak deserves this."

She has had good family support, she said, and had an early break with a free nursery place. "I was lucky that when I accessed the nursery it was just before they changed the entry criteria," she said. "I know how hard it is to get a place. Good childcare is equivalent to a good relationship - you need to know it's there and reliable."

Ms Chazen had a variety of jobs before becoming manager of the creche at Liverpool One Parent Families Trust. She may be an inspiration to Brown, she said, but there she met many lone parents, including fathers, who inspired her. "You can't stereotype single parents," she insisted. "Only a very low percentage are teenage girls. Of course my own experience has informed my work, and it's all about challenging perceptions." She spent a year as chief executive of the trust, and from there it was a natural progression to the national council.

Her day job at Sure Start counterpoints her national role. She clearly believes that the project can unlock the potential in areas like Speke, where she is based. Speke, a pre-1939 housing estate at the southernmost end of Liverpool, is an isolated community, landlocked by industrial estates and cut off from the city centre.

"We're talking second and third generation unemployment here," said Ms Chazen. Children in the area grow up without expectation of work and, perhaps even more damning, without anger about it. She said: "There's no: 'I want to be an astronaut when I grow up.' And if we want to break that cycle of deprivation, we have to start with young children. In fact, it goes even further back to babies and antenatal care.

"People tend to stay within the area, and if we want them to access the services Sure Start is offering then we have to provide everything here. We're only in our infancy, but I'm committed to making it work because I believe it can. It's a unique opportunity to break down the barriers and for the community to play a pivotal role."

Ms Chazen works closely with health visitors, and one of the many issues that have come out of the Sure Start consultation process is the need for people to access the services when they need to - not at the practitioner's convenience. "As a single parent I know what it's like when you've only had a couple of hours sleep and your baby won't stop crying and you haven't talked to anybody for 18 hours," she said. "It's when you are at your most vulnerable and you need to see someone straight away, not: 'Can you make an appointment, can you come back at 5 o'clock?'"

She remains hopeful about the government's aims of getting 70% of lone parents into work by the end of the decade and ending the catch 22 of the benefit trap. "It's OK to give us a hand up, and the working families tax credit is making a big difference, but we want to go further," she said. "It's not enough to just manage; single parents want a better quality of life."

She has no plans to leave Liverpool. She loves her job, loves the city - "there's just something about the place" - and her son is settled and happy. But the suspicion lingers that bigger things beckon. A friend jokingly called her the lone parent tsar. "The funny thing is," she said, "Chazen is a Russian name."

 The lone parents' helpline is 0800-018 5026.

webTitle: Globalisation needs stricter controls

fields.headline: Globalisation needs stricter controls
fields.standfirst: If rich countries continue to use the WTO for their own interests, poor countries, public health and the environment will continue to suffer, writes Oxfam's Kevin Watkins
fields.trailText: If rich countries continue to use the WTO to their own interests, poor countries, public health and the environment will continue to suffer, writes Oxfam's Kevin Watkins.
fields.body:
The wreckers have been at it again. Over the year, since the collapse of world trade talks in Seattle, dedicated and well-organised groups have been ruthlessly chipping away at the remnants of the World Trade Organisation's (WTO) credibility. Without firm action, there is now a real danger that they will cause the rules-based trading system to collapse, destroying efforts to reduce poverty and global inequality.

The wreckers are not from the ever broadening anti-WTO and globalisation protest movement. The wreckers in question are the governments of the world's richest countries who continue to use their power to subordinate the WTO to their own national interests and to the pursuit of corporate profit, regardless of the cost to poor countries, public health and the environment.

Media attention in Seattle, Prague and, to some extent, in Nice focused on the street protests and the activities of a few balaclava-clad "globaphobes" with a disdain for McDonald's windows. But the real battle over the past year has been taking place off camera, where developing countries are still challenging the northern government's abuse of the WTO system.

The charge sheet is impressive and is only partly answered by Clare Short's white paper on globalisation, which was unveiled this week. While poor countries have liberalised their markets, rich countries have remained resolutely protectionist, especially in areas like textiles and agriculture. The authority of the WTO, which drives globalisation, has actually been extended into new areas, such as intellectual property rights. Whatever Ms Short says, the negotiating process has continued to be profoundly undemocratic, with big countries stitching up deals in secret negotiations.

It was the failure of the US and the European Union (EU) to address these concerns that produced the real debacle in Seattle.

Last week, European commissioner Pascal Lamy said he thought the time had come for the EU to consider reformulating its position on world trade negotiations if a new round of multilateral negotiations is to be launched. There was still no mention of the reforms that Britain and other countries had said were vital to make the WTO more democratic and accountable.

So the charade goes on. Take the issue of protectionism. It's not mentioned in Ms Short's white paper, but each year, developing countries lose around $700bn (£484bn) as a result of trade barriers in rich countries. Stated differently, for every $1 provided by the rich countries in the form of aid and debt relief, poor countries lose another $14 because of trade barriers. Reducing these barriers would help to create jobs and take millions of people out of poverty.

Unfortunately, the post-Seattle record is abysmal. The industrialised countries promised they would provide the 48 least developed countries, which collectively account for 12% of the world's population but only 0.5% of trade, with improved market access. One year on from Seattle, they have done nothing.

Today, poor countries exporting to the industrialised world face tariffs four times as high as those facing rich countries. True, industrialised countries have promised to withdraw restrictions on imports of textiles, the Third World's biggest manufactured export. But so far less than 10% of the restrictions have been lifted, and the pace of liberalisation has slowed.

Nowhere are the double standards as deeply ingrained as in agriculture. US trade negotiators wax lyrical about the virtues of "level playing fields" in farm products. Yet the industrialised countries collectively spend over $240bn subsidising environmentally destructive intensive agriculture, and the "free trading" US has increased farm subsidies over the past year.

For the millions of smallholder farmers in developing countries, these subsidies are a disaster. It is not just that they result in poor countries losing export markets. Rural livelihoods are also being destroyed on a massive scale because poor farmers in Africa, Asia and Latin America cannot compete against subsidised imports. The resulting loss of food self-sufficiency is good news for the giant corporate grain exporters, who dictate US trade policy, but bad news for poverty.

Since Seattle, countries such India, Kenya and the Dominican Republic have been demanding a WTO food security clause that would allow them to restrict imports in the interests of achieving food self-sufficiency. But the US has systematically blocked the proposal, claiming that it would distort world markets. In reality, the WTO is being used to ensure that US commercial interests supersede basic human rights.

The same principle applies to WTO rules on patents. These rules are the product of a concerted lobbying campaign led by giant pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies. Shorn of their mind-numbing legalistic complexity, they have extended the duration and scope of patent protection, and backed corporate claims with the threat of WTO-sponsored trade sanctions.

One consequence of the WTO regime is that countries with strong generic drugs industries - such as India, Thailand and Egypt - will no longer be permitted to produce low-cost copies of patented drugs for low-income populations. These industries are able to produce drugs for the treatment of HIV and Aids at less than one-twentieth of market price of patented equivalents, providing a lifeline for millions of sufferers.

Over the past year, India and Egypt have asked for more time to find ways of adapting to the new regime. The American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association has demanded US trade sanctions against both countries, and the US Trade Representatives Office has obligingly placed them on notice.

Various polite formulations can be found to describe what is happening on drugs and patenting. But at a time when public health in poor countries is threatened by new diseases and drug-resistant variants of old killers like diarrhoea, measles and pneumonia, the truth is relatively simple. WTO rules dictated by powerful corporations and enforced by northern governments will deprive millions of poor people access to vital drugs, causing premature death and suffering on a massive scale.

Against this background, it is not hard to see why calls for much firmer and fairer management of globalisation and the abolition of the WTO are growing. But abolitionism is a counsel of despair. It offers nothing more than a power vacuum in which the powerful can use their economic muscle to bully the powerless into submission. We desperately need a rules-based system of global governance that places people before corporate profit, and shares the benefits of globalisation more equitably. And we need to get the wreckers under control.
