webTitle: Class still biggest killer

fields.headline: Class still biggest killer
fields.trailText: Reduction in child poverty is the key to health equality, writes John Carvel
fields.body:
A grim reminder that children are dying in Britain as a direct result of poverty will come tomorrow from charity Barnardo's. Earlier this week, other research suggested that the Labour government's progress in reducing inequality had been painfully slow.

The Barnardo's study, on health inequalities, will say that children from the lowest social class are twice as likely to die by age 15 as are children from the highest class. The former are nine times more likely to die in a house fire and are disproportionately exposed to risk of fatal accidents - the main childhood killer.

The study, by Helen Roberts, the charity's head of research, will maintain that the only long-term answer is a direct attack on inequalities of income and wealth. The cost of eliminating child poverty would be 0.48% of GNP.

"Projects dealing with the effects of poverty ... are an Elastoplast on a gaping wound," said Ms Roberts. Although such schemes could be beneficial, especially if the people running them paid more attention to research showing what works, a focus on them could be used "to avoid having to confront the reality" that child poverty can be reduced by political and economic action.

"Inequalities in health can only be fundamentally tackled by policies that reduce poverty and income inequality," said Ms Roberts. "That means poor people getting more money."

A separate report on Monday analysed 50 poverty indicators and found that nine deteriorated last year, while 17 improved. The report, published by social research body the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, said the number of adults in homes where disposable income was less than 40% of the national average had increased 500,000 since the election. But that was based on 1998 data - before introduction of the minimum wage and working families tax credit.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, has promised to lift 1m children out of poverty by the next general election and a second million during a second Labour term. Yet that would still leave 2m children living in poverty in 2005.

The Barnardo's report will provide some positive ideas about what can be done pending achievement of the government's objective to eradicate child poverty by 2020. "The biggest differences to child health," it will say, "will not be made by the NHS, but by changes in other sectors [including] education, housing and public policy."

Environmental improvements are likely to be more effective than pamphlets and safety education in reducing accidents. Roberts said: "Treating children and parents as defective in child safety matters is as ineffective as treating airline passengers as defective in air safety."

As an example of an effective scheme, Barnardo's cites the charity's Tullycarnet project in a deprived part of Belfast. By improving the subway between a housing estate and its local primary school, children were encouraged to avoid crossing dangerous roads. This produced better results than road safety training.

Other effective initiatives have included: pre-school provision by well-trained staff, bearing in mind that poor day care may do more harm than good; and community cafes and promotion of cheap food in the community, bringing more promising results in improvement of nutrition than those achieved by "didactic" nutrition education.

 What Works in Reducing Inequalities in Child Health is available at £12 on 01268-520224.

webTitle: Getting Britain giving

fields.headline: Getting Britain giving
fields.standfirst: In a climate where people are now less inclined to give to charity it is vital that the voluntary sector work closely with the government, writes NCVO chief executive Stuart Etherington
fields.trailText: In a climate where people are now less inclined to give to charity it is vital that the voluntary sector work closely with the government, writes NCVO chief executive Stuart Etherington.
fields.body:
At this traditional time of goodwill and charity it might be worth considering some of the worrying research findings published over the past year.

The public are giving less to charity than they were 10 years ago and, despite an overall growth of the sector, many charities, particularly those falling into a middle income bracket, have experienced a real decline in their incomes.

There are almost certainly a multitude of reasons for this trend. Perhaps the most controversial one given is an apparent increase in the lack of trust and community spirit displayed by the British public. However, even if the reasons are blurred, the solution is clear. The voluntary sector must work with government to encourage a better environment within which charities can operate effectively and giving can be encouraged. The good news is that this is already happening.

Next spring sees the launch of the Giving Campaign. It is the brainchild of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) and the Charities Aid Foundation (CAF), and has the principle aim of focusing attention on the opportunities for increased giving presented by the new tax incentives the chancellor announced earlier this year. These include the abolition of the £250 minimum for donations through gift aid, which allows the charity to claim back the tax on your gift, and the abolition of the £1,200-a-year limit on payroll giving. There will also be tax relief on gifts, shares and securities and an extension of the tax exemption for fundraising events.

Last month saw Treasury Minister Stephen Timms grant £1m of government money toward the campaign. This represents a significant commitment from the government, who also plan to second staff to the campaign team. By the new year the Giving Campaign team expect to have raised an additional half a million for the launch. Generous donations have already been received from across the sector. With ongoing funding, the campaign should run for a total of three years and aims to achieve a £1bn increase in income to the voluntary sector.

However, for many in the sector it appears that the government is giving with one hand and taking with the other. While they donate money to our national campaigns they are still refusing to budge on a VAT rebate for charities. It is estimated that this costs the sector £400m a year.

Nonetheless, the government has taken a number of important steps towards stronger support of the voluntary sector in the past three years. The chancellor stated his desire to build a democracy of giving by 2000. Central and local government are turning increasingly to the voluntary sector to help with the delivery of public services and to address issues of health and social exclusion. Income generated through public donation will be enhanced by the tax relief on giving announced in the last budget and other changes to payroll giving and charity trading. Meanwhile, NCVO, with the support of its members, will continue to campaign for VAT rebates and other issues which affect the sector, such as free criminal records checks for volunteers.

In the new year, with a general election on the way, it is vital that the voluntary sector focuses on further development of close and equal partnership with government. We must stand firm and independent on issues which affect us all and work together on improving public understanding and knowledge of the good work we do. The Giving Campaign will be a splendid way to kick off the first new year of a new millennium and will, I am sure, play a significant role in reversing the decline in giving that we have witnessed over the past decade.

There will also be tax relief on gifts, shares and securities and an extension of the tax exemption for fundraising events. Last month saw Treasury Minister Stephen Timms grant £1m of government money toward the campaign. This represents a significant commitment from the government, who also plan to second staff to the campaign team. By the new year the Giving Campaign team expect to have raised an additional half a million for the launch. Generous donations have already been received from across the sector. With ongoing funding, the campaign should run for a total of three years and aims to achieve a £1bn increase in income to the voluntary sector. However, for many in the sector it appears that the government is giving with one hand and taking with the other. While they donate money to our national campaigns they are still refusing to budge on a VAT rebate for charities. It is estimated that this costs the sector £400m a year. Nonetheless, the government has taken a number of important steps towards stronger support of the voluntary sector in the past three years. The chancellor stated his desire to build a democracy of giving by 2000. Central and local government are turning increasingly to the voluntary sector to help with the delivery of public services and to address issues of health and social exclusion. Income generated through public donation will be enhanced by the tax relief on giving announced in the last budget and other changes to payroll giving and charity trading. Meanwhile, NCVO, with the support of its members, will continue to campaign for VAT rebates and other issues which affect the sector, such as free criminal records checks for volunteers. In the new year, with a general election on the way, it is vital that the voluntary sector focuses on further development of close and equal partnership with government. We must stand firm and independent on issues which affect us all and work together on improving public understanding and knowledge of the good work we do. The Giving Campaign will be a splendid way to kick off the first new year of a new millennium and will, I am sure, play a significant role in reversing the decline in giving that we have witnessed over the past decade.

webTitle: Why the poor will suffer if globalisation is not controlled

fields.headline: Behind closed doors
fields.standfirst: Why the poor will suffer if globalisation is not controlled
fields.trailText: Why the poor will suffer if globalisation is not controlled
fields.body:
The wreckers have been at it again. Over the year since the collapse of world trade talks in Seattle, dedicated and well-organised groups have been ruthlessly chipping away at the remnants of the World Trade Organisation's (WTO) credibility. Without firm action, there is now a real danger that they will cause the rules-based trading system to collapse, destroying efforts to reduce poverty and global inequality.

The wreckers are not from the ever broadening anti-WTO and globalisation protest movement. The wreckers in question are the governments of the world's richest countries who continue to use their power to subordinate the WTO to their own national interests and to the pursuit of corporate profit, regardless of the cost to poor countries, public health, and the environment.

Media attention in Seattle, Prague and, to some extent, in Nice focused on the street protests and the activities of a few balaclava-clad "globaphobes" with a disdain for McDonald's windows. But the real battle over the past year has been taking place off-camera, where developing countries are still challenging the northern government's abuse of the WTO system.

The charge sheet is impressive and is only partly answered by Clare Short's white paper on globalisation, which was unveiled this week. While poor countries have liberalised their markets, rich countries have remained resolutely protectionist, especially in areas like textiles and agriculture. The authority of the WTO, which drives globalisation, has actually been extended into new areas, such as intellectual property rights. Whatever Short says, the negotiating process has continued to be profoundly undemocratic, with big countries stitching up deals in secret negotiations.

It was the failure of the US and the European Union (EU) to address these concerns that produced the real debacle in Seattle.

Last week, European commissioner Pascal Lamy said he thought the time had come for the EU to consider reformulating its position on world trade negotiations if a new round of multilateral negotiations is to be launched. There was still no mention of the reforms that Britain and other countries had said were vital to make the WTO more democratic and accountable.

So the charade goes on. Take the issue of protectionism. It's not mentioned in Short's white paper, but each year, developing countries lose around $700bn (£484bn) as a result of trade barriers in rich countries. Stated differently, for every $1 provided by the rich world in the form of aid and debt relief, poor countries lose another $14 because of trade barriers. Reducing these barriers would help to create jobs and take millions of people out of poverty.

Unfortunately, the post-Seattle record is abysmal. The industrialised countries promised they would provide the 48 least developed countries, which collectively account for 12% of the world's population but only 0.5% of trade, with improved market access. One year on from Seattle, they have done nothing.

Today, poor countries exporting to the industrialised world face tariffs four times as high as those facing rich countries. True, industrialised countries have promised to withdraw restrictions on imports of textiles, the Third World's biggest manufactured export. But so far less than 10% of the restrictions have been lifted, and the pace of liberalisation has slowed.

Nowhere are the double standards as deeply ingrained as in agriculture. US trade negotiators wax lyrical about the virtues of "level playing fields" in farm products. Yet the industrialised countries collectively spend over $240bn subsidising environmentally destructive intensive agriculture, and the "free trading" US has increased farm subsidies over the past year.

For the millions of smallholder farmers in developing countries, these subsidies are a disaster. It is not just that they result in poor countries losing export markets. Rural livelihoods are also being destroyed on a massive scale because poor farmers in Africa, Asia, and Latin America cannot compete against subsidised imports. The resulting loss of food self-reliance is good news for the giant corporate grain exporters, who dictate US trade policy, but bad news for poverty.

Since Seattle, countries such India, Kenya and the Dominican Republic have been demanding a WTO food security clause that would allow them to restrict imports in the interests of achieving food self-sufficiency. But the US has systematically blocked the proposal, claiming that it would distort world markets. In reality, the WTO is being used to ensure that US commercial interests supersede basic human rights.

The same principle applies to WTO rules on patents. These rules are the product of a concerted lobbying campaign led by giant pharmaceutical and biotechnology companies. Shorn of their mind-numbing legalistic complexity, they have extended the duration and scope of patent protection, and backed corporate claims with the threat of WTO-sponsored trade sanctions.

One consequence of the WTO regime is that countries with strong generic drugs industries - such as India, Thailand and Egypt - will no longer be permitted to produce low-cost copies of patented drugs for low-income populations. These industries are able to produce drugs for the treatment of HIV and Aids at less than one-twentieth of market price of patented equivalents, providing a lifeline for millions of sufferers.

Over the past year, India and Egypt have asked for more time to find ways of adapting to the new regime. The American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association has demanded US trade sanctions against both countries, and the US Trade Representatives Office has obligingly placed them on notice.

Various polite formulations can be found to describe what is happening on drugs and patenting. But at a time when public health in poor countries is threatened by new diseases and drug-resistant variants of old killers like diarrhoea, measles and pneumonia, the truth is relatively simple. WTO rules dictated by powerful corporations and enforced by northern governments will deprive millions of poor people access to vital drugs, causing premature death and suffering on a massive scale.

Against this background, it is not hard to see why calls for much firmer and fairer management of globalisation and the abolition of the WTO are growing. But abolitionism is a counsel of despair. It offers nothing more than a power vacuum in which the powerful can use their economic muscle to bully the powerless into submission. We desperately need a rules-based system of global governance that places people before corporate profit, and shares the benefits of globalisation more equitably. And we need to get the wreckers under control.

&;149; Kevin Watkins works for Oxfam

webTitle: How charities can end cash worries

fields.headline: Lending a hand
fields.standfirst: Patrick McCurry on how charities can end cash worries
fields.trailText: Patrick McCurry on how charities can end cash worries
fields.body:
Charities have, understandably, always avoided borrowing. After all, why borrow when you can get a grant? But as the funding climate for many groups becomes more uncertain, and local authorities continue to cut grants, more voluntary organisations are looking at the role of loans.

The government, too, is keen to see charities take a more entrepreneurial approach to their work and for more private capital to be channelled into under-invested communities.

This was illustrated by the chancellor's decision, last month, to commit £10m to a new community development venture fund and his willingness to explore the introduction of a community investment tax credit - two recommendations put forward by the social investment task force.

But there are still significant obstacles to the development of loan finance, with banks often ignorant about how voluntary organisations work and with many charities lacking the proper financial systems to reassure lenders. As a result, several specialist loan funds have been set up to act as intermediaries between commercial lenders and charities.

The Brighton community arts group, Same Sky, turned to community loan fund Investors in Society last summer when it needed funds to complete a financing package for its expansion plans. "After years of having to move around and operate from a variety of sites, we'd been offered a permanent home but had only been able to raise £60,000 in grants to refurbish the building and we needed a further £40,000," says Same Sky general manager Iain Cartwright.

The only option was seeking a loan, but Cartwright found the local high street banks unhelpful. He says: "They agreed to lend us the money in principle but wanted our board of trustees to be personally liable for any borrowing, and they didn't seem to understand that we were a voluntary organisation, not a limited company."

The expansion plan was saved when Investors in Society, a loan fund for the sector set up four years ago by the Charities Aid Foundation, agreed to step in. The fund, which has received interest-free loans from sources such as the Woolwich building society to lend on to charities, specialises in supporting voluntary organisations that have been turned down by the mainstream banks.

"I don't know what we'd have done otherwise," says Cartwright. "It's a common situation for charities that want to expand, but lack the funds. It would have taken us several years to find the money we needed."

As well as specialist loan funds for charities, "social banks" such as Dutch-owned Triodos have significantly increased their lending to community organisations and social business. Last year its loans in the UK increased 89% to £28m. One of the bank's innovations is allowing charities to use their supporter base to guarantee loans.

When Christian Action and Resource Enterprise, a charity working with the homeless in Cleethorpes, Lincolnshire, ran into problems with the mainstream banks, Triodos agreed to come up with the deposit it needed to buy its premises if the charity could find 29 supporters each willing to guarantee £2,000. It did, and the charity was able to buy the building and expand its operations.

But loan finance is still a fraction of overall finance for the sector, one problem being that voluntary organisations rarely consider borrowing until it's too late.

Roger Broklehurst, director of the Local Investment Fund (LIF), a community loan fund, says there is a lot more awareness in the sector of the need to break away from grant dependency. But there is still far too little focus by charities on business planning.

"We had a loan inquiry from a Liverpool community cinema that had had its grant from the council halved," says Brokleshurst. "But when we asked them about their business plan, they said they'd never needed one because they relied on grants."

A growing use of loan finance would benefit the voluntary sector in terms of increased efficiency, according to Martin Hockly, who heads Street UK, a new loan fund for entrepreneurs in under-invested communities. He says: "I've seen an awful lot of sloppy thinking, weak management and poor use of resources in the voluntary sector over the years, but when an organisation has a loan it is forced to think much more clearly about its activity and where it is going."

Andrew Robinson, head of community development banking at Royal Bank of Scotland-NatWest, compares the current under-developed loans market in the voluntary sector with that of housing in the past. "In the 70s, there was no private capital in social housing, but now it makes up the majority of finance," he says.

What is needed, argues Robinson, is for the emergence of intermediaries which can operate between the banks and private financiers on one side, and the voluntary sector or social businesses on the other. The two sides often do not understand each other, he maintains, arguing that it is not fear of bad risks that has put off mainstream banks from lending to charities, but lack of understanding about what the risks are.

Loan funds, while still small, are pioneering the role of intermediary. The market could also be boosted by social investment initiatives like NatWest's community bond, which allows investors to put their money into social projects, and the London Rebuilding Society, a credit union-style community investment fund.

webTitle: Anti-road protesters get ready to battle against bypass proposals

fields.headline: Road rage
fields.standfirst: With 30 controversial road schemes planned throughout the country, all eyes are on Hastings as anti-road protesters get ready to battle against bypass proposals
fields.trailText: With 30 controversial road schemes planned throughout the country, all eyes are on Hastings as anti-road protesters get ready to battle against bypass proposals
fields.body:
Green campaigners are gearing up for a battle in Hastings over plans to build new roads through an area of outstanding natural beauty round the Victorian seaside town. Environmentalists say they'll provoke a major Swampy-style conflict if ministers approve the roads when the Hastings multi-modal transport study lands on their desks in the new year. The study is seen as a key test, as it is the first of around 30 reports on potentially controversial road schemes due in the next few months, and activists threaten to make Hastings a cause celebre like Newbury or Twyford Down.

The Hastings study is complex, detailed and taut with policy conflicts at the heart of the debate over sustainable development. It says the planned roads could potentially bring new jobs to the Sussex town, which has some of the worst pockets of deprivation in the south-east. But it warns that the bypasses would wreck the tranquil countryside by throwing a high embankment along a flood plain in the High Weald area of Sussex where wildlife abounds and the field system has remained unchanged for centuries.

The consultants' report recommends a package of local improvements, including more dual carriageway on the A21 to cut journey times to the M25, and a faster rail link to the Chunnel station at Ashford. But it says it cannot make a recommendation on the bypasses because although they could have major economic benefits, they are in direct conflict with stated government policy to avoid new roads significantly affecting prime countryside unless there is overwhelming national interest.

Unless John Prescott is prepared to abandon the government's countryside protection pledge, the decision could hinge on whether the proposed roads are of national significance. Figures in the report show that in purely traffic terms they are not. Ninety-five per cent of vehicles on the main road along the Hastings sea front are local, and the bypasses would primarily help suburban drivers to scoot from one edge of the city to the other (slightly increasing greenhouse gas emissions in the process). The roads, though, would also potentially improve the urban environment by creating more space for pedestrians, cyclists and buses at the sea front.

These may not be sufficient criteria for overriding the presumption against roads in areas of beauty, but there is another factor: the need to improve the local economy. Hastings is a charming Victorian seaside resort suffering from a fall in family holiday visitors and a near collapse in the local fishing industry. Houses are cheap and the town has provided an overspill for London's boroughs who offered long-term unemployed people grants to buy flats by the sea if they relinquished their rights to homes in the capital. This policy, coupled with the long-term decline in local jobs, has left Hastings with five council wards which sink into the bottom 10% of the UK deprivation tables, measured by health, education, skills and access to services. Among the workforce, 5.4% are unemployed, although Hastings has admittedly seen a better than average surge in job creation in the last five years. When the bypass was discussed before the election, the jobless total stood at 12%.

Some local firms say they would like to have the option of expanding but there is a shortage of industrial space, and the study concludes that the balance of evidence suggests the area will only be regenerated if a business park is built on a 70-hectare greenfield site to the north-west of the town. The factories would be accompanied by a housing estate, and unlocking the land in a picturesque valley will mean building the western bypass - an option overwhelming supported by business.

But there are several snags. The first is over the environment: the study concludes that the western bypass would create too many traffic jams unless it were built in conjunction with the eastern bypass, which wrecks an area of outstanding natural beauty. The second snag concerns the economic analysis itself. The study accepts that new business park jobs are not guaranteed because major firms are likely to avoid Hastings because of its location and its lack of an obvious drawcard, such as a university. And it warns that incomers may take up any new jobs on offer, leaving the existing unemployed in the most deprived areas still on the dole. (Employers in the town say that their biggest problem is a shortage of skills - not a shortage of premises.)

In the worst case, it says, the new developments could actually harm the town. Existing firms might shift to the new business park, leaving black holes behind. Or new employers in the business park might bid up the local low wage levels and threaten the competitiveness of existing employers. The study also forecasts that the bypass-related developments will actually increase unemployment in Hastings town itself, and that the new out-of-town jobs will be hard to reach for the poorest who do not drive. There is another imponderable not considered by the study: what happens if the new out-of-town homes lure existing families out of Hastings, leaving behind even more vacant properties in the town which already has 9.6% of homes empty - almost double the national average.

The jobs arithmetic bears closer examination too. The study says that in a best case scenario, the business park could create 2,000 jobs, with a potential for 500-1,000 extra jobs if the wealth trickles down through the local economy. But let us suppose that each of the 1,500 new greenfield homes has 1.5 adult workers: that necessitates 2,250 jobs ... leaving either 250 or 750 for local people, depending on the level of optimism over the extent of trickle-down. On the other hand, the study says that job creation schemes within Hastings town itself, which are not covered by the study, could create up to 700 jobs without the bypass or the new homes being built - with a concomitant saving of £130m of public money. This would leave the jobless figure of Hastings at 3.5%.

When the study was originally commissioned, the idea was to examine broader economic issues like this. Would public money be better spent on transport - or on education, training, tourism developments, micro job schemes or housing improvements? This exercise in joined-up government was deemed too unwieldy and ended as an exercise in joined-up transport planning, to the dismay of some local councillors.

In their struggle to come to a decision on the issue, ministers are advised by the study to take note of public opinion: a survey shows that 63% of local people want the western bypass, following a long campaign by businesses, councillors and the media. But a close reading of the survey shows a more confused picture. Most people would prefer to spend money on public transport rather than to build new roads.

Only a minority support the eastern bypass, and most think the countryside should be protected even if it means restricting car use. Only a minority of people supported the view that new firms should be attracted at the expense of the countryside. What is more, people in central St Leonard's Ward, which is one of the most deprived, were among the least likely to want the new roads - because they fear that traffic would increase in their neighbourhood.

The South-East Regional Assembly (composed of councillors, businesses and voluntary groups) will pick up this hot potato over the next few weeks, then hand it to Prescott in time for a decision just before the general election. Hastings is a Labour marginal, but this fact will not, civil servants promise, affect the decision.

 Roger Harrabin is a correspondent for BBC Radio 4's Today Programme

Some local firms say they would like to have the option of expanding but there is a shortage of industrial space, and the study concludes that the balance of evidence suggests the area will only be regenerated if a business park is built on a 70-hectare greenfield site to the north-west of the town. The factories would be accompanied by a housing estate, and unlocking the land in a picturesque valley will mean building the western bypass - an option overwhelming supported by business. But there are several snags. The first is over the environment: the study concludes that the western bypass would create too many traffic jams unless it were built in conjunction with the eastern bypass, which wrecks an area of outstanding natural beauty. The second snag concerns the economic analysis itself. The study accepts that new business park jobs are not guaranteed because major firms are likely to avoid Hastings because of its location and its lack of an obvious drawcard, such as a university. And it warns that incomers may take up any new jobs on offer, leaving the existing unemployed in the most deprived areas still on the dole. (Employers in the town say that their biggest problem is a shortage of skills - not a shortage of premises.) In the worst case, it says, the new developments could actually harm the town. Existing firms might shift to the new business park, leaving black holes behind. Or new employers in the business park might bid up the local low wage levels and threaten the competitiveness of existing employers. The study also forecasts that the bypass-related developments will actually increase unemployment in Hastings town itself, and that the new out-of-town jobs will be hard to reach for the poorest who do not drive. There is another imponderable not considered by the study: what happens if the new out-of-town homes lure existing families out of Hastings, leaving behind even more vacant properties in the town which already has 9.6% of homes empty - almost double the national average. The jobs arithmetic bears closer examination too. The study says that in a best case scenario, the business park could create 2,000 jobs, with a potential for 500-1,000 extra jobs if the wealth trickles down through the local economy. But let us suppose that each of the 1,500 new greenfield homes has 1.5 adult workers: that necessitates 2,250 jobs ... leaving either 250 or 750 for local people, depending on the level of optimism over the extent of trickle-down. On the other hand, the study says that job creation schemes within Hastings town itself, which are not covered by the study, could create up to 700 jobs without the bypass or the new homes being built - with a concomitant saving of £130m of public money. This would leave the jobless figure of Hastings at 3.5%. When the study was originally commissioned, the idea was to examine broader economic issues like this. Would public money be better spent on transport - or on education, training, tourism developments, micro job schemes or housing improvements? This exercise in joined-up government was deemed too unwieldy and ended as an exercise in joined-up transport planning, to the dismay of some local councillors. In their struggle to come to a decision on the issue, ministers are advised by the study to take note of public opinion: a survey shows that 63% of local people want the western bypass, following a long campaign by businesses, councillors and the media. But a close reading of the survey shows a more confused picture. Most people would prefer to spend money on public transport rather than to build new roads. Only a minority support the eastern bypass, and most think the countryside should be protected even if it means restricting car use. Only a minority of people supported the view that new firms should be attracted at the expense of the countryside. What is more, people in central St Leonard's Ward, which is one of the most deprived, were among the least likely to want the new roads - because they fear that traffic would increase in their neighbourhood. The South-East Regional Assembly (composed of councillors, businesses and voluntary groups) will pick up this hot potato over the next few weeks, then hand it to Prescott in time for a decision just before the general election. Hastings is a Labour marginal, but this fact will not, civil servants promise, affect the decision.  Roger Harrabin is a correspondent for BBC Radio 4's Today Programme

webTitle: Profile:  Karen Chazen, a lone parent singled out for success

fields.headline: A tsar in the making?
fields.standfirst: Karen Chazen, a lone parent singled out for success
fields.trailText: Profile: Karen Chazen, a lone parent singled out for success
fields.body:
Karen Chazen is on a high after attending the annual meeting of the National Council for One Parent Families. It takes a moment to sink in that the "Jo" she has been chatting to is JK Rowling, who addressed the event. And Gordon Brown, the chancellor, mentioned her by name in his speech, thanking her for her work on Merseyside, where she is a Sure Start programme co-ordinator.

"He came over afterwards and asked me how I was, how my son was and how Sure Start was doing," says Chazen. She is laughing, but obviously delighted. "It's nice to be acknowledged, but it doesn't really matter whether it's Gordon Brown or Anne Brown, as long as I can raise the profile of the project." And then she is laughing again at the incongruity of it all and how everything has snowballed from the inauspicious start of an unplanned pregnancy seven years ago.

Her dual role, as a Sure Start programme co-ordinator in Liverpool and an executive member of the national council's board, means she is tackling child poverty and single parent issues head on. Chazen, 31, realises she has become something of a figurehead, and feels slightly in awe of the responsibility that brings. Back in April, she spoke at 11 Downing Street at the launch of the lone parents' helpline - again attended by Brown, who later spoke of how moved and inspired he had been by her story of struggle as a single parent to achieve her career ambitions.

But she is quick to point out that her experiences are no different from the isolation, anxiety and - more often than not - poverty of millions of other single parents. "I see myself as a representative, really, and it's great to have the opportunity to give lone parents a voice," she says. "We've had a tremendous year as a charity, with Jo Rowling coming on board and a chancellor who is committed to the eradication of child poverty, just as we are committed to eradicating lone parent poverty."

Chazen was born in Liverpool and spent five years working for an insurance company after leaving school because she was, by her own admission, aimless. She then decided to study childcare and it was in the middle of the course that she got pregnant. She had her son, Zak, in October 1993 and qualified in January 1994, breastfeeding him in lectures because she was so determined to finish the course.

When her relationship foundered, she started on the relentless round of juggling work and childcare. "I just did it, as others do it," she recalls. "I look back and wonder if I should have done it differently, but I know it was right for me, and I look at Zak now and know it was right for him. I think I said this in Downing Street - that with ambition comes guilt, but at the back of my mind was always that Zak deserves this."

She has had good family support, she says, and had an early break with a free nursery place. "I was lucky that when I accessed the nursery it was just before they changed the entry criteria," she says. "I know how hard it is to get a place. Good childcare is equivalent to a good relationship - you need to know it's there and reliable."

Chazen had a variety of jobs before becoming manager of the creche at Liverpool One Parent Families Trust. She may be an inspiration to Brown, she says, but there she met many lone parents, including fathers, who inspired her. "You can't stereotype single parents," she insists. "Only a very low percentage are teenage girls. Of course my own experience has informed my work, and it's all about challenging perceptions." She spent a year as chief executive of the trust, and from there it was a natural progression to the national council.

Her day job at Sure Start counterpoints her national role. She clearly believes that the project can unlock the potential in areas like Speke, where she is based. Speke, a pre-1939 housing estate at the southernmost end of Liverpool, is an isolated community, landlocked by industrial estates and cut off from the city centre.

"We're talking second and third generation unemployment here," says Chazen. Children in the area grow up without expectation of work and, perhaps even more damning, without anger about it. She says: "There's no: 'I want to be an astronaut when I grow up.' And if we want to break that cycle of deprivation, we have to start with young children. In fact, it goes even further back to babies and antenatal care.

"People tend to stay within the area, and if we want them to access the services Sure Start is offering then we have to provide everything here. We're only in our infancy, but I'm committed to making it work because I believe it can. It's a unique opportunity to break down the barriers and for the community to play a pivotal role."

Chazen works closely with health visitors, and one of the many issues that have come out of the Sure Start consultation process is the need for people to access the services when they need to - not at the practitioner's convenience. "As a single parent I know what it's like when you've only had a couple of hours sleep and your baby won't stop crying and you haven't talked to anybody for 18 hours," she says. "It's when you are at your most vulnerable and you need to see someone straight away, not: 'Can you make an appointment, can you come back at 5 o'clock?'"

She remains hopeful about the government's aims of getting 70% of lone parents into work by the end of the decade and ending the catch 22 of the benefit trap. "It's OK to give us a hand up, and the working families tax credit is making a big difference, but we want to go further," she says. "It's not enough to just manage; single parents want a better quality of life."

She has no plans to leave Liverpool. She loves her job, loves the city - "there's just something about the place" - and her son is settled and happy. But the suspicion lingers that bigger things beckon. A friend jokingly called her the lone parent tsar. "The funny thing is," she says, "Chazen is a Russian name."

 The lone parents' helpline is 0800-018 5026.

webTitle: The 'name and shame' campaign has failed reformed paedophiles

fields.headline: Inner circle
fields.standfirst: The 'name and shame' campaign has not helped the safe return of reformed paedophiles to society.  Rosemary Harthill  looks at a new approach to a risky business
fields.trailText: The 'name and shame' campaign has not helped the safe return of reformed paedophiles to society. Rosemary Harthill looks at a new approach to a risky business
fields.body:
It's Saturday night in a church hall. But this is no youth club dance. Nor is it a typical church meeting. Instead, five people are quietly meeting to help a paedophile reintegrate into the community.

This is the first British meeting of a "circle of support and accountability". Together, the members of the circle are working out a mutual agreement which will reduce risk - risk to the community, risk to his victims and risk to himself.

The circle model has worked successfully in Canada for six years.If this new model works here too, it could radically improve the care and supervision on release of some of the more dangerous of Britain's 100,000-plus convicted sex offenders.

Darren (not his real name) is 36. A former alcoholic, over 20 years he has collected a number of convictions for indecently assaulting adolescent females and young adult women. After six months in prison for sexual abuse, he underwent 15 months' intensive therapy at Wolvercote Clinic in Epsom, Surrey, which focuses on reducing abuse by assessing and treating sex offenders. His time at the clinic ended last month.

Donald Findlater, clinic manager at Wolvercote, regularly sees men leave the clinic or prison who are going out to nobody. "Their former family and friends - if they ever had any - may well have fallen by the wayside," he says. "Without a job, or other support, some end up sleeping in night shelters, living on the streets, and returning to drink."

Many of those obliged by the terms of their release from prison to keep in contact with the hard-pressed probation service may have only very limited contact - weekly meetings initially, reducing to monthly meetings after a relatively short period.

Findlater reckoned there must be a better way to reduce the risk of re-offending. Last June, he attended a workshop run by the Religious Society of Friends in Britain, the Quakers. Five Canadians addressed representatives from the Home Office, police, probation services, church groups and charities. The Canadians described a new scheme set up to deal with similar problems in Canada. Backed by the Mennonite Church and founded in Ontario, the scheme offers support for offenders with no one else to turn to, and tries to reassure public fears by encouraging members of the local community to play a part in the rehabilitation process.

It is a practical response to the kind of fear generated by the indiscriminate attacks on paedophiles and others triggered by the News of the World campaign last August "naming and shaming" released paedophiles.

The circles usually consist of between four and six people. A covenant is drawn up among all the members of the circle, detailing their expectations and what happens if they are broken. The "core member" (the sex offender) must state that he is committed to "no more victims of sexual abuse".

Knowing Darren would need support when he left the Wolvercote this month, Findlater decided to set up a pilot scheme himself. "I'm an impatient sort, and I wanted to see something live and kicking," he says.

He began by phoning three or four church leaders he knew in the area where Darren was going to live. "I told them I'd got this crazy idea about how the church could help sex offenders live safely in their community, and what did they think?"

He then introduced the idea to a wider group of their contacts. "They were very positive about the concept, but remarkably pessimistic about finding volunteers with that much time to commit."

In the first few weeks the core member meets the group every week and talks to at least one member every day. The circle may continue for one, two or three years, though members may change.

Volunteers do not need social work or counselling experience. "We wanted people who had a life, and were willing to share that life," says Findlater. "It helps if they are wise, and a bit cautious, people with their feet on the ground, not too prurient, and not easily shocked. It's not a mind-delving exercise. It's befriending."

In October he went to see for himself the Canadian scheme working. He and the coordinator in Toronto spent a day out at Niagara Falls with a former sex offender. Later they all dropped in to see the coordinator's sister, then went on to eat pizza at a party.

"It's not about giving them a bit of your time, it's more about doing things together whether playing computer games, table tennis, or going for a walk. Sometimes this creates community that the core member may never have had before."

He says he approached church people to help find volunteers because of the Christian belief in the value of every human being, and that everyone could be encouraged to make a constructive contribution. But he is absolutely clear that joining a circle is not an evangelistic activity.

"We don't want people coming along with the aim of saving someone's soul. Not because I don't believe it, but I don't think it's a helpful starting point. Instead, it's closer to the words of Jesus: 'I was in prison, and you visited me'."

He also reckons the churches have a lot to learn. "They need to exercise more caution, and open their eyes a bit wider. There's evidence that church communities contain a higher rate of sex offenders than the community as a whole. I hope a bi-product of this might be more vigilance in their own communities." In the future, he says he would welcome volunteers of all faiths as well as non-believers.

Four volunteers between 35 and 50 emerged for Darren's circle: Findlater himself, a quantity surveyor, a community worker and a church minister. Five detailed training sessions covered the legal and social context, and information about the behaviour of sex offenders. They also covered the purpose and aims of developing a personal plan for the core member to prevent re-offending, and a background briefing on Darren himself.

The female member of the group decided to meet Darren only in public places, not at her home. There was also the question of who they could share their involvement with. One said sadly that they felt at present, given the feeling against paedophiles, they couldn't tell anyone at all, outside close family. "It is sad," says Findlater, "but I hope over time that will change."

Out of the recent church hall meeting, Darren's group has come to a framework agreement. In pursuit of the goal of not re-offending, Darren has now committed himself to meeting circle members regularly, not drinking, and keeping any appointments made on his behalf with the probation service or the local drugs and alcohol agency. He has also agreed to continue efforts to get work. In return, the other members of the circle have agreed to give him regular and sustained support.

If Darren starts breaking the agreement, the group will discuss this with him at an emergency meeting. If a problem continues, the circle will inform the local sex offender registration police office or other statutory agency. The circle's job is not supervision: it is to help supervision through close contact.

Warning signs could include starting to drink, missing appointments, stopping shaving or bathing, using inappropriate language, or showing signs of depression or withdrawal.

In Canada, some agreements have been broken. But early evidence shows a reduction in re-offending. For those high-risk offenders who have been in one of the 30 circles of support in Canada over a two-year period, the re-offending rate so far is down to 10%. That's compared with the usual level of 21.5%.

The Society of Friends last month hosted a second follow-up meeting with representatives of the Home Office and other agencies. The Home Office is believed now to be considering setting aside some funding for further pilots under the programme of its dangerous offenders' unit. In the meantime, a partnership of Thames Valley Police, the Society of Friends, and the Ox-Bucks Probation Service is pursuing whether some government funding for restorative justice work with adults might be available for a pilot along circle lines beginning next spring.

"There is real interest in developing other pilots," says Helen Drewery, secretary of the Quaker crime and community justice committee. "But everyone's a bit twitchy. One worry is the fear of what happens if a high-profile case were to go horribly wrong, and discredit the idea. But everything has some risks. Wearing a car seat belt might trap you in a fire but that's no reason not to wear one. And on the Canadian evidence, something is more likely to go horribly wrong without a circle of support."

fields.body:

Rugby Advertiser, 23.11.00 (John Forster, Daventry)

Deep joy A grotto for Santa Claus has been set up 450 feet underground in a former colliery at the national mining museum near Wakefield, Yorkshire.
Huddersfield Weekly Examiner, 25.11.00 (RC Adamson, Milnsbridge)

On the fiddle A shoplifter managed to walk out of a music shop in Brighton with a four-foot cello under his coat.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 25.11.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Vindaroo? The owner of a Wolverhampton balti house has added curried kangaroo meat to the menu after spending two years setting up restaurants in Australia.
Midlands Metro, 22.11.00 (Jon Gurling, Birmingham)

Lamp life Staff at an RSPCA shelter used a heat lamp to save a 13-foot python found dying of cold on a beach in Tywyn, Wales.

webTitle: Eco soundings

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Disputed facts
fields.body:
Disputed facts

As is quite clear to Londoners, who really like having no trains, waiting days for buses, choking on cars stuck in gridlock, being mugged and knocked down on pavements, the city is more sustainable now than it was in 1995. So declares London First, a business group sponsored by corporations such as British Airways, BAA, Thames Water and Canary Wharf to promote and improve London. Their report says business is booming, heart disease is falling, water quality is better and there is less deprivation. Perhaps. Critics might also say that the fact that crime is up 10%, energy use is up, waste is massively increasing, that Terminal 5 will probably be built, and traffic is expected to increase 20%, with fuel use already rising, suggests something else. But it's Christmas, so let's not have an argument.

Feisty farmers

Blimey. The National Farmers Union (NFU) has come out strongly against GM crops, calling them polluting, threatening to the biosphere, injurious to human health and economically risky. Dream on. This is not our own NFU, but the feisty Canadian version. OK, it only has 12,000 members, but it says no one has resigned and it is being congratulated around the world.

Waste of energy

Bet you didn't note the wee sentence in the homes bill, which will legally oblige anyone selling a house to provide an energy survey? One in the eye for Bromley MP Eric Forth, who has spent three years personally blocking the energy efficiency bill in which this sensible measure was first mooted.

Green Browne

Gloom at Eco Soundings on seeing the ad for the new head of Greenpeace in that well-known organ for visionaries and environmentalists, the Observer business section. It offers £55-75,000 for a "courageous individual" with "political judgment". Who in the corporate world could it be aimed at? Thoughts turn to Sir John Browne, presently head of BP but known to want to save the world, a deeply committed man with great interest in the environment (Amazon, Tibet, Arctic, etc). The only question they need ask him at the interview is whether he's prepared to dress up as a funky chicken. Latest odds: J Browne 3-1; T Juniper 6-1; S Tindale 8-1; D Voynet 9-1; J Prescott 15-1; G Monbiot 100-1; V Shiva 2,000-1.

webTitle: Poverty continues to thrive

fields.headline: Where influence matters more
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Poverty continues to thrive as the New Policy Institute's excellent poverty audit, published on Monday, grimly reminded everybody
fields.body:
Poverty continues to thrive as the New Policy Institute's excellent poverty audit, published on Monday, grimly reminded everybody. Two decades of brutal, regressive Tory policies, which tripled the numbers living below the poverty line, cannot be wiped out in one parliamentary term. Sensibly, ministers have set themselves a 20-year goal of eliminating child poverty - with an intermediary target of a 50% reduction within 10 years. Even this is a steep challenge.

Would a ministry of poverty help? Recently, the Guardian suggested that the prime minister was considering replacing the present social exclusion unit (SEU) with a new department for social inclusion to spearhead an anti-poverty drive in the most deprived areas. The expanded department would carve out responsibility for crucial poverty issues - from John Prescott's DETR, inner city regeneration and 1,370 run-down estates suffering multiple problems, plus possibly 18,000 excluded pupils.

Certainly large numbers of poor people live on run-down estates. Indeed, two-thirds of heads of households in all council and housing association homes do not have a job, and 75% have incomes of less than £200. But the proposal does not make sense. If you want a poverty ministry, you do not start with the DETR. You have to begin with social security, add in employment and the New Deal, and take in tax. Cynics might even call it the department of paid work. The naive might believe that Whitehall departments would welcome losing their most difficult clients - but history shows they fight for every last part of their empires.

The impetus for the change was said to be a review of the SEU, published a year ago, which concluded that the unit's work "has been, on the whole, less enthusiastically received inside government than outside". Far from being a criticism, this should have been seen as an accolade. It is the job of Cabinet Office units to be unpopular with insiders. In the words of Lord Rothschild, boss of the former think tank, their role is to produce the grit which creates the oyster.

Abolishing the SEU would be a huge setback for the poor. Moira Wallace, the director, was an ideal choice with her former posts at the Treasury and Downing Street. It has far more influence as a Cabinet Office unit with close ties to the PM, than it would have as a separate department - it would be quickly marginalised by Whitehall's big bruisers and turned into a minor irritant.

Tony Blair should read his history. Harold Wilson carved two new departments - land and economic affairs - out of existing departments. Both failed miserably.

webTitle: Ex-miner helping to breathe new life into a dying community

fields.headline: The Grime-buster
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot  meets an ex-miner helping to breathe new life into a dying community
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot meets an ex-miner helping to breathe new life into a dying community
fields.body:
We're driving slowly down a pot-holed street in Grimethorpe, past terraced houses ready for demolition. Roofbeams are visible through great holes in the tiles. Bulldozers are hovering, ready to execute the final coup de grace on Old King Coal. Generations of miners lived in these terraces. Today, contractors are consulting plans and shouting orders. Private homes are to be built here and, nearby, new light industrial units offering new hope to new generations from the surrounding estates.

Suddenly our ears are assailed by the whine as three motorbikes flash past, careering across the adjoining wasteland. The youths astride them could be bunking off school or old enough to be at work. It's difficult to tell at the speed they're going.

Danny Gillespie shakes his head and mutters: "I know who they are." And they would almost certainly know him if they had paused long enough to glance through the car window. Everybody in Grimethorpe (population 4,200) seems to know Gillespie. He is founder of the neighbourhood watch association, a big man who's made a big impression on criminal activity in a part of South Yorkshire that was rapidly being dubbed Crimethorpe.

The joy-riding incident is an indication that there is still some way to go. But then Gillespie is not a miracle worker. He's a decent, former miner of 57 who stood up to be counted on behalf of a community he cares for, built around a coal mine that gave him a living for over 35 years. When it closed in 1993, the grime went out of Grimethorpe. But the name stuck.

Everybody had heard of the place because it had a world-famous brass band. And as for that name - well, it simply helped to keep alive southern prejudices about the landscape of northern England being all belching chimneys and slagheaps. It gave way to that predictable tale of despair and drug-taking among disillusioned local youth and a consequent sharp rise in vandalism and robbery. End of story.

Well, not quite. The latest figures show a very significant reduction in crime in Grimethorpe. Burglaries are down by 23% and car crime by 43%. Judges in the Norwich Union Neighbourhood Watch Awards were impressed enough to give Grimethorpe first prize in the urban section. Next Monday, Gillespie and his association's secretary, Elsie Smith, will be in Brussels to represent the UK in the European crime prevention awards.

Whether they win or not, there will be no let-up in their drive to make their village a better and safer place. They can't turn back the clock to the days when Elsie's husband, Bryan, was solo horn player in a Grimethorpe Colliery band full of colliers. They can never recapture the community spirit forged by men working together in harsh, dangerous conditions. But they can continue the steady crawl away from the mid-90s depths of low morale.

"The streets were looking mucky, yobs were strutting around being very verbal, and there were no end of break-ins," Gillespie recalls. "I was talking to a mate of mine and we decided that we'd both had enough. So we went down to the Acorn Centre, home of the Grimethorpe Regeneration Executive, and asked about starting a neighbourhood watch scheme. While we were there, a lady tapped me on the shoulder and introduced herself as the local crime prevention officer. That was it. She put us on the right road."

But she was careful not to be seen leading the way. Police uniforms are not universally respected, even among law-abiding folk in South Yorkshire pit villages, where they have keen memories of what happened during the 1984-85 miners' strike."Anyway," says Gillespie, "it was the Metropolitan police who gave us some hammer during the strike, not the local bobbies." Indeed, the local bobbies have since donated more than £25,000 for two youth workers.

All the same, Gillespie knew he would be a target for the "wrong 'uns" who would see him as a "grass" when he went round knocking on doors to generate support for his scheme. He expected trouble and, sure enough, it found him. "That place on the corner used to be full of druggies," he says, pointing through the front window of the house which he and his wife, Kathleen, bought from the coal board for £2,800 in 1983. "But I only had problems with one of them. He spread nails all over my drive one Friday when I was out at a disco I run for the kiddies. I knew there was something wrong as soon as I pulled in."

The morning light revealed 38 shining heads embedded in his tyres. When he returned from the garage, there were 10 young men eyeballing him from the wall across the street. He stood and faced them down. Gillespie has suffered back injuries and a heart attack in his hardworking life, but he's not a man to be intimidated.

Nor is he a man whose idea of neighbourhood watch is simply sitting behind a lace curtain and dialling the police at regular intervals. His association has become adept at raising funds and ploughing the proceeds back into the community.

Security lights have been provided for every elderly resident. A rat-infested piece of wasteland has been transformed into a safe, security-lit parking area and a Portakabin houses a mothers-and-toddlers group in the mornings and a youth club four evenings a week.

It's run, voluntarily, by another former miner, Roy Mills, who says that more than 50 youngsters have passed their Duke of Edinburgh Award.

Mills and Gillespie used to take their families on camping trips in the days when they earned a good living underground. Perhaps it's hardly surprising that they look back fondly. "I went to prize-giving day at my grand-daughter's school the other day and dropped on and old mate from the pit," Gillespie reveals. "We started reminiscing and I don't mind admitting we cried over what we'd lost."

Still, he's realistic enough to understand that the future for his grandchildren depends on the new building, which continues apace on the site of the old colliery. Old King Coal is dead and buried, its waste products moulded into the grassed-over hills which flank the new Dearne Valley link road - a ribbon of black Tarmac beckoning the 21st century into Grimethorpe.

European threat to new jobs

The sites on and around former collieries at Grimethorpe and nearby Houghton Main now make up one-third of the potential development land set aside by Barnsley metropolitan borough council. Since the 1997 general election, the council has been working with a government-backed regional development agency called Yorkshire Forward. Money has also come from the European Union.

But the possibility of attracting big employers to the area is under threat from a ruling by the European Commission that direct grant subsidies breach state-aid rules on fair competition. The subsidies had been used as an insurance to reassure private sector investors that they won't lose money on buildings.

"The ruling could have a fundamental impact on areas like this where land values are low," says Ben Morley, of the Grimethorpe Regeneration Executive. "It may be that the public sector will have to take the lead by building units and renting them out."

webTitle: Readers'  letters

fields.headline: Readers'  letters
fields.trailText: Charter for bullies | Workers losing out | False Cambridge claims | Population problems
fields.body:
Charter for bullies

Malcolm Dean says the problem with the "no blame" approach to bullying is not its approach, but its name (No blame is not a soft option, December 6). He is wrong: the problem is the approach.

Kidscape has a file full of complaints from parents about the no blame method - several have withdrawn their children from schools employing it. Basically, the idea of no blame is that victims and bullies get together and talk, no one has to accept responsibility and no one apologises. In theory, the chronic bullies learn to develop sympathy for the victims they have been tormenting. In practice, parents tell us that the bullies pretend to be "nice" while the teacher is around - and then beat the living daylights out of the victims for telling.

This concern about the no blame approach is shared by leading researchers. Dan Olweus, considered the world expert in the field of bullying prevention, says the no blame approach does not work and "it would be very unfortunate if schools tried to use this instead of more effective methods".

Bullies should apologise to victims, feel ashamed of what they've done and there should be consequences or they will go through life thinking they can do anything they wish to others. Long-term studies of bullies show that they are four times more likely to end up in prison, to abuse their spouses and children, and to have difficulty with relationships and holding down jobs.

Caring parents raise children to accept responsibility for their actions. This trendy, flawed no blame approach only reinforces the idea that actions, including bullying, have no consequences. It is a charter for bullies and a recipe for disaster for their victims.

Michele Elliott
Director, Kidscape

Workers losing out

Scope's plans to refocus and rationalise (Five-year plan for cerebral palsy charity, November 22) are not going down well with its employees.

The new works council - introduced despite strong support for union recognition among staff - was told about the planned 90 staff redundancies and sworn to secrecy. Then the plan was rolled out to Scope's members at its conference in November, with many of the workers who would lose their jobs present to assist or act as carers for delegates. What a way to learn that your job is going! Now proposals are being made to reduce redundancy terms. Has Scope been taking lessons from BMW?

I was one of the parents of children with cerebral palsy whom Scope failed to contact years ago. In those days it was called the Spastics Society, which put me right off. My daughter did go to their innovative holiday centre in Cornwall this year, and experienced the excitements of abseiling and water spray in her face, but of course all this will be closed if the plans go through.

Chris Ball
Voluntary sector secretary, MSF union

False Cambridge claims

The highly coloured article on rough sleepers in Cambridge (The cold shoulder, November 29) gives a lop-sided, superficial picture, taking no account of the huge amount of work now in progress.

Cambridge plans to make a more positive difference to the lives of rough sleepers this winter, rather than passively providing another emergency winter shelter. During the past weeks, all statutory and voluntary agencies providing services for the homeless have been making significant, coordinated efforts to help existing residents of hostels, who are ready for it, to move on into permanent accommodation.

This has created precisely the degree of flexibility to take in the street homeless that the article applauds in Brighton, but falsely claims is lacking in Cambridge. Early December was the usual date for the opening of an emergency winter night shelter. This year instead, 21 spaces in hostel and all-year-round night shelter accommodation will be available for people off the street.

This means, too, that 21 current residents of these projects, themselves formerly homeless, will have received keys to their own front doors. While they will continue to receive support from tenancy sustainment workers, these represent success stories for the hard work of hostel staff.

Money from the government's rough sleepers' unit has provided additional staff to join together and enhance existing services. Homelessness agencies in Cambridge, who designed this approach and bid for these funds, know they face a big challenge, but their frontline workers are backing it because it offers, at last, real long-term prospects of change for many individuals.

Ian Nimmo-Smith
Liberal Democrat chairman
Mike Talbot
Labour spokesperson
Chris Howell
Conservative spokesperson
Housing and health committee, Cambridge city council

Population problems

The article about using "ecological footprints" as a way of seeing the unsustainability of people's or communities' lifestyles (Map of your life, November 29) was good at showing the undeniable physical realities of our planet, which many members ignore, but omitted some obvious arithmetical logic .

If a group of people is living unsustainably, the unsustainable footprint is a product (in the arithmetical sense) of the per capita real land usage and the number of people involved. So, of course, a less profligate lifestyle helps, but so too does a lower population - yet there was no mention of this point.

Drastic short-term cuts in average consumption levels of just about everything - primarily among the world's richer people - are crucial. But, logically, decreases in population density in the longer term can make this less painful. Doing my bit by remaining childless ...

Albert Beale
London

fields.bodyText: Charter for bullies Malcolm Dean says the problem with the "no blame" approach to bullying is not its approach, but its name (No blame is not a soft option, December 6). He is wrong: the problem is the approach. Kidscape has a file full of complaints from parents about the no blame method - several have withdrawn their children from schools employing it. Basically, the idea of no blame is that victims and bullies get together and talk, no one has to accept responsibility and no one apologises. In theory, the chronic bullies learn to develop sympathy for the victims they have been tormenting. In practice, parents tell us that the bullies pretend to be "nice" while the teacher is around - and then beat the living daylights out of the victims for telling. This concern about the no blame approach is shared by leading researchers. Dan Olweus, considered the world expert in the field of bullying prevention, says the no blame approach does not work and "it would be very unfortunate if schools tried to use this instead of more effective methods". webTitle: Many charities have put their cards up for sale on their internet sites

fields.headline: Coming to a screen near you
fields.standfirst: Special report: Charities' online shopping
fields.trailText: For the first time, many charities have put their cards up for sale on their internet sites this Christmas. While enthusiastic about the potential, especially to attract younger buyers, they describe 2000 as a "test year" reports Alison Benjamin, while Jonathan Sale looks at the best cards on offer
fields.body:
For the first time, many charities have put their cards up for sale on their internet sites this Christmas. While enthusiastic about the potential, especially to attract younger buyers, they describe 2000 as a "test year".

"We believe it's a growing market but we'll have to wait until next Christmas to see by how much," says Julie Evans, NSPCC mail order marketing manager.

Her counterpart at the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds is also upbeat after a survey of its members, in the autumn, revealed that 42% were internet-friendly. But again, she says it is too early to assess the volume of online Christmas sales.

Cards for Good Causes and Card Aid, run by the Charities Advisory Trust (CAT), have been slow to embrace new technology. Both have websites detailing the work of the organisations and the charities they support, but as yet you cannot buy their cards on-line. "It is something we hope to be able to offer in future," says Cards for Good Causes.

Hilary Blume, director of CAT - which has 40 Card Aid retail outlets - is more dismissive. "Online buying is just mail order by a different name, and mail order has only captured 10% of the Christmas card business," she says.

Newcastle-based Greetings Card Company, runs the website www.charitycards.co.uk. In its first year it sold just 7,000 packs of Christmas cards and made £25,000, of which 66% of the retail price, less VAT, went to those charities that had sold their cards to the company to sell online. This year, managing director William Ruffman reports a fivefold increase in sales. He says his customers are predominately women whose sales choice is influenced more by the card's design than the charity it supports. "The fact that money is going to a charity is enough," says Ruffman.

In addition, the company has received 300 corporate orders, of which 15% of the retail price, after VAT, goes to a charity of the company's choice or is split among the 25 charities which have signed up with the site. NSPCC is one of those charities. In 1999, it only sold £1,000 worth of cards through charitycards.co.uk, but this year it's already nearer £5,000.

Evans says it's a good deal. However, she points out that no matter how big internet sales become, charities' preferred sales technique will remain the most old fashioned method - volunteers selling to family, friends and neighbours.

"They act as an unpaid sales force and we can't praise them enough," she says. "They require no marketing spend, so more money goes to charity."

How to decide what to buy from the mountain of charity Christmas cards on offer
Jonathan Sale

My wife is not impressed. "I've got this great dove," I tell her. "Produced by the Samaritans, 10 for £2.95." She snaps back: "No doves. If it's a Christmas card, it's got to have the nativity on it. Angels, mainly. Preferably by Fra Angelico."

The crucial information on any card received in our household is not the design, nor even the sender, but the charity it sponsors. Or does it - shock horror - have no charitable link at all?

Charity cards cost us about £114m - before shelling out for stamps - and make up an estimated 230m of the 700m cards bought at Christmas, according to Neville Bass, chief executive of the Charity Christmas Card Council. He says: "The whole cake is not getting that much bigger, but the charity slice is steadily growing."

This is just as well. Christmas greetings cards can contribute a substantial chunk of a charity's annual income. Unicef, which 50 years ago was the first to use them as a fund raiser, made £1.3m profit from last year's UK sales of 2.5m cards; its profit ratio of more than 50% is made possible by having massive global sales (155m) and its own distribution network. Oxfam sells more than 15m cards and makes 35% on those sold in its own shops.

A high street store tends to hand over a lower percentage to the charities but brings their cards before the eyes of a vaster public. In general, a charity keeps as profit between 10% and 15% of the cost of each card.

Cards for Good Causes offers the widest choice, with more than 260 outlets in churches and similar temporary outlets. Staffed largely by volunteers, it shifts more than £5m-worth of small pieces of festive cardboard. The largest branch of this charitable chain is to be found just inside the doors of Holy Trinity church in Sloane Street, London SW1. Last year, it clocked up sales of £350,000 - or about 1.25m cards.

It is now in the middle of its peak period and business is brisk when I pop in to look for angelic designs for my fundamentalist wife.

Patrick Tynte-Hickey, one of the three paid staff among the volunteers, has just what I want: scenes of the Christmas Story, by Angelico, featuring nine bright nativity panels and the Angel Gabriel in pole position.

"This is the best-selling card," declares Tynte-Hickey. "The reason is that nobody else has used this image before. It is well reproduced. And it is for a high-profile charity - Macmillan Cancer Relief." If the design has a fault it is that it is a bit too religious for some customers, to judge by the Sloane Ranger of mature years declaring to her friend: "I want a design which isn't too in-your-face, such as a Christmas pudding."

Holy Trinity's stalls display several cards each from 68 different charities. How on earth do we make a choice? "People ask for their favourite charity and then look at the others," Tynte-Hickey says. "And 50% start at A and work their way to the end."

I start at A: the Army Benevolent Fund, which offers First Light, Slad 1997. Trying to be benevolent about this, I should say that the design features a landscape and two dwellings with holes in the roof. Perhaps the follow-up, Slad 2000, would show the holes being repaired.

It is certainly the best picture of dawn at Slad on display. My award for Best Picture Painted by a Duchess is in aid of Help the Hospices; Christmas Morning is its stirring theme. "Painted by the Duchess of Norfolk, chairman of the association", this depicts a church, snow, improbably rolling hills and sheep plus shepherd. Apparently, the previous Duchess of Norfolk used to paint the Help the Hospices cards too, so it clearly goes with the territory.

Competition for the Best Robin Card is intense. Arthritis Research offers Restful Robin, and Red Cross has Christmas Robin. Cancer Research depicts Festive Robin in a dark blue circular card - a round robin, in fact.

The Elizabeth Finn Trust, for "people from a professional background who have fallen on hard times", brings us Robin on Holly. Also fluttering about: Robin on a Postbox (Fight for Sight); Robin on a Fence (Mind); Robin on Snow (Home Farm Trust); and Robin & Holly (Parkinson's Disease Society). But the Best Robin Award goes to Red, Red Robin from the Notting Hill Housing Trust, a cartoon treatment of a happy, replete-looking bird.

Shelter's Mother and Child, by Picasso, is hard to beat on the artistic and ethical front. I am tempted by the charity Marriage Care, which "supports people through the best and worst times" - Christmas springs to mind - but I finally plump for the dove pack after all. It has the Samaritans' address on it, which could be very handy at this time of year.

 Cards for Good Causes is on 01962-862272.
