webTitle: Class still biggest killer

fields.headline: Class still biggest killer
fields.standfirst: Reduction in child poverty is the key to health equality
fields.trailText: Reduction in child poverty is the key to health equality
fields.body:
A grim reminder that children are dying in Britain as a direct result of poverty will come tomorrow from charity Barnardo's. Earlier this week, other research suggested that the Labour government's progress in reducing inequality had been painfully slow.

The Barnardo's study, on health inequalities, will say that children from the lowest social class are twice as likely to die by age 15 as are children from the highest class. The former are nine times more likely to die in a house fire and are disproportionately exposed to risk of fatal accidents - the main childhood killer.

The study, by Helen Roberts, the charity's head of research, will maintain that the only long-term answer is a direct attack on inequalities of income and wealth. The cost of eliminating child poverty would be 0.48% of GNP.

"Projects dealing with the effects of poverty ... are an Elastoplast on a gaping wound," says Roberts. Although such schemes could be beneficial, especially if the people running them paid more attention to research showing what works, a focus on them could be used "to avoid having to confront the reality" that child poverty can be reduced by political and economic action.

"Inequalities in health can only be fundamentally tackled by policies that reduce poverty and income inequality," says Roberts. "That means poor people getting more money."

A separate report on Monday analysed 50 poverty indicators and found that nine deteriorated last year, while 17 improved. The report, published by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, the social policy research body, said the number of adults in homes where disposable income was less than 40% of the national average had increased 500,000 since the election. But that was based on 1998 data - before introduction of the minimum wage and working families tax credit.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, has promised to lift a million children out of poverty by the next general election and a second million during a second Labour term. Yet that would still leave 2m children living in poverty in 2005.

The Barnardo's report will provide some positive ideas about what can be done pending achievement of the government's objective to eradicate child poverty by 2020. "The biggest differences to child health," it will say, "will not be made by the NHS, but by changes in other sectors [including] education, housing and public policy."

Environmental improvements are likely to be more effective than pamphlets and safety education in reducing accidents. Roberts says: "Treating children and parents as defective in child safety matters is as ineffective as treating airline passengers as defective in air safety."

As an example of an effective scheme, Barnardo's cites the charity's Tullycarnet project in a deprived part of Belfast. By improving the subway between a housing estate and its local primary school, children were encouraged to avoid crossing dangerous roads. This produced better results than road safety training.

Other effective initiatives have included: pre-school provision by well-trained staff, bearing in mind that poor day care may do more harm than good; and community cafes and promotion of cheap food in the community, bringing more promising results in improvement of nutrition than those achieved by "didactic" nutrition education.

 What Works in Reducing Inequalities in Child Health is available at £12 on 01268-520224.

webTitle: Council's disabled adaptations 'scandal'

fields.headline: Insult to injury
fields.standfirst: Council's disabled adaptations 'scandal'
fields.trailText: Council's disabled adaptations 'scandal'
fields.body:
Local government ombudsman Jerry White has branded North Warwickshire council's behaviour "scandalous", following the authority's refusal to pay £4,500 compensation to a couple whose home it failed to provide with mandatory disabled adaptations. The case highlights the ombudsman's lack of power to enforce findings.

Six months after his initial call for compensation was ignored by North Warwickshire, a second report from White is calling on the council to fulfil his recommended remedy for the injustice.

White upheld the couple's initial complaint that the council failed to comply with its statutory duty when dealing with their application for adaptations to their council property to enable the wife, who is registered disabled, to continue living there. As a result of the failure, the couple spent more than two years living in unsuitable conditions.

The ombudsman found maladministration causing injustice, and recommended the council pay the complainants £4,500, offer them the choice of adaptations or suitable rehousing, and review its procedures for disabled adaptations for council-owned properties.

The Labour-run council agreed to carry out the adaptations as soon as possible, but declined to pay compensation on grounds that the couple had refused an offer of alternative accommodation and that compensation would have to come from its disabled facilities budget.

In a further report, White says: "It was for Mr and Mrs North [not their real names] to be persuaded that any offer of alternative accommodation, given their personal circumstances and given Mrs North's needs as a disabled person was acceptable ... and I see no reason why the compensation should be met from the budget set aside for people with disabilities. The council's intentions to do so adds insult to injury and is further discrimination against disabled people in its area."

North Warwickshire is declining to respond. Peter Oliver, director of administration, says: "We will be considering the report at a meeting of housing services in January which will make recommendations to full council."

Should the council stick to its guns, the ombudsman will be powerless to make it cough up. While the couple may be able to challenge the council through a judicial review, on the rare occasions when councils refuse to accept the ombudsman's recommendations - four cases out of 33,000 in the past two years - the ombudsman cannot legally force them.

Surprisingly, White is the first to jump to the defence of what amounts to a voluntary system. "Lots of people would like our decisions to be legally binding, but I believe it would make the investigative process much harder if elected members felt they had no choice but to abide by our decisions," he says. "Currently most councils willingly comply with our investigations and the vast majority comply with the recommendations. If it were more legalistic, we would not have a such a high success rate."

White says that councils have a change of heart in half of all cases where a second report is issued. To assist North Warwickshire's thought process, he has sent copies of his further report to the minister for disabled people and the disability rights commission.

If all else fails, the ombudsman can require the council to publish a statement in a local newspaper setting out why he considers the authority's response to be unsatisfactory. White says: "The anger of local people is often the best means to get a democratically elected body to change their minds."

"Lots of people would like our decisions to be legally binding, but I believe it would make the investigative process much harder if elected members felt they had no choice but to abide by our decisions," he says. "Currently most councils willingly comply with our investigations and the vast majority comply with the recommendations. If it were more legalistic, we would not have a such a high success rate." White says that councils have a change of heart in half of all cases where a second report is issued. To assist North Warwickshire's thought process, he has sent copies of his further report to the minister for disabled people and the disability rights commission. If all else fails, the ombudsman can require the council to publish a statement in a local newspaper setting out why he considers the authority's response to be unsatisfactory. White says: "The anger of local people is often the best means to get a democratically elected body to change their minds."

webTitle: Assessments focus on the future

fields.headline: Assessments focus on the future
fields.trailText: Analysis: Now that the NHS "winter crisis" seems a self-fulfilling prophecy, hospital workers must feel as if trapped in the headlights of a speeding train
fields.body:
Now that the NHS "winter crisis" seems a self-fulfilling prophecy, hospital workers must feel as if trapped in the headlights of a speeding train. But today at least they can set aside the apocalyptic predictions, and the tabloid talk of "third world wards", and focus on the first of what will be the most comprehensive assessments of the quality of the nation's health care.

The findings are not at all bad. Judging by these first three reports, hospital care has undoubted room for improvement but is not at all the outdated, insensitive and broken down service of media caricature.

The City Hospitals Sunderland trust is judged to have a "range of systems to support a high standard of patient care" and a "strong performance culture". The Chesterfield and North Derbyshire Royal trust is said to have "built a good foundation" and to have "a number of strengths". And the Southampton University Hospitals trust is found to be "making good progress", with an ambitious programme to reshape services across health and social care boundaries.

But the reviews have also highlighted clear failings. Although Sunderland emerges the best of the three, there are doubts about its "prevailing style"; Chesterfield is told to give priority to explaining and reducing its "significantly higher than average" death rates; and Southampton, which plainly has most to do, is reprimanded for inability to assure acceptable care standards on some wards.

"At the time of the review," says the commission for health improve ment (CHI) report on Southampton, "CHI had serious concerns about the quality of care given to trauma and orthopaedic patients. Management of clinical staff on the wards was deficient, junior doctors lacked direction and supervision from consultants, and nurses were under constant pressure."

Over the next four years, the commission is to assess the "clinical governance" of every NHS body in England and Wales. This is the core of the role of the new health watchdog, which also has a lesser brief to be sent into trusts in difficulties to troubleshoot. Because its first published reports, last month, fell under the latter heading - on past abuse of patients at the North Lakeland Healthcare trust and the death of a patient after a blunder at the Carmarthenshire trust - the commission is likely to be saddled for some time with a "hit squad" image.

As Dame Deirdre Hine, who chairs the commission, recently said: "Very early on - far too early for our own comfort - we were asked to take on two investigations."

The trusts in today's reports were chosen at random, according to the commission, and were subject to a 24-week review process, including a visit by a team of NHS staff and others. The team which went to Southampton comprised a trust chief executive, a general manager, a nurse director, a manager of cancer services, a consultant radiologist, a consultant anaesthetist and, as lay member, a management consultant in health and social care. Lay members of the two other teams were a teacher and a social worker.

The teams observed practice at close hand. The Chesterfield report says: "Our observations at night revealed a significant amount of controllable noise. For example, CHI heard telephones with loud rings, frequently used doors that bang shut and members of staff with noisy shoes."

Patients and carers were also asked about their experiences. Standards of food and cleanliness were common complaints, but the overriding grievance was waiting times.

One Southampton patient said: "I attended clinic, sat and waited one-and-a-half hours only to be told this clinic was now being cancelled, with no explanation why." At Chesterfield, a patient who had been waiting to see a nurse said: "One hour went by; still I hadn't seen her. Eventually I asked a member of staff I'd noticed chatting to other nurses - and it was her!"

Far more positively, another Chesterfield patient wrote: "I was very surprised at being admitted to hospital at 6pm. Immediate treatment as soon as I arrived. The doctors and nurses were sympathetic and reassuring. A meal was provided, even at 8pm at night."

Prior to publication of today's reports, the trusts have had an opportunity to address criticisms. At Southampton, "immediate action" is said to have been taken in the trauma and orthopaedic areas, including appointment of a senior clinical nurse to improve leadership. At Chesterfield, a decision has been taken to recruit a statistician to help discover the reasons for the trust's high mortality rates.

Chesterfield's action plan comprises 28 points; Southampton's runs to 32 pages. All the action plans, like the review reports themselves, will be available to the public. As Avril Johns, Chesterfield's chief executive, says: "The developments in the plan show we are committed to better clinical services and high standards of care."

All three trusts report satisfaction with the review process. Johns describes it as "valuable and challenging"; Peter Campion, head of public relations at Southampton, says of its report: "It's fair, it's balanced, in terms of showing a busy organisation that has achieved a lot but obviously has more to do."

At Sunderland, Carol Harries, director of corporate affairs, echoes the other trusts in saying that CHI has come up with "no surprises". But she adds: "While we have numerous outside bodies coming in, like the [medical] royal colleges and district audit, we have never before had any single body looking at a whole range of things across the trust. That's the value."

But the trusts are braced for some selective representations. "We are a £130m trust and had an audit report exemplary in terms of financial procedures, but it mentioned a £167 catering fiddle," Harries recalls. "People outside picked it up as 'major fraud at local hospital'."

 The reports on the Sunderland, Chesterfield and Southampton trusts will today be posted on the CHI website at www.doh.gov.uk/chi or are available free on 020-7448 9200

webTitle: Warning for housing charities over competitive behaviour

fields.headline: Strength in numbers
fields.standfirst: Warning for housing charities over competitive behaviour
fields.trailText: Warning for housing charities over competitive behaviour
fields.body:
Housing charities must stop competing against each other and colluding in a funding merry-go-round if they are serious about improving the lives of the people they are supposed to be serving, a leading housing expert will tonight warn.

Richard Best, director of the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, the social policy research body, argues: "Too much time and energy has been spent in competitive pursuits when talents could be better used by acting in concert. Housing charities have competed with other charities for donations from the public, competed in winning bids for government funds - they even have had to compete for the ear of a minister."

Best, former director of what is now the National Housing Federation, will be speaking to an invited audience of guests celebrating the 40th anniversary of the Housing Association's Charitable Trust (Hact). He welcomes the achievements of social housing over the past four decades, which have meant that only a tiny proportion of tenants now live in poor conditions and overcrowding, but he will also deliver a less palatable message: that the sector needs to take a hard look at itself.

"Whether it be drug and alcohol abuse, family difficulties that have driven young single people to leave home, racial attacks, bullying or neighbourhood nuisance - the answers lie in social housing landlords cooperating with each other, their residents and other agencies," Best insists. "We own the properties, we have the money. But we can't work alone and make decisions at a distance from the very people experiencing the problems."

While Best welcomes much in the government's housing green paper, from fostering mixed communities to stimulating resident involvement, he is calling on housing charities to join with other agencies to challenge government where policies are clearly failing.

"Housing charities with older residents need to risk the wrath of government in pointing out that very substantial increases in public funding will be needed to meet the care needs of poorer elderly people in the next 40 years," Best says. "There's a lot of sweeping under the carpet as elderly people don't count for very much in terms of votes and they don't make a fuss."

Hact, which distributes £1m a year to voluntary organisations working on housing-related projects, is using its 40th birthday to review and re-focus its role. But it is determined to retain its community remit. "Supporting partnerships and networks is the way forward," says Heather Petch, Hact's director. "But it is vital that small organisations are not swallowed up as they reflect diversity and encourage the active involvement of people in need of, and using, the services."

webTitle: The benefit of hospital reviews

fields.headline: Dream teams
fields.standfirst: Some still fear that the commission for health improvement is a 'hit squad'. But as its first hospital reviews come out today,  Peter Homa, head of the new watchdog, argues that only good can come of closely examining the NHS
fields.trailText: Some still fear that the commission for health improvement is a 'hit squad'. But as its first hospital reviews come out today, Peter Homa, head of the new watchdog, argues that only good can come of closely examining the NHS
fields.body:
I have a vision where, in four years' time, when a patient is sent by a GP for a hospital appointment, they will know that an independent assessment has been made of that hospital and that the report is available to the public.

For hospitals in Chesterfield, Southampton and Sunderland, that vision is a now a reality.

Today, the commission for health improvement publishes the reports of its reviews of those hospitals - the beginning of a four-year programme of reviews that will cover every hospital, health authority, primary care trust and NHS trust in England and Wales.

The reports look at the issues that affect the quality of care patients receive, asking key questions. Are staff up-to-date with the latest clinical developments? Are junior staff properly supervised? Do the hospitals know how well they treat patients - and are they comparing themselves with similar hospitals? Do patients feel fully informed about their treatment?

These may seem obvious issues, but it is only recently that the NHS has had a legal duty to guarantee the quality of care it provides. For a long time, trust boards concentrated on how much treatment they were pro viding and what it was costing, with an assumption that quality was being looked after.

The three hospitals we report on today are well run; they all have areas that demonstrate very good practice in the health service; and they all have aspects that need improvement. In writing the reports, we have tried to present a picture of the hospitals that their local communities and staff would recognise.

Unsurprisingly, these pictures are a blend of strength and areas for improvement. My hope is that, in conveying our reports to local communities, local news and broadcast journalists will reflect that balance.

Each of the hospitals we report on today has produced a comprehensive action plan to address the issues the report raises. These action plans are very important. They give local people a way of being sure that the hospitals have taken our reports seriously and are doing something about them.

But it should not only be the staff of those hospitals and their communities who are interested in today's reports.

I hope that people everywhere will read them and use them to ask questions about their local health services and what they are doing to improve the quality of care they offer to patients. I also hope that health service staff across the country use them to help assess their own care of patients.

The commission has set out a bold aim - to bring about demonstrable improvement in patient care in the NHS. Our first three reports represent a major force for that improvement.

 Peter Homa will be answering questions online at 2.30pm today about the work of the CHI, at www.SocietyGuardian.co.uk Peter Homa is chief executive of the commission for health improvement

webTitle: Charities go online to sell Christmas cards

fields.headline: Charities go online to sell Christmas cards
fields.standfirst: While enthusiastic about the possibilities of selling cards on their internet sites, most charities describe this Christmas as a 'test year', writes Alison Benjamin
fields.trailText: While enthusiastic about the possibilities of selling cards on their internet sites, most charities describe this Christmas as a 'test year', writes Alison Benjamin.
fields.body:
For the first time, many charities have put their cards up for sale on their internet sites this Christmas. While enthusiastic about the potential, especially to attract younger buyers, they describe 2000 as a "test year".

"We believe it's a growing market but we'll have to wait until next Christmas to see by how much," said Julie Evans, NSPCC mail order marketing manager.

Her counterpart at the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds is also upbeat after an autumn survey of its members revealed that 42% were internet-friendly. But again, she said it was too early to assess the volume of online Christmas sales.

Cards for Good Causes and Card Aid, run by the Charities Advisory Trust (CAT), have been slow to embrace new technology. Both have websites detailing the work of the organisations and the charities they support, but as yet you cannot buy their cards online. "It is something we hope to be able to offer in future," said Cards for Good Causes.

Hilary Blume, director of CAT - which has 40 Card Aid retail outlets - is more dismissive. "Online buying is just mail order by a different name, and mail order has only captured 10% of the Christmas card business," she said.

Newcastle-based Greetings Card Company runs the website www.charitycards.co.uk. In its first year it sold just 7,000 packs of Christmas cards and made £25,000, of which 66% of the retail price, less VAT, went to those charities that had sold their cards to the company to sell online. This year, managing director William Ruffman reported a fivefold increase in sales. He said his customers are predominately women whose sales choice is influenced more by the card's design than the charity it supports. "The fact that money is going to a charity is enough," said Mr Ruffman.

In addition, the company has received 300 corporate orders, of which 15% of the retail price, after VAT, goes to a charity of the company's choice or is split among the 25 charities which have signed up with the site. NSPCC is one of those charities. In 1999, it only sold £1,000 worth of cards through charitycards.co.uk, but this year it's already nearer £5,000.

Ms Evans said it's a good deal. However, she pointed out that no matter how big internet sales become, charities' preferred sales technique will remain the most old fashioned method - volunteers selling to family, friends and neighbours.

"They act as an unpaid sales force and we can't praise them enough," she said. "They require no marketing spend, so more money goes to charity."

webTitle: Guide to choosing your charity Christmas cards

fields.headline: Guide to choosing your charity Christmas cards
fields.standfirst: This year shops are offering a wide range of Christmas cards sponsored by various charities. Jonathan Sale sifts through the options
fields.trailText: This year shops are offering a wide range of Christmas cards sponsored by various charities. Jonathan Sale sifts through the options.
fields.body:
My wife was not impressed. "I've got this great dove," I told her. "Produced by the Samaritans, 10 for £2.95." She snapped back: "No doves. If it's a Christmas card, it's got to have the nativity on it. Angels, mainly. Preferably by Fra Angelico."

The crucial information on any card received in our household is not the design, nor even the sender, but the charity it sponsors. Or does it - shock horror - have no charitable link at all?

Charity cards cost us about £114m - before shelling out for stamps - and make up an estimated 230m of the 700m cards bought at Christmas, according to Neville Bass, chief executive of the Charity Christmas Card Council. He said: "The whole cake is not getting that much bigger, but the charity slice is steadily growing."

This is just as well. Christmas greetings cards can contribute a substantial chunk of a charity's annual income. Unicef, which 50 years ago was the first to use them as a fundraiser, made £1.3m profit from last year's UK sales of 2.5m cards; its profit ratio of more than 50% is made possible by having massive global sales (155m) and its own distribution network. Oxfam sells more than 15m cards and makes 35% on those sold in its own shops.

A high street store tends to hand over a lower percentage to the charities but brings their cards before the eyes of a vaster public. In general, a charity keeps as profit between 10% and 15% of the cost of each card.

Cards for Good Causes offers the widest choice, with more than 260 outlets in churches and similar temporary outlets. Staffed largely by volunteers, it shifts more than £5m worth of small pieces of festive cardboard. The largest branch of this charitable chain is to be found just inside the doors of Holy Trinity church in Sloane Street, London SW1. Last year, it clocked up sales of £350,000 - or about 1.25m cards.

It is now in the middle of its peak period and business was brisk when I popped in to look for angelic designs for my fundamentalist wife.

Patrick Tynte-Hickey, one of the three paid staff among the volunteers, had just what I wanted: scenes of the Christmas Story, by Angelico, featuring nine bright nativity panels and the Angel Gabriel in pole position.

"This is the best-selling card," he declared. "The reason is that nobody else has used this image before. It is well reproduced. And it is for a high-profile charity - Macmillan Cancer Relief." If the design has a fault it is that it is a bit too religious for some customers, to judge by the Sloane Ranger of mature years declaring to her friend: "I want a design which isn't too in your face, such as a Christmas pudding."

Holy Trinity's stalls display several cards, from 68 different charities. How on earth do we make a choice? "People ask for their favourite charity and then look at the others," Mr Tynte-Hickey said. "And 50% start at A and work their way to the end."

I started at A: the Army Benevolent Fund, which offers First Light, Slad 1997. Trying to be benevolent about this, I should say that the design features a landscape and two dwellings with holes in the roof. Perhaps the follow-up, Slad 2000, would show the holes being repaired.

It is certainly the best picture of dawn at Slad on display. My award for Best Picture Painted by a Duchess is in aid of Help the Hospices; Christmas Morning is its stirring theme."Painted by the Duchess of Norfolk, chairman of the association", this depicts a church, snow, improbably rolling hills and sheep plus shepherd. Apparently, the previous Duchess of Norfolk used to paint the Help the Hospices cards too, so it clearly goes with the territory.

Competition for the Best Robin Card is intense. Arthritis Research offers Restful Robin, and Red Cross has Christmas Robin. Cancer Research depicts Festive Robin in a dark blue circular card - a round robin, in fact.

The Elizabeth Finn Trust, for "people from a professional background who have fallen on hard times", brings us Robin on Holly. Also fluttering about: Robin on a Postbox (Fight for Sight); Robin on a Fence (Mind); Robin on Snow (Home Farm Trust); and Robin & Holly (Parkinson's Disease Society). But the Best Robin Award goes to Red, Red Robin from the Notting Hill Housing Trust, a cartoon treatment of a happy, replete-looking bird.

Shelter's Mother and Child, by Picasso, is hard to beat on the artistic and ethical front. I am tempted by the charity Marriage Care, which "supports people through the best and worst times" - Christmas springs to mind - but I finally plump for the dove pack after all. It has the Samaritans' address on it, which could be very handy at this time of year.

 Cards for Good Causes is on 01962-862272.

Charity cards cost us about £114m - before shelling out for stamps - and make up an estimated 230m of the 700m cards bought at Christmas, according to Neville Bass, chief executive of the Charity Christmas Card Council. He said: "The whole cake is not getting that much bigger, but the charity slice is steadily growing." This is just as well. Christmas greetings cards can contribute a substantial chunk of a charity's annual income. Unicef, which 50 years ago was the first to use them as a fundraiser, made £1.3m profit from last year's UK sales of 2.5m cards; its profit ratio of more than 50% is made possible by having massive global sales (155m) and its own distribution network. Oxfam sells more than 15m cards and makes 35% on those sold in its own shops. A high street store tends to hand over a lower percentage to the charities but brings their cards before the eyes of a vaster public. In general, a charity keeps as profit between 10% and 15% of the cost of each card. Cards for Good Causes offers the widest choice, with more than 260 outlets in churches and similar temporary outlets. Staffed largely by volunteers, it shifts more than £5m worth of small pieces of festive cardboard. The largest branch of this charitable chain is to be found just inside the doors of Holy Trinity church in Sloane Street, London SW1. Last year, it clocked up sales of £350,000 - or about 1.25m cards. It is now in the middle of its peak period and business was brisk when I popped in to look for angelic designs for my fundamentalist wife. Patrick Tynte-Hickey, one of the three paid staff among the volunteers, had just what I wanted: scenes of the Christmas Story, by Angelico, featuring nine bright nativity panels and the Angel Gabriel in pole position. "This is the best-selling card," he declared. "The reason is that nobody else has used this image before. It is well reproduced. And it is for a high-profile charity - Macmillan Cancer Relief." If the design has a fault it is that it is a bit too religious for some customers, to judge by the Sloane Ranger of mature years declaring to her friend: "I want a design which isn't too in your face, such as a Christmas pudding." Holy Trinity's stalls display several cards, from 68 different charities. How on earth do we make a choice? "People ask for their favourite charity and then look at the others," Mr Tynte-Hickey said. "And 50% start at A and work their way to the end." I started at A: the Army Benevolent Fund, which offers First Light, Slad 1997. Trying to be benevolent about this, I should say that the design features a landscape and two dwellings with holes in the roof. Perhaps the follow-up, Slad 2000, would show the holes being repaired. It is certainly the best picture of dawn at Slad on display. My award for Best Picture Painted by a Duchess is in aid of Help the Hospices; Christmas Morning is its stirring theme."Painted by the Duchess of Norfolk, chairman of the association", this depicts a church, snow, improbably rolling hills and sheep plus shepherd. Apparently, the previous Duchess of Norfolk used to paint the Help the Hospices cards too, so it clearly goes with the territory. Competition for the Best Robin Card is intense. Arthritis Research offers Restful Robin, and Red Cross has Christmas Robin. Cancer Research depicts Festive Robin in a dark blue circular card - a round robin, in fact. The Elizabeth Finn Trust, for "people from a professional background who have fallen on hard times", brings us Robin on Holly. Also fluttering about: Robin on a Postbox (Fight for Sight); Robin on a Fence (Mind); Robin on Snow (Home Farm Trust); and Robin & Holly (Parkinson's Disease Society). But the Best Robin Award goes to Red, Red Robin from the Notting Hill Housing Trust, a cartoon treatment of a happy, replete-looking bird. Shelter's Mother and Child, by Picasso, is hard to beat on the artistic and ethical front. I am tempted by the charity Marriage Care, which "supports people through the best and worst times" - Christmas springs to mind - but I finally plump for the dove pack after all. It has the Samaritans' address on it, which could be very handy at this time of year.  Cards for Good Causes is on 01962-862272.

webTitle: Name and shame campaign has failed reformed paedophiles

fields.headline: Name and shame campaign has failed reformed paedophiles
fields.standfirst: The tabloids' "name and shame" campaign has not helped the safe return of reformed paedophiles to society.  Rosemary Harthill  looks at a new approach to a risky business
fields.trailText: The tabloids' "name and shame" campaign has not helped the safe return of reformed paedophiles to society. Rosemary Harthill looks at a new approach to a risky business
fields.body:
It's Saturday night in a church hall. But this is no youth club dance. Nor is it a typical church meeting. Instead, five people are quietly meeting to help a paedophile reintegrate into the community.

This is the first British meeting of a "circle of support and accountability". Together, the members of the circle are working out a mutual agreement which will reduce risk - risk to the community, risk to his victims and risk to himself.

The circle model has worked successfully in Canada for six years.If this new model works here too, it could radically improve the care and supervision on release of some of the more dangerous of Britain's 100,000-plus convicted sex offenders.

Darren (not his real name) is 36. A former alcoholic, over 20 years he has collected a number of convictions for indecently assaulting adolescent females and young adult women. After six months in prison for sexual abuse, he underwent 15 months' intensive therapy at Wolvercote clinic in Epsom, Surrey, which focuses on reducing abuse by assessing and treating sex offenders. His time at the clinic ended last month.

Donald Findlater, clinic manager at Wolvercote, regularly sees men leave the clinic or prison who are going out to nobody. "Their former family and friends - if they ever had any - may well have fallen by the wayside," he said. "Without a job, or other support, some end up sleeping in night shelters, living on the streets, and returning to drink."

Many of those obliged by the terms of their release from prison to keep in contact with the hard-pressed probation service may have only very limited contact - weekly meetings initially, reducing to monthly meetings after a relatively short period.

Findlater reckoned there must be a better way to reduce the risk of re-offending. Last June, he attended a workshop run by the Religious Society of Friends in Britain, the Quakers. Five Canadians addressed representatives from the Home Office, police, probation services, church groups and charities. The Canadians described a new scheme set up to deal with similar problems in Canada. Backed by the Mennonite Church and founded in Ontario, the scheme offers support for offenders with no one else to turn to, and tries to reassure public fears by encouraging members of the local community to play a part in the rehabilitation process.

It is a practical response to the kind of fear generated by the indiscriminate attacks on paedophiles and others triggered by the News of the World campaign last August "naming and shaming" released paedophiles.

The circles usually consist of between four and six people. A covenant is drawn up among all the members of the circle, detailing their expectations and what happens if they are broken. The "core member" (the sex offender) must state that he is committed to "no more victims of sexual abuse".

Knowing Darren would need support when he left the Wolvercote this month, Findlater decided to set up a pilot scheme himself. "I'm an impatient sort, and I wanted to see something live and kicking," he said.

He began by phoning three or four church leaders he knew in the area where Darren was going to live. "I told them I'd got this crazy idea about how the church could help sex offenders live safely in their community, and what did they think?"

He then introduced the idea to a wider group of their contacts. "They were very positive about the concept, but remarkably pessimistic about finding volunteers with that much time to commit."

In the first few weeks the core member meets the group every week and talks to at least one member every day. The circle may continue for one, two or three years, though members may change.

Volunteers do not need social work or counselling experience. "We wanted people who had a life, and were willing to share that life," said Mr Findlater. "It helps if they are wise, and a bit cautious, people with their feet on the ground, not too prurient, and not easily shocked. It's not a mind-delving exercise. It's befriending."

In October he went to see for himself the Canadian scheme working. He and the coordinator in Toronto spent a day out at Niagara Falls with a former sex offender. Later they all dropped in to see the coordinator's sister, then went on to eat pizza at a party.

"It's not about giving them a bit of your time, it's more about doing things together whether playing computer games, table tennis, or going for a walk. Sometimes this creates community that the core member may never have had before."

He says he approached church people to help find volunteers because of the Christian belief in the value of every human being, and that everyone could be encouraged to make a constructive contribution. But he is absolutely clear that joining a circle is not an evangelistic activity.

"We don't want people coming along with the aim of saving someone's soul. Not because I don't believe it, but I don't think it's a helpful starting point. Instead, it's closer to the words of Jesus: 'I was in prison, and you visited me'."

He also reckons the churches have a lot to learn. "They need to exercise more caution, and open their eyes a bit wider. There's evidence that church communities contain a higher rate of sex offenders than the community as a whole. I hope a bi-product of this might be more vigilance in their own communities." In the future, he says he would welcome volunteers of all faiths as well as non-believers.

Four volunteers between 35 and 50 emerged for Darren's circle: Mr Findlater himself, a quantity surveyor, a community worker and a church minister. Five detailed training sessions covered the legal and social context, and information about the behaviour of sex offenders. They also covered the purpose and aims of developing a personal plan for the core member to prevent re-offending, and a background briefing on Darren himself.

The female member of the group decided to meet Darren only in public places, not at her home. There was also the question of who they could share their involvement with. One said sadly that they felt at present, given the feeling against paedophiles, they couldn't tell anyone at all, outside close family. "It is sad," said Mr Findlater, "but I hope over time that will change."

Out of the recent church hall meeting, Darren's group has come to a framework agreement. In pursuit of the goal of not re-offending, Darren has now committed himself to meeting circle members regularly, not drinking, and keeping any appointments made on his behalf with the probation service or the local drugs and alcohol agency. He has also agreed to continue efforts to get work. In return, the other members of the circle have agreed to give him regular and sustained support.

If Darren starts breaking the agreement, the group will discuss this with him at an emergency meeting. If a problem continues, the circle will inform the local sex offender registration police office or other statutory agency. The circle's job is not supervision: it is to help supervision through close contact.

Warning signs could include starting to drink, missing appointments, stopping shaving or bathing, using inappropriate language, or showing signs of depression or withdrawal.

In Canada, some agreements have been broken. But early evidence shows a reduction in re-offending. For those high-risk offenders who have been in one of the 30 circles of support in Canada over a two-year period, the re-offending rate so far is down to 10%. That's compared with the usual level of 21.5%.

The Society of Friends last month hosted a second follow-up meeting with representatives of the Home Office and other agencies. The Home Office is believed now to be considering setting aside some funding for further pilots under the programme of its dangerous offenders' unit. In the meantime, a partnership of Thames Valley Police, the Society of Friends, and the Ox-Bucks Probation Service is pursuing whether some government funding for restorative justice work with adults might be available for a pilot along circle lines beginning next spring.

"There is real interest in developing other pilots," said Helen Drewery, secretary of the Quaker crime and community justice committee. "But everyone's a bit twitchy. One worry is the fear of what happens if a high-profile case were to go horribly wrong, and discredit the idea. But everything has some risks. Wearing a car seat belt might trap you in a fire but that's no reason not to wear one. And on the Canadian evidence, something is more likely to go horribly wrong without a circle of support."

webTitle: Reviews: Les Arts Florissants

fields.headline: Les Arts Florissants
fields.standfirst:
Guildhall
London
****
fields.trailText:
Guildhall

London

****
fields.body:
Marc-Antoine Charpentier is a composer close to William Christie's heart - the conductor's Parisian ensemble, Les Arts Florissants, is named after one of Charpentier's many choral works. It's a shame that Charpentier is remembered today chiefly for the rather pompous opening of one of his Te Deum settings. For, as this concert of his Christmas music showed, there's a lot more to his writing than that.

This 17th-century composer had a keen ear for the dramatic and pictorial potential of the words he set to avoid boring his listeners. And he embraced the popular side of Christmas, weaving 11 carol tunes into his Messe de Minuit - a lively work, even though to recognise many of the tunes you'd have to be a 17th-century Frenchman.

But it was the more subdued or mystical images of his texts that brought out the best in Charpentier. Not for nothing was he a pupil of Carissimi, a composer who knew a thing or two about making harmonies twist and turn. In the second work on the programme, In Nativitatem Domini Canticum, the slow, sustained vocal lines as the angels called for peace on earth were intertwined lovingly and irresistibly, and the incarnation as described in the Credo of the Messe de Minuit seemed truly mysterious in the right sense. The choir, with their secure intonation and warm, unfussy timbre, brought off such moments with simple style.

The orchestra, for its part, did not seem to contain any players who could be described as rank and file. Christie is an authoritative but not domineering conductor - one senses that his success with this ensemble is the result of careful nurturing and detailed rehearsal rather than excessively firm guidance during the actual performance.

Though presented under the auspices of the Barbican Centre, the concert took place in the ornate, cathedral-like setting of the Guildhall. The hall's acoustics, resonant but not excessively so, suited the whole ensemble to the ground. It couldn't disguise the reediness of some of the higher-voiced male soloists, nor could it make their Parisian Latin, with French vowels and soft Js, sound natural to English ears. But, acoustically and visually, the venue produced an atmosphere that would have been impossible to replicate in the Barbican itself.

webTitle: Review: The The

fields.headline: The The
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall
London
**
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall
London

**
fields.body:
It begins rather well. With the house lights semi-dimmed, Matt Johnson and his three hired American hands saunter on to the stage of the Royal Festival Hall. From there, sadly, the evening plummets. Since Margaret Thatcher's defenestration, Johnson has found himself a cause-free former rebel. With no windmills to tilt at, he has moved from the political to the personal with mixed (although generally fascinating) results, but ever-diminishing commercial returns.

In theory, a The The show should be a treat: a hatful of old songs, a selection from the most recent album, Nakedself, and perhaps a smattering of the Hank Williams songs Johnson covered with distinction on Hanky Panky. But Johnson, now 39, has other ideas.

The first three songs are played in virtual darkness, which seems contemptuous of the paying audience and those songs alike. Voidy Numbness - "He's all stressed up with nowhere to go" - pootles along pleasantly enough, but watching a spinning CD of Nakedself would have been more visually rewarding.

Slowly, the lighting sorts itself out (although it never reaches the level of a village hall hootenanny) and by the time of the foreboding Soul Catcher and This Is the Day, it is finally possible to see that Johnson is wearing a carney-style checked jacket.

This Is the Day is the set's high point. Johnson carefully croons this beautiful song about mundanity, while white-suited bassist Spencer Campbell adds sumptuous backing vocals and the whole 17-year-old package serves as a reminder of what a great songwriter Johnson once was. He refuses to play his other contender for posterity, Uncertain Smile.

"Does anyone here share my loathing of the advertising industry?" he asks his bemused audience before Swine Fever, oblivious to the probability that many people here probably work in it.

Johnson's band is tight, if lacking charisma. Infected rocks like the demon it always was and, of the more recent material, December Sunlight shows there is still heart in his songwriting.

Later, he peppers a lament to the demise of Ken Livingstone (the London mayoral elections seem to have passed him by) and the metamorphosis of County Hall from council building to hotel with ugly anti-Japanese sentiment.

Finally, before the excellent Heartland with its chorus of "This is the 51st state of the USA", he hoists the politically ignorant canard about Britain having surrendered its sovereignty to America after the second world war. And how does he preface this? By bragging about living in Manhattan. The man's gall is breathtaking. His show, alas, is not. Smug and dull.

webTitle: Review: Merrily We Roll Along

fields.headline: The heart-piercing, time-travelling Sondheim
fields.standfirst:
Merrily We Roll Along
Donmar Warehouse
London
****
fields.trailText:
Merrily We Roll Along

Donmar Warehouse
London

****
fields.body:
This revival of one of Stephen Sondheim's less familiar musicals is misleadingly billed as the London premiere. In fact, I have a vivid memory of seeing it played by Guildhall students at the Bloomsbury in 1983. But, pedantry aside, this is a glorious show that nails two of the prevailing myths about Sondheim: that he's a clever clogs who can't do emotion and that he has no facility for melody.

This show's blend of irony and nostalgia stems from its structure. Like the 1930s Kaufman and Hart play that inspired it, George Furth's book uses reverse chronology. It starts in 1980 with a Hollywood producer-songwriter, Franklin Shepard, advising a group of graduating students to embrace the practical. It then backtracks in time, ending in 1955, to show both how Franklin compromised his ideals and betrayed the sacred trust of friendship, in particular his close alliance with his lyricist, Charley, and his adoring chum, Mary, who has dwindled from aspiring novelist to drunken film critic.

It's a perfect structure for Sondheim, allowing him to play with various verbal and musical motifs. The lyrics constantly acquire a retrospective irony. Thus Mary, at a Hollywood party in 1979, looks through the bottom of a glass darkly and announces wryly: "These are the movers, these are the shakers", only for the recurring phrase to shed its cynicism as the evening progresses.

For all his intelligence, Sondheim also knows how to pierce the heart. For me the high point comes when Franklin and Charley, as showbiz debutants, sing Good Thing Going at a swish Manhattan cocktail party in 1962. On one level the song is a haunting romantic ballad, which Sinatra recorded, about time's corrosive effect on relationships. But it also prefigures the eventual crack-up of the writers' own partnership. And, since Charley is forced to sing it at the behest of the hostess who is out to seduce Franklin, he delivers it with simmering rage.

Like Pinter's Betrayal, the show uses reversed time to give every scene a layered irony. And, even if its assumption that Hollywood equals creative sell-out seems conventional, the form itself constantly reanimates a stock attitude. Michael Grandage's production also poignantly underscores the fact that Sondheim and Furth, who co-wrote Company, have created a musical full of lambent regret about the triumph of expediency over youthful idealism.

Samantha Spiro is particularly impressive in conveying Mary's passage from wide-eyed optimism to woozy cynicism. But Julian Ovenden also lends Franklin the right aura of debauched glamour and Daniel Evans sharply conveys the anger that underlies Charley's fierce integrity. Anna Francolini even makes the svelte temptress who leads Franklin on the downward path intriguingly unhappy rather than simply wicked. fields.bodyText: This revival of one of Stephen Sondheim's less familiar musicals is misleadingly billed as the London premiere. In fact, I have a vivid memory of seeing it played by Guildhall students at the Bloomsbury in 1983. But, pedantry aside, this is a glorious show that nails two of the prevailing myths about Sondheim: that he's a clever clogs who can't do emotion and that he has no facility for melody. This show's blend of irony and nostalgia stems from its structure. Like the 1930s Kaufman and Hart play that inspired it, George Furth's book uses reverse chronology. It starts in 1980 with a Hollywood producer-songwriter, Franklin Shepard, advising a group of graduating students to embrace the practical. It then backtracks in time, ending in 1955, to show both how Franklin compromised his ideals and betrayed the sacred trust of friendship, in particular his close alliance with his lyricist, Charley, and his adoring chum, Mary, who has dwindled from aspiring novelist to drunken film critic. It's a perfect structure for Sondheim, allowing him to play with various verbal and musical motifs. The lyrics constantly acquire a retrospective irony. Thus Mary, at a Hollywood party in 1979, looks through the bottom of a glass darkly and announces wryly: "These are the movers, these are the shakers", only for the recurring phrase to shed its cynicism as the evening progresses. webTitle: Reviews: Tobermory tonics

fields.headline: Tobermory tonics
fields.standfirst:
Mull Historical Society
Monarch
London
****
fields.trailText:
Mull Historical Society

Monarch
London

****
fields.body:
Mention the name Tobermory and you're likely to have the Wombles theme sung at you. But Mull Historical Society have reclaimed their hometown from the depths of novelty pop hell and are bent on showing there's more to Tobermory than strange creatures who collect litter.

Still, they're keeping the strange bit. Because Mull Historical Society create clever pop songs with eccentric lyrics wrapped in swooning harmonies, while snippets of the shipping forecast filter through. "Hearing the shipping forecast is like sailing home," the singer and guitarist Colin MacIntyre says wistfully, and from his effects-laden vocals as he begins I Tried, he could well be back on the island, singing through a loudspeaker to reach the Camden crowd. It's a style that gives these simple songs an otherworldly quality and, combined with an unerring way with a chorus and a delicious sense of melody, makes Mull Historical Society not-so-distant cousins of Welsh wizards Super Furry Animals.

There's also the same seductive joy in creating music. Bopping up and down on the balls of his feet, MacIntyre has an infectious belief in his sound, and an easy charm. "This got to number 106," he says by way of introducing the band's debut single, Bar Code Bypass. "It was one of those weeks when the top 106 sold unexpectedly well." It's a fantastic song that already sounds like a classic.

With a harder sound live than recorded, Mull Historical Society are the missing link between the experimental side of the Beatles and the delicately crafted rock of proteges Badfinger. But then the band get punky, with bassist Alan Malloy funking up the bassline as Automatics gives us an unlikely marriage of Andrew Gold and the Undertones, the ever-growing drum sound matching MacIntyre's speeded-up vocals. And as he plays some sweet country-tinged guitar and pleads for us all to join the Society, refusal seems impossible.

webTitle: Classical: Weill punctures the American Dream

fields.headline: Weill punctures the American Dream
fields.standfirst:
One Touch of Venus
Linbury Studio
London
****
fields.trailText:
One Touch of Venus

Linbury Studio
London

****
fields.body:
The Kurt Weill centenary celebration, which has dragged on for 18 months now, has been a messy effort. Even Weill's most ardent devotees would accept that his output is uneven, but with excessive emphasis placed on obscurities at the expense of acknowledged masterpieces, we've had little chance to re-examine the works that make him great.

Only now do we have the chance to hear One Touch of Venus, the finest score from his American period, first performed on Broadway in 1943. Mercifully, the Lost Musicals company has revived it at the Linbury, semi-staged, though with Agnes de Mille's original choreography painstakingly reconstructed and performed by dancers from the Central School of Ballet.

Weill, we are often told, assimilated happily in America after fleeing Nazi Germany, but One Touch of Venus tells a more ambivalent story. Ogden Nash's acidic text allows Weill to puncture the American Dream by looking at it through European eyes, as the classical goddess of love and sexuality arrives in New York to find it wanting. Her statue, illegally imported from Greece, comes to life amid the garish abstractions of a modern art gallery. An awkward plot convention demands she fall in love with the man who brings about her revivification, a nerdy barber called Rodney, whose views are alarmingly conventional.

At first all seems to go well. Venus gets rid of Rodney's obnoxious girlfriend and reveals her divine beneficence by organising illicit, passionate encounters for New York's inhabitants. But it all turns sour as both America's plutocracy and its normative values begin to hem Venus in.

In places, Weill's score reverts to the gritty, jazz-drenched sound of his Berlin years, as edgy waltzes and acerbic blues seditiously probe New York's superficial glitz. The best-known numbers - Speak Low and I'm A Stranger Here Myself - have remained firm favourites of cabaret divas and opera singers alike, though their force increases in context. Speak Low runs through the work like a refrain, gradually taking on a chilling irony as the relationship between Venus and Rodney comes unstuck. De Mille's choreography plays tribute to Venus's impact and origins by juxtaposing spiky modernism with European influences: regimented blocks of dancers suddenly take on the rhapsodic fluidity of Isadora Duncan; New York spivs adopt the flat-bodied, turned-in postures of Nijinsky's faun.

Lousie Gold's Venus is a sensual art nouveau siren. Michael Cantwell's Rodney struggles a bit, though he's touching and maddening by turns. There are impressive performances from Ethan Freeman as the dubious art dealer and Jessica Martin as his sassy sidekick. The whole work cries out for a full staging, though whether we shall ever get one is a different matter. Catch this if you can.

In rep until Sunday. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: Yorkshire Fund launches new VCT

fields.headline: Yorkshire Fund launches new VCT
fields.trailText: Yorkshire Fund Managers has underlined its commitment to the venture capital trust (VCT) market with the launch of a second British Smaller Companies Trust.
fields.body:
Yorkshire Fund Managers has underlined its commitment to the venture capital trust (VCT) market with the launch of a second British Smaller Companies Trust.

The fund, which requires a minimum investment of £3,000, will invest in a wide range of new British technology companies. In particular, it will target information technology, advanced engineering and life sciences.

The announcement comes less than one week after Close VCT Management launched a similar trust.

The Close Technology & General VCT will put 30% of its funds into unquoted UK technology companies. Some 50% will be invested in unquoted British companies from other sectors and the remaining 20% will be put in European and US quoted technology stocks.

VCTs are becoming more popular as the public becomes more aware of them, but financial advisers are quick to warn would-be investors that the trusts can be very high risk. Investors are attracted to them, they say, because of the tax breaks they offer, but there is no guarantee that the trusts will make an profits and you could loose your money. As such, they recommend that only seasoned investors with spare cash consider them.

The issue explained:

What are venture capital trusts?
VCTs invest in small, growing companies. They are similar to investment trusts as their shares are often traded in the stock market, but are higher risk as the companies they invest in are typically unquoted and less established.

The pros ...
Anyone can invest up to £100,000 in a VCT each year and because theyre high risk, you get 20% income tax relief on the cost of the investment. This means a £10,000 investment will reduce your income tax liability by £2,000.

Capital gains on any growth in the value of the VCT shares and any dividends paid by the trust are tax free. Capital gains tax on assets sold in the year before or after the investment are deferred.

... and the cons
There are no guarantees that the VCT will make a profit and the shares have to be held for five years, the life of the trust. VCTs are restricted to investing most of their money in small, unlisted companies that can be very volatile and can fail.

What sectors do they invest in?
Trusts do tend to be thematic, focusing on just one sector, but there will be a VCT for pretty much all investment areas, so you should find one to suit you.

When should you invest?
Because of their tax efficient nature, interest in VCTs peaks towards the end of the tax year and most new share issues are timed to coincide with it.

webTitle: Abbey vows to fight on as it spurns Lloyds £18.2bn advance

fields.headline: Abbey vows to fight on as it spurns Lloyds £18.2bn advance
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Abbey National last night rebuffed Lloyds TSB's £18.2bn friendly but "inadequate and uncertain" takeover advances for the second time
fields.body:
Abbey National last night rebuffed Lloyds TSB's £18.2bn friendly but "inadequate and uncertain" takeover advances for the second time, raising expectations that its predator was left with little option but to launch a hostile attack.

The persistence of Lloyds, which made its first approach a week ago, raises the prospect of at least 7,000 job cuts and has effectively prevented Abbey completing its month-long merger talks with Bank of Scotland.

Those talks with BoS are rumoured to put a value on Abbey's shares of £12.50 and, for the first time, Abbey revealed the terms Sir Brian Pitman, the out-going Lloyds TSB chairman, had offered to pay for Abbey, which valued each share at £12.74.

The deal, rejected by the Abbey board on grounds of "value, deliverability and regulatory risk", comprises 1.5 Lloyds TSB shares and 260p in cash - 94p higher than the £11.80 at which Abbey's shares closed last night.

Abbey made it clear that any other efforts by Sir Brian and his chief executive Peter Ellwood to make advances on similar terms would be dealt with in a similar fashion. "If they come back on these terms we will fight them vigorously," said an Abbey spokeswoman.

Lloyds TSB is thought to be prepared to increase the cash component of the offer to £3 and some industry sources believe that, at a stretch, it could pay as much as £14 for each Abbey share. At this level, the offer would be just 35p below Abbey's all-time high of £14.35 in April 1999 but likely to leave Lloyds TSB open to criticism that it was paying too much.

Lloyds TSB, which made no comment last night, is laying claim for Abbey at a time when some of the sparkle has been lost from its shares, boosted in the past by its record for cutting costs through acquisitions ranging from Cheltenham & Gloucester to Scottish Widows more recently.

One of the biggest uncertainties facing Lloyds TSB is the tolerance of the competition authorities for the bid, which would boost its share of current accounts close to 30%.

webTitle: The rise of the night shift

fields.headline: The late, late shift
fields.standfirst:
Anyone who has been a student will know that working through the night is exhausting and counter-productive. So why do many professionals routinely burn the midnight oil? Is it just macho posturing? Tim Dowling investigates

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Anyone who has been a student will know that working through the night is exhausting and counter-productive. So why do many professionals routinely burn the midnight oil? Is it just macho posturing?
fields.body:
'We cannot do business like this in the future," said a bleary-eyed Tony Blair after the final day of the European Union summit in Nice turned into a protracted all-night vigil, which had television reporters flat on their backs with anticipation.

European negotiations are notoriously bureaucratic and this one appears to have broken a few records. But staying up all night to clinch a deal is an increasingly common business practice, although few of the people who routinely do all-nighters think they are a good idea, or even strictly necessary.

Most of us first experienced the all-nighter as students, as the end product of some seriously flawed time management. We persuaded ourselves that the small hours were an untapped resource: while the world slept we would stay up to write that history essay in one intense burst of pure concentration, and use whatever time was left over to read Little Dorrit. The shortcomings of this system were only too apparent.

The work itself suffered from impaired decision-making - why shouldn't a lab report be written in rhyming couplets? - and the knock-on effect of exhaustion compromised one's schedule further.

We put our student days behind us, only to discover that much of the adult world still works that way. All-nighters occur in any profession that operates on strict deadlines.

It is a fairly common occupational hazard for journalists, and many of us who work from home budget our time now no better than we did when we were 19. Computer geeks without social lives to sacrifice will happily beaver away all night with nothing but a free Chinese takeaway as an incentive.

Corporate transactions are often negotiated against the clock, through the night, because one side or another is keen to wrap things up before the end of the tax year. Complex contract negotiations require huge amounts of documentation, forcing teams of people to stay up all night just assembling paperwork.

And legal deadlines clearly have a way of sneaking up on lawyers. It is safe to assume that the respective legal teams of Al Gore and George W Bush have had very little sleep over the past few days.

Although no one actually likes them, all-nighters can be grimly satisfying, giving you the feeling that you are going the extra mile, exhausting every avenue, working under extraordinary circumstances to achieve the impossible, to salvage a lost cause, to pull a rabbit out of a hat.

This is, of course largely an illusion, or perhaps more accurately, a hallucination, brought on by severe sleep deprivation.

In reality the all-nighter is usually an anarchic mess, fuelled by junk food and caffeine, and constantly on the verge of breaking down. As people get tired they become more intractable, their attention spans shorten and their brains turn to jelly. In the middle of the night it takes hours to achieve what you could have got done in minutes the previous afternoon.

In fact no matter how much of a high-flier you are, all the familiar drawbacks of the student all-nighter still apply: nobody performs particularly well at four in the morning, and nobody who stays up all night is at their best the next day.

Piers Feltham, a barrister, is occasionally instructed by a client's solicitor so late in the day that he is forced to work into the night before appearing in court the next morning. "There's always a trade-off between getting the preparation done and being a complete wreck the next day," he says. There is an element of macho posturing to working through the night, an attitude summed up by Feltham with the statement: "I pride myself on being the type of guy who, in my professional life, will go that extra distance."

In a world where stamina is a major business asset, sometimes the all-nighter is employed strategically. According to an assistant solicitor at one of the big so-called "magic circle" law firms in London, meetings are purposely begun in the late afternoon, often for no good reason. "It's then a question of who lasts the longest. If you can stay up all night and still talk, then you have the advantage. Sometimes it's driven by a genuine need, but the rest of the time, it's simply macho."

Much of the all-night vigil, he says, actually revolves around waiting for things to be typed up or for something to happen abroad. "A lot of deals in London are New York-driven . . . if you come in at 8.30am and want to go home at 7pm, say, you can think again, because if they are working late, then that takes you into the early hours.

"We got it from New York. Twenty years ago, it was all very different: civilised hours, gentlemen's agreements. Then after the Big Bang the late nights started. And the worst of it is, most law firms will tell you to come in the next day if you finish before 5am."

For this reason the all-nighter is generally a young man's game. Jacques Chirac has reportedly been told by his doctors to quit burning the candle at both ends.

According to another veteran of all-night business meetings, anyone who bills by the hour has an incentive to supplement their income with late-night overtime, and anyone who does business with them suffers as a result. He also claims that there are some people who actually enjoy it: "There is a breed of sicko who takes pleasure in negotiating a document to the last detail. If you get one of them on each side then the whole thing takes forever."

He maintains that such people get a feeling of importance from working all night on projects, although he also points out an obvious flaw in their logic. "People who actually matter don't stay up all night. They make underlings do it." (Copy to Tony Blair.)

There is no question that sometimes the all-nighter is driven by genuine need, in the face of a final, unmoveable deadline. Ultimately however, the all-nighter still smacks of disorganisation and desperation, whether it is practised by media studies majors or ministers.

Occasionally something can be rescued by an all-night vigil, but mostly it consists of waiting for the clock to run out so you can accept the inevitable substandard result: a poorly written paper, a raw deal, a hopeless compromise.

If only we could persuade ourselves to take second best in the first place, we could all go home and get a good night's rest.

According to another veteran of all-night business meetings, anyone who bills by the hour has an incentive to supplement their income with late-night overtime, and anyone who does business with them suffers as a result. He also claims that there are some people who actually enjoy it: "There is a breed of sicko who takes pleasure in negotiating a document to the last detail. If you get one of them on each side then the whole thing takes forever." He maintains that such people get a feeling of importance from working all night on projects, although he also points out an obvious flaw in their logic. "People who actually matter don't stay up all night. They make underlings do it." (Copy to Tony Blair.) There is no question that sometimes the all-nighter is driven by genuine need, in the face of a final, unmoveable deadline. Ultimately however, the all-nighter still smacks of disorganisation and desperation, whether it is practised by media studies majors or ministers. Occasionally something can be rescued by an all-night vigil, but mostly it consists of waiting for the clock to run out so you can accept the inevitable substandard result: a poorly written paper, a raw deal, a hopeless compromise. If only we could persuade ourselves to take second best in the first place, we could all go home and get a good night's rest.
